Unraveled

by EchoesInTheMargins

Summary

The thought of being with a woman had once seemed impossible to Agatha Harkness—a door locked tightly and never to be opened. After all, she was 48 years old, for Christ’s sake.

Then, without so much as a warning, Rio Vidal, a first-year associate, strode into her perfectly controlled life and blew Agatha’s closet door off its damn hinges.

Marching Ever Forward

Agatha Harkness strode through the crowded lobby of a towering skyscraper, her heels clicking rhythmically against the polished marble floors. The place buzzed with life— executives in tailored suits, assistants juggling coffee and laptops, all part of the Fortune 500 empires that called this building home. Legends had walked these very floors. But as she moved, the sea of people parted, instinctively clearing her path.

Her signature purple coat, vibrant and bold, sliced through the sea of black and white, a startling contrast that drew eyes in her direction. She felt their glances, the flicker of curiosity before they quickly looked away. She relished it—the acknowledgment, however brief, that she was someone .

She remembered being a child, dreaming of being a superhero, of wielding magic, saving the day, and standing above mortal men. But that was fantasy.

Magic didn’t exist.

Power, though—that was real.code

And she had it.

She reached the elevator, watching with delight as the crowd instinctively parted, people stepping back to give her space. They pressed against one another, clinging to the edges, avoiding any accidental contact with her. Untouchable—that’s what she was. And they knew it.

The doors slid shut, and the elevator was engulfed in a heavy silence, the kind that made the air feel thick. She could feel them holding their breath, as though they feared making the slightest sound. Each time the doors opened at a stop, there would be a soft shuffle of apologies as they hurried out, clinging to the walls, moving briskly as if their lives depended on it. And as they crossed into their floors, she could hear their quiet, collective sighs—relief.

They had survived a ride in the elevator with her.

The Witch of Wall Street.

At first, the term irritated her. A witch? As if she relied on magic or illusion to get to where she was. But then she understood. It wasn’t her presence they doubted—it was the control she commanded. The icy stillness that filled the room the moment she walked in, the subtle shift in posture, the way conversations died on people’s lips. Her arrival wasn’t seen—it was felt . A chill that made everyone sharpen their focus, as if they could sense the power she carried in her wake.

She wasn’t invisible; she was inescapable .

Agatha didn’t just win cases or close deals—she devoured them. She dismantled everything in her path, leaving no room for her opponents to recover. When she entered a courtroom, it wasn’t just about money; it was about domination. She didn’t simply defeat people—she unraveled them, stripping away their confidence, their sense of self, leaving nothing but a hollow shell of who they once were.

She didn’t just win; she consumed .

When Agatha Harkness stepped into a courtroom, she didn’t just take your money.

She took your power.

She could see it in their eyes—the fear, the uncertainty.

And she thrived on it.

She clenched her jaw tightly, feeling her patience fray with every stop.

This was one of the few downsides of being on the top floor—the slow crawl as the elevator emptied floor by floor. She had considered, more than once, simply telling everyone to get out and let her ride alone. They would listen. No one questioned her. But then, she’d miss the fear—the way the tension thickened in the small space, the way they avoided eye contact, pressing themselves against the walls as if she might devour them whole.

It was entertaining . Still irritating, yes, but in a way, it was the best part of her morning. Watching them squirm, watching the unease crawl across their faces, knowing she caused it. They feared her without her saying a word. Just her presence was enough to unsettle them.

A small price to pay for the thrill.

Finally, she reached the 70th floor and stepped out into the sprawling office of Calderu, Wu- Gulliver, Kale, and Harkness . A mouthful of a name. When she became a partner here a decade ago, she fought to have her name at the front. They refused, of course—too much history, too much ego. At first, it irritated her, the thought of being tacked on like an afterthought.

But then, she realized something—she liked being at the end.

It was fitting.

She wasn’t just another name; she was the period . The final word. The exclamation point that closed the deal. After her, there was nothing left to say, no argument left standing. She was the one who ended it all.

And there was power in that.

Agatha walked with purpose, her heels clicking sharply against the polished marble floor as she moved toward her office. It was in the corner, of course—like she would have anything less. The floor-to-ceiling windows offered a sweeping view of the city, a view befitting someone who had clawed her way to the top.

As she passed by the rows of desks, she could feel the silence in her wake, a ripple of stillness that followed her like a shadow. The underlings—the junior associates and paralegals, working furiously to finish their briefs, draft arguments, and scour case law—fell silent as she approached. Fingers that had been typing with frantic energy slowed, then stopped altogether. Conversations ceased, and the only sound left was the faint rustle of papers being shuffled and the occasional throat being cleared.

They tried to appear busy, as if they hadn’t noticed her, but she knew better. Desperation clung to them like a second skin. They all wanted to make their mark, to impress, to be noticed—but not by her . Not like this. They understood that if she stopped to speak to them, it wasn’t going to be for a pat on the back. And they feared what it would mean if her attention landed on them at the wrong moment.

She relished their nervous energy, letting it fuel her as she continued walking.

At the end of the hall, just outside her corner office, her assistant, Billy, was waiting, standing dutifully with coffee in hand. She barely glanced at him as she approached. Billy—or "Pet," as she often called him, with a mix of amusement and indifference—was always there, just like this. Silent, obedient, reliable. Like a well-trained dog, always eager to please.

“Morning, Ms. Harkness,” he said, his voice soft, as if afraid to break the unspoken rule of quiet that followed her. He held the coffee out, the cup already perfectly to her liking—black, hot like the searing sun.

Just like her.

She took it without a word, without so much as a nod of acknowledgment. Billy didn’t need one. He existed to serve, and she had no use for gratitude. He was there because he understood the rules. She was everything in this office, and everyone else was just playing for scraps.

With her coffee in hand, she breezed past him, the silence trailing behind her like a heavy shadow. Billy followed a few steps behind, his voice steady as he recited her schedule for the day. He had been with her for five years, long enough to understand the rhythm of her world.

Billy wasn’t like the others who feared her from a distance. He was afraid, of course—how could he not be? But it was a different kind of fear now. It had settled into him like a coal miner’s acceptance of the dark. He wasn’t scared of the shadows anymore; he’d spent too long walking in them by her side. He had learned to thrive in that cold, oppressive quiet, but he also knew the danger of digging too deep, of pushing too far. He understood better than anyone the kind of collapse Agatha could bring down on him if he made a single wrong move.

"Your 9 a.m. is a meeting with Gulliver," Billy started, his voice low and professional. "They're still pushing back on the terms from yesterday's negotiation, but it's expected. I’ve prepped the latest drafts for review."

Agatha didn’t react, her gaze fixed ahead as she glided into her office.

"At 11, you have a call with the board of ZanderTech to finalize the settlement." Billy continued, falling into step beside her now, keeping his voice even, always careful not to overstep. "Then the lunch meeting with Judge Kellerman to discuss the new financial rulings."

She gave a slight nod, the barest flicker of acknowledgment, but Billy didn’t need more. He had learned long ago that the absence of her displeasure was the closest thing to approval he would ever get.

"And at 2 p.m.," he added, lowering his voice slightly, "you’re scheduled to meet with the legal team from Morrison & Blake. They’ve requested a sit-down regarding the new acquisition."

A slight twitch of her lips. Billy knew that twitch. She was anticipating a battle—and battles were her lifeblood. The legal team from Morrison & Blake had no idea what storm they were walking into.

Billy continued, meticulously marking off each meeting between now and her 7 PM dinner with a new client. Agatha abhorred these kinds of schmoozing dinners, the fake smiles, the idle pleasantries. But it was how the firm stayed ahead. More money, more revenue—those meant more power. And power was always worth a little work, even if she despised it.

She fought the urge to rub the bridge of her nose, feeling the dull ache of a headache starting to creep in.

Another late night.

Nicky's going to be disappointed—again.

It was her week with him. Shared custody with her ex-husband meant her son was dropped off at her doorstep every other week. And usually, she tried to keep her schedule in check when he was around. Billy knew this. If she had a meeting tonight, it wasn’t by choice—it was because Billy had no other option. He didn’t make mistakes. Not with her. Not ever.

She took a long sip of her coffee, trying to stave off the headache, drowning it in caffeine. It was a temporary fix, but it would keep her sharp for now.

Billy’s voice droned on in the background, listing tasks and schedules.

“And...” Billy started, his voice faltering as it trailed off.

Her eyes snapped to him, sharp and unyielding. Hesitation. Agatha hated hesitation. She despised weakness, uncertainty—the kind of doubt that poisoned potential. She thought she’d beaten that out of him by now. If Billy was going to become the diamond she knew he could be, he needed the heat. She flooded him with it, over and over. The pressure. The burn. It had nearly broken him— nearly .

Most of her assistants couldn’t take the heat. They quit before they even got close to greatness, wilting under the intensity, unable to handle the fire it took to truly become something. But Billy had surprised her—not that she would ever tell him. He wasn’t perfect, but he was a quick learner, and unlike the others, he always came back for more. More punishment, more pressure. Somewhere inside, he must have known she was molding him into something stronger, something worthy.

He hadn’t slipped in a while. Which meant whatever he was about to say, he knew she wouldn’t like. That hesitation wasn’t fear of the unknown—it was the certainty that he was about to disappoint her.

"Speak, Pet," she said, her voice cutting through the silence like a finely honed blade. She could feel the tension radiating from Billy as he braced himself, gathering the courage to deliver whatever unfortunate news he had.

Billy swallowed hard but kept his composure, though she could see the faint flicker of hesitation behind his eyes.

“The new associates are here,” he finally said.

Agatha’s gaze flicked over his shoulder to the glass-walled conference room in the center of the firm—a glorified hamster cage. Inside, the freshly graduated associates stood awkwardly, shifting nervously, like the little rodents they were. Wide-eyed. Eager. Clueless. Her eyes snapped back to Billy, cutting through the moment with a cold, precise focus.

“And that’s my problem because...?” she drawled, her words sharp and bitter, like they left a bad taste in her mouth.

Billy gave the faintest flicker of a flinch, barely noticeable but there. His lips twitched, curling at the edges as he prepared to explain.

“Kale’s tied up in a deposition,” he said, his voice carefully steady. “Her assistant called. She needs you to cover the introduction to the firm.”

Agatha’s jaw tightened, irritation bubbling beneath her calm exterior. Of course, she thought. It had been years since she engaged with the associates. HR had all but barred her from the process—not officially, but after a couple of expensive settlements with a few fragile souls claiming "emotional damage," her involvement was strongly discouraged.

She scoffed internally at the memory. Weak. She’d barely done anything. Merely shown them what the real world was like. Apparently, not everyone had the stomach for it. So, HR had handed the task of introductions to the other partners, while Agatha focused on more meaningful work—like tightening the ironclad language of their contracts, ensuring no associate would ever dream of suing again.

The irony wasn’t lost on her. Any lawyer worth their salt would’ve read the fine print before signing. If they didn’t, well, they deserved the consequences. But these new recruits? They were too green, too eager to belong. They never looked past the first few pages, never questioned the terms, and by the time they did, it was too late. The firm owned them.

Her gaze flicked once more toward the glass conference room, where the wide-eyed associates stood, nervously fidgeting. The sight of them, so raw and uncertain, irritated her, yes—but there was also something oddly satisfying about it. It had been so long since she was allowed to play with the associates.

There was a certain thrill in it. Watching them squirm, watching the hope and ambition in their eyes slowly drain as reality settled in. They all came in thinking they’d change the world, that they’d be the exception to the rule. But by the time she was finished with them, they'd understand just how small and insignificant they really were.

A part of her relished the opportunity. She could almost feel the anticipation, the way it tugged at the edges of her calm demeanor. It had been years since HR had stepped in, taking away her favorite pastime. But now, with Kale stuck in a deposition, the door was cracked open just enough for her to have a little fun.

Her lips curved into a sharp smile. Well, if they wanted an introduction to the firm, they’d get one.

She turned to Billy, her voice smooth but edged with a scowl, the irritation carefully played out on the surface, while the excitement churned deep inside, locked where it belonged. Never show your cards.

“Fine,” she snapped, setting her coffee down on her desk with a sharp click and shrugging off her coat. Billy was already stepping forward, ready to take it from her. She handed it over without a glance, her attention shifting briefly to her reflection. High-waisted dark plum trousers, perfectly tailored, and a crisp white button-down tucked in. She cursed internally— if she’d known she’d be meeting the associates today, she would’ve worn something a little more intimidating.

More black, probably.

Never red.

Red was overrated. It washed her out, and besides, it carried too much cliché. Everyone thought power was red. But if you listened to the real whispers of Wall Street, the ones that floated through the corridors of power and wealth, they knew the truth.

The devil didn’t wear red.

It wore purple.

Tricks and Trials

Agatha moved through the firm’s sleek, gleaming halls with her usual quiet intensity, her eyes locked forward as she closed in on the glass-walled conference room. Her fingers flickered subtly at her sides, an unconscious dance she could never quite tame. The restless energy was always there, simmering beneath her composed exterior, just out of reach.

It was a trademark of hers, something she knew people noticed but never dared to comment on. Her fingers had drafted ruthless agreements, shredded defense strategies, and left her opponents exposed in the aftermath. Now, as she neared the room of trembling associates, they moved again, eager for something— someone —to take apart.

Inside the glass walls, the fresh-faced associates stood in awkward clusters, their eyes darting through the glass as she approached. Even through the thick glass, she could sense their discomfort, the low hum of whispers breaking the otherwise tense silence.

They’d heard the stories.

Of course, they had.

No one applied to work here for the prestige of the other partners—formidable as they were in their own right. Everyone knew the truth: if you survived a year under her roof, you were cut out for the relentless grind of the law. This firm was her domain, her garden, and she meticulously weeded out the weak.

Agatha didn’t just demand excellence; she cultivated it. She pushed, tested, and tore apart those who couldn’t keep up, leaving only the strongest to thrive. And every associate in that room knew it—they weren’t just here to learn; they were here to survive her.

Agatha’s lips twitched into the barest hint of a smile, her eyes glinting with a predatory gleam. This was her favorite part—the feeling of being watched, the knowledge that they feared her long before she ever spoke. It was why she’d insisted on the glass-walled conference room the moment she became a partner. For this exact reason. So everyone could see her, circling like a predator, while her prey sat inside, trapped.

It was more than a room—it was a stage. And she controlled the performance from the moment she stepped into view.

Her fingers stilled as she reached the door, hovering momentarily before she gripped the handle and pushed it open. The atmosphere in the room shifted instantly, thickening with the kind of tension she thrived on. Every head turned toward her, their eyes glued to her as she walked to the front of the room. Some stared with wide-eyed anticipation, others with barely concealed dread.

At least twenty faces, fresh and eager, all waiting for her to speak. Fresh graduates from Ivy League law schools, handpicked for their brilliance and potential. This firm only took the best—on paper, at least. But Agatha knew better. By the end of the year, less than half of these hopefuls would still be standing. The rest would be weeded out, broken by the relentless pressure she thrived on. Only one or two might prove worthy of her time, worthy of her trust to actual work a case.

As she reached the front of the room, she let her gaze sweep across them, lingering just long enough on each face to watch the anxiety ripple through them. They wanted to impress her. They needed to impress her. And she knew that fear would be their greatest motivator—or their undoing.

Agatha let the silence hang, watching the tension rise, her fingers moving again at her sides. They were waiting, and she always enjoyed making them sweat.

“Welcome to Calderu, Wu-Gulliver, Kale, and Harkness,” she said breaking the silence.

Agatha’s eyes swept across the room, a practiced, unimpressed gaze moving from one young face to the next. Designer suits on young men with haircuts far too expensive for their salaries, no doubt paid for by their parents. Women in skirts and dresses that screamed sorority more than law firm, posturing like they had something to prove. Agatha had a knack for sniffing out potential with just a glance, but as her eyes dragged across the room, she felt nothing.

Bored.

Indifferent.

Monotony.

And then, something caught her attention. Someone, standing near the back—not huddled toward the front like the rest, not scrambling to make a good impression. Instead, there was an air of indifference, as if this whole gathering was beneath them.

A woman.

Older then rest. Early 30's, probably.

She leaned against the glass wall, casually, almost defiantly. Unlike the others, her outfit wasn’t the standard corporate fare. A men’s suit and a green tie.

Bold .

Her raven hair was pulled back, a few stray wisps falling down, framing a face that wasn’t made up in the typical, polished way. No, this one wore eyeliner darker than appropriate, making no effort to blend in. And as Agatha zeroed in on her, her eyes narrowing in curiosity, she noticed the final detail that almost made her smirk.

She’s chewing gum.

Agatha’s pulse quickened, ever so slightly, her earlier indifference dissolving into intrigue. This one wasn’t here to impress anyone. She wasn’t here to beg for approval. And suddenly, Agatha wasn’t bored anymore.

Interesting.

Someone shifted uncomfortably, the squeak of their shoe cutting through the silence like a blade. Agatha’s eyes snapped to him instantly, her gaze sharp and unrelenting.

Golden blonde hair, a chiseled jawline that seemed carved from stone, and a cocky smile that made her pause for a moment. He leaned back in his chair, too relaxed for someone in this room, his posture screaming entitlement. Agatha’s lips twitched, but not in a smile—more of a flicker of curiosity laced with disdain. She briefly wondered whose son he was, what strings had been pulled to get him here.

Typical.

The arrogance in his expression told her he thought himself above the others. He wasn’t here to prove himself. In his mind, he’d already arrived, sitting on a pedestal he hadn’t even begun to earn. She’d seen it before—wealth, privilege, and a complete lack of understanding about how things truly worked in her world.

Her eyes narrowed, and the cocky smile on his face faltered ever so slightly under her unblinking scrutiny.

“And you are?” Agatha’s voice sliced through the air, smooth and lethal, like a blade drawn just for him.

The blonde hesitated, caught off guard for a split second before straightening in his chair, his practiced grin faltering.

“Jameson Hale,” he replied, but the charm that dripped from his voice had lost its polish under her cold stare.

Hale. Agatha’s mind sifted through the Rolodex of high-powered names and old money. Hale Industries—privilege passed down like a family heirloom. Generations of wealth, entitlement baked into his very being. He wasn’t just a fresh Ivy League graduate—he was a product of legacy. But to her, he was just another arrogant boy who thought his last name was his ticket to power.

Agatha’s expression didn’t shift. She tilted her head, her eyes narrowing as if seeing right through him.

“Hale,” she repeated, her tone devoid of any warmth. “How quaint.”

“My father is—”

“Stop,” she interrupted, her voice sharp enough to cut him off mid-sentence. She didn’t need to hear the rest. She already knew the story.

“Let me save you the effort, Jameson,” she made sure to say his name with as much venom as possible. “Your father, your money, your name—none of that matters here.”

She gestured around her, the sleek conference room that held the fate of every person sitting inside.

“This is not a country club where you can waltz in with your last name and expect doors to open.”

Agatha stepped forward, closing the distance between them, her heels echoing like a death knell on the polished floor.

“Here’s your first lesson, Mr. Hale,” Agatha’s voice dropped, cold and final, each word cutting deeper. “The law is brutal. Unforgiving.” She paused, savoring the weight of silence, her gaze fixed on him. “But I? I’m worse.”

The words hit him like a blow. His bravado shattered completely, leaving him stripped of the confidence he’d carried in like armor.

And god, she relished it.

She stepped back from him, already dismissing him as if he were nothing more than an afterthought. He wouldn’t last six months. She could see it now—he’d go crawling back to his father’s company, where names carried more weight than skill. He wasn’t worth another breath.

But as she turned to move away, her eyes caught the woman at the back of the room. The one leaning against the glass, looking on with an amused smirk, as if she’d enjoyed the takedown just as much. Agatha forced herself to look away, returning to the task at hand, her gaze sweeping across the room, assessing the group of associates with an intensity that made the air feel heavier.

“Good news for you,” she said, her lips curling into a predatory grin that promised the opposite. She gestured with her hand, and the door swung open. Several senior associates entered, carrying box after box, stacking them in front of the wide-eyed group. Each box hit the table with a thud, and Agatha’s grin widened as the pile grew. It took a good 10 minutes before the final box hit the ground with a resounding thud.

“This is discovery for a case,” she said, her voice rising as she gestured grandly to the nearly 100 boxes stacked before them, each one bursting with thousands of documents. “A corporate espionage case—one of my finest.” Her tone turned almost gleeful as she laid it out for them.

“Broken contracts, faulty products, and a payout that could rival a small country’s GDP. The only problem?” She leaned forward slightly, her eyes glittering with malicious delight. “The company is a military weapons supplier with more influence in Washington than most senators, more money than God, and technology that could make us all disappear if they wanted.”

She gave a little shrug, feigning innocence.

“Ergo, the million-document discovery dump they handed us. Buried us, really. These boxes? They’ve been sitting in storage for years . They’ve been combed through by people far smarter than any of you. But...” Her grin widened. “You? You’re perfect for this.”

She let the silence hang, letting them absorb the gravity of the task—and the impossibility of it.

“You won’t find anything,” she said, her voice turning almost playful. “You’ll dig, and dig, and dig until your hands bleed and your brains fry, and in the end, you’ll realize you’re chasing a ghost.” She paused, savoring the dread she saw flicker in their eyes. “But here’s the fun part,” she continued, her voice dropping lower, dripping with dark glee.

“If you do—if you somehow manage to unearth something real, something no one else has found? I will personally mentor you. Build you. Mold you into something unstoppable.”

Agatha watched as her words landed, saw the spark of determination ignite in their eyes.

Perfect.

That was the point, after all—to dangle a prize so alluring, yet so impossibly out of reach. She never— ever —took on associates. Everyone in the firm knew it. It was legend. To be personally mentored by Agatha Harkness was the ultimate reward, a gilded promise no one had ever claimed. But now, here it was, presented as if it could be theirs.

She saw it—the greed, the hunger. The flicker of belief in their eyes, that glimmer of arrogance that whispered, I could be the one. The first.

For Agatha, it was a win-win. They would fail, and their failure would bring her satisfaction. Watching their determination dissolve into desperation would be entertainment enough. But if— by some inconceivable stroke of luck —one of them did manage to unearth something? Well, then she’d have her white whale, wouldn’t she?

Not that it would happen. Agatha had combed through those documents herself, meticulously. There was nothing there. She knew that. But letting them try was the perfect trap.

Wonderful, she thought. Oh, how delicious it would be to watch them throw themselves into this lost cause, clawing and scratching for something they would never achieve. The more they fought, the sweeter their inevitable downfall would be.

Her amusement faded, her voice turning sharp as her eyes narrowed to cold, predatory slits.

“But if you fail...” She let the threat linger in the air, thick with tension. “Then you’re nothing but another disappointment.”

Agatha paused, watching their faces tighten under her gaze, before delivering the final blow with deadly precision.

“And trust me when I say— I don’t waste my time with disappointments. ”

The silence that followed was heavy, almost suffocating. She could see the gears turning behind their eyes, the frantic calculations as they weighed their options. Already, the spark of desperation had flickered to life. They would chase her approval, pour themselves into this impossible task with everything they had.

And when they inevitably failed, it would mark them. The harsh reality would sink in—the precedent set. Working for Agatha Harkness wasn’t just demanding, it was merciless . She didn’t just push people to their limits—she obliterated them. And now, they would spend the rest of their year knowing exactly what that meant.

A small smile tugged at the corner of her lips as she watched them fall neatly into the trap she’d crafted with such precision.

Oh yes, she thought, this is going to be magnificent.

With that, she stepped back, her presence still looming over them as she prepared to leave.

“You have 24 hours,” she said, her voice sharp and theatrical, letting the tension linger for just a moment longer. Then, with a dramatic sweep of her hand, she added.

“Happy Hunger Games! May the odds be ever in your favor.”

With that final flourish, Agatha turned on her heel and strode out, leaving them to their fate. She didn’t need to look back to know what would happen next—she could already imagine it. They’d be rushing forward, grabbing at the boxes, their faces lit with determination. And from the vantage of her office, over the next 24 hours, she would watch that determination slowly crumble into desperation as the clock ticked away.

She reached her office and sank into her chair, the leather cool against her back as she reveled in the impending crush of those tiny little associate hearts.

Technically, she mused, I didn’t threaten anyone. So HR wouldn’t say a word.

Another win in her book.

Staring out at the cityscape, she reached for her coffee, took a sip, and grimaced—it had already gone cold.

“Billy,” she called, her voice cutting through the silence, and within seconds, he was there, practically running to her side. She didn’t say a word, just lifted the cup. He took it immediately, and she heard the sound of his footsteps fading as he left to fetch a fresh one.

But something tugged at her mind.

That smirk.

That woman—the associate with the dark hair.

“Wait—come back here,” she commanded, her voice sharper now. Billy reappeared, quick as ever.

Good pet.

Agatha’s eyes drifted past him, toward the hamster cage. The gerbils were already at work, tearing into the boxes like scavengers, forming little teams to tackle the overwhelming load of documents. It was a smart move—expected, really. More eyes, more chances of finding something.

She scanned the room, and there she was.

At the far end of the table, alone , she moved with quiet confidence, her fingers shuffling through the papers with an unhurried, methodical ease. Agatha watched, intrigued despite herself. And then, as if sensing her gaze, the woman looked up.

There gazes locked, and then—she blew a bubble.

A large, obnoxious bubble with her gum, the pop, unheard, but still breaking through the silent tension. The woman’s tongue flicked out, casually pulling the remnants of the bubble back into her mouth, all while maintaining eye contact with Agatha—and, of course, wearing that smirk.

Agatha’s eyes narrowed into a sharp, piercing glare, the surge of irritation instantaneous. Who did she think she was? That casual arrogance... it was infuriating. She could feel her pulse quicken, annoyance boiling just beneath the surface.

This one, she thought, is going to be fun to break.

Without another second wasted, Agatha tore her gaze away, refusing to give that woman the satisfaction of knowing she’d rattled her. But beneath her icy exterior, something unexpected flickered— curiosity , sharp and undeniable, a feeling Agatha hadn’t entertained in years.

It was then she realized Billy was still standing in front of her. She jumped, startled by his presence.

“ Jesus ,” she snapped, her irritation spilling over. “Don’t sneak up on me like that.”

Billy, unfazed by her theatrics, remained silent, simply waiting as he always did. His calm demeanor only served to annoy her further.

She glared at him.

“Get me the personal file on the new associate—the woman with the black hair, wearing the black suit with the green tie.”

Billy started to turn, instinctively looking for who she was talking about, but Agatha’s hiss stopped him cold.

“ Don’t turn around! ” she hissed, her voice low and threatening. She didn’t need that woman realizing she was under scrutiny. “Do you have a subtle bone in your body, pet ?”

Billy at least had the decency to look slightly ashamed, his cheeks tinged with embarrassment. He nodded quickly, and without another word, he hurried off to retrieve what she’d asked for.

Agatha leaned back in her chair, fingers tapping rhythmically on the armrest, replaying that damn smirk in her mind. The nerve—to blow a bubble, to meet her gaze with such bold indifference. It should have enraged her. It did enrage her. But beneath the anger, something else stirred—something far more exhilarating.

This must be what Godzilla felt like when he first laid eyes on a city ready to be obliterated. The anticipation, the hunger for destruction. A grin tugged at the corner of her mouth.

She wasn’t just going to tear that woman down. She was going to savor it—watching her confidence wither, her defiance crumble under the weight of Agatha’s relentless pressure. It was going to be a spectacular fall, and Agatha would revel in every moment of it.

Oh, this was going to be fun.

Giveth Sight

Agatha leaned back against the plush leather seat of the town car, her fingers absently brushing over the fabric of her white button-down. She glanced down at it, noticing the few buttons she had left undone earlier in the evening. With a slight smirk, she buttoned two of them back up, pulling the collar higher.

Men.

They were predictable, easy to manipulate. A little cleavage, a well-placed laugh at their terrible jokes, a subtle touch of her fingers on the rim of her glass as she sipped the bourbon they’d ordered—overpriced, of course, but they loved that kind of thing. Feed them expensive red meat and stroke their egos, and they practically signed the contract themselves. By the time dessert was over, all she had to do was let her reputation speak for itself.

And just like that, Larkin & Reed Solutions was now the newest client of Calderu, Wu- Gulliver, Kale, and Harkness. A nice little $25 million addition to her already bulging portfolio.

She let out a quiet, satisfied sigh as the car slipped through the quiet streets, her eyes drifting to the city skyline. The deal had gone exactly as expected—smooth, seamless. Men in boardrooms rarely expected a woman to outmaneuver them with such ease. But Agatha had perfected the art long ago. She didn’t need to play their game. She owned it. They never saw her coming, not really. They never understood that the moment she stepped into the room, they were already caught in her web.

Her mind wandered back to the dinner. It had been like all the others—too much bourbon, too much ego. One of the men had spent ten minutes trying to explain blockchain technology to her, as if she hadn’t already built a dozen successful cases around it. She’d smiled, nodded along, threw in the occasional "interesting" for effect, and watched him puff up like a peacock.

It was all so... tedious.

And yet, so effective.

She crossed her legs, staring out the window, a small, satisfied smile playing on her lips. The men had no idea she barely needed to lift a finger to win them over. They were convinced they’d gotten a bargain by the end of it—thought they’d charmed her . But in reality, they were just another trophy for her shelf, another deal closed in the blink of an eye.

Her fingers tapped lightly on her lap, a quiet rhythm of victory, but her gaze drifted to her bag where the manila human resources file sat, tucked just beneath the leather. Billy had snagged it for her earlier, right from HR. She hadn’t had the chance to open it yet, though she’d been tempted—several times. The day had been relentless. Too many meetings, too many fires to put out.

But now, in the quiet of the town car, with the city lights flickering by, she couldn’t resist any longer.

Agatha pulled the file from her bag, the crisp paper cool in her hands. She flipped it open, her eyes narrowing immediately as they landed on the photo. Of course. Even in her employee photo, she was smirking—cocky, bold. That same damn smirk that had irked her earlier. Agatha’s eyes flicked down to the name under the picture.

Rio Vidal.

Interesting name.

She’d guessed the age right—32, older than her peers. That alone was unusual. Most associates were younger, fresh out of Ivy League law schools. But Rio? She’d gone to law school late, another oddity. Agatha scanned the details, her brow furrowing as she read further. No Ivy League pedigree. In fact, Rio hadn’t attended any of the usual suspects— Harvard, Yale, Princeton. Not even a Columbia grad.

No, Rio Vidal had attended some obscure law school in... Texas.

Agatha paused, blinking at the word as if it didn’t quite compute.

Texas. The woman was from Texas.

How in the hell did she get into my law firm? Agatha thought, her annoyance mounting. Who hired her? And more importantly, why?

She continued skimming the file, searching for answers.

Valedictorian, Agatha noted. Not just in law school but all through her academic life. Her eyes widened slightly as she saw the LSAT score.

172. Impressive.

Agatha's fingers tapped faster, her mind racing.

Smart, then.

Smarter than the Ivy League brats who had their seats bought by mommy and daddy, coasting through law school and slipping into her firm on the weight of their last names and trust funds. The kind who thought expensive degrees equaled talent.

But this one... She wasn't like them.

Agatha flipped through the recommendations, scanning them quickly. Raving reviews, glowing endorsements—nothing unusual for someone who made it this far. But then she paused, her eyes narrowing as she read a particular letter from one of Rio's law professors.

"Rio Vidal has an exceptional mind—one of the sharpest I’ve encountered in my years of teaching. Her quick wit and ability to think on her feet are unmatched. She doesn’t just understand the law; she anticipates it, often seeing solutions others overlook. She possesses all the makings of an extraordinary lawyer—one who won’t just practice law, but redefine it."

Agatha closed the folder with a sharp snap, the force of it reverberating in the quiet of the car. The raving reviews, the exceptional LSAT score, the professor’s glowing words—none of it mattered in the end.

Not until this, Rio proved herself to her.

She leaned back against the seat, fingers drumming on the folder’s edge, her mind still circling around the woman in the photo.

Sharp. Quick. Unmatched. Beautiful.

Wait . Beautiful?

Agatha froze, her fingers stilling against the folder. Where had that come from? She shook the thought away, irritation bubbling up inside her. Beauty was irrelevant. It wasn’t what she valued, certainly not in an associate . She prided herself on seeing only talent, skill, potential.

Focus, she chastised herself, forcing her mind back to the task at hand. But the word lingered, unsettling her more than she wanted to admit.

Her phone rang, and for once, she didn’t mind the interruption—it was exactly what she needed. She glanced at the caller ID and rolled her eyes.

“What?” she snapped into the phone.

Silence.

“ Hello, Jen. How are you doing, Jen? ” came the mocking tone on the other end.

Agatha rolled her eyes harder, settling back into her seat.

“Talking to yourself now? All those illegal moisturizers you put into your face finally melting your brain?” she bit back, the sharpness of her tone unmistakable.

Jen huffed, clearly unimpressed.

“I need you to come in.”

Agatha pulled the phone away from her ear to check the time—9:14 PM. She had been working since 5 that morning, and she was tired. Exhausted , really. She hadn’t seen Nicky all day. By now, he’d be asleep—she’d checked with the nanny earlier. Still, she wanted to be there, to kiss him goodnight, to run her fingers through his hair, to be mom for just a moment.

“No—it’s late,” she said, her voice flat, decisive.

A pause. Silence on the other end. Then Jen’s voice, low but firm.

“ Agatha —just get your ass in here.”

Before she could respond, the line went dead.

Agatha stared at her phone, irritation bubbling up. She let out a sharp breath.

This night just keeps getting better, she thought sarcastically, tossing the phone into her bag. She let out a loud heavy sigh. Her shoulders slumped, taking advantage of the privacy of the car to finally let herself collapse.

She gave herself exactly one minute. One minute to completely surrender to the weight of the day, to let the stress settle in and roll off, if only briefly. In this quiet, fleeting moment, the exhaustion hit her all at once, the strain of the day settling deep into her bones. The invisible armor she wore every day felt heavier than usual—pressing down on her shoulders, tight in her chest.

But then, like a switch flipping, she forced herself to pull out of it. Her back straightened, her shoulders squared, and the walls she so carefully kept in place slid back into position. Agatha Harkness couldn’t afford cracks, not even in the privacy of her own car.

She reached for the intercom button, her finger pressing it with a controlled, steady motion.

“Back to the office, Dan,” she ordered, her voice sharp, fully composed.

“Yes, Ms. Harkness,” came her driver’s prompt reply. She felt the subtle turn of the car, the shift in direction steering her away from home and back to the office.

Agatha leaned her head back against the seat, her mind already shifting gears. Whatever awaited her at the office had better be important. Jen knew better than to drag her back this late without a damn good reason.

And if it wasn’t?

Well, then someone’s head was going to roll.

Agatha stepped out of the elevator, her irritation bubbling dangerously close to the surface. She knew herself— knew her limits —and she was on the edge of losing her composure. And when Agatha Harkness lost it, no one was safe. She marched through the office with a fierce intensity, her steps sharp, her focus singular. She was on a warpath.

Her gaze flicked to the glass-walled conference room as she passed, taking a small, malicious delight in seeing the associates still toiling away inside. Their once-pristine designer suits and dresses were now wrinkled, their faces tense with frustration as they argued over the documents.

Good. At least she wasn’t the only one suffering tonight.

She kept walking but felt the nagging urge to glance back, wondering if Rio was in there—if she, too, was slogging through the night, just as frustrated as her peers. The thought of seeing that infuriating smirk wiped clean, replaced with a frown of disappointment or perhaps even the taut line of stress, had Agatha glancing over her shoulder, unable to resist.

But as her eyes scanned the room, she frowned.

She wasn’t there.

A flicker of disappointment sparked inside her. If Rio had already given up, she certainly didn’t have the makings of an exceptional lawyer , as her professor had so boldly claimed. Agatha had expected more—a dramatic collapse, perhaps. Something with fire, or at least a satisfying level of frustration.

But there was nothing. No spectacle. No crumbling under pressure. Just... absence.

The disappointment lingered, heavier than she wanted to admit. She had been looking forward to watching Rio break—or perhaps she was simply annoyed that she had missed it.

Either way, it left her feeling unsatisfied.

What a letdown, she thought, pushing the irritation aside as she continued toward her office. But the annoyance only deepened as she caught sight of people inside— her space.

Three women lounged on her couch, and she recognized them immediately: Lilia Calderu, Jennifer Kale, and Alice Wu-Gulliver—the other partners. They were laughing, casually sipping on her whiskey as if they belonged there, making themselves comfortable in a place they had no right to be.

Agatha’s eyes narrowed, her fury simmering. This did not look like an emergency.

She marched forward, her steps quick and sharp, and dramatically ripped the door open, stepping in with a stormy presence.

The laughter died immediately, the room quieting as all three women turned to face her, their expressions faltering.

Agatha’s gaze swept over them, eyes cold and cutting.

“Well,” she said, throwing her hands in the air with an exaggerated flourish, her tone dripping with sarcasm. “The building clearly isn’t on fire. So why am I here?”

Her words hung in the air, thickening the already tense atmosphere. The partners exchanged uneasy glances, clearly unsettled despite how accustomed they were to Agatha’s theatrics. No matter how well they knew her, she still had the power to get under their skin.

All except Lilia.

Lilia, the oldest and most seasoned of them, simply raised an eyebrow. She was always unfazed by Agatha’s theatrics, a fact that both annoyed and impressed Agatha in equal measure. Lilia had a gift—an unnerving ability to read people like open books, as if she could peer into their souls and know exactly what made them tick, what they would do next. It made Agatha uncomfortable, but she begrudgingly respected her for it.

“Agatha,” Lilia said, her tone carrying a hint of exasperation, like a mother addressing an overly dramatic child. She leaned forward, grabbing the decanter of whiskey with a casual grace, and poured a generous amount into a glass. Offering it to Agatha, she gestured toward the empty chair. “Sit.”

Agatha’s eyes narrowed, her annoyance flaring again. She didn’t take orders from anyone, and Lilia knew that. But the sooner she figured out what this impromptu gathering was about, the sooner she could get back home.

With a reluctant sigh, she took the glass and settled into the chair, her posture stiff, her gaze unyielding.

“This better be good,” she muttered, taking a sip of the whiskey, her sharp eyes scanning the three women.

Jen met her gaze evenly before leaning back in her chair, arms crossed in that casual but calculating way Agatha despised.

“You have the new associates working the Vanguard case.”

Agatha’s eyes narrowed, her patience wearing thin.

“Is that why you dragged me in here? Because I have associates working? That’s not exactly groundbreaking news, Jen. This literally could’ve been an email. ” Her tone was mocking, laced with sharp irritation.

Jen’s expression hardened, her eyes narrowing in return.

“I thought we all agreed to put Vanguard to rest.”

Agatha leaned forward, her fingers tightening around the glass.

“I never agreed to that,” she said, her voice cold and sharp. “Vanguard was shelved because the rest of you lost your nerve, not because it’s a dead case.”

She took a slow sip of whiskey, throwing Jen an unapologetic look.

“And besides—you dumped the associates on me, remember?” she added, her tone turning defensive. “What else was I supposed to do with them?”

“We have plenty of active cases,” Jen shot back, her irritation clear.

“None of them are challenging enough,” Agatha bit out. “I wanted to see what they were made of.”

Lilia chuckled softly, her knowing gaze settling on Agatha.

“You didn’t want to test them. You wanted to break them.”

Agatha raised a hand to her chest in mock offense, her eyes wide with exaggerated innocence.

“Who, me?” she said dramatically, her voice dripping with false sincerity.

Jen’s patience snapped.

“Enough,” she cut in, her tone sharp, silencing the room. She glanced at Alice, giving her a quick nod.

Alice, who had been quietly watching, shot Agatha a look before reaching for a folder on the table. She handed it to Agatha, her expression unreadable.

Agatha eyed the folder suspiciously, then snatched it from Alice’s hand.

“What’s this?” she asked, her voice edged with curiosity.

“This,” Jen deadpanned, “is the reason I called you in.”

Agatha gave her a look, full of skepticism.

“And here I thought you were finally inviting me into your little sisterhood of the traveling jade egg.”

Alice gagged at the comment.

“Gross, Agatha.”

“Just read the damn file,” Jen growled, clearly losing patience.

Agatha, still smirking, flipped open the folder, her amusement quickly fading as her eyes scanned the contents.

Agatha flipped open the folder, her initial smirk fading as she skimmed through the documents. Emails, reports—familiar enough. All of them from the Vanguard file. She recognized every page. But as she continued to flip through, something caught her eye. Handwritten notes, scribbled in sharp, messy black ink. Chicken scratch, really. And there were small tabs sticking out of the sides of certain pages, marking specific sections.

Her brow furrowed, curiosity piqued as she studied the scrawled handwriting. The notes were meticulous, pointing out dates and correlating them with other reports. A pattern emerged— subtle, almost invisible. But the handwriting—whoever it belonged to—had spotted it.

She flipped to another page, her eyes scanning a hand-written note that called out discrepancies between official reports and internal memos. Some of these reports had been

doctored, their numbers altered just enough to avoid raising suspicion. And they’d slipped through even her scrutiny. Agatha’s stomach churned slightly at the realization.

How the hell did I miss this?

The handwriting continued to circle glaring issues she hadn’t noticed—small but damning irregularities hidden beneath layers of data. She flipped through faster now, eyes scanning the tabs and notes with growing intensity. Whoever had gone through this file had not only found cracks in Vanguard’s defense but had started pulling at those threads, unraveling the very thing Agatha had thought was impenetrable.

She paused at a particular note, her fingers brushing over the ink. It wasn’t just pointing out an error—it was laying out a trail. A breadcrumb of clues Agatha herself hadn’t followed.

Who the hell wrote this?

She glanced up at Jen, then Alice, but neither of them spoke. They just watched her, waiting for her to put the pieces together.

Agatha’s eyes narrowed, flipping back to the beginning of the file, her mind racing. She hadn’t missed this because of negligence. No, this was the kind of work that required more than skill— it required obsession .

She slammed the folder shut, the room’s silence thick with anticipation.

"Who wrote these?" Agatha demanded, her voice sharp, slicing through the heavy silence.

The three women exchanged knowing glances, as if they had anticipated this exact moment. Jen, taking her time, raised her glass to her lips and sipped her whiskey slowly, leaning back into her chair with a casual, almost cocky posture. She met Agatha’s gaze, savoring the tension like a fine wine.

"Rio Vidal," she said, drawing out the words with relish. “ Your new mentee .”

Blood and Tears and Bone

Agatha despised being late. Every minute she wasn’t in the office felt like she was losing ground, like the day was slipping from her grip before it even started. She didn’t just want to keep up—she wanted to conquer each day, crush it beneath her heel. But today had been different. Today, she’d woken up with Nicky wrapped around her, clinging to her as if holding on tightly enough would make her stay.

His little arms, wrapped like a boa constrictor around her waist, squeezed with all the love and desperation a five-year-old could muster. And the moment she felt his grip, she knew it was going to be one of those mornings.

It had been a battle from the start: first, a meltdown over a pair of socks that didn’t fit just right, then she didn’t cut his toast the way he liked, which led to a complete refusal to ride with the driver to school. Every moment felt like she was dragging him out of quicksand, and through it all, she could feel the weight of his frustration. But she couldn’t blame him. He was his mother’s son —he had the same flair for dramatics, the same spiral when things slipped out of his control, and the same intensity, burning with the heat of a thousand suns.

He was, in many ways, her recompense for how she had acted all her life. Every tantrum, every stubborn refusal, felt like a mirror reflecting her own relentless need for control. And now, at five years old, Nicky had the same fire, the same relentless energy. Yesterday she had missed dinner and bedtime—big moments in his little world. He didn’t understand why his mother couldn’t be there. He just knew she wasn’t.

So, when he lashed out, she let him.

It was familiar— deserved .

In the end, she just gave in. Afterall, it was his last day with her before he went to his fathers for the week.

So, she let him ride with her, even though it meant going in the opposite direction of the office. She sat in the back, scrolling through her phone, reading emails, pretending not to notice him still sulking next to her. Her time was ticking away, the demands of work looming closer, but she didn’t mind.

Not today.

Beside her, Nicky was fiddling with something—probably one of the files she had tossed into her bag last minute. She was used to him doodling on her documents, often using them as makeshift canvases while she worked. Once, he’d drawn over a contract and when she brought it back to the associate who wrote it covered in crayon, she pointed out the “mistakes” her son had marked, just to remind them to stay humble.

“She’s pretty,” Nicky said, his small voice cutting through the quiet of the car.

Agatha’s eyes snapped up from her phone, her brow furrowing in confusion as she looked ahead, out the window.

“Who is pretty?”

She didn't see anything, so she looked down at him and her stomach dropped when she saw what he was holding—Rio Vidal’s personal file. Open. Her son’s tiny fingers were tracing the edges of Rio’s photo, his innocent eyes studying the image intently.

Agatha’s heart skipped a beat, an unexpected surge of emotion hitting her as she tried to process the sight of Nicky holding Rio’s file. How did he—?

"Who is she?" he asked, his little voice curious, blue eyes—just like hers—staring up at her expectantly.

Agatha rarely found herself speechless, but now, with her son’s innocent question hanging in the air, she struggled to find the right words. Her mind raced. Who is she?

"She is—" Agatha hesitated, searching for an answer that wouldn’t betray the truth. She couldn’t very well tell her son that this woman was her newest challenge, her latest game— someone she intended to crush under the weight of impossible expectations. That kind of cruelty didn’t fit in a world where her son was watching.

"She’s a friend at work," she finally said, the words coming out carefully, tasting foreign on her tongue.

Nicky blinked, eyes moving back to the picture.

"She’s pretty," Nicky repeated, as if that single observation was all the explanation he needed.

For a fleeting moment, Agatha couldn’t help but agree—and she hated herself for the thought. She quickly pushed it aside, forcing her focus back to something she could control. Reaching into her bag, she pulled out a red permanent marker and held it out to him.

"Here," she said, offering the marker with a subtle nod toward Rio’s personal file. “Have at it.”

Nicky’s eyes lit up, and he grabbed the marker eagerly.

HR wouldn’t like it, but Agatha didn’t care. Rules didn’t apply to her. And this Rio woman? She wouldn’t be around long enough for it to matter—not if Agatha had anything to say about it.

The hamster cage was empty when Agatha arrived at the office. The Vanguard files had been moved to a new room, now that something had finally been found, and the partners— reluctantly —gave her the green light to pick the case back up.

But they’d made it painfully clear—no more pouring millions into this fight. No more endless hours and resources bleeding into the abyss. If she wanted to chase her white whale,

it would be on her terms this time.

One associate, they said.

One .

That was all she got.

If Agatha wanted Vanguard, she had to roll up her sleeves and dive headfirst into the dirt herself. She could practically feel the disapproval clinging to her like a shadow, the weight of their judgment pressing against the back of her mind. They were done funding her fight. Even with the new findings, they still saw it as a lost cause—a battle she couldn’t win.

And gods —that burned something fierce inside her.

She wasn’t done with Vanguard. She would never be done with them. Not until she had her heel on their throat, pressing down until there wasn’t even the faintest gasp left.

She wanted them broken.

Completely.

It wasn’t just a case anymore; it had become something darker, something bordering on obsession. The gnawing pull of unfinished business that kept her awake at night, dragging her thoughts back again and again. When she couldn’t sleep, she would find herself in the file room, fingers brushing through old documents, searching for something— anything —that might have been missed.

She knew it was unhealthy. Knew that the case had sunk its claws into her, tightening its grip every day. But she couldn’t let it go.

Wouldn’t let it go.

Vanguard wasn’t just a case anymore. It was a reckoning . And Agatha needed to be the one to deliver it.

On her way to her office, she paused outside the war room adjacent to her door. Stepping inside, the familiar thrill shot through her veins. Stacks of Vanguard files towered against the walls, the whiteboard beside them still untouched, waiting to be filled with the threads of conspiracy that Agatha knew she was about to unravel.

It didn’t matter that she only had one associate. She thrived in the chaos, and that board was going to tell the story of Vanguard’s downfall. All she needed was a crack in the armor, a single loose thread to pull.

The hunt. This was the part of her job she lived for.

On the surface, the company was clean as the whiteboard—a massive defense contractor with deep ties to the Department of Defense. They supplied everything from tanks to missiles, anything designed to kill. If it could destroy, Vanguard had a hand in making it. But Agatha

knew when a company was that big — in that line of work , there was always a trail of filth hiding under the glossy veneer.

Five years ago, an anonymous whistleblower dropped a bombshell on her desk—serious allegations that painted Vanguard in a very different light. It was like someone handed her a blacklight to expose the mess, and like a truck stop bathroom, it showed just how absolutely filthy those fuckers really were.

According to the tip, Vanguard wasn’t just arming the U.S. military. They were allegedly selling weapons to terrorist organizations in the Middle East, drug cartels in South America, and organized crime families that held entire cities in their grasp.

It wasn’t just shady— it was catastrophic .

The data dump that came with it was massive—financial records that didn’t line up, shipping manifests that made no sense, and buried within the files was an obituary. Brooke Sinclair, an accountant at Vanguard, twenty-seven years old. Dead by suicide. Found by her family in her garage, the car still running.

Agatha had felt a chill run down her spine when she read it. That’s when she knew the case wasn’t just numbers on a page.

It was bigger.

Darker.

The final piece in the whistleblower’s file had been an innocuous-looking email—something so routine it almost seemed irrelevant. Brooke had forwarded a concern to her higher-ups. She’d found inconsistencies: missing storage containers, financial line items that didn’t trace back to any purchases. She was simply requesting a meeting to clear things up before finalizing her month-end report.

That was it.

No grand reveal.

No dramatic accusations.

Just a simple request for clarity.

And that email had been the last time anyone heard from Brooke.

The whole thing reeked of a cover-up, and Agatha could smell it a mile away.

Brooke’s death was ruled a suicide, but nothing about it sat right with Agatha. The pieces didn’t fit. She managed to convince Brooke’s grieving parents to let her take on the case, pro bono, of course. They were Midwestern farmers, barely scraping by, but they were desperate for answers.

“Brooke wasn’t suicidal. She was happy ,” her mother had sobbed, clutching her husband’s arm. The father, stoic and broken, had nodded along silently, his weathered hand reaching out for the contract.

“ Give it to me ,” he had said, his voice rough, his signature swift and deliberate. He handed the contract back to Agatha, fury burning in his eyes. With one hand, he held his grieving wife; with the other, he handed over the last thing he had—the hope that Agatha could give them justice.

It was enough to bring a suit, but Agatha knew this was going to be an uphill battle. Vanguard was too big, too powerful. And they’d already hired the only firm in the U.S. that had a reputation to rival her own.

A firm out of Boston: Fox, Ratcliff, Coyotl, Wise, Crow, Orm, and Swarmen. A fucking mouthful.

But most people just called them The Salem Seven.

It had a certain gravitas to it, didn’t it?

The Witch of Wall Street v. The Salem Seven . It felt like something ripped from a Marvel movie—two juggernauts going head-to-head, each wielding their own brand of legal magic.

But this wasn’t a movie, and reality was a much harsher beast.

They didn’t need to destroy her with a knockout punch. No, they played it smart. They dragged it out, bogged her down in procedural delays, tiring her out with endless paperwork and technicalities. Agatha could see the strategy, and she hated to admit it—but she respected the move.

It was ruthless.

Effective .

The whistleblower’s records? Thrown out. The Seven claimed they were doctored.

Fine.

Agatha put in a formal request for the originals then. The court granted it. But of course, they didn’t just give her what she needed.

They gave her everything .

They practically annihilated a rainforest to bury her in paper. Files upon files, crates upon crates of documents, all designed to slow her down, to drown her firm in an avalanche of meaningless information.

They were good. So, fucking good.

And it worked.

After a year of relentless digging, after burning through five million dollars in associate hours, combing through mountains of case files and finding nothing, the partners finally called it. Vanguard was bleeding them dry. It had become a war of attrition, and her own firm was starting to crack under the pressure.

3-1 vote.

Agatha had to put the case away.

She hated it.

Every part of her seethed with frustration, knowing they were being played. Vanguard had won—not by being smarter, but by exhausting her, by exploiting the resources of her firm and dragging down into the mud until she couldn’t breathe.

Shutting down the case had felt like swallowing glass.

Now, as she stood in the war room, staring at the mountain of files towering before her, Agatha couldn’t help but feel the weight of it all pressing down on her. The thought crept in —the possibility of failing again. She wasn’t afraid of much. She prided herself on that. But failure? That was the one thing that clawed at her insides, the one fear she could never shake.

To be less —that was her nightmare.

She didn’t set the bar sky-high without holding herself to those same brutal standards. She wasn’t completely heartless. She demanded perfection, but she demanded it from herself first.

And now, with Vanguard staring her in the face, she had to wonder—could she survive another fall?

Out of the corner of her eye she spotted Billy waiting for her, standing there with that wide- eyed, puppy-dog expression, holding her coffee like a peace offering.

Agatha sighed loudly, the weight of the war room and the gnawing thoughts of failure still heavy on her mind. Without a word, she turned and walked out it, brushing past him, snatching the coffee from his hand as she made her way out the door. The morning with Nicky, the pressure, the looming task ahead—it was all too much, and it made her snappy.

"Get me the updated financials from Vanguard," she barked, barely giving him a glance. "And the client contracts from last quarter reviewed by noon."

Billy opened his mouth, clearly ready to say something, but before he could, she cut him off.

"Also, track down those emails— you know the ones —and I want a report on the last quarter of stock movement. I wanted those 5 minutes ago."

Billy’s mouth hung open again, his eyes darting as he tried to keep up, but Agatha didn’t slow down, her words spilling out like a rapid-fire barrage.

“—And I want those updated financials on my desk before lunch. And call IT about the damn firewall issues at my home office—”

Agatha’s words and her steps halted simultaneously as she entered her office and realized she was not alone.

There, on the cream-colored couch, sat Rio Vidal. Leaning back with infuriating ease, dressed in a forest green suit paired with a high-collared white button-down, her presence was impossible to ignore. Her hair was down today, framing her face in a way that softened her sharp look, but that smirk— that damn smirk —and the casual way she crossed her legs, as if she belonged there, made Agatha’s brain short-circuit for a brief, disorienting second.

Agatha blinked, her composure faltering for only a heartbeat before she whirled on Billy, who had the decency to look properly terrified.

"You have a visitor," he mumbled, offering an apologetic grimace and a look that practically screamed, I tried to tell you.

Agatha narrowed her eyes at him, the sharpness in her gaze cutting like a blade.

" I have eyes, " she hissed, her voice a low warning.

With a flick of her hand, she shooed him away, her irritation barely contained.

Her mind whirred back into focus, her attention shifting back to Rio, who looked far too comfortable in her office. It set Agatha’s nerves on fire, but she refused to show it. One of her many talents was projecting confidence and resolve, even when she didn’t feel a shred of it.

She ignored Rio completely, striding to her closet to hang up her jacket as if the woman weren’t even there. Then, with calm precision, she moved to her desk, booting up her computer and diving into her emails. The silence between them was thick, almost tangible, but Agatha could do this all day. The steady sound of her typing filled the room as she fought the urge to look up, knowing Rio’s gaze was on her, watching.

Ten minutes passed in silence, the tension growing by the second.

“I liked your speech yesterday,” Rio’s voice finally broke through, cutting through the quiet like a blade. Agatha’s fingers stilled on the keyboard. It wasn’t the comment that threw her— it was the voice. There wasn’t a trace of the Texas drawl she had expected. Instead, Rio’s voice was rough, a gravelly tone with an undercurrent of lilting precision, tinged with something else. Something... bilingual.

And Rio wasn’t done.

“It was very—‘ I can teach you how to bewitch the mind and ensnare the senses. I can tell you how to bottle fame, brew glory, and even put a stopper in death .’”

Agatha’s mind screeched to a halt. What in the hell was this woman talking about?

Then it clicked. She was the mother of a five-year-old who had learned to read at three, well beyond The Very Hungry Caterpillar. They’d started reading Harry Potter together earlier this year, and now Agatha recognized the quote, the words landing in her mind like a bomb.

Her head snapped up, her neck practically breaking from the speed of it. Eyes narrowed, she glared at Rio.

“Did you just compare me to Snape ?”

And gods, that smirk. It stretched across Rio’s face like she could taste Agatha’s annoyance and was savoring it.

“Dark, brooding, powerful— misunderstood ,” Rio shrugged casually, her smirk deepening. “It fits, doesn’t it?”

Agatha clenched her jaw, torn between irritation and— though she would never admit it — something dangerously close to amusement.

Agatha’s jaw tightened as she stared at Rio, a sharp retort poised on her lips, but she hesitated. Rio was clearly enjoying this little game, and feeding into it wasn’t going to give Agatha the upper hand. Still, the comparison gnawed at her.

Misunderstood?

Agatha wasn’t misunderstood. She was crystal clear about who she was and what she wanted. Power. Control. Victory. There was no mystery in that.

“I’m not misunderstood,” Agatha said coldly, her voice slicing through the tension like a blade. “I’m very clear about what I do— and how I do it. ”

Rio’s smirk only widened, leaning back on the couch as if settling in for a long, enjoyable battle.

“Oh, I don’t doubt that. But misunderstood doesn’t have to mean unclear, does it?” Her tone was playful, teasing—yet there was something sharp underneath, like she was trying to poke at something deeper. “Sometimes, people can see exactly what you are and still miss the point.”

Agatha raised an eyebrow, refusing to rise to the bait. She turned back to her screen, her fingers resuming their steady typing, dismissing the conversation.

Rio didn’t seem deterred.

‘"You know, I think people misjudge you,” she continued, her voice taking on a more serious tone. “They think they see all there is to you. But they don’t.”

Agatha paused mid-keystroke, her irritation growing with each word. She didn’t like being analyzed, especially not by someone—lesser.

“And what, exactly, do you think they’re missing?” she asked without looking up, her voice cool and measured.

Rio was silent for a beat, long enough to make Agatha glance up, meeting her gaze. The smirk had faded, replaced by a thoughtful expression.

“They miss how much you care,” Rio said quietly, her eyes locking onto Agatha’s. “You hide it well, but I see it. You’re ruthless, yes. But it’s because you give a damn.”

Agatha stared at her, caught off guard. She hadn’t expected that . Most people assumed her ruthlessness came from a cold, detached place. The idea that someone might see her drive as a sign of care— of passion —unnerved her.

She shook her head, breaking the eye contact, her fingers clenching the edge of the keyboard.

“You don’t know me. Don’t pretend you do.”

Rio leaned forward, her tone soft but insistent.

“Maybe I don’t. But I know people like you .”

Agatha met her gaze again, this time with a mix of annoyance and curiosity.

“People like me?”

There were no people like her.

Rio smiled faintly.

“People who fight like hell because they care too much. Not because they don’t care at all.”

Agatha stared at her, unsure whether to feel insulted, intrigued, or both. For the first time in a long while, someone had managed to catch her off guard.

And it bothered her.

This woman was going to be a problem.

Agatha turned from her screen, her gaze finally settling fully on Rio. She really looked at her this time —studying her, sizing her up. The playful smirk was still there, but beneath it, Agatha could see something else: resolve. The kind of resolve that didn’t crack easily, the kind that didn’t care about boundaries or hierarchies.

And it wasn’t just her words. It was the way Rio held herself, the calm confidence that radiated off her, the way she didn’t flinch under Agatha’s scrutiny. Most people—hell, most seasoned lawyers—would have backed down by now, would have shown some flicker of doubt or fear.

But not this woman.

Agatha's eyes narrowed, taking in every detail, from the tailored green suit to the way Rio’s fingers drummed softly against the arm of the couch, as if daring her to make the next move. This wasn’t some naive associate trying to make a name for herself—this was someone who knew exactly what she wanted and wasn’t afraid to push for it.

Leaning back in her chair, Agatha crossed her arms, her eyes narrowing as she studied Rio more closely, weighing her options. She wasn’t used to being on this side of the equation.

“Why are you here?” Agatha found herself asking, her voice sharper than she intended.

Rio tilted her head, as if assessing her, sizing her up in a way that Agatha hadn’t experienced in a long time. Most people looked at her with fear or reverence. But Rio? She looked at her like a challenge, like she was ready to meet her head-on.

“I work here,” Rio deadpanned, her tone infuriatingly calm.

God, that was good.

Agatha felt the tug of a smile pulling at her lips, and she had to fight it, biting down on the inside of her cheek to keep it from showing. Instead, she clung to the simmering self- righteous anger she always kept close, using it as her shield.

“Why are you in my office ?” she hissed, her voice low and dangerous, eyes locked on Rio, waiting for her next move.

Rio didn’t flinch. In fact, the smirk on her lips deepened, as though she was fully aware of the effect she was having—and relishing every second of it.

“Mrs. Kale said I was helping you with Vanguard,” she said, her tone maddeningly casual, as if the monumental weight of the case meant nothing.

Your new mentee. Jen’s voice echoed in Agatha’s mind, curling through her thoughts like a thorny vine, digging deeper with every passing second. Agatha’s jaw clenched, her teeth grinding as she fought back the rising surge of irritation.

“She said I earned it because I found something on Vanguard. That I’m officially your associate now,” Rio said, her voice steady and maddeningly calm.

Agatha exhaled deeply through her nose, half-expecting smoke to billow out with the fire that was steadily building inside her.

“Did she now?” Agatha’s voice was cold, sharp enough to slice through the thick tension that filled the room.

Rio’s smirk didn’t waver. She shrugged, completely unfazed.

“I mean, technically, you said it first. If I recall, your exact words were: ‘ If you somehow manage to unearth something real, something no one else has found, I will personally mentor you. Build you. Mold you into something unstoppable.’ ”

Agatha’s jaw clenched. Jesus Christ . Those were her exact fucking words .

What was she, Rain Man?

Agatha’s eyes narrowed, her gaze hardening into something lethal.

“If I wanted to hear myself talk, I’d do it. I don’t need you of all people quoting me back to myself.”

But Rio didn’t flinch. That damn smirk stayed fixed on her lips, taunting Agatha, pushing her, challenging her.

And god—Agatha had never wanted to break something so badly.

She leaned forward, her voice dropping dangerously low, her eyes locking onto Rio’s with unblinking intensity.

“Let me make one thing very clear: I don’t play games. You’re mistaken if you think this is going to be some mentor-mentee bonding experience,” she hissed, her tone venomous. “I don’t do hand-holding. If you’re staying, you’ll keep up or get crushed. No in-between.”

Rio’s expression didn’t falter. She shrugged again, that irritatingly calm demeanor still intact.

“I’m not here to play. I’m here to help. And from where I’m standing, it looks like I’ve already gotten further than your last attempt.”

Agatha’s eyes burned, and for a moment, the room crackled with silent fury. She studied Rio in silence, her fists tightening at her sides. This woman—had nerve. A dangerous nerve .

Finally, Agatha leaned back in her chair, crossing her arms over her chest.

“Alright then,” she said, her voice cold and cutting. “If you’re so eager to prove yourself, let’s see how long you last. But don’t expect any help from me. You sink or swim—either way, I don’t care.”

For the first time, the smirk on Rio’s face softened. Her eyes gleamed, not with arrogance but with something far more dangerous—excitement. Real, unbridled excitement.

“Good,” she said, her voice steady and sure. “That’s how I prefer it.”

Agatha’s lip curled into a slow, predatory smile. Her voice, when she spoke, was dripping with challenge.

“Okay, Vidal . Let’s see what you’re made of, then.”

Where All That's Wrong is Right

Agatha’s day was a relentless barrage of phone calls, emails, and fires that constantly needed extinguishing. Being a partner meant she was more of a firefighter than a lawyer these days, managing crises instead of sinking her teeth into the work that used to ignite her. Budgets, briefs, frantic clients—she moved through them all like a machine.

Efficient.

Precise.

But it didn’t stop the pull— to the case .

Every time her gaze slipped from the pages in front of her and drifted toward the war room, that’s what she repeated to herself. It was Vanguard —the hunt for her white whale—that tugged at her focus, not the woman inside that room.

Her office offered the perfect view of the war room, a constant reminder of the battle waiting for her. Every free second—a breath between calls, a brief pause between emails—her eyes would find their way there. Watching the case take shape, watching the clues unfold, watching the documents mount.

That’s what mattered. That’s what she was watching.

But the lie tasted bitter on her tongue every time she told it.

When Rio Vidal had first stepped into the war room, Agatha had watched her closely, narrowing her eyes, half-expecting the woman to stand there paralyzed, realizing the sheer magnitude of what Agatha had put on her. But no. Vidal just stood there, taking it all in, a quiet, unsettling calm about her.

She's in over her head. She will soon see, Agatha had thought, almost waiting for her the moment her to crack— to see it .

But then the phone rang, dragging Agatha into yet another client emergency. Irritation simmered as she spent the next twenty minutes navigating someone else’s disaster, her attention fracturing. She tried to shove the pull— Vanguard , she forced herself to think—into the background as she dealt with the issue, but it lingered like a shadow at the edge of her mind.

The second the call ended, her eyes snapped back to the war room, instinctive and immediate.

And there was Vidal—now at the table, the first of the boxes spread out before her, a document in hand. She looked calm. Too calm, really. The predatory smirk Agatha had come to expect was gone, but something else had taken its place—something that looked disturbingly like... pleasure.

It was unmistakable in the way Vidal’s lips curled, ever so slightly, as she read. Her eyes moved across the page with a slow, deliberate satisfaction, her fingers tracing the edge of the paper like she was savoring every bit of it. Agatha could feel it, that quiet enjoyment, the subtle shift in her expression—so calm, so focused, so utterly immersed in the work.

The pleasure in it was tangible, almost intimate.

And then Nicholas’s words from this morning echoed through her mind like a punch to the gut.

"She’s really pretty."

The thought jolted her, snapping her out of the moment.

What the hell was that?

Agatha shook her head, a surge of emotion flooding her chest—anger, yes, but something else too, something she refused to name.

Focus, she commanded herself, ripping her gaze from the war room as if it burned her. She tried to steady the sudden quickening of her pulse, tried to shove down whatever it was stirring inside her.

Thankfully, her email dinged, yanking her back to reality. A brief from one of the senior associates she’d been waiting on. She clicked it open, desperate to shift her mind back to something— anything —else.
