But as her eyes scanned the first page, her thoughts refused to follow. No matter how hard she pushed herself to focus, her mind stayed stubbornly locked on Vidal.

No, not Vidal.

Vanguard . Fuck.

Irritation flared hot in her chest. She tore through the first two pages of the brief, redlining it ruthlessly before she even made it halfway through. The work was sloppy, half-baked. Her temper rose as she furiously typed an email in response, not bothering to sugarcoat her words.

"Submit something like this to me again, and the next thing you’ll be drafting is your resignation," she fired back.

Her fingers hovered over the keyboard for a moment, her pulse racing—not just from the poor quality of the work.

This fixation was dangerous.

Agatha couldn’t afford it— didn’t want it .

Grabbing a folder off her desk, she opened it and she forced herself to focus on the contract in front of her. It was for one of her biggest clients, so it needed by perfect.

She needed to be sharp, precise.

But instead, she gnawed on the top of her pen, frustration simmering just below the surface. Her eyes kept pulling toward the war room, despite every ounce of will she tried to muster against it.

Don’t look. Focus.

But the thought alone had her glancing up—and god , she wanted to slap herself.

There was Vidal, seated at the table, chewing on the end of her pen, lips brushing against the plastic in the same thoughtless way Agatha had just been doing. Agatha’s breath caught, her grip tightening around her own pen. She quickly tore it from her mouth and tossed it aside as if it burned her.

The scene in front of Vidal was controlled chaos: papers scattered everywhere, stacks teetering on the edge of collapse, but somehow, the woman didn’t look overwhelmed. If anything, she looked... pleased .

Agatha’s heart stuttered, her pulse quickening as she watched Vidal lean forward slightly, that faint smile playing on her lips as she studied something on the page.

Then— goddammit —her tongue flicked out, just briefly, running over her lips in thought.

Agatha felt heat rise in her chest. It sent a pulse straight through her, sharp and unwanted.

Nope. No Fucking. Way.

She tore her gaze away, her jaw clenched so tightly she thought she might crack a tooth.

What is wrong with me?

“ Billy! ” she barked, her voice sharp enough to cut through the hum of the office, and everything went quiet. Out of the corner of her eye, she saw Vidal look up too—just a glance, no smirk, no expression, just looking. And god , Agatha forced herself to stay locked on Billy’s panicked face instead, fighting the urge to meet Vidal’s gaze.

She needed to get the hell out of here.

“Move my lunch meeting to now,” she ordered, already on her feet, heading for her coat.

Billy blinked, stammering, “Um—Ms. Harkness, it’s only 10 AM. I don’t even think the restaurant is—"

Pulling on her coat with a swift, irritated motion, she fixed him with a look that made him shut up instantly.

“Figure it out, Pet,” she hissed, brushing past him as if the very air around her was suffocating.

She stalked down the hallway, her coat billowing behind her with the sheer speed of her steps. Agatha's heels clicked sharply against the polished floor, each step echoing like the crack of a whip, a warning to anyone in her path. She refused to look toward the war room as she passed it, keeping her eyes fixed straight ahead.

But god—she could feel it. Feel her eyes on her. That quiet, insufferable gaze of Rio Vidal watching her, and it only made her walk faster. She felt the heat rise in her chest, a frustration she couldn’t name, and the need to get away from it— from her —was overwhelming.

The client meeting had gone... okay. Of course, the client wasn’t thrilled about the meeting being pushed two hours early, but when Agatha Harkness reschedules, you move with her or don’t move at all. That’s just how it worked. By the end of it, Agatha felt steadier, like she’d finally found her footing again, her core settling back into place. The tightness in her chest eased.

She walked back into the office with a singular purpose: head straight to her desk and bury herself in the next task. Passing the war room, she was fully determined to keep going—until something stopped her cold.

The whiteboard was no longer white.

Agatha paused mid-step, her eyes narrowing as they took in the scene through the glass. There, standing next to the now-cluttered board, was Vidal, completely immersed in the board. Documents were pinned up, sticky notes scattered across the surface, and in the middle of it all, written in that familiar messy handwriting, was a name that hit her like a freight train.

Brooke Sinclair.

And just below it, a picture of the woman herself. Agatha’s heart gave a heavy thump, the kind that pulled her forward like she was tethered to the case itself.

She couldn’t help it. The pull— this time of the case , she told herself—had her moving toward the door, her hand reaching for the handle before she even realized what she was doing.

As the door creaked open, Vidal turned, her eyes widening ever so slightly at the sight of Agatha. It was a subtle reaction, but one Agatha didn’t miss. And god , she took a small, satisfying pleasure in catching Vidal off guard. It was a rare thing, and Agatha savored it.

"Working hard, I see," Agatha said, her voice cool as she stepped into the room. But as soon as the words left her mouth, she noticed something that caught her completely off guard— Vidal had shed her green jacket, now standing there in just her tailored green pants and a

crisp white button-down, the sleeves rolled up to her elbows. A dark leather-banded watch hugged her left wrist, and the simplicity of it—the rolled sleeves, the effortless confidence— threw Agatha more than she cared to admit.

For a moment, Agatha’s gaze lingered, betraying her control. She wasn’t used to this—being the one caught off balance—and it took everything in her to tear her eyes away from Vidal and force her focus back to the board.

Focus on the case.

The case.

Agatha repeated to herself, forcing the thought into her head like a mantra.

"What have you found?" she asked, her voice steadier than she felt as she nodded toward the board and stepped forward.

Vidal snapped back to the task, nodding and stepping aside so Agatha could get a clearer view. But Agatha’s attention flickered, unwillingly, from the board to Vidal’s rolled-up sleeves, her toned forearms casually on display.

“I’ve found a couple of things in the data," Vidal said, pointing at a series of numbers that were incomprehensible to Agatha. She nodded absently. "I need more time to see if the pattern repeats itself, but there’s something here."

Agatha gave a sharp nod, barely able to keep her mind tethered to the words.

“And this report..." Vidal reached for a document pinned to the whiteboard, handing it to Agatha. As Agatha took it, their fingers brushed again, and the contact sent an unwanted jolt of heat up her arm. She stiffened but kept her expression cold, despite the sudden warmth rushing under her skin.

“This is a logistics report from 2022," Vidal explained, stepping closer as she pointed to a section of the report. Agatha could feel the proximity now, the way the air seemed to tighten between them. "It outlines shipping containers, their contents, deliveries. But this page—" Vidal reached for the report again, her fingers brushing Agatha’s with maddening ease, "— this page was scanned separately from the rest.”

Agatha’s eyes snapped up.

“How could you possibly know that?” she asked, a little sharper than she intended, trying to shake off the effect Vidal’s presence was having on her.

Vidal’s smirk returned, lazy and confident, and god , it sent a pulse of frustration—and something else—through Agatha. Vidal leaned in closer, too close, flipping through the pages with a deliberate slowness that had Agatha grinding her teeth. Their hands touched again, and Agatha felt her breath catch against her will.

"You see this?" Vidal pointed to a small, nearly imperceptible black dot at the corner of the page. "It’s on every page of the report—except for this one."

Agatha’s brows furrowed.

What was this woman doing to her?

“And why does that matter?” she asked, forcing herself to focus.

Vidal leaned in closer, close enough for Agatha to catch the faint scent of her perfume—a subtle blend of cedar and forest, earthy and intoxicating. Agatha’s jaw tightened.

“Because,” Vidal continued, her voice smooth, her fingers brushing against Agatha’s again as she flipped back to the key page. “That dot comes from a scanner defect, something that burned into every page of this report. Except page 37.”

Agatha’s gaze snapped to Vidal’s fingers—long, nails short, well manicured, tracing the document. The heat between them felt unbearable, almost suffocating.

Vidal glanced at her, satisfaction practically glowing on her face.

“Which means someone scanned this entire report, removed page 37, and replaced it with a different one from another scanner. They are hiding something.”

Agatha’s eyes flicked back to Vidal, heart pounding a little harder than it should have.

She was good.

Too good.

And the way she stood there, just a breath away, that self-satisfied smirk on her face—it set something off in Agatha. She hated being off-balance, hated the way her body reacted to Vidal’s closeness.

But damn if it wasn’t getting harder to tear her eyes away.

Agatha swallowed, trying to ignore the heat coursing through her.

“Good catch,” she said, her voice tight. “But next time, try not to take so long explaining it.”

Vidal’s smirk didn’t waver; if anything, it sharpened.

“I didn’t think you minded the details.”

Agatha glared at her, trying to push away the pull, the distraction of Vidal’s proximity. She tore her eyes back to the board, forcing herself to focus on the case. Her gaze landed on the picture of Brooke Sinclair, and she stepped away from Vidal closer to the board.

Vidal tracked her movement, her eyes following the shift.

“Brooke Sinclair,” she began, her tone more serious, but still carrying that annoying edge of confidence. “I think there’s something you and your team might’ve missed with her.”

Agatha’s brow arched, irritation creeping in.

“Oh yeah?” she mocked.

“Yeah.” Vidal stepped a little closer, filling the gap Agatha tried to between them. “The deep dive your investigator did on her—did you catch her text messages with her co-worker, Kelcie?”

Agatha frowned, trying to place the name.

“The engineer at Vanguard?”

Vidal gave a small nod, her eyes meeting Agatha’s with that same challenging gleam.

“That’s the one.”

Agatha sighed, her patience hanging by a thread. She hated being led around, especially by someone who was clearly enjoying it.

“You’re going to have to give me more than that, Vidal.”

Vidal huffed, rolling her eyes in a way that was both exasperated and somehow...endearing. Then, without hesitation, she dropped the bomb.

“They were definitely fucking.”

The word hit Agatha like a slap—unexpected, raw. Her breath caught in her throat, and for a brief second, her mind blanked. The bluntness of it, the way Vidal said it so casually, so brazenly —it sent a shockwave through her, leaving her momentarily off-balance.

She stared at Vidal, her expression carefully neutral, but her mind was anything but.

Vidal seemed to realize her slip a beat too late, her face reddening slightly as she quickly corrected herself.

“I mean—they were definitely having sex,” she amended, clearing her throat and shifting uncomfortably.

But the damage was done. The word still hung in the air between them, heavy and sharp.

Fucking.

Agatha felt a strange heat crawl up her neck, her pulse quickening despite her best efforts to stay composed. There was something about hearing Vidal say it—so bluntly, without apology —that had her struggling to control the ripple of tension that passed through her.

For a split second, Agatha found herself frozen, staring at Vidal’s flushed face, the awkward shift in her stance, the way her fingers nervously tapped the edge of the report in her hands. It was such a rare crack in Vidal’s usually cool, impenetrable demeanor that Agatha wasn’t sure if she found it amusing or maddening.

She cleared her throat, trying to force the tension back down, though when she spoke, her voice was tighter than she intended.

“And how exactly did you come to the conclusion they were—” she paused, letting “ fucking ” linger in the air, “ having sex ? All indications point to them being friends, colleagues who hung out after work.”

"Colleagues have sex," Vidal said casually, her tone so dismissive, so self-assured, as if it were the most obvious thing in the world.

The words hit Agatha harder than she expected. A sharp, visceral reaction stirred inside her, one she couldn’t easily tamp down. It wasn’t just the bluntness of the statement—it was the ease with which Vidal said it, as if the line between professional and personal was one she could cross without a second thought.

As if it were normal.

Expected.

Wanted.

Agatha’s pulse quickened, her irritation flaring as she tried to smother the deeper, more unsettling emotion rising in her chest. She stiffened, her jaw tightening as she forced her voice to remain steady, neutral—controlled.

"Not everyone crosses that line," she replied, her words clipped, but the faint edge in her tone betrayed her. She couldn’t help it—something about Vidal’s nonchalance struck a nerve, poking at the carefully constructed boundaries Agatha had built over the years.

The line between personal and professional.

The line she never crossed.

“And there’s nothing in Brooke’s profile that suggests she was gay,” she added, as if the facts could reinforce her point, could pull her back from whatever slippery slope Vidal had her teetering on. Agatha threw Vidal a sharp look before returning her gaze to Brooke’s photo pinned on the board. “Catholic upbringing, only ever dated men, Republican farmers for parents.”

Agatha wasn’t usually one for boxing people in, for making assumptions. But sometimes facts were just facts, and she needed facts to steady herself. Facts anchored her, gave her control— and she needed control —especially now with the storm brewing inside her.

But Vidal wasn’t even slightly fazed. She snorted, and the sound of casual dismissal stung more than Agatha expected.

“So what? You think religious upbringing and a few boyfriends in her past makes her straight? People are more complicated than that.” Vidal leaned in just slightly, her voice low and almost teasing, as if she was enjoying this push-and-pull. “Sexuality is not always concrete—it can be fluid—and it can surprise you.”

Agatha's jaw tightened, a flicker of heat rising in her chest. She hated the way Vidal spoke with such confidence, as if she knew something Agatha wasn’t willing to admit. The deliberate playfulness in Vidal’s words stoked a fire of irritation, but beneath it, something else churned—something she refused to acknowledge.

“Speaking from experience, Vidal?” Agatha shot back, needing hit back, but unable to keep the edge from her voice.

Vidal didn’t miss a beat.

“Oh—I am not straight,” she said so casually, like it was the most natural thing in the world. “I exclusively—” she paused, letting that word hang between them, charged, lingering, “— see women.”

Jesus Christ , Agatha thought. I’m not going to survive this.

The air felt too thick, too charged, and Vidal was entirely too calm. Too comfortable. Agatha was suddenly acutely aware of the way Vidal's eyes hadn’t wavered, how she didn’t flinch or hesitate.

She was so...unapologetic.

She had to pull herself together, fast. Mockery was her best weapon, her shield, and she wielded it now.

“Oh, how touching that you trusted me enough to come out,” Agatha replied, her voice laced with sarcasm so sharp it could cut glass. “I’ll be sure to put a rainbow flag in my pen holder, so you know I’m a proper ally.”

The words were barbed, dripping with disdain, but deep down Agatha felt the tension rising. The sarcasm came too easily, masking the discomfort Vidal’s candor stirred. It wasn’t the gay thing—Agatha wasn’t ignorant, wasn’t naive. It was the fact that Vidal delivered it with such quiet confidence, like it was a power move. Like she was in control.

And god, Agatha hated how much she respected that. How much she— no .

No .

Agatha fought against that train of thought. She forced herself to hold her ground, to stay rooted in logic, in the facts. She straightened, her chin lifting, eyes narrowing as if daring Vidal to challenge her further.

“There’s nothing in this case to suggest Brooke was anything but straight.”

Vidal didn’t back down. In fact, her smirk deepened, her eyes glittering with that maddening confidence.

"Really? You’re straight, right?” she asked, her voice a slow, deliberate drawl, like she was savoring the words. Letting them hang between them, heavy, charged, deliberate.

Agatha held her ground, but only barely.

The truth?

She’d always considered herself straight— strictly men . They were uncomplicated, predictable. She didn’t like complications, not in her personal life. Professionally, sure, she could outmaneuver anyone, but intimacy? She wanted it clean, simple, controlled. She dated men, married one, divorced him, and now she was 48. Too old, she told herself, to consider what she never allowed herself to entertain in her youth. Those fleeting thoughts, the ones she buried deep.

But Vidal’s eyes were on her now, and the way they narrowed with predatory curiosity made Agatha’s chest tighten.

Focus , she commanded herself, trying to keep her expression unreadable, but the charge between them was undeniable. She couldn’t ignore it, couldn’t ignore her .

Vidal was watching her too closely, taking in every shift, every subtle movement. The silence stretched, and Agatha felt the heat rise in her, skin prickling as she fought to maintain control. She glared at Vidal, determined to remain stone-faced, unaffected.

But Vidal wasn’t done. That damn smirk—cocky, knowing —stretched across her face.

“You’re telling me,” she said slowly, her voice almost a purr now, “there’s not a single woman in the world you’d let into your bed?”

The question was like a challenge thrown between them, and Agatha could feel the pull, the heat behind the words wrapping around her, daring her to engage. Her chest tightened, and for the first time in a long while, she was at a loss for words. She opened her mouth, but nothing came out—caught between the raw, unspoken tension in Vidal’s gaze and her own need to keep control.

The silence stretched again, and Vidal’s smirk only deepened, like she’d won something. She leaned back, her body relaxed, but her eyes gleaming with triumph.

“I rest my case,” she murmured, almost mockingly.

Agatha felt something inside her snap, a pulse of heat rushing through her veins. This was no longer about work, no longer about a case. This was personal, a dangerous push-and-pull that had her teetering on the edge.

And she wasn’t sure which way she wanted to fall.

Unlock Thy Hidden Gate

Three days later, Agatha sat in the war room, the glow of the overhead lights casting sharp shadows across the piles of documents and tangled threads of the Vanguard case. Night had fallen long ago, and while her days were consumed by the responsibilities of being a partner —meetings, clients, and the endless fires that required her attention—after seven, Agatha was finally able to dive into what she truly craved: the hunt.

The Vanguard case was different.

Special.

It gnawed at her, demanded her attention, and pulled her in ways she hadn’t felt in years.

And though she would never, ever admit it out loud, Rio Vidal made the chase even more intoxicating.

Vidal was sharper than anyone Agatha had worked with in a long time. The way she could recall details from reports she’d read days ago, quoting them word for word, or cite case law with frightening accuracy, was nothing short of extraordinary. It was like she had a photographic memory, effortlessly cataloging and retrieving information like it was nothing.

But Vidal was also green.

Agatha wasn’t.

That’s where the real dance began.

Vidal would unearth something she believed was bulletproof—a key link, a watertight argument—and Agatha would systematically tear it apart. She’d poke holes in it until there was nothing left but the shredded remains of Vidal’s confidence. But where most would shrink under that kind of scrutiny, Vidal didn’t.

She absorbed it.

Every critique, every jab Agatha threw her way, Vidal took it like it was nothing— no , not nothing. She took each blow like a challenge. Fuel that made her dig deeper, push harder, and come back sharper, more determined.

Agatha had to hand it to her—Vidal was either a masochist or had the kind of unrelenting resolve that could cut through steel.

Probably a little of both , she thought and that sent Agatha’s mind spiraling.

Professionally, the working relationship between them had become a well-oiled machine.

They were good together.

Agatha hated it.

She despised how well they worked, the efficiency, the rhythm. She hated that every part of her knew it was true.

But personally? Privately? That was a different beast entirely. The part of herself Agatha kept locked away, tightly controlled, felt like a live wire sparking dangerously next to an open gas can. It was volatile, electric, and it was only getting worse.

Every touch—which Agatha swore was intentional.

Every look Vidal sent her way.

That fucking smirk.

The constant challenges. The playful word games. The way Vidal’s lips would quirk ever so slightly when she caught Agatha staring—like just now, chewing on the end of a pen cap as if it wasn’t driving Agatha mad.

It ate at her, little by little, each moment sparking something dangerous. Something Agatha hadn’t felt in a long time. She couldn’t remember the last time she’d felt this affected by anyone.

Not like this.

Never like this.

She needed to get her shit under control.

Control.

It was everything .

Her rule.

Her shield.

Her weapon.

Her armor.

But with every passing day, every heated glance from Vidal, every veiled innuendo, Agatha felt that control slipping, unraveling bit by bit. And that terrified her.

And when Agatha was scared—when control seemed just out of reach—she lashed out.

Hard .

The entire office was walking on eggshells around her. Yesterday, she swore she saw Billy's eyes glisten with tears when she tore into him over something he had no control over. But he was closest, and she needed something— someone —to attack.

The moment she entered a hallway, senior associates who were quite used to her antics, turned and went the other way. She had already driven two new associates to hand in their resignations within the last 48 hours. A personal record, really. Usually, it took a week to break them.

Two in two days? That was impressive, even by her standards.

Jen, however, was not impressed.

The two who quit had been Jen’s picks—clients' kids, no less. Now, those clients were calling, demanding to know why their golden children left the firm in tears, questioning what kind of place they were running.

Agatha braced herself for the usual shovel talk from Jen, the lecture about how they needed to “ play nice ” with important clients. But instead, Jen threw her a curveball that hit her like a brick.

“Is Nicholas, okay?” Jen had asked, her voice unexpectedly soft, filled with genuine concern.

The question startled Agatha. Jen was looking at her differently, with something Agatha despised— pity.

“What?” Agatha snapped, her voice more defensive than she intended. “He’s fine.”

Jen didn’t blink, just continued to look at her—really look at her in a way that made Agatha feel exposed.

"It’s just—I haven’t seen you like this since..." Jen trailed off, but the unspoken words hung heavy between them.

Agatha’s chest tightened. She knew exactly what Jen was talking about.

Since Nicholas was sick.

The memory slammed into her— unwelcome , like a sharp sting.

When Agatha finally died, hopefully it would be a long, long time from now—because she had plenty more things to destroy—there was one thing she knew for certain. The first thing she'd do, wherever she ended up, would be to find the powers that be, wrap her hands around their necks, and scream:

“ What kind of god gives a three-year-old cancer?! ”

Thankfully it was treatable.

Modern medicine had advanced just enough for them to catch it in time, treat it, and put Nicholas into remission. Now, there was barely a chance it would ever return. But during that time, when he was sick, when her little boy had been hooked up to machines, fighting a battle he shouldn’t have ever had to fight... Agatha had lost control.

Completely.

She became a monster.

Nothing survived her wrath.

She tore through the office like a storm, annihilating everything in her path. Six contempt citations in court—a personal record. She fired so many people in the span of those months that the partners had to temporarily strip her of the authority to fire anyone because they couldn’t fill positions fast enough.

No one wanted to work with her. No one wanted to be near her.

And James, her husband at the time? He was in that group, too.

Agatha wasn’t surprised when James left. He had always been weak—too weak to handle her, too weak to handle Nicholas’s illness, and too weak to shoulder the weight of their world crumbling around them. So, he walked away. And Agatha, true to form, didn’t have time to mourn him—didn’t care to, either. She was too busy clawing her way back to control.

It wasn’t until the remission diagnosis, when the words “he’s going to be okay” finally reached her ears, that she felt something inside her ease. The only thing that pulled her back from the brink, from the chaos she’d become, was the knowledge that Nicholas had survived.

That she had fought through it and won.

It was control, pure and simple. It had always been control that kept her anchored.

“I’m glad Nicholas is okay,” Jen said quietly, letting the words linger between them.

They weren’t friends— not exactly —but they were something . Her and Jen’s relationship was the kind that was built on mutual survival, where only they could stab each other in the back and no one else. In a weird, twisted way, they protected each other, even while plotting each other’s downfall.

Symbiotic.

The silence between them thickened before Jen snapped out of it, her expression hardening into the familiar glare.

“Stop terrorizing the first years,” Jen warned. “They see you coming and practically sprint in the opposite direction. And if I have to take one more call from a client asking why their golden-child left the firm in tears—”

Agatha’s sharp laugh cut her off, the tension between them breaking as she slipped back into her usual bravado.

“Oh, please,” Agatha said, rolling her eyes. “You’re just mad that your hires turned out to be incompetent. There’s no way those two passed the bar on their own merit. Did you see the brief Callaway wrote? It looked like it was written in crayon! And don’t get me started on

Wright. Do you know why I yelled at him? I overheard him asking another associate what prima facie meant.”

Jen’s mouth twitched, fighting back a smile, though the stern look in her eyes remained.

"Agatha,” she said with a tired sigh. “Just lay off them. I’m running out of excuses for your behavior."

“Have you tried blaming it on my ‘ mommy issues ’? That’s what my therapist says.” Agatha quipped, earning an eye roll from Jen.

Jen turned to leave clearly giving up on the battle, but something clicked in Agatha’s mind, and before she could stop herself, the words slipped out.

“Who picked Vidal?”

Jen froze, brow raised, her eyes flicking toward the war room, then back to Agatha, as if she were trying to piece something together. Agatha instantly regretted asking, watching Jen’s lips quirk into a devilish smirk.

“Why do you ask?” Jen’s voice dripped with amusement, almost taunting.

Agatha fought to keep her face impassive, unwilling to give Jen an inch.

“Well,” she said carefully, searching for words Jen couldn’t pick apart. “She’s... surprisingly — not an idiot , unlike the rest of your recruits.”

Jen’s smirk deepened, her eyes gleaming with amusement.

“Not an idiot?” repeated Jen with an almost sing-like tone. “That’s high praise coming from you. Careful , Agatha, someone might think you actually like her.”

Agatha’s jaw tightened, irritation flaring.

“I don’t like anyone, Jen. You know that.”

“Oh, I know,” Jen said, her tone light, teasing. “But you’re curious, aren’t you? She’s gotten under your skin.”

Agatha’s eyes narrowed, refusing to take the bait.

“She’s just competent. Which is more than I can say for the rest of the associates you’ve sent my way.”

Jen shrugged, unbothered by the jab.

“Whatever you say.”

She turned to leave, clearly enjoying the small victory she thought she’d gained, but before walking out the door, Jen called over her shoulder.

“She was Lilia’s pick, by the way.”

Agatha froze.

Lilia— of course .

Lilia didn’t hire often, but when she did, she had an unshakable talent for picking the good ones. She had a sixth sense for potential, seeing things in people that others couldn’t. Agatha knew that all too well—Lilia had been the one to poach her from her old firm when she was a third-year associate, recognizing her potential long before anyone else had.

If Lilia picked Vidal—then that meant she was special.

The memory lingered until Vidal’s voice cut through, pulling Agatha out of her thoughts. She jerked slightly, realizing she’d missed whatever Vidal had said.

“What?”

Vidal stood in front of the whiteboard, her expression bored, arms crossed.

“I want to talk to Kelcie Baker,” she repeated. “She knows something.”

Agatha leaned back in her chair, her lips pursing.

“She won’t talk to us. Vanguard will never allow it without a lawyer present.”

Before Agatha could react, Vidal stepped forward, moving closer— too close, almost hovering over her. The proximity made Agatha’s skin prickle with tension.

“What are you—” Agatha began, but Vidal was already reaching past her, grabbing Agatha’s laptop without hesitation. The fact that Vidal’s chest was nearly pressed against her face wasn’t lost on her, and Agatha’s irritation flared and something else flared.

“Do you have any respect for personal space?” Agatha growled as Vidal moved away, though not far enough for her liking—still standing way too close, a teasing smirk playing at the edges of her lips.

Vidal paused mid-typing, glancing at Agatha with that infuriating flash in her eyes.

“Does me being close to you bother you?” she asked, voice low and loaded with challenge.

It was such a simple question, but it was delivered like a dare. The way Vidal’s eyes gleamed, the way she stood there as if she knew exactly how much she was getting under Agatha’s skin, left Agatha bristling with frustration and something she still refused to name.

Agatha’s jaw clenched, her voice steely.

“No,” she lied. "But I do expect some professionalism."

Vidal's smirk finally emerged.

"Of course," Vidal said, her voice dripping with feigned innocence. "Just checking."

Then she turned back to the laptop, typing away as though the tension between them hadn’t just skyrocketed.

Agatha’s patience wore thinner with each click of the keys. She was about to snap when Vidal suddenly stood and turned the laptop toward her.

Agatha leaned forward, her eyes narrowing as she read the screen.

“ Gay of Thrones: The Dance of the Dragon Queens. Drag Show at the Red Light Tonight ,” she read aloud, her irritation palpable. She exhaled sharply. "And what exactly does this have to do with work?" she practically hissed.

Vidal’s grin grew predatory.

“Kelcie RSVP’d to the event,” she said, her eyes gleaming with satisfaction. "She’ll be there."

That caught Agatha’s attention. Her eyes flicked back to the screen, which looked like a unicorn had thrown up a rainbow all over it. Interesting.

“Even if we could get her to talk,” Agatha said slowly, her mind working, “we can’t use anything she says in court. It’s hearsay. She’ll never sign an affidavit.”

Vidal nodded, not missing a beat.

“We don’t need her statement. If she gives us something— anything —we can use it as a lead. Let her point us in the direction we need to follow. Instead of building this case blind, we let her be our compass.”

Agatha hated that it wasn’t a terrible idea. In fact, it was annoyingly clever. She chewed over it, her mind racing through the possibilities.

"And what if she won’t talk?" Agatha asked, still searching for any flaw in the plan.

Vidal’s smirk widened.

“She’ll talk.”

Agatha raised a brow.

“You sound awfully confident.”

Vidal leaned in just slightly, her voice low, almost cockily.

“Let’s just say I have a way of getting people to open up.”

Agatha’s pulse quickened, but she tamped down the reaction, keeping her expression impassive.

This woman was impossible .

She stared at Vidal, then back at the screen, before finally exhaling.

"Fine. We'll go," Agatha said, her decision already made the moment Vidal mentioned Kelcie’s name. She stood, grabbing her purple trench coat from the back of her chair and swinging it on with a practiced ease.

"We?" Vidal echoed, sounding genuinely surprised. "You’re actually going?"

Agatha turned, eyes narrowing as if the very question was an insult.

"This is my case," she said, the weight of authority clear in her tone. "I’m not letting some baby lawyer question a key witness— again —in my case without me there."

For a brief second, Vidal looked impressed before she masked it with a neutral expression.

"Okay," she nodded, grabbing her own jacket. "Are we riding together?"

Agatha laughed at that, the sharp sound echoed in the war room as she moved toward the door, tossing Vidal a withering look over her shoulder.

" I’ll be riding in my town car," she said, her eyes scanning Vidal up and down with a hint of condescension. " You can take an Uber."

She gave a dismissive wave, her fingers wiggling in a mock farewell.

"Ta ta," Agatha added, her voice dripping with sarcasm as she sauntered out, a smirk tugging at her lips.

She didn’t bother looking back—satisfied with the certainty that Vidal was probably frowning behind her. The smirk deepened as she strode down the hallway, savoring the small victory in a game that was becoming more intriguing with each move.

She wasn't entirely sure of the rules yet, but she knew one thing : she was determined to win .

Neath the Wooded Shrine

People always assumed Agatha went into law for power, and sure , that was partly true.

But the reality was simpler.

Agatha liked boundaries.

She liked the law because, while its interpretation could be fluid, its roots ran deep— immovable and grounded in centuries of precedent. It could sway, but it never broke.

It was steady, predictable, and Agatha thrived on that steadiness.

She was accurately aware that she was a walking contradiction. A living, breathing oxymoron.

Outwardly, she was known for being wild, untethered, and completely unpredictable. That was her brand—what made her feared and respected in equal measure. But deep down, Agatha craved structure. Rules kept the chaos at bay, gave her control in a world that thrived on disorder. She needed boundaries—clear lines to draw and redraw as she saw fit.

So, as Agatha eyed the Red Light bar from the safety of her town car, she knew that she was about step into a world far outside her carefully controlled boundaries. The vibrant crowd and the unapologetic energy—it didn’t take a genius to see what the Red Light was—a gay bar.

Only a gay bar would host a "Game of Thrones Drag Night," and only a place like this would have such an eclectic crowd gathered outside. Men in everything from skimpy outfits and stilettos to jeans and boots. Women in skin-tight dresses or rocking masculine wear with a swagger. Every damn letter of that acronym, LGBTQIA+, was out there in full display—an alphabet soup she could hardly keep up with.

And it wasn’t just the terminology that tripped her up.

Out there was a world she didn’t know how to navigate.

Give her a courtroom, a boardroom— hell —even a men’s club, and she could walk in like she owned the place and leave owning it. But here—outside this place, with its carefree happiness, its freedom —it was like stepping into a scene from her worst nightmare.

Agatha stared out at the crowd, her fingers tapping anxiously against her leg.

She didn’t want to go outside.

The thought of stepping into that world, where everything seemed so loose, so free—it unsettled her in ways she wasn’t comfortable acknowledging. It wasn’t the kind of place she belonged, and the idea of being in the middle of it made her stomach tighten.

But she knew she had to.

She refused to still be sitting in this car when Vidal arrived. Refused to let her see even a flicker of hesitation. Vidal would be walking into this place like she owned it, slipping into the chaos effortlessly. And Agatha couldn’t afford to show a crack in her armor, to show Vidal she was uncomfortable. It was a point she wasn’t willing to concede this game they have been playing with each other.

So with a deep heavy sigh that did nothing to settler her nerves, she shrugged off her coat, because this was definitely not the kind of establishment that had a coat check, and she’d be damned if she was going to hang her designer jacket over a barstool. Her Hermes purse stayed in the car as well; she wasn’t to risk that in there. She grabbed only the essentials— cash, credit card, phone—before throwing her hair into a messy bun and looked at herself in her pocket mirror to make sure she looked acceptable.

She looked nervous, and she snapped the pocket mirror closed with a hiss. She closed her eyes, and then, with one final inhale, she opened the door and stepped out into the night.

No one even looked her way when her heels hit the sidewalk.

Which was rare—Agatha commanded attention when she walked into a room.

But here?

She was just one among many.

When you’re sharing space with a 6’5” drag queen, sporting a full beard, flawless makeup, and a barely-there dress, well... you’re not exactly the center of attention anymore.

For once, Agatha wasn’t the shiniest object in the room. It was full of personalities, larger- than-life people with confidence radiating from every corner, and—dare she admit it— some even larger than hers. But as she stepped through the door and into the bar, it felt oddly refreshing.

Nice, even.

Not being recognized.

Not having every eye on her.

A few appreciative glances came her way—mostly from impeccably dressed men who eyed her designer clothes and a couple from women who seemed to appreciate how well she wore said clothes . But for the most part, she was just another person at the bar.

And god, did she need a drink.

Or ten.

Agatha slid onto an empty barstool, her eyes scanning the room before landing on the bartender approaching her.

The woman was striking —blonde hair pulled back into a ponytail, strong, angular features framed by a pair of circular glasses. She was dressed in tight black pants and a sleeveless black shirt that showed off toned arms covered in intricate, inky tattoos that snaked down both sides. She had that effortless hipster/lesbian vibe down pat—too well.

Agatha could definitely see the appeal.

“What can I get you?” the bartender asked, her voice smooth, professional, but carrying a subtle teasing quality.

Agatha didn’t hesitate, her gaze lingering a little longer than she intended.

“The most expensive bourbon you’ve got,” she said, pulling out her credit card and slamming it down on the counter with a snap. “And keep it open.”

The bartender raised an impressed eyebrow as she slid Agatha's sleek black credit card off the counter. Without another word, she turned to make the drink, leaving Agatha a moment to scan the room. The place was packed, a swirling mass of and if Vidal was here, finding her would be like looking for a needle in a glitter-covered haystack.

Agatha cursed under her breath, irritated that she hadn’t insisted on giving Vidal a hard time —of making her take an uber. This entire mission to track down Kelcie Baker was already off to a rocky start.

Just as her frustration began to bubble beneath the surface, Agatha heard the clink of glass sliding across the bar top. She turned to see the bartender smiling softly in her direction, bourbon in hand, pushing it towards her.

“One of our finest bourbons, for one of our finest lady,” the bartender teased with a wink, her voice smooth, with just the right amount of playfulness.

Agatha grabbed the drink, smirking to herself. There was no harm in a little game while she waited.

“I bet you say that to all the ladies,” Agatha quipped, raising an eyebrow.

The bartender’s smile widened, and she leaned in slightly, closing the distance between them.

“Actually—no,” she replied, her tone dropping to something almost conspiratorial. “Not many people that come here can afford a $50 glass of bourbon.”

“Only $50?” Agatha took a slow sip, exaggerating her grimace a little more than necessary. “It tastes like it only cost $50.”

The bartender chuckled, leaning forward with an easy, knowing smile.

“Oh, the $8 one will really knock your socks off,” she teased.

Agatha laughed, surprising herself. For a moment, the tension in her shoulders eased. But as her eyes swept over the bar again, the reason she was there tugged her back to reality.

Flirting, as nice as it was, could only serve as a distraction for so long.

Where the hell was Vidal?

“Waiting for someone?” the bartender asked, the curiosity in her voice unmistakable.

Agatha nodded, downing the rest of her drink and setting the glass down with a little too much force.

“Yes.”

“That’s a shame,” the bartender said, her lips quirking up in a smile that Agatha grudgingly admitted was... effective .

“What? That I finished my drink so fast?” Agatha asked, still scanning the crowd for any sign of Vidal.

The bartender shook her head, her eyes locking onto Agatha’s with a look that was far too knowing.

“That you’re waiting for someone,” she said, the disappointment in her tone softened by that same smile.

Agatha’s mind stalled for a moment, thrown by the sheer boldness of the bartender’s words. It had been a long time since someone had flirted with her so openly, so casually. Of course, there was Vidal, but with her, Agatha could never be sure—was Vidal flirting or just testing her boundaries? Pushing her, seeing how far Agatha’s control stretched before it snapped?

But this bartender— this woman —wasn’t playing mind games. She was just... flirting. Plain and simple. And that, oddly enough , was kind of a relief. There were no complex motives, no hidden agenda—just pure, uncomplicated interest. And damn if that didn’t stir something deep inside her, something she hadn’t felt in longer than she cared to admit.

She opened her mouth, the response hovering on the edge of something—flirty, playful, she wasn’t even sure what. But there was an undeniable pull, a subtle urge to engage, to throw a little heat back into the mix. Then, just as the words were forming, she felt it—a hand on her shoulder. At first soft, then firm, fingers curling with purpose.

Agatha froze.

Who the hell had the audacity to touch her?

She spun around, ready to deliver a cutting remark, her irritation spiking, when a voice rumbled near her ear—low, familiar , and entirely too close.

“There you are, baby ,” Vidal murmured, her voice laced with teasing edge. "Sorry to keep you waiting..." The hand tightened slightly, fingers pressing with deliberate kind of possession. “There was traffic .”

Agatha hated the shiver that went through her body.

Hated the way her body responded before her mind could catch up, the curl of heat that swept through her, and the way her lips parted ever so slightly, just for a second— a split second — where she let herself feel Vidal, just like that.

And Jesus , she felt like she was on fire.

But then, she snapped back to herself. How she found her control, she didn’t know, but she did. She turned to face Vidal, standing there in her untucked forest green shirt, dark ash pants, sleeves rolled up, the top buttons undone, revealing layered gold chains that caught the dim light against the backdrop of the pale skin of her chest.

She hated how good Vidal looked.

Hated even more how it made her feel—restless, hot, and annoyed all at once.

A fake smile slipped onto her face, the kind that came far more easily than her real ones. If Vidal wanted to play this game, Agatha could play it better.

“Hi, sweetheart ,” she said, the word dripping with mock affection, heat woven into the taunt. She leaned forward, just enough to watch the subtle way Vidal’s eyes darkened, her jaw tightening as Agatha closed the distance between them.

And then, with her lips barely brushing Vidal’s ear, she whispered, low and dangerous, just for her.

“Touch me again, and I’ll break your hand.”

Agatha had expected Vidal to pull back like she’d been burned, but instead, the woman— this infuriatingly bold woman —slowly withdrew her hand, her fingertips deliberately trailing down Agatha’s arm.

There was a spark in Vidal’s eyes, a smirk on her lips that screamed: I’m a pyromaniac, and I love playing with fire, even if it hurts.

Her touch lingered, setting Agatha’s skin ablaze with a sensation she both hated and couldn’t shake. Vidal’s hand finally dropped, but her gaze stayed, locked with Agatha’s in a long, charged moment that made the air between them thrum with unspoken tension.

Then, Vidal’s eyes flicked past Agatha’s shoulder, her smirk faltering into a thinner line.

“Max,” she said, her tone now having a different edge to it.

Agatha, confused, followed her gaze and found the bartender— Max —watching them with a raised brow.

“Rio,” the bartender acknowledged, nodding with a familiarity that annoyed Agatha more than she’d admit. Max’s eyes shifted to Agatha, her earlier flirtation replaced by something more subdued, almost apologetic.

“Another drink?” Max asked, reaching for Agatha’s empty glass.

Agatha nodded, momentarily at a loss for words, watching as Max turned to prepare her drink. The moment stretched between them, leaving Agatha alone with Vidal again, and she could feel the tension settling back into place as smoothly as before.

Turning to Vidal, she raised a brow, her voice laced with mockery.

“ A friend of yours ?” she asked, savoring the slight crack—just the tiniest tick at the corner of Vidal’s mouth—that appeared at her question.

The sound of glass sliding against the bar echoed behind them, and Vidal threw Agatha a glance before stepping forward. Her body brushed against Agatha’s for a fleeting moment as she reached around her, fingers curling around a beer bottle that hadn’t been there before. Agatha’s skin tingled where they’d touched, but before she could register it, Vidal had pulled back, taking a slow drink from the bottle, her eyes never leaving Agatha’s.

“No,” Vidal finally said, her tone calm, detached, like she was closing the door on a conversation that Agatha had barely started.

Agatha’s lips pursed, unsatisfied.

She had finally felt the crack, and she wasn’t ready to let it go—not when she’d finally found a way through Vidal’s carefully crafted armor. Her eyes flicked to the beer in Vidal’s hand.

She hadn’t ordered it, and yet it was there, as if summoned.

The connection clicked in Agatha’s mind.

“Come here often?” she drawled trying to find another way to slip past her defenses, to land another blow.

Vidal’s gaze sharpened, but instead of biting back, she raised the bottle again, taking another slow, deliberate sip.

And Agatha’s jaw clenched involuntarily, hating how good Vidal looked with the bottle pressed to her lips, framed by the strobing lights from the dance floor. She looked like she’d stepped right out of one of those over-sexualized beer commercials—effortlessly tempting, the kind of image men— or Agatha , if she had no taste and an unfinished basement—would tack up on the wall.

The thought of Vidal’s effect on her had Agatha gritting her teeth, irritation mixing with something else she still refused to name .

And judging by the knowing look Vidal threw her way as she lowered the beer bottle from her lips, Vidal was well aware of the reaction she was causing.

“Have you seen her yet?” Vidal asked, her eyes never leaving Agatha’s, not even bothering to glance around the bar.

Agatha felt a rush of relief.

Work .

Thank god.

Snapping back to the task at hand, her nerves settled like a gentle rain after a storm. She didn’t show it, of course—her expression remained as impassive as ever—but the distraction of the case was welcome. It gave her something solid to grip onto, something familiar to ground herself in.

“Not yet,” she said, her voice cool and controlled, though the shift in focus steadied her more than she’d like to admit.

"Then let's grab a seat," Rio suggested, her voice easy, almost nonchalant. "The show’s about to start, and we’ll have a better chance of spotting her once everyone’s settled."

Agatha nodded, not trusting herself to say anything. She stood up, flicking her hand dramatically for Vidal to lead the way.

Vidal smirked but didn’t push it, as she turned to walk away.

Agatha followed, sharply aware of the shift in energy as they moved through the crowd. It wasn’t so much that people were looking at them—no, they were looking at her .

Vidal.

She was the kind of woman who drew attention effortlessly. Agatha could feel the curious glances, the subtle stares of appreciation, but what really caught her off guard was the way several women looked at Vidal.

Those looks weren’t just admiration—they were steeped in history.

Longing.

Something unfamiliar and unwelcome flared in Agatha’s chest as she caught those glances. She hated how much they bothered her, how much they twisted something sharp inside her.

Vidal led them to a table and, with that infuriating smirk still playing on her lips, pulled out a chair for Agatha, eyes glinting with amusement.

Agatha shot her a glare, refusing to play into it. She grabbed her own chair with deliberate spite and sat down.

It was supposed to be a power move, a silent declaration that she was in control here—but instead of backing down, Vidal just snorted, amused, and sat down in the very chair she’d originally pulled out for Agatha. She sat down and took a drink, not surprised nor affected by Agatha’s little display at all.

Damn her.

Agatha grabbed her drink, taking a healthy sip, hoping to drown the restless energy coursing through her. She hated the way her nerves buzzed under her skin, even more so when she glanced at Vidal, lounging back in her chair, casually sipping her beer like they were at some beachside resort. It was unnerving how at ease she seemed, how unbothered she was by everything.

Agatha’s fingers tightened around her glass, her frustration building. She opened her mouth, ready to snap something sharp and cutting, but the words were swallowed by the sudden shift in the room. The music faded, giving way to the familiar, dramatic swell of the Game of Thrones theme. The lights dimmed even further, casting everything in shadows, as a wave of cheers erupted around them—catcalls, squeals, hollers from all sides.

The crowd surged like a living tide, the dance floor clearing as people scrambled for seats, crammed around tables, or lined up against the walls, their excitement palpable. Agatha watched with guarded curiosity, unsure of what to expect.

But the drag show that followed was, quite possibly, one of the most entertaining things Agatha had ever witnessed. She had a secret love for Broadway, and if there was one thing she knew, it was how a sprinkle of sex appeal could elevate a performance. These men—no, these women —were simply magnificent. The pageantry, the confidence, the humor—it was spellbinding. More than once, she caught herself smiling, drawn in by the energy of it all.

And then, a queen dressed as a scantily clad Cersei Lannister sauntered by their table, her hips swaying in time to the music as she collected dollar bills from the crowd. Agatha, not one to be left out, reached into her pocket and pulled out a bill, and without a second thought, she handed one over.

The queen’s eyes widened in shock, her expression turning reverent as she dramatically bowed before Agatha, sending a ripple of laughter through the nearby crowd, before moving on.

Vidal, who had been watching with amused disbelief, finally broke into laughter.

"Did you just give that drag queen a hundred?" she asked, her voice a mix of shock and amusement.

Agatha turned to her with a casual shrug.

“It was all I had.”

Vidal just shook her head, still laughing.

"You shouldn’t have done that," she said, her eyes gleaming with a mischievous glint.

Agatha frowned, confused.

"Why not? Isn't that what people do?"

Vidal leaned back in her chair, taking a swig of her drink, her grin spreading wider.

"Oh, you'll see," she said in a teasing, sing-song voice, clearly enjoying whatever inside joke she was keeping to herself.

And sure as shit , nine performances later, the show ended, and Agatha was out a thousand bucks. Turns out, drag queens are greedy little things. They kept coming back to her table, their eyes lighting up as soon as they saw the woman who’d handed out a hundred like it was pocket change.

Not that Agatha really minded. She’d definitely spent a thousand dollars on things far less enjoyable, and watching the queens work the crowd was worth every bill.

Still, she couldn’t help but throw Vidal a sideways glance, seeing the smug amusement that had settled on her face.

"Enjoying yourself?" Agatha asked, her voice dripping with sarcasm, though even she couldn’t hide the smirk tugging at her lips.

Vidal chuckled, leaning in slightly.

“Oh, absolutely. Watching you get worked by the queens? Worth every second .”

Agatha rolled her eyes, though she couldn't completely stifle her own amusement.

"I'll consider it charity," Agatha quipped, tossing back the last of her drink. "A tax write-off."

Vidal smirked at that, but then her eyes flicked past Agatha’s shoulder, narrowing with sharp focus. The playfulness evaporated, and her entire demeanor shifted.

"There she is," Vidal murmured, nodding behind Agatha.

Agatha’s pulse quickened. She turned to follow Vidal's gaze, and there she was—Kelcie Baker. For a brief moment, during the show, amid the banter and drinks, Agatha had almost forgotten why they were there. But seeing Kelcie now, flesh and blood, brought everything rushing back.

A different kind of excitement stirred through her—sharp, electric. Like a shark that had just caught the scent of blood in the water.

Agatha turned back to Vidal, their eyes locking, and the atmosphere between them shifted. The smirks and teasing exchanged during the show were gone, replaced by something more charged, something with weight.

The drag show had been the opening act.

But this?

This was the main event.

And the real show was about to begin.

The Tower Reversed

Agatha's eyes studied Vidal, feeling the tension between them shift. This was the moment, the one they’d been building toward all night, and the weight of it settled heavily on her shoulders. The air in the bar seemed to thicken, the background noise fading as she focused on the task ahead.

“Well, this was your plan,” she said slowly, her voice straddling the line between mocking and serious. “So, what’s the grand idea for getting her to talk?”

Vidal’s eyes flicked toward Kelcie Baker, narrowing slightly as she watched her sip her drink, seemingly oblivious to the fact that she was being hunted. Then, Vidal turned back to Agatha, her expression unreadable, the usual playful glint replaced with something more calculating.

“She might recognize you,” Vidal said quietly, her voice steady, betraying none of the nerves that Agatha expected. “Let me handle it.”

Agatha’s immediate reaction was visceral. A surge of discomfort hit her chest like a punch, and she stiffened.

“No,” she said sharply, the absurdity of that idea having her nearly bite Vidal’s head off. “Have you ever even questioned someone before?”

Vidal merely shrugged, calm as ever— and gods Agatha both hated and respected Vidal’s ability to deal with her.

“No,” she answered truthfully, but looked Agatha in the eye when she spoke next. “But this isn’t a deposition,” she replied, the edge of a smirk pulling at her lips. “It’s a conversation. Between two lesbians at a bar.”

Lesbian.

The word hit Agatha with a strange, unexpected force. The simplicity of it, the way Vidal just said it— like it was nothing . But it wasn’t nothing, not to Agatha. It rang in her head, making her feel unsettled in a way she hated to admit. Her jaw tightened as she tore her gaze away, pretending that the word didn’t rattle her.

Vidal leaned forward, her voice softer now, more controlled—calculated.

“Look,” she said, drawing Agatha's gaze back to her, “Kelcie’s not going to open up if she feels cornered. She’s here to relax, maybe let her guard down. She’s not expecting to be interrogated. Let me talk to her. We need her to trust us.”

Agatha’s eyes flicked back to Kelcie, who was still oblivious, chatting with a group of friends at the bar. It was true —Agatha’s presence would be too much. There was a chance that she didn’t know who Agatha was, but if she did— if she did know she was the lawyer currently

representing Brooke Sinclair and trying to bring down the company she worked for, well then there was no way she was going to talk.

She hated it.

Hated this.

The thought of letting Vidal take control gnawed at Agatha, a constant, bitter tug-of-war between the logic that insisted she let go and the fierce instinct to keep her grip on everything. The tension in her chest tightened as she stared at Vidal, trying to force herself to consider it, but her body seemed to revolt at the very idea.

“ I don’t like it ,” she snapped, the words sharper than she’d intended, her voice laced with the frustration she’d been barely holding back.

Vidal, unsurprisingly , didn’t flinch.

She never did.

Instead, she just watched Agatha, her gaze steady, as if peeling back layers and seeing straight into the heart of her. She tilted her head slightly, a habit that told Agatha she was sizing her up, finding something buried there. And then, as if satisfied, Vidal leaned back in her chair, adopting that maddeningly laid-back posture that made Agatha want to kick the chair right out from under her.

“You don’t have to like it,” Vidal said, her voice smooth and calm, each word measured but unshakable. Her eyes held a glint, flashing in the strobe lights from the dance floor—a barely veiled challenge that was impossible to ignore. “ But you do have to let me do it .”

Agatha’s teeth ground together.

Gods—she was right.

Agatha knew it, but knowing didn’t make the bitter pill any easier to swallow.

“ Fine ,” she ground out, the word barely escaping before she felt every instinct in her body revolt. The surrender tasted sour, her control clawing its way back up her throat, fighting to snatch the words from the air and drag them back, keep them safely under her grasp. But it was too late; the words had already slipped, and Vidal was already moving to stand.

Desperate to reclaim some sense of authority, she shot out a warning. “If you mess this up—”

But Vidal, halfway to her feet, moved with an infuriatingly easy confidence, a grace that seemed to mock Agatha’s attempt to hold onto any last shreds of control. Her calm was maddening, her stride steady as if she had owned this outcome from the start. And just as Agatha forced out the rest of her warning, Vidal stopped beside her, then bent down, close enough that her breath was a whisper against Agatha’s ear, her voice soft, teasing, and maddeningly calm.

“I got this, boss.”

The words were a soft taunt, and they sent a jolt down Agatha’s spine.

For just a split second, she was frozen, her pulse spiking in response. Vidal’s breath lingered too close to her skin, and Agatha hated how much it got to her. And then with a smirk that Agatha didn’t need to see to feel, Vidal pulled away and walked off, moving toward Kelcie like she owned the moment.

Agatha’s eyes narrowed, watching with a mixture of irritation and curiosity. Vidal had swagger, sure , but this was where it mattered—where her confidence would either pay off or crumble. Agatha leaned back in her chair, eyes fixed on the scene, watching because that was the only thing she could do.

Kelcie stood in a crowded part of the bar, people pressed shoulder to shoulder. Vidal moved smoothly through the throng, slipping between bodies with ease. And then, as if by accident, Agatha watched as Vidal fumbled with her phone, letting it dangle carelessly by her side. Just as she passed Kelcie, the phone “ slipped ” from her hand, landing right on Kelcie’s foot.

Kelcie startled, bending down to grab the phone, and Agatha could already see it—the bait had been taken. Vidal kept walking, seemingly unaware, until Kelcie called after her, holding out the phone.

The look of innocent surprise that crossed Vidal’s face was pure gold.

Agatha almost smirked.

It was a clever move, a casual icebreaker that didn’t reek of manipulation— at least not on the surface .

Nice move, Agatha thought, grudgingly impressed as Vidal turned back, flashing easy charm and a practiced smile as she accepted the phone from Kelcie. But this was where it counted— whether Vidal could really deliver. Agatha’s eyes narrowed as she leaned forward, watching intently.

Twenty minutes later, Agatha wasn’t sure if she hated the game or hated that Vidal was winning it.

It was obvious —Vidal knew exactly what she was doing. Kelcie was engaged, smiling, laughing— hell , was she blushing?

What in God’s name had Vidal said to her to get her blushing life like that?

Agatha wasn’t sure if she wanted to know or if it would just piss her off more.

Why did this bother her so much?

Vidal was doing her job—getting Kelcie to open up, to talk.

She was doing exactly what she had promised, but it gnawed at Agatha in a way she couldn’t fully explain. Kelcie wasn’t just talking; she was hanging on Vidal’s every word. Laughing at every joke. Smiling at every teasing remark.

Then Vidal laughed.

The sound, bright and carefree, sliced through the noise of the bar like a knife, catching Agatha off guard. And for the first time, Vidal’s smile wasn’t a smirk, wasn’t teasing or predatory—it was genuine, soft, and... beautiful .

Agatha’s chest tightened, the realization hitting harder than she liked.

Vidal reached out, still laughing, and her hand brushed Kelcie’s arm, fingers lingering just a moment longer than necessary. The movement was subtle, but it was impossible to miss.

Agatha’s jaw clenched as she remembered how those same fingers had felt on her hand when the exchanged reports, or when they curled into her shoulder. The thought caused an uncomfortable twist in her stomach, and as if she was reacting to the unknown emotion that curled inside her, she shoved herself up from her chair, nearly knocking it over in the process. The sharp sound of wood scraping against the floor barely registered as she turned on her heel and walked away.

She needed a fucking drink.

Agatha marched to the bar and found an open seat, settling into it with more force than necessary. She still made sure she chose a spot at the bar, that she could still see them— Vidal and Kelcie . Their heads pressed together now, speaking in low, intimate voices as if the rest of the bar didn’t exist, and she gritted her teeth and looked away.

It was then she caught the eye of the bartender— Max , who raised a brow in surprise at her presence back at the bar.

Agatha didn’t wait for her to approach. She just held up two fingers, her expression flat. Max, thankfully understood and gave a nod and, this time, grabbed the bottle bringing it straight over to her. She placed the two glasses in front of Agatha and started pouring.

The moment the first glass was poured, Agatha snatched it and downed nearly all of it in one go, wincing as the burn hit her throat, but welcoming the familiar buzz that followed.

She glanced back at Vidal and Kelcie. Her stomach twisted in a way she didn’t want to acknowledge as she watched them huddle even closer, Vidal smiling while Kelcie animatedly waved her hands, clearly caught up in whatever they were discussing.

“She does that,” came a voice, breaking Agatha out of her reverie. She turned to see Max pushing the second drink towards her.

“What?” Agatha snapped, turning to see Max, hands raised in a mock surrender that practically screamed, Don’t shoot the messenger.

Max met her gaze calmly, then nodded toward Vidal and Kelcie with a tilt of her head.

“ Rio ,” Max clarified, leaning easily against the bar. “She’s got a knack for pulling you in, then leaving you high and dry. I swear, the number of tears women have cried over Rio Vidal could mop this whole floor clean.”

Agatha’s eyes widened, surprise flickering across her face. Her knowledge of Vidal barely extended beyond their work relationship—she was sharp, devilishly smart, and had that infuriating confidence that both fascinated and grated on her. But this —this was new territory.

Personal .

And the thought of piecing together the fragments of who Vidal was beyond the office sent a thrill down her spine. The idea of knowing her better, even understanding her... it was as both exhilarating and as it was dangerous.

“Really? So, what—she’s a player?” Agatha’s voiced curiously, but it was still edged with more bitterness than she’d intended.

Max shrugged, a knowing glint in her eye.

“I wouldn’t say a player, exactly. She’s just allergic to commitment. Doesn’t hurt them intentionally. She sets her rules upfront. But women fall for her anyway.”

Agatha’s grip on the glass tightened, the warmth of the bourbon doing nothing to settle the growing frustration in her chest. She threw back the rest of her drink, savoring the brief burn in her throat, hoping it would numb whatever gnawed at her insides.

“Well, you don’t have to worry about that with me,” she said, the words clipped, sharp—an attempt to shut down the conversation before it could veer into even more dangerous territory.

Max raised an eyebrow, leaning in just a fraction closer, the teasing smile never leaving her lips.

“You sure about that?”

Agatha’s glare was ice-cold .

“Yes. We’re colleagues. That’s it .”

Max chuckled, not at all phased.

“Hmm... so, does that mean you’re single, then?”

Agatha set the empty glass down with a bit more force than intended, the sound loud against the polished wood of the bar and reached for the second one. This woman was tenacious she would give her that, but surprisingly she wasn’t in the mood for games, and she glared at her.

“Don’t you have a job to do?”

Max shrugged unphased, still grinning.

“I haven’t taken my 20-minute break yet.”

Agatha blinked, caught off guard by the smoothness of the response.

“Just like that?”

“Just like that," answered Max said, her tone dancing with a hint of playfulness, eyes bright with amusement.

Agatha took a slow breath, her mind working through the strange sensations going at war within her, and hated that her thoughts immediately darted to Vidal—the very reason she was even in this god-forsaken place and feeling whatever these feelings were .

And to her surprise, Vidal’s gaze was already on her, dark and narrowed, the playful look she’d worn moments ago replaced with something fierce and smoldering. Her jaw was set tight, and Agatha swore she could feel the heat of her gaze even across the room. Then, almost like a flash of lightning, Vidal’s eyes flickered to Max, a spark of something unmistakable and raw.

But in a blink, it was gone, as Vidal was forced to engage with Kelcie again.

Well, that was interesting.

The uncomfortable, roiling feeling that had been knotting her chest like sour milk in the sun suddenly shifted, morphing into something she knew well.

Excitement —a thrill, the anticipation of a game worth playing.

She turned back to Max, letting a sly smirk pull at her lips.

“You know what? You do look tired,” she murmured, her voice low.

Max raised an eyebrow at the shift in her body language and tone, clearly intrigued.

"Do I?" Max echoed, a hint of challenge in her eyes.

“Mmhmm.” Agatha patted the empty seat beside her, her smile widening. “You should sit. Take a break .”

Max chuckled, pausing just long enough to give Agatha a playful look before shrugging, a silent, Alright, let’s play. She called over her shoulder to announce her break, then turned to walk around the bar, moving slowly enough to give Agatha time to steal one more glance at Vidal.

Vidal’s eyes were still on her, intense and unyielding, her posture rigid. A thrill pulsed through Agatha; she smirked, letting the smirk morph into something that felt like a dare. She held Vidal’s gaze, savoring the tension, practically daring her to look away first. But just then, Max slipped into the chair beside her, and Agatha was pulled back, forcing herself to look away.

Around them, the bar pulsed with energy: laughter, clinking glasses, the distant beat of music. But Agatha’s focus tightened, split between Max’s relaxed smile in front of her and the slow-

burn heat she could feel from Vidal’s gaze, burning over Max’s shoulder like a low flame.

Max had been talking to her for ten minutes now, but Agatha could barely recall a word. Max — poor woman —was just a pawn in this chess game between her and Vidal. And Agatha was the queen, every move calculated, manipulating the board with a familiar, addictive rhythm— like closing a case, like the precise path to victory.

All she had to do was topple Vidal, and she would win.

As Max leaned in to speak again, Agatha’s eyes drifted back to Vidal.

Arms crossed, Vidal stood beside Kelcie, who was still chattering away, unaware. But Vidal’s gaze flicked back to Agatha, her dark eyes razor-focused, holding Agatha’s stare like a challenge.

This suddenly, didn’t feel like a game anymore.

It was a charged, tenuous line straining to hold, and Agatha’s pulse thrummed at the thought of it finally snapping. She felt the thrill of risk, a spark of defiance, and decided to push it further.

She turned to Max, leaning in close, her hand lingering on the bartender’s arm as she traced a fingertip along a tattoo winding around her shoulder and down her arm.

“Tell me about this one,” she asked, her tone laced with interest.

Max’s eyes brightened, launching into the story behind the ink, her excitement evident. Agatha nodded along, smiling, but her gaze kept darting over Max’s shoulder, searching for Vidal. When she finally looked up again, there she was—watching her with an intensity that made her heart jump.

Agatha’s defiant streak flared. She didn’t pull her hand from Max’s arm; instead, she leaned in closer, her fingers tracing another tattoo thoughtfully as she murmured.

“And this one?”

Her hand practically caressed Max’s arm, her smile edged with challenge.

Her fingers trailed down Max’s arm, lingering just enough to toe the line between playful and intentional, her smile edged with challenge. Max launched into another story, her enthusiasm bright and infectious, and Agatha feigned a laugh, all the while savoring the quiet thrill of Vidal’s gaze, the awareness that her actions were stirring something in her. She glanced up, craving Vidal’s reaction, eager to see what she’d make of her lingering touches on Max.

But Vidal was gone.

In her place stood Kelcie, grinning goofily as she chatted with her friends. Agatha’s stomach twisted slightly at the sight. Where had Vidal gone? She scanned the room, eyes sharp and searching, feeling a pang of disappointment she couldn’t quite place. Just as she was about to

give up, a familiar hand landed on her shoulder, firm, fingers curling just enough to command her attention.

She nearly jumped.

Nearly.

Agatha forced herself to turn slowly, drawing out the moment with a lazy, practiced ease. She looked up with mock surprise, her tone dripping with feigned innocence.

"Oh... hi," she drawled, letting the words linger in the air as her gaze met Vidal’s, who stood far too close, her expression unreadable but intense.

Vidal’s eyes narrowed, and Agatha fought to keep her face neutral, holding back the gleeful smirk threatening to break free. She had gotten under Vidal’s skin, and that knowledge sparked something wild and undeniable in her.

“You ready to go?” Vidal’s voice was low, rough, and it sent a shiver down Agatha’s spine that she did her best to ignore.

But Agatha wasn't done playing.

She was having too much fun.

“Hmm... no, actually,” she said, her own smirk defiant. "Max and I were just getting acquainted.” Her fingers lingered on Max’s arm, her touch almost a dare.

Vidal’s gaze flicked to Max, then returned to Agatha, unreadable and steady, like a storm waiting to break. Her words came out measured, each one laced with tension.

“I think you should cash out.”

Agatha tilted her head, feeling the heat flare between them, igniting something fierce and familiar in her chest.

Agatha Harkness didn’t take orders—especially not from a first-year associate. Not in her professional life, not in her personal life, and certainly not here.

She raised a brow, her voice measured and dangerous.

“You know, what? I’ll take that as a suggestion,” she said slowly, each word a deliberate warning. “Because the only other option for what that was is a line you definitely don’t want to cross with me—”

“Agatha— Cash. Out .”

Her breath hitched.

Oh.

The way Vidal said her name was something she hadn’t expected—something she certainly didn’t expect to be so... intoxicating. Agatha was used to hearing her name in every tone: curt, reverent, exasperated—but never like this. Vidal had wrapped herself around the syllables, dragging the her name over hot coals, leaving it smoldering in the air between them.

And it wasn’t just her name that unraveled her. She should be furious— livid, even —that Vidal dared to think she could give her an order.

But the truth?

The truth clawed its way into her chest with brutal clarity: she wasn’t angry at all.

The realization felt like a punch to the gut.

Her control—the one thing she relied on, the one constant she clung to—was slipping from her grasp.

And what was more unsettling?

She didn’t want a choice in this, not right now.

Not with Rio Vidal.

Vidal’s gaze lingered, sharp and searching, before she leaned in close, her voice brushing against Agatha’s ear in that same low, gravelly tone that seemed designed to unravel her.

“I’ll be outside waiting.”

With one last look, a brief flicker toward Max, Vidal turned and walked away, cutting through the crowd with a confidence that didn’t need to look back.

Agatha’s heart pounded louder than the bass reverberating from the speakers, each beat unsettlingly out of rhythm. She watched Vidal disappear into the though the door, her pulse drumming with an intensity she hadn’t felt in— ever ?

A touch grazed her knee, jolting Agatha out of her thoughts. She blinked, clearing the haze as she realized Max was still there, watching her intently.

“Where were we?” Max’s voice was suggestive, her gaze soft, inviting.

Agatha’s eyes drifted to the door where Vidal had disappeared, her chest tightening with a nameless urgency, a fire that crawled up her spine, insistent and consuming.

“Cash me out,” she said, her voice sounding foreign even to herself, shaky and unstable.

Max’s brow furrowed, the confusion clear.

“What?”

Fully turning to her now, Agatha’s gaze locked onto Max’s, the urgency driving her words before she could second-guess herself.

“ Cash me out ,” she repeated, the sharp edge unmistakable, as she moved her knee out of Max’s reach.

“You’re... not serious?” Max’s eyes widened, disbelief flickering across her face.

Agatha leaned in, her breath mingling with the scent of bourbon, fingers gripping the edge of the bar as if anchoring herself to something solid. Her voice dropped, slow and deliberate, every word carrying weight like a stone sinking into deep water.

"You don’t know me very well, but you’re about to if I have to repeat myself again ."

Max’s face shifted, the playful glint fading as Agatha’s words hung heavy in the air. She hesitated for just a heartbeat, taking in the weight of Agatha’s gaze before she nodded, all pretense gone.

The unspoken message was clear: the game was over .

As Max turned away to retrieve the check, Agatha’s attention drifted to the door where Vidal had vanished, her chest tightening with an unfamiliar mix of anticipation and tension. The echo of Vidal’s command lingered in her mind like an electric hum, impossible to ignore, sparking something deep inside her that she didn’t even know was there.

Left alone, minutes dragged on, each second winding her thoughts tighter.

Why did Vidal’s words still pulse in her head, stirring something restless, something almost primal?

When Max finally returned, Agatha didn’t bother looking at the bill, simply scribbling her signature on the slip with a practiced flick of the wrist, sliding it back across the bar without a second thought.

“I thought we had something there,” Max’s voice broke through, a teasing edge still lingering in her tone, though it was laced now with something more—curiosity, maybe, disappointment.

Agatha’s eyes flicked up, cool and sharp, the heat she felt inside hidden under layers of practiced indifference.

“I’m straight,” she said, the words biting, dismissive.

Max snorted at that, a soft, knowing sound as she slid the card back across the bar with a smirk tugging at her lips.

“Sure, you are,” she muttered, a hint of amusement curling in her voice.

Agatha didn’t respond, she simply picked up her card and turned toward the door. The truth settled heavily in her chest, lingering with each step as she left behind the bar and Max’s

knowing smirk. The bourbon hummed in her veins, but it was the thought of Vidal waiting outside that ignited something deeper, hotter —something she wasn’t ready to face.

But Agatha Harkness didn’t run. Not from anyone, and certainly not from herself.

And All That's Bad is Good

Chapter Notes

I am going to be gone all day tomorrow for my birthday, so no new chapter will come out. To make up for it, here is a double drop. See you Sunday!

Agatha stepped out into the night, letting the crisp air wash over her heated skin. She could chalk up her flushed cheeks to the packed bar and the overwhelming warmth of bodies pressed close—it was definitely not because of Vidal’s voice rumbling against her ear. She inhaled deeply, letting the coldness settle in her lungs, grounding herself as best she could.

Once she felt decently steady, she scanned the street for Vidal, frowning when she didn’t see her. Groups of people lingered nearby, smoking or waiting for Ubers, but Vidal was nowhere in sight.

Did she ditch me?

The thought set her blood boiling again. But then, movement caught her eye further down the street, a familiar silhouette slipping into an alley beside the bar.

It was unmistakably Vidal.

Agatha stiffened, her frustration flaring anew.
