She wasn’t one to follow people, especially not first-year associates who had practically dragged her to a gay bar and then had the nerve to order her to cash out. Her cheeks burned hotter, and her irritation grew with every passing second. This wasn’t just a game anymore; it was something far messier—and it was starting to piss her off.

She marched forward, heels clicking sharply, each step feeling like a blow against the concrete.

Rounding the corner quickly, she stopped short as Vidal stepped out of the shadows, blocking her path with an unreadable expression.

“ Jesus ,” Agatha hissed, pulse quickening as she took a half-step back. “Are you trying to give me a heart attack?”

Vidal’s gaze didn’t waver, her calm composure only intensifying with the simmering tension in the air. The silence stretched, heavy—tangible, and finally, Vidal broke it, her voice dark and gravelly.

“You want to tell me what that was about?”

Her tone was a deliberate, low rumble that seemed to settle under Agatha’s skin, leaving a trail of goosebumps in its wake. And the question? It wasn’t just a demand—it was a challenge, one that had Agatha’s temper sparking to life.

Who did Vidal think she was to question her?

Agatha crossed her arms, meeting Vidal’s unyielding stare with a raised chin.

“What was what?” She asked feigning ignorance as she kept her voice steady, steel masking the heat curling beneath her ribs, twisting her insides into something taut and unfamiliar.

Vidal’s gaze narrowed.

“Don’t play dumb. It doesn’t suit a woman of your intelligence or skill.”

The barb nestled itself perfectly within the compliment, and Agatha clenched her jaw, refusing to let it unsettle her.

“I saw you having fun, so I thought I’d do the same. What’s wrong with a little fun?”

Her words were sharp, each syllable landing like a perfectly calculated move in a game she was still figuring out.

“ Fun ?” Vidal repeated, the corner of her mouth curving into a frown. “I was working. What you were doing... that didn’t look like work.”

She took a step closer, her eyes never leaving Agatha’s.

“I thought you were straight?”

Agatha fought against the urge to step back as Vidal closed the distance. She gritted her teeth at even the urge of retreat.

What was happening to her?

“I am straight,” she shot back, the retort too quick, too defensive, betraying the turmoil beneath her icy exterior.

Vidal’s smirk deepened, her expression bordering on predatory.

“You sure about that?”

Agatha’s pulse jumped, the steady beat accelerating as something flared within her—a mix of anger, defiance, and an unsettling desire, that had her fingers twitching at her side.

“Don’t,” she hissed, the word slipping out before she could leash it. She tried to hold onto her composure, but her gaze drifted, caught on Vidal’s infuriatingly calm expression, her steady proximity. “I was bored. So, I played. End of story .”

Vidal cocked an eyebrow, watching her with a maddening hint of amusement that set Agatha’s teeth on edge.

“If that’s what you want to call it.”

“We are not calling it anything,” Agatha snapped, her voice tight, cheeks flushed as the game slipped further from her control with each exchange. “It was exactly what it was.”

Vidal held her gaze, her head tilting in that maddeningly calm way, eyes scanning Agatha as if she could see past every guarded layer, straight to the parts of her that Agatha kept buried deep, out of reach. Agatha’s pulse spiked, an urge rising to step forward, to straighten Vidal’s head herself, to demand that she stop looking at her like that—like she saw straight through her.

For a charged moment, Vidal’s gaze lingered, and then, in a subtle motion that left Agatha both frustrated and relieved, she took a small step back.

“Okay.”

Vidal’s tone was disarmingly smooth, as if she was completely immune to the tension winding around them, binding tighter.

Agatha didn’t like that. It felt too easy, like Vidal was just giving her a pass.

“Don’t say it like that.”

Vidal’s gaze didn’t waver, her voice maddeningly calm and controlled, like she was merely humoring Agatha’s irritation.

“Like what?”

“Like you don’t believe me,” Agatha’s voice was sharp, her stare intense as she tried to read something— anything —on Vidal’s infuriatingly neutral face.

Vidal shrugged, her eyes never leaving Agatha’s, and her lips curled into the slightest smirk —a subtle movement that somehow sent a wave of uncomfortable heat through Agatha’s body.

She felt as though Vidal had taken control of the very air around her, wrapping her in a web of unspoken challenges and easy confidence that left her unsettled.

She couldn’t let Vidal have this kind of power over her.

No, she needed to level the playing field.

Instincts took over, as she she took a step towards Vidal, and leaned in.

She wasn’t blind —Vidal hadn’t liked her flirting with Max, even if it had been just a game.

But Vidal didn’t even blink at the question. Instead, something dark and thrilling sparked in her eyes as she held Agatha’s gaze, her lips curving into the slightest of smiles.

"So, you admit you were flirting with a woman?" Vidal’s voice was calm, but her words held a weight that made Agatha’s pulse quicken.

Agatha scoffed, masking the flicker of vulnerability with a dismissive shrug.

“For fun,” she corrected, her voice laced with defiance.

Vidal chuckled quietly, a low, easy sound that made something twist deep in Agatha’s chest. But then she went silent, her gaze locked onto Agatha’s as she stepped forward, closer than before. The air between them thickened, charged with an energy that was impossible to ignore.

“Yes,” Vidal said, her voice a murmur that seemed to echo in the tight space between them.

Agatha blinked, taken off guard as the full meaning of that single word sank in. Her brain scrambled to catch up, and when it did, she felt the steady rhythm of her control start to crack. She swallowed, feeling exposed under Vidal’s unflinching gaze.

“Wait... are you saying—?”

“That I didn’t like seeing you flirt with someone else? Yes. I did not like it. ”

Vidal’s tone was firm, like she was stating a simple fact, yet there was an intensity behind her words that turned the air between them into something almost electric.

Agatha’s lips parted, her breath hitching as she searched Vidal’s face, hunting for any sign of hesitation.

“Why?” she finally asked, her voice barely more than a whisper.

Vidal’s gaze softened, her tone gentle, coaxing.

“Why do you think?”

Silence stretched between them, thick and charged, the unspoken tension simmering to the surface, leaving Agatha exposed with nowhere to hide. It pressed on her, both thrilling and unnerving, daring her to acknowledge it.

She took a breath, her voice barely a whisper as she finally spoke, making the thing between them real, forcing Vidal to own it.

“You’re attracted to me.”

The words hung in the air, weighty, undeniable, a challenge as much as a confession. Agatha’s gaze held steady, her pulse quickening as she watched Vidal’s reaction, waiting for her to either retreat.

But Vidal didn’t retreat. She simply met Agatha’s gaze, eyes dark and unwavering.

“Yes.”

Agatha drew in a deep breath, struggling to regain her footing.

“Just like that?” she asked, her voice tinged with disbelief. She’d never met anyone like Rio Vidal before—someone who could answer something so intimate with such calm certainty, without hesitation or shame.

Who in the world was this woman?

How did she have the nerve to be so direct?

There was a flicker of something in Vidal’s gaze, an intensity that sent another shiver down Agatha’s spine.

“Just like that,” Vidal repeated, her voice unwavering, her eyes locked onto Agatha’s with a confidence that bordered on audacious. The openness in her gaze was almost unsettling, like she didn’t just want Agatha’s attention but demanded it, meeting her defenses head-on without blinking.

Agatha’s heart thudded painfully as she tried to process what was unfolding. Vidal was unlike anyone she’d ever met—an impossible mix of audacity and restraint, honesty and mystery.

And the worst part?

Agatha wasn’t sure she wanted to stop her.

“Don’t worry.” Vidal’s tone was maddeningly calm, placating even as she broke the silence. “I can keep my personal and professional lives separate.”

Now that, had a disbelieving laugh escaped Agatha, sharp and defensive.

“Are you kidding me?” she hissed, a surge of frustration slipping through the cracks in her control. “You’ve been pushing me for days— on purpose .”

Vidal’s brow lifted, her gaze sharpening in that infuriatingly self-assured way.

“Noticed that, did you?” Her voice softened, as if she’d hit a nerve. “Interesting.”

Agatha’s teeth clenched, every word from Vidal stoking her anger, igniting something more volatile beneath the surface.

“And what, exactly, do you find so interesting?” she shot back, her voice colder than the air outside.

Vidal didn’t flinch. Instead, her gaze held steady, a flicker of amusement in her eyes that only pushed Agatha further.

“That you noticed,” she replied, voice smooth, dangerously controlled. “And didn’t tell me to stop.”

A flare of indignation surged through Agatha.

“Yeah, well—I’m telling you to stop now,” she snapped, the words out before she could rein them in.

A tense silence settled between them, the air thickening as Vidal simply held her gaze, before nodding.

“Okay,” Vidal replied, her voice maddeningly calm, each syllable like a weight pressing on the already charged silence between them. The single word hung in the air, taunting Agatha, daring her to respond, to push back, to confront it.

Agatha’s chest tightened, her frustration mounting at the ease with which Vidal had agreed.

She wanted more—a reaction, a challenge, something to justify the roiling tension that churned inside her. She felt her pulse spike, a fierce thrum beneath her skin that defied her usual control.

“That’s it?” she demanded,

Vidal’s gaze didn’t waver, but her lips twitched into a knowing, almost dangerous smile.

“You sound... disappointed .”

A quick, defensive laugh slipped from Agatha’s lips, her bravado slipping as she searched for words that eluded her.

“Me? No. It’s just...” But the sentence trailed off, as if the rest of it was lost somewhere she couldn’t quite voice without saying too much, without exposing herself.

Vidal took a single step forward, closing the space between them their bodies nearly touching now. Her gaze steady and piercing, their bodies may not have been touching, but every inch of her presence focused on Agatha.

“What do you want, Agatha?”

The question cut through the air, landing like a challenge wrapped in silk. It drew Agatha forward and pushed her back all at once, her heart pounding, her breath shallow.

“What?” Her voice wavered, more vulnerable than she’d intended.

“ What do you want?” Vidal’s repeated, her eyes stayed sharp, not giving Agatha a moment’s respite. “Do you want me to stop?”

Agatha’s throat tightened as Vidal’s words wrapped around her, pulling her in, tempting her to reach out and grip something she didn’t fully understand.

“Or—” Vidal continued, her voice low and deliberate, “—do you want me to continue?”

The word settled over Agatha.

“Continue?” she echoed, momentarily off-balance.

Vidal’s eyes flashed.

“Flirting with you,” Vidal murmured, her voice a low, teasing drawl. Her gaze held a challenge that twisted the air between them. “ Pushing you .”

Agatha straightened at that—not liking that one bit, as she lifted her chin defiantly.

“I don’t like to be pushed.”

A glimmer of amusement danced in Vidal’s eyes as she took Agatha in, her gaze slow and deliberate.

“I think you do.”

Agatha’s heart stuttered, her voice coming out sharper than intended, like armor hastily thrown up.

“You don’t know me.”

“No,” Vidal replied, her voice soft, unbothered, like she’d expected the response. “Not everything. But I can read people.” She paused, her eyes lingering on Agatha’s, unrelenting. “And you—you may hate being pushed, but some part of you craves it. ”

Agatha hated the shiver that went down her spine at that, and the way her legs weakened just a little.

“What are you even talking about?”

The words slipped from Agatha’s mouth, sharper than she’d intended, an instinctive defense against the tightening feeling in her chest.

“I’m talking about what I see, Agatha.” Vidal’s tone softened, and a hint of something deeper shimmered in her gaze. “You wear control like armor. Always the strong one. Always in charge. But...” She leaned in, her voice dropping, each word slipping past Agatha’s defenses, “there’s a part of you that’s tired. And maybe... a part that wants to let go, just for once, to let someone else take over, even just for a moment.”

Agatha’s breath hitched, the words striking a chord she hadn’t even realized existed. Her pulse pounded, the heat of Vidal’s proximity making her feel exposed. She fought to keep her voice steady, but it came out ragged, raw.

“Let go... to you?”

Vidal’s answer was immediate, quiet, and unwavering, her gaze locked onto Agatha’s like she’d just laid down a challenge.

“Yes.”

“No,” Agatha shot back immediately, but the conviction she tried to muster slipped, her voice failing to sound as resolute as she wanted.

Vidal stared at her again, and then gave the slightest nod, almost indulgent.

“Okay.”

Agatha was really starting to hate that word and her frustration spiked, mixing with something else she didn’t want to name.

“Stop saying that!” she snapped, feeling the control she so carefully held begin to fray.

Vidal didn’t miss a beat.

“Stop giving you what you want?” Vidal’s voice was soft, mocking, a dark gleam in her eyes. “I thought that’s exactly what you wanted.”

Agatha opened her mouth, ready to snap back, but her words tangled, her pulse racing under the weight of Vidal’s gaze.

“You’re twisting my words,” she finally managed, though the words lacked their usual sharp edge.

“Am I?” Vidal’s eyebrow arched in a quiet challenge. Her voice lowered, rich and unwavering. “Agatha, I know you like it with I flirt with you, and that's okay. It doesn't have to mean anything If you’re worried about me kissing you—or anything else—you don't have to worry.”

Agatha sucked in a sharp breath. Kissing Vidal hadn’t been in her thoughts, not consciously. And yet, now, the idea burned through her mind, impossible to ignore.

“—I won’t kiss you,” Vidal continued, her smirk widening, eyes gleaming. “Not until you ask me to.”

The words hit her like a blow, winding her, her pulse racing in a way that felt foreign and maddening. Her next words slipped out, more breathless than defiant.

“You can’t be serious.”

Vidal’s look was steady, telling her everything.

Agatha stared, something hot and restless swirling inside her. She gritted her teeth, barely holding onto her slipping control.

“I swear, I’ve never met someone I want to strangle more.”

Vidal’s eyes glinted with a dangerous amusement, and she leaned in just close enough to make Agatha’s breath hitch.

“If you ask... I’ll let you.”

Agatha recoiled, a sharp gasp slipping out as she stumbled back a step, as if trying to escape the vivid image that had just seared through her mind. Jesus Christ. The words left her in a ragged whisper, barely controlled, her fingers tingling with the phantom sensation of Vidal’s neck beneath them, her hand curled possessively, commandingly around that smirking face.

She blinked hard, pushing the image away, but her pulse thundered, her mind refusing to let it go. Vidal hadn’t moved, her eyes dark and dangerous, watching Agatha with a satisfaction that was almost predatory. That faint, infuriating smirk played on her lips as though she knew exactly what Agatha had just imagined—and exactly how much it had shaken her.

Agatha forced herself to stand taller, to shake off the fire curling low in her stomach.

“I—” Her voice faltered, betraying her usual composure, and she felt the heat rise to her cheeks. She shot Vidal a glare, her mouth pressed into a tight line, hoping it would somehow mask the turmoil twisting within her.

“Careful, Vidal,” she managed, her voice barely more than a whisper, roughened with an intensity she didn’t want to acknowledge. “You don’t know what you’re asking for.”

Vidal didn’t hesitate.

“I know exactly what I want, Agatha. Can you say the same for you? ”

Agatha’s jaw clenched as Vidal’s words hit her, taunting her in ways she wasn’t prepared to face. Every instinct urged her to brush it off, to laugh in Vidal’s face and walk away without a second thought. But Vidal’s smirk lingered, pushing past her defenses.

Did she know what she wanted?

For so long, it had been so clear—success, power, control. But here she was, battling an unfamiliar ache for something she never thought she wanted.

Her thoughts shattered as Vidal stepped back, her voice cutting through the charged silence.

“It’s getting late. I think I’ll be heading home.”

Agatha blinked, thrown.

“You can’t be serious?”

Vidal cocked her head.

“Would you like to talk more?”

The challenge was clear in Vidal’s eyes, and Agatha gritted her teeth, hating how it forced her closer to a line she wasn’t ready to cross.

“No.”

A spark flickered in Vidal’s gaze, her expression unreadable. She took another step back, her voice dropping to that dangerous murmur.

“Do you want me to kiss you?”

Agatha’s breath hitched. She bit down against the pulse of heat that surged through her, her voice strained.

“No.”

Vidal’s smirk returned, slow and infuriating, as if she knew Agatha’s resistance was hanging by a thread.

“Okay then—in that case, I’m going to go home,” she said, leveling Agatha with a look that stole the breath right from her lungs. “Remember–you just have to ask, Agatha.”

Agatha glared, the denial on her tongue fierce and defensive.

“I won’t ask.”

Vidal’s grin spread knowingly, and Agatha felt the words forming in Vidal’s mouth before she could even speak.

“Don’t you dare say ‘okay,’” she hissed.

Vidal only smiled, her eyes flashing with amusement.

“Goodnight, Agatha.”

And with that, she turned and walked away, leaving Agatha standing there. She watched Vidal’s silhouette fade, her heart racing in a way that defied every carefully constructed wall she’d built around herself. Desperate to regain her footing, she seized the one thing that always grounded her— business .

“Wait—what did you get out of Baker?” she called.

Vidal stopped, glancing back over her shoulder, and a playful, almost sheepish smile tugged at her lips.

“Oh... nothing yet. She clammed up about work.” She paused, a glint of mischief sparking in her gaze. “So I have a coffee date with her tomorrow. I’m going to press harder then.”

“A date ?” Agatha’s voice sharpened, the word twisting uncomfortably in her chest.

Vidal’s grin widened, as if sensing her frustration, and this time, she threw her a wink—a real, genuine smile that sent a strange thrill through Agatha, leaving her breathless.

“See you in the morning, Agatha.”

Agatha stood in the alley, her heartbeat still racing, every instinct screaming at her to chase after Vidal, to demand answers, to regain the control Vidal had so effortlessly taken from her.

The alley fell silent, the distant hum of the city fading into the background, leaving her alone with the quiet realization that everything she thought she understood about herself had shifted —and for the first time in a very long time, Agatha Harkness felt out of control.

I Stray Not From the Path

When Agatha finally crawled into bed, exhaustion tugging at her, sleep wouldn’t come. Every time she closed her eyes, Vidal’s voice echoed, looping through her mind with maddening clarity.

“What do you want, Agatha?”

The question rippled through her, reverberating deeper with each replay.

"Maybe... a part that wants to let go, just for once, to let someone else take over..."

The words haunted her, slipping beneath her defenses, teasing out questions she wasn’t ready to answer, taunting her in the quiet dark.

The idea of letting someone else take control—it was foreign.

Unthinkable.

Agatha was always in command with sexual partners, always the one setting the pace, dictating every step from the first touch to the last breathless moment.

It suited her.

It kept her comfortable.

And the men she’d been with expected it, welcomed it .

She was known for her professional dominance, and the men she was with weren't really surprised when then that same dominance carried into the bedroom.

It was who she was.

Or... was it?

The question snuck up on her, seizing her in a moment of raw, startling clarity.

Was it the control she craved, or what it the easiness that came with keeping her control?

Agatha shifted uncomfortably, feeling the weight of it settle, heavy and intrusive, as her mind raced in ways she couldn’t quiet. The answer loomed before her, unsettling, as she replayed each moment she’d taken the reins, every move she’d calculated to secure her power. But here, in the stark quiet of her bedroom, the control she’d held so fiercely didn’t feel like true strength.

It was like armor—layer upon layer that shielded and insulated her, something she’d never questioned. But, as if it were real armor, it suddenly felt— weighted . And now, for the first time in her life, she could feel the pressure of it, the toll it took.

Could she let it go?

The question stirred something in her chest, unsettling and foreign. She didn’t like the thought at all—it wasn’t who she was. But her mind turned it over, breaking it down like a case, examining it from every angle.

And then a factor surfaced she hadn’t considered before— gender .

Could she surrender to a man?

The thought twisted something deep inside her, but not with any thrill. Instead, it pulled at her with a discomfort that bordered on disgust. The idea of letting a man take charge, to dominate her, felt about as enticing as rubbing one out with sandpaper. She could almost laugh at the absurdity of it—there was no appeal, no thrill, only the stark repulsion that reminded her exactly why she kept men at arm’s length in every sense of the word.

But a woman...

Now, that stirred something different.

Unexpected.

Exciting.

Safe.

The thought, foreign and strangely electrifying, sent a shiver racing down her spine, igniting something deep within her. She couldn’t ignore the way her pulse quickened at the image: a woman, self-assured and confident, taking her by surprise, challenging her in ways that went beyond words. The allure was undeniable, clashing with everything she thought she knew about herself, but it was there, daring her to explore the idea further.

The more she dwelled on it, the more vivid the image became.

Dark hair, dark eyes, that infuriatingly confident smirk... the rasp of a voice that teased, pushed, drew her in.

The woman in her mind had taken on a form she couldn’t deny— Rio Vidal .

Agatha clenched, a gasp catching in her throat.

She suddenly became painfully aware of the heat building inside her, of how her body reacted to the thought of Vidal’s control, her touch, her words coaxing her past every boundary she’d carefully constructed.

The mere idea of Vidal leading her to release, guiding her in ways she’d never allowed... it had Agatha biting her lip, a moan slipping free as her hips moved instinctively. Without thinking, her hand drifted downward, and the instant she touched herself, her breath hitched —she was already drenched, the lightest touch sending a wave of pleasure coursing through her.

A low groan escaped her as her fingers circled slowly, building herself up with deliberate pressure. Her mind filled with vivid flashes of Vidal—her hands curling into Agatha's shoulder, that scent of forest around her, the brush of her lips low against her ear. Each image tightened the coil inside her, and she could almost feel Vidal’s presence, her voice a dark whisper in her ear, coaxing, daring, no doubt murmuring filthy words of encouragements.

The release crashed over her like a tidal wave, her body arching, shuddering, as every nerve lit up with a raw, electrifying intensity. Her fingers moved in tight, rhythmic circles as she rode the high, soft gasps filling the quiet of her room. As the sensation ebbed, her chest heaved with ragged breaths, and she sank back into the bed, basking in the lingering tremors that left her tingling, weightless.

Her wet hand fell to her side, body still pulsing from the aftershocks, and she pressed her other to her forehead, letting out a shaky exhale. She could hardly remember the last time she’d come this hard— if ever .

She’d always known her body, knew the paths to release, yet it still took her time to reach her peak.

But tonight?

Tonight was something else entirely. And she had to face the truth of why.

She was lying here, breathless, legs still weak, utterly undone... all from the thought of Rio fucking Vidal.

Just the fantasy of her—dark eyes, that infuriating smirk, the quiet control in her voice—had sent Agatha spiraling into an intensity she hadn’t even thought herself capable of. The thrill of it left her heart pounding, the dark edges of temptation sinking deep into her chest, making it hard to breathe.

And as she laid there staring up at the ceiling, the weight of it all crashing down on her, pressing heavily against the silence. Her body still hummed from the aftershocks, but her mind began to settle, clarity creeping in with an unsettling force.

“What the hell am I doing?” she whispered, her voice barely more than a breath.

There was no denying it now.

Rio Vidal was a problem.

A big fucking problem.

Agatha’s steps echoed through the quiet hall, the morning air still heavy with the remnants of her restless night. She hadn’t truly slept—Vidal’s words had haunted her like a persistent shadow, trailing her into every crevice of her mind. Every time she tried to find peace, tried to silence her thoughts, she’d found herself back there, in that dark alley, replaying Vidal’s voice, those teasing eyes, that maddening, unyielding confidence.

And when she’d finally drifted off, of course Vidal had invaded her dreams too, each encounter twisting the knife deeper, fueling the inferno she couldn’t seem to escape. Now, walking into the office, the very place where Vidal would be, her nerves were raw, frayed beyond recognition.

She braced herself as she stepped through the main doors, the familiar scent of the flowers in the lobby and coffee doing nothing to steady her. Her fingers twitched, her pulse quickened as memories from the previous night clawed their way back to the surface—the thoughts she’d surrendered to alone in the dark, letting herself unravel to the idea of Vidal’s hands— Vidal’s voice— Vidal .

It had her unmoored, rattled in a way she’d never been before. How the hell was she supposed to look her in the eye today?

Vidal read her like an open book, picking up every detail, every tremor beneath her facade.

Would she notice?

Could she tell that Agatha got herself off last night thinking about her?

Agatha gritted her teeth, feeling her thoughts spiral and hating every second of it. She needed something, anything to cut through the haze of confusion clouding her mind. Just then, a third-year associate came around the corner, his head buried in a report, oblivious to her approach. The moment he nearly collided with her, her restraint snapped.

“Oh, so sorry, was I in your way ?” Her voice dripped with mock sweetness, a sharp smile forming as she watched the him fumble for words. “No, really—why would a senior partner be strolling in her own office? Clearly, you’ve got far more important places to be.”

The poor man looked up, paling as he realized his mistake. Jefferson was actually one of the good ones here. She actually found him decent to work with.

Jefferson to his credit, tried to mumble an apology, but Agatha wasn’t done.

“Let me guess,” she continued, crossing her arms, “you’re going to dazzle us all with your ‘astounding work ethic’ and ‘commitment to excellence’ while you can’t even manage the radical responsibility of watching where you’re walking?” Her voice lilted on every word, wrapping disdain in a faux-polite bow. “Here’s a little free advice: if I can't trust find your way around a hallway, how in the hell am I supposed to trust you to find your way around a courtroom.”

The associate stammered an awkward “Yes, ma’am,” backing away, but she gave him a pointed look, rolling her eyes.

"Oh, spare me the ‘yes, ma’am,’" she bit out, her tone dripping with disdain. "Grow a spine, Jefferson. Develop some self-awareness, and get out of my sight.”

The associate's face paled, and he nodded, practically tripping over himself to escape.

The office descended into an even sharper silence, a tension so thick you could slice it.

Everyone knew the signs.

When Agatha cut down someone she actually respected, it was a clear warning: the rest of them had better watch their step.

She swept through the office, her gaze icy, catching sight of the war room.

It was empty—no sign of Vidal.

Agatha wasn’t sure if that made her feel more relieved or irritated.

She wanted her here.

No, she didn’t.

But yes, she did.

She gritted her teeth as Billy fell into step beside her, briefing her on her day as he handed her coffee.

It was an endless list of meetings, calls, and negotiations, and by the third item, Agatha’s patience was on a knife’s edge. But she let Billy continue, keeping her face impassive as she shrugged off her coat, tossing it his way. He caught it with a deftness she couldn’t help but appreciate, maintaining his steady cadence through her schedule.

She had to give him credit for that, at least; Billy could take it.

Settling into her chair, she took a sip of coffee, a small flick of her hand sending him on his way. Her eyes flicked to the war room again.

Where was Vidal?

She was always punctual, if not early.

A spark of irritation flared. Did she think she could waltz in whenever she pleased?

Apparently, she’d muttered the thought aloud because Billy paused in the doorway, glancing back.

"She called this morning," he said, with a hint of hesitation, "said she had an early interview for the Vanguard case—told me you knew about it."

Agatha’s jaw clenched as she connected the dots, Vidal’s words from last night echoing in her mind:

"I’ve got a coffee date with her tomorrow. I’m going to press harder then."

The twist in her chest tightened, and she couldn’t shake the heat that flared each time she replayed that scene from last night—Vidal’s hand on Baker’s arm, the laugh, the smirk that looked too real.

The idea of Vidal doing it all over again, maybe even getting Baker to open up in ways Agatha couldn’t imagine...

She hissed under her breath, the irritation spiking.

“Get me last quarter’s reports. All of them ,” she snapped, more forcefully than she intended.

Billy, unfazed, nodded and slipped out of her office, giving her the space she needed to wrangle her thoughts back under control.

This had to stop.

She needed to focus, to work.

Clenching her jaw, she grabbed her phone, forcing her attention onto her first client meeting of the day.

Maybe they’d bring a problem big enough to drown out the thoughts of Vidal in a coffee shop with Baker, smiling in that infuriatingly easy way that made her feel—

No .

She stopped the thought in its tracks, and took a deep breath. She dialed the number and resolved to bury herself in work until she couldn’t remember why her hands were still shaking.

Agatha tackled call after call, sinking into the rhythm that kept her mind occupied. One client wanted to put two lawsuits to bed quietly; another was wrangling with an SEC investigation over questionable stock buys. The requests kept coming—urgent, frantic, and complex enough to occupy her mind.

She relished these questions—the “How can I legally get away with this?” that bordered on ludicrous but kept her sharp.

She was mid-sentence, explaining patent law to a client with an overly ambitious vision, when the war room door opened across the hall.

Out of instinct, she turned, and the words stalled on her lips.

Vidal stood in the doorway.

In a dress.

Agatha’s grip tightened on the phone as her gaze swept over Vidal, taking in the elegant, form-fitting forest green dress that clung to her frame. It was simple but devastatingly effective, hugging her in all the right places and ending just above the knee, showing just enough to draw eyes and keep them there. Her dark hair was loose, cascading over her shoulders softening the look even more.

“Uh, Agatha? Are you still there?” her client’s voice crackled through the phone.

Agatha blinked, snapping back to reality, catching herself before the pause could stretch too long.

“Yes,” she managed, forcing her voice into its usual, crisp professionalism, though she felt anything but in control.

As the client rattled on, she made herself turn away, swiveling her chair to face the skyline, gripping the armrests with white-knuckled intensity. She couldn’t turn back around—not yet. The image of Vidal in that dress was seared into her mind, and the low, throbbing tension she’d spent the entire morning trying to shake was now back tenfold.

She finished the call, her responses automatic, as she pushed the phone from her ear and set it down. The city’s hum outside her window was meant to ground her, to refocus her, but it did nothing. The only thought that registered clearly was the sight of Vidal in that dress.

Without giving herself another second to doubt, she stood and made her way to the war room, steps purposeful, as if this were any other meeting, any other case. But the truth was, she wanted to see Vidal up close—wanted to see how the soft fabric of that dress shifted with her movements.

When Agatha entered, Vidal had her back turned, a hand poised against the whiteboard, her marker moving quickly in her barely legible writing. She finished a final note and turned, catching sight of Agatha and grinning. Her dark eyes sparkled with an excitement that made her look even more striking, and it took Agatha a moment to register that she was speaking.

“I was right,” Vidal said, her voice sharp, laced with barely contained excitement as she held the marker. “Kelcie and Brooke were involved. Brooke was closeted, and they’d been seeing each other for six months. Kelcie finally opened up about it over coffee today.”

Vidal’s voice cut through the room, but Agatha’s attention was already split between what she was saying and how god damn good she looked . The fabric hugged her figure in a way that felt both powerful and dangerously close to alluring, outlining her arms with a refined elegance, then skimming down to a subtle slit that flirted just within the bounds of office propriety. The dress’s dark forest green color only heightened the effect, sharpening every curve, every line.

Vidal set the marker aside and took a step forward, her hands moving with an energy that matched the gleam in her eyes.

“Right before Brooke died, she mentioned a cargo report that had accidentally landed on her desk,” Vidal continued. “The ship was called The Meridian Star. Brooke told Kelcie that the items on board couldn’t be tied to any payment or contract records. It set off alarms for her, and she was planning to confront her boss the next day.”

Vidal’s gaze grew darker, her excitement tempered by a new edge.

“That was the last time Kelcie saw Brooke alive.”

The words hung in the air, heavy with gravity, but Agatha’s mind was elsewhere. The silence stretched between them, thick with unspoken tension. Agatha struggled to process what Vidal was saying, her thoughts spiraling chaotically around the implications of the case while simultaneously being drawn back to the sight of Vidal.

Every part of her was on fire, igniting the filthy thoughts that had haunted her since she touched herself last night. It was all muddled together, and for a moment, she felt paralyzed, trapped in this strange whirlwind of desire and duty.

“Agatha?” Vidal’s voice cut through the silence sharply, a hint of impatience in her tone as she caught Agatha’s eye. “Did you hear me?”

The question hit like a splash of cold water, jolting Agatha back to the present.

“Yes,” Agatha replied, her voice steadier than she felt, fighting to bring her attention back to the case details she’d almost missed.

But Vidal was looking at her, not just looking—seeing her, and Agatha could pinpoint the exact second Vidal’s excitement over the case shifted, the spark in her eyes darkening into something sharper. That smirk, knowing and infuriating, curved at Vidal’s lips as she stepped closer.

“You look...” Vidal murmured, her words timed to her slow, deliberate steps. Each syllable stretched, matching the rhythm of her approach, and Agatha’s breath hitched as she realized just how close Vidal was coming. With those nude heels, Vidal was taller than her now, leaning in as if savoring her new height advantage.

“...flushed,” she finished, her gaze dropping just a fraction, her tone a velvet purr laced with a hint of feigned concern.

“Are you feeling okay?” she asked, her question innocent, but her eyes far from it, a glint of knowing amusement flickering there.

Agatha forced herself to stand straighter, but the lingering heat from last night simmered to the surface, traitorous and relentless. Vidal’s presence, so close she could practically feel the warmth radiating from her, made it impossible to shut out the images from her mind. Her response teetered on her tongue, a mix of denial and challenge, but words failed her in the face of Vidal’s unrelenting gaze.

“Yes,” she finally managed, though her voice betrayed her, carrying more breath than defiance. “I’m fine.”

Vidal’s smirk deepened, her gaze unwavering, promising with unspoken certainty that she knew exactly what she was doing—and exactly what it was doing to Agatha.

“Mmm...” Vidal murmured, the low hum sending a shiver through Agatha, as if she could see each crack her presence caused in Agatha’s carefully built armor. Her mouth opened, poised to say something else, no doubt another push, another nudge toward that dangerous edge of control Agatha felt slipping away with each word, each glance.

Panic clawed up her chest, raw and disorienting. The tension, the uncertainty, the fierce pull Vidal had on her—she needed it to stop.

The word escaped before she could catch it, a slip that felt both reckless and vulnerable.

“Stop.”

The words were barely out before regret seized her. She wanted to pull them back, to say something else— anything els e.

But Vidal’s eyes flickered, her expression flashing with shock for a fraction of a second, and then, with a single measured step back, her entire demeanor transformed. The teasing warmth, the playful smirk—all of it vanished, replaced by a chilling neutrality that was almost unsettling in its precision.

Agatha swallowed hard, both irritated and strangely admiring of how effortlessly Vidal could switch it all off. Her face may have been blank, but her eyes—they searched Agatha with a sharp, careful intensity, reading her, moving over her face as if picking up the pieces of something unsaid, something Agatha didn’t quite know how to put into words herself.

And then, just as quickly, something shifted in Vidal’s gaze—a hint of understanding.

She gave a brief nod, acknowledging the unspoken.

Agatha clenched her jaw, frustration simmering under her skin.

She’d let the words slip and now there was no taking them back.

She cursed herself for it, for the way her heart twisted at Vidal’s sudden distance, for the flicker of regret she refused to acknowledge. Saying she wanted it to stop was one thing, a moment of vulnerability she could almost excuse—but admitting she didn’t actually want it to stop?

That was unthinkable.

But the silence between them, Vidal’s carefully unreadable face, felt like a wall. And that was worse. Agatha’s pulse pounded as her mind raced, part of her wanting to reach out and tear down the wall she’d just thrown up between them, to make some kind of move that would prove she hadn’t lost her edge, her control.

Vidal just watched her, waiting, that calm gaze unwavering, her expression blank, the complete opposite of Agatha’s own tangled thoughts. Somehow, that was the hardest part— how easily Vidal respected Agatha's request without hesitation.

Finding her voice, though the words tasted sour as she forced them out, Agatha managed to say, “Comb through everything and find all references to The Meridian Star . Find me something.”

Vidal nodded, the acknowledgment almost too simple, too composed.

Agatha nodded back, feeling the weight of it settle uncomfortably between them. She turned, intent on leaving, desperate to escape the tension in the room. The silence thickened, stretching taut as she reached for the door and yanked it open, ready to step away from whatever held her back, but something stopped her.

She looked back.

Vidal was already bent over a box of documents, already working, her focus sharp and steady, displaying no adverse reaction to Agatha ending the game between them.

It was like she completely let it go.

But Agatha couldn’t let it go.

Something in her needed to say one last thing.

“Rio,” she said, the name slipping from her lips with surprising weight, her voice soft but loaded. It was the first time she’d used her first name, and she could see the impact of it immediately.

Rio’s head snapped up, her eyes meeting Agatha’s, a flash of something unmistakable—want, desire—before it dulled into composure.

Agatha swallowed.

“Good work on this,” she murmured, her words feeling like a bridge stretched across the tension. It wasn’t much—a compliment from her mouth was rare—but it felt insufficient against everything that hung unsaid in the room.

Rio nodded, her voice quiet but warm.

“Thank you.”

Agatha held her gaze for a second longer, feeling the pull of it before she tore herself away, needing the distance more than ever. With a final, silent nod, she turned and walked out, her steps echoing down the hallway, leaving that charged silence— and Rio —behind her.

Circle Sewn With Fate

Agatha stared at the ceiling of her bedroom, her hands folded on her stomach, feeling the weight of her own thoughts pressing down on her. The morning sun filtered in through her bedrooms large glass windows, painting the ceiling in its light.

The silence of the morning felt heavier than usual.

She let out a sigh, frustrated and unwilling to admit how much her current state grated at her.

It had been four days since she’d told Rio to stop.

Four days since she drew the line in the sand between them and said, “don’t cross it.”

And, in true form, Rio had done just that—no smirks, no lingering touches, no flirtatious banter.

It was all professional now.

Impeccably, maddeningly professional .

And it was torture.

The tension that had once buzzed between them had disappeared, replaced by a stark void that left her feeling unbalanced. Their once-charged exchanges now felt lifeless, as if she was speaking into a mirror instead of the spark that had lit her up in ways she’d refused to acknowledge.

Her chest tightened as she thought of the moments when a fleeting smirk or a word laced with hidden meaning would’ve changed her for the entire day.

But now?

There was nothing.

It was like staring at a starry sky covered in thick, impenetrable clouds. The spark was still there, but it was hidden beyond Agatha's reach now.

Agatha clenched her hands into fists, resisting the urge to curse herself for every confused thought she’d wrestled with since Tuesday. She’d made her choice, demanded her boundaries. And yet, she couldn’t shake the dull ache that had settled within her, each day feeling a little greyer, each interaction a little emptier.

Not even the progress Rio had made on the Vanguard case— work that was undeniably impressive —held any real satisfaction for her.

She could hardly focus on the details anymore, too wrapped up in what had been lost between them.

It didn’t help that each night, as she undressed, brushed her teeth, and prepared to sleep, the tension in her body would unfurl in waves, stirring up memories of Rio’s dark, intense gaze, the graze of her hands, the low, gravelly timbre of her voice teasing at the edge of Agatha’s self-control.

She’d clenched her jaw, already knowing where her thoughts would drift, the same way they had every night since the professional distance had settled between them.

And no matter how hard she tried to ignore it, her resolve would eventually falter.

Her mind would helplessly replay the sound of what had once been Rio’s voice, that low, teasing murmur; the flash of her smirk; the feel of her hands, imagined but vivid, lingering like a phantom touch.

Each time, breathless and aching, Agatha would surrender, slipping her hand beneath the band of her silk pants, chasing a release that always came too quickly, leaving her spent and satisfied, yet, still haunted.

Because now, even in the quiet aftermath, Rio never left her mind.

Somehow, the woman had burrowed beneath her skin, her presence lingering long after the warmth of release faded, like an echo she couldn’t silence.

Rio was rooted in her, deep and undeniable, as if each whisper of her memory declared, "I live here now."

Agatha wanted to scream.

She was forty-eight, for Christ’s sake.

She was far too old for a... sexual awakening?

An identity crisis?

A kink revelation?

O r whatever the hell this actually was .

And yet here she was: Nearly fifty, more confused than she’d ever been in her life, so insatiably frustrated, and so ridiculously, impossibly turned on , she quite literally could not think straight.

Rio Vidal, a woman 16 years younger than her , had stepped into Agatha's carefully constructed Jenga-tower of life, circling it like a hawk. With each pass, she probed at Agatha's core pieces, searching for any weakness, any tremor, before methodically slipping them away with chilling precision.

Agatha could feel each absence, a hollow ache expanding within her, revealing emptiness she hadn’t known existed until Rio showed her.

But Rio didn’t just take— she was also rebuilding .

Layering unfamiliar, thrilling pieces onto Agatha’s foundation, forcing her to sway on the edge of everything she thought she understood. Every extracted piece, every newly added layer, left her precarious, teetering in a dizzying balance between fear and exhilaration.

And Rio—she stood there, just watching, never once looking away.

Rio’s held her gaze with an intensity that felt like a dare, inviting Agatha to give in— to fall .

Let me break you, those dark eyes seemed to say, and then I’ll put you back together in a way you never thought possible.

Agatha laid there in the quiet of her bedroom, Rio’s unyielding gaze haunting her mind and let out a long, frustrated sigh and threw back the covers.

It was Saturday.

Nicky wouldn’t be back until after school on Monday, which meant two entire days with nothing but herself—a version she was barely recognizing in the mirror lately. She didn’t want to spend another minute alone in this house, trapped with someone she hardly knew anymore, and the questions that Rio brought out in her followed her around like a ghost she couldn't shake.

So, what did she do?

Simple.

She turned to the one thing that had never let her down. The one place she could bury herself so deeply that her mind would eventually, finally quiet.

Work.

In less than twenty minutes, she was dressed. Her hair pulled back in a messy bun, her makeup softer than usual—a look that still felt polished but relaxed. She slipped into a chunky sweater, designer leggings hugging her figure, heeled boots, and threw on a trench coat, the tailored fabric adding a touch of her usual sharpness, before heading out the door.

Agatha stepped off the elevator, the music loudly blaring between her ears. She had slid her AirPods in the second she left her apartment, drowning herself in a playlist that moved from Lizzo to Noah Kahan, Nicki Minaj to Taylor Swift, and finally, the rich notes of Queen. Each step brought her closer to a quiet morning of burying herself in emails and uncompleted work from Friday, a welcome respite from her relentless thoughts.

So far, the office was blissfully quiet.

Not a single soul.

She could practically feel the relief creeping over her as she neared her office door.

But then she caught movement from the corner of her eye and halted. Her gaze drifted over to the war room, and, as if the universe were playing some kind of twisted joke, Hozier’s Take Me to Church began playing in her ears.

Rio was there, head down reading a report.

Agatha nearly turned right back around, tempted to walk straight out the door, but of course, just as she considered retreating, Rio looked up, their eyes locking through the glass.

Rio’s brows raised, and Agatha could practically feel the current between them intensify.

She watched as Rio’s gaze dipped, taking in her casual outfit with a quick, appreciative look that seemed almost reflexive. But just as quickly, she caught herself, her expression shifting, and forced her eyes back to Agatha’s with a steadier, more professional focus.

Agatha felt the heat of Rio’s gaze like a live current, but she steadied herself, willing her feet to move forward. The urge to stay, to let herself linger in that heavy, charged silence, was almost overwhelming.

But she’d come here to regain her control, not to surrender it .

With a deep breath, she straightened her shoulders, forced a dismissive look, and walked toward her office, each step feeling heavier than the last. She could sense Rio’s gaze trailing after her, but she didn’t look back.

Instead, she strode into her office, shutting the door behind her with a calmness that belied the turmoil roiling inside.

The silence in her office was an immediate relief. She set her purse on the desk, shrugged off her coat, and took a long, steadying breath.

Sitting down at her desk, she logged into her computer, the familiar glow of the screen bringing a sense of purpose.

She could do this —she could bury herself in work and let the hours pass, let herself escape in tasks that required no emotional investment.

In the quiet of her office, she could almost forget that Rio was only a few rooms away.

Almost.

She worked as the sun drifted across the sky and disappeared, leaving an inky darkness pressing against the glass walls of her office. Every email she answered, every report reviewed, every typed-out brief or signed document settled her frayed nerves, calming the tempest inside her piece by piece.

But like a temptation she couldn’t shake, her gaze kept drifting toward the war room, her eyes betraying her.

Rio was still there.

Tenacious, focused, working her way through the boxes that they hadn’t yet combed through. The whiteboard filled with notes and connecting lines, evidence of her relentless mind at work, and each time Agatha glanced up, she was there—opening another box, writing another note, marking down another discovery. She moved with an ease that felt almost hypnotic.

She was wearing black denim pants, a blue button-up with a crisp white T-shirt underneath, and white tennis shoes that looked worn but intentional. Her dark hair framed her face in loose waves, more relaxed than usual, and Agatha didn’t miss the aviators sitting on the table beside her.

The casual look shouldn’t have suited the office, but it worked on her with an effortless elegance, as if Rio owned the space just by being in it.

And as Agatha observed her— more often than she wanted to admit —she felt an odd kinship.

Here they were, two people in outfits that didn’t belong in the office, tethered to this place on day when they should have been anywhere else.

She forced her gaze back to the file folder in front of her, reminding herself with a fierce mental mantra that she was here for one reason: work .

She picked up one of the final file—the last loose end on her desk, her last task to complete before calling it a night. She opened the folder, hoping for a dense report or a legal puzzle, something complex enough to keep her rooted here a bit longer.

But inside, there was only a simple expense report, just awaiting her signature.

No notes, no analysis— just an empty dotted line .

With a reluctant sigh, she signed it and set the folder aside, officially out of things to occupy her mind.

The silence that filled the room felt too final, too pointed, and she wasn’t ready to face the night ahead or the restless thoughts she knew would haunt her the second she walked through her door. She could practically feel the weight of the last four nights pressing on her—the lingering tension and frustration she couldn’t shake.

Clenching her jaw, she stood and crossed to the small liquor bar tucked into the corner of her office. Pouring herself a generous glass of bourbon, she took the bottle back with her to the desk, sinking into her chair and swiveling it to face the city skyline.

It was easier to stare at the glowing lights of the city than risk glancing back toward the war room.

The bourbon was smooth, its warmth spreading through her with each sip as she sat there, staring out into the night, feeling a familiar ache that even the good bourbon couldn’t quite numb.

A sharp knock on glass broke her thoughts.

Agatha turned, her gaze landing on Rio standing by the door, a folder in hand, eyes expectant. Despite the turmoil churning within her, Agatha nodded, her instinct taking over.

Rio stepped inside, crossing the room with an ease that only amplified Agatha’s tension, before setting the folder on her desk. Agatha set down her bourbon, took the file, and opened it, scanning the pages with a practiced eye.

The document inside was a report Rio had been combing through, uncovering details about The Meridian Star , the cargo ship that Brooke had mentioned to her girlfriend.

As she read, her fingers tightened around the paper. The report detailed anomalies in the shipping manifest—items listed under ambiguous codes, weights that didn’t align with standard cargo, and no matching invoice or record to account for the items. There was also an unusual frequency of dockings along the Eastern Seaboard, the locations changing each time, almost like someone was intentionally making the ship’s path difficult to track.

Each page revealed more discrepancies, the pieces stacking up into something much bigger, something deliberate .

Agatha closed the folder and set it on her desk, nodding as she drummed her fingers lightly on its cover.

"This is good work," she murmured, her gaze fixed downward on the file, refusing to betray the storm brewing beneath her calm exterior.

They weren’t at the finish line yet, but they were closer than ever before.

And she knew the difference— it was Rio .

She was relentless, methodical, always pushing.

“There’s got to be more,” Rio said, her voice low and steady, a hint of resolve that echoed through the silence. “I’ll keep pulling the string.”

Agatha nodded again, her fingers still tapping the folder, grounding herself. She didn’t look up, couldn’t meet those eyes that no longer looked at her with that spark.

The silence between them was thick, teetering between familiar and unsettling.

"Goodnight, Agatha."

It was a simple farewell, delivered without warmth or edge.

Flat.

Detached.

But for reasons Agatha couldn’t begin to untangle, those words burrowed deeper inside her than any smirk, taunt, or glance Rio had ever given her.

The neutrality of it twisted within her, winding tighter and tighter, until it felt like something inside her snapped.

"Wait."

Agatha’s voice cut through the quiet, and she looked up and watched as her words landed.

Rio stopped, turning back, her expression blank, unreadable, as if she were just... waiting.

Waiting, watching with that calm detachment that felt like an insult.

Agatha’s jaw clenched.

She hated that look.

Hated the emptiness in it.

Hated the way Rio could stand there as if she hadn’t the very person who dismantled everything Agatha thought she knew about herself, forcing her onto this twisting, relentless journey of self-discovery with no end in sight.

How could she just step back now, as if she hadn’t taken a hammer to Agatha’s sense of self?

Just walk away?

That simmering anger rose, propelling her next words.

“ Stop looking at me like that ,” she snapped, her voice laced with an intensity she could barely contain.

Rio didn’t so much as blink, her composure as steady as ever.

“I don’t understand,” she said, her voice maddeningly calm. “Did I do something to offend you?”

Agatha’s fingers tightened around the edge of her desk. Every part of her wanted to scream, to demand an answer, but the words lodged in her throat, caught between frustration and vulnerability.

“Yes, actually,” Agatha snapped instead, her voice slicing through the air sharper than intended.

Rio’s brow arched, a glimmer of something in her eyes—curiosity, maybe surprise—before it quickly vanished. She tilted her head slightly, her tone gentler than Agatha could stand.

“What did I do?”

A hollow laugh escaped Agatha, cold and brittle, she stood up, needing to level the playing field—needing to look her in the eye.

“What haven’t you done?” she bit out, each word dripping with barely contained frustration. “ You’ve completely ruined me . Do you even realize that?”

Rio held her gaze, the weight of her own silence enough to stoke the embers of Agatha’s anger.

Rio’s face softened, but she didn’t look away.

Instead, she stepped closer, her gaze steady, unflinching.

“Ruined you?” she echoed, her voice low, a touch of sadness laced within her usual calm. “How exactly have I ruined you, Agatha?”

Agatha’s throat tightened, and her fingers curled, grasping for control she no longer had.

“You made me question everything I thought I knew about myself,” she whispered, almost to herself. “You’ve made me want things I can’t have, things I never even thought I’d want.”

Rio’s gaze remained unwavering, a quiet intensity simmering in her eyes.

“Why can’t you have them?” she asked, her voice barely a murmur. “I told you Agatha, all you had to is ask?”

The simplicity of it— just asking —sent a surge of frustration through Agatha, mingling with a longing so strong it felt like a physical ache.

She let out a bitter, breathless laugh.

“Just ask?” she repeated, a tremor in her voice. “What exactly would I even ask for?”

Rio’s gaze softened, her lips curving into a faint smile, one that held a thousand unspoken promises.

“That depends. What do you want, Agatha?”

The question hit her like a wave, crashing into the carefully built walls she’d surrounded herself with. And in that moment, the weight of her own vulnerability was almost too much to bear.

She felt a sting in her eyes—tears , actual fucking tears —and she swallowed hard, willing them away.

The silence thickened, and Rio stepped closer again, closer than they’ve been in days.

“Tell me what you want,” she whispered, her voice a quiet invitation, filled with a tenderness Agatha hadn’t expected.

Agatha’s pulse thundered in her ears as she stood there, feeling the weight of Rio’s words settle over her, wrapping around her like a tether both binding and freeing.

This was it.

She knew it, felt it in every nerve, every tremor of her racing heart.

It was that precipice—the moment before a jump, the second a skydiver teeters on the edge of the open door, staring down at the dizzying drop, caught between two choices: retreat back into the safety of the plane or leap forward into the unknown, letting gravity pull them into a freefall they couldn’t control.

Her mind spun, half-tempted to pull herself back, to escape the raw vulnerability of the moment.

But her body—the way it leaned ever so slightly closer to Rio, her breath quickening in anticipation—betrayed her.

She wanted this.

Needed it.

All she had to do was say the words.

Rio’s gaze remained steady, unwavering, her patience a quiet, unspoken invitation that dared Agatha to step forward.

Agatha felt a tremor roll through her as she stood there, feeling each of her defenses fall away, piece by piece, under the weight of that stare. Her lips parted, words struggling to surface, but they caught, hesitating on the edge.

“I want...” She started, her voice barely a whisper, her hands twitching at her sides as if searching for something to anchor her.

The words evaded her, slipping through her grasp, and she gritted her teeth in frustration, fighting against everything she had always known herself to be—controlled, precise, unshakable.

She looked away, drawing a breath to calm herself, but the admission clawed its way out before she could stop it.

“I want...” Her voice broke, and with it, the walls she had carefully built around herself cracked.

And then, with a certainty that both terrified and thrilled her, she turned back and met Rio’s gaze, feeling something snap inside her—a release, raw and undeniable.

“I want you.”

The words hung between them, alive and irrevocable, vibrating in the silence.

She couldn’t take them back, and in that moment, she realized she didn’t even want to.

The pleased rumble that sounded in the back of Rio’s throat at her words sent a violent shiver down Agatha’s spine.

“You want me?” Rio’s voice was low and intimate, each word igniting a spark that traveled through Agatha’s entire body. Her gaze held an intensity that smoldered, a heat so unrelenting that Agatha had to fight the urge to shift under it.

Every nerve seemed to stand at attention as Rio studied her, her eyes dark and expectant, pushing Agatha to commit fully, to double down on her admission.

Even now, this woman was still fucking pushing.

“Yes,” Agatha forced out, a mix of frustration and surrender.

The single word hung in the air, electric, and Rio’s lips curled into a slow, devastating smile. There was confidence in that smile, a knowingness that danced on the edge of cocky but felt earned, undeniable, and rooted in certainty. It was the look of someone who knew exactly what she wanted—and had no intention of accepting anything less.

Rio leaned forward, close enough that Agatha could feel her warmth, every word slipping from her lips like a caress but with a firm undertone that made Agatha’s pulse spike.

“How do you want me?”

The question twisted through her, unraveling any remaining composure.

Frustration flared in her chest, mixing with an undeniable desire that she wasn’t prepared to face.

“You can’t be serious," Agatha hissed out.

Rio’s smirk deepened, and her eyes, sharp and unreadable, traced over Agatha’s face.

“When it comes to your wants and needs, Agatha... you will find that... I am always serious .”

Her gaze held Agatha’s, penetrating, almost searching, as if inviting her to take the leap.

“Words matter,” she pressed, the intensity of her voice wrapping around Agatha, drawing her in.

She held Agatha’s gaze, each word deliberate, leaving no room for retreat. Her eyes darkened, studying Agatha’s reaction, taking in every flicker of hesitation, the way her breathing quickened, how the tension tugged at her.

“How do you want me?” she repeated, her tone steady, waiting, demanding. “ Tell me. ”

The room felt thick with tension, a living, breathing thing.

Agatha’s throat tightened as she looked away, her chest rising and falling, her pulse erratic.

“Don’t make me say it,” she whispered, each word a struggle. “It’s too much. You’re pushing for too much.”

The silence that followed was heavy, fraught with the weight of unspoken things, with the steady thrum of Agatha’s heartbeat filling her ears.

She looked away, out into the night, needing that distance, that small retreat.

The city lights blurred into a haze as Agatha stared out into the dark, the vast night a comforting emptiness compared to the intensity she felt burning in front of her. She clung to that inky black, hoping— no, begging —for Rio to ease up, to give her even a sliver of reprieve.

Admitting that she wanted her had cost her every shred of pride she could muster.

Anything more would shatter her.

But then, there it was —the soft, ghostly graze of fingertips along her jaw, so delicate at first it was almost a question.

Agatha’s breath hitched, a raw, needy sound slipping from her lips, escaping before she could catch it.

The sound was so foreign to her own ears, so unlike anything she’d ever let anyone hear, that she wanted to sink into the ground, to take it back.

How could she have made that sound?

From just a single touch.

She had never once made a sound like that in her life, not even in the depths of pleasure. And now, here she was, trembling beneath the feather-light touch of Rio’s fingertips on her jaw.

Her gaze remained locked on the skyline, refusing to meet Rio’s, terrified of what she'd find —some mixture of smugness or satisfaction that would only make the moment worse.

But Rio’s fingers pressed a bit more firmly, her touch insistent, wordlessly coaxing her to turn.

Agatha resisted, pressing back against the pressure, her defiance sparking to life, a last-ditch attempt to shield herself from the vulnerability clawing at her.

“ Agatha .”

Rio’s voice cut through the air, low, firm, carrying a tone Agatha had never heard from her before.

Gone was the playful teasing, the soft patience.

No —this was something different.

Demanding.

Exact .

And threaded with a warning Agatha couldn’t ignore.

Agatha’s breath stilled as she felt Rio’s fingers trail from her jaw, slipping beneath her chin and curling there, gripping just enough to make her pulse spike.

The bite of Rio’s hold was gentle but undeniable, an unspoken command that had her pulse roaring in her ears.

“ Look at me .” Rio’s voice was quiet but heavy, the words as steady as her grip.

With a subtle, insistent tug, Rio guided her gaze away from the comforting blackness outside, pulling her back to the charged, shadowed depths of her own eyes.

Relief washed over Agatha as she didn’t find mockery in Rio’s gaze, instead there was nothing but a quiet thrill, the kind that felt as dangerous as it was alluring.

Rio’s fingers loosened their grip on her jaw, but they didn’t leave; they lingered, ghosting up the side of her face, mapping the lines and angles with a touch so soft it felt like fire.

Agatha’s eyes fluttered shut as Rio brushed a stray strand of hair that fell against her face, tucking it gently behind her ear, leaving a trace of warmth where her hand had been.

“Alright,” Rio murmured, a slight ache of disappointment weaving through her tone, as if she had hoped Agatha would have said something, anything . Her hand shifted to cup Agatha’s cheek, thumb brushing over her cheekbone, a simple, slow caress that somehow felt charged with unspoken promises.

“How about I tell you what I want,” she whispered, her voice a low, throaty hum that reverberated through the small space between them, heavy with intention.

Her eyes stayed fixed on Agatha’s.

Her fingers glided from Agatha’s brow to her temple, a touch steeped in tenderness, but her voice whispered of something far deeper, a controlled intensity that wrapped around Agatha like a slow-burning fuse.

And then, Rio closed the distance, claiming her in a searing kiss that left no question, no hesitation, branding those words into Agatha’s soul in a way she knew she’d never forget.

“Good girl.”

The words echoed in Agatha’s mind, and she hated the way her body reacted. Her brain resisted, every rational part of her reminding her that she was a grown woman—she wasn’t a girl, and she sure as hell wasn’t good .

Those moments had been fleeting but memorable, etched into her mind as something she sometimes recalled in the dark, the quiet. She pulled back with an unnerving precision, her hand slipping from Agatha’s hair, leaving her breathless and dazed.

She watched Rio carefully, hoping the question would land, would somehow turn the tables.

Rio simply held her gaze, looking entirely unaffected, her smirk still firmly in place, the look in her eyes only deepening.

Her gaze flicked briefly over Agatha, making her feel acutely aware of her own disheveled state, her breath still heavy, her skin warm.

“ Why, Agatha ,” she practically sang, voice soft but teasing, “did you not want me to stop?”

Agatha’s jaw tightened, her immediate reaction a sharp glare. But the words she wanted to fire back caught in her throat, refusing to come out.

The fact that she didn’t answer was an answer all its own.

She read the hesitation, the flicker of vulnerability like she was reading her favorite book, page by page, understanding every line with infuriating clarity.

Rio’s smirk grew.

“Didn’t think so,” she murmured, her voice almost a purr, thick with satisfaction.

Anger.

Control.

The absolute need to even the playing field.

She didn’t know exactly where she found the courage, but she did.

Her fingers shook slightly as she tapped the screen, but she ignored it, typing the message to her driver with focused intent before hitting send and tucking her phone into her purse. A twisted sense of satisfaction flared in her chest at the sight.

She had unsettled her, even if only a fraction.

It was a start.

Absolutely not.

She was, as the kids today would say, a “ Self-Aware Queen .”

She knew her faults—more than she cared to count.

She knew her strengths—probably too well.

The scar on her elbow was proof enough—a lasting reminder from when she was eight years old, and the neighborhood boys had goaded her, claiming she’d never make it over the Grand Canyon-sized ditch outside their trailer park.

Every kid in the neighborhood had tried and failed.

But not Agatha.

She pedaled harder than her little legs could manage, threw caution to the wind, and fucking flew.

She cleared it— of course , but the landing was less than graceful. Her front tire caught on a rock, sending her flying over the handlebars and straight into a barbed-wire fence.

Twenty stitches later, she’d earned her first scar and her mother’s fury.

And it was on that day, at eight years old, that Agatha Harkness developed an addiction to proving people wrong, no matter how much it hurt, no matter what it cost her.

Some cut deeper, hidden under her skin, the psychological marks left behind by every challenge she’d taken head-on, every time she refused to back down. They’d shaped her, sharpened her into who she was today, and as painful as they’d been, she wore each one with a fierce sense of pride.

Rio.

She’d goaded Rio to jump the ditch, and Rio hadn’t even blinked.

too much, like a line she wasn’t ready to cross.

The words had barely left her mouth and she already regretted them. She saw the glint in Rio’s eyes, that familiar look of interest shifting into something sharper, hungrier.

“Would you like me to spank you?” Rio asked, her voice dropping, threading the question with dark amusement.

Agatha’s pulse spiked, her cheeks warming under Rio’s intense gaze. She opened her mouth to fire back a retort, but nothing came. Her throat was dry, her mind scrambling to reject the idea, but her body betrayed her, a faint shiver running down her spine. She forced herself to meet Rio’s eyes, feeling both exposed and cornered, as though Rio had peeled back a layer she hadn’t meant to show.

Finally, she managed to mutter, “I didn’t say that,” but her voice lacked conviction, sounding far more uncertain than she’d intended.

“No, you didn’t. But you didn’t exactly say no, either.”

Rio paused, her gaze holding Agatha’s with an intensity that felt almost suffocating. When she finally spoke, her tone was like steel, unyielding and final.

“The rules are non-negotiable,” she said, her voice low but unshakable. “If you can’t accept them, then we shouldn’t continue this.”

“All because I won’t let you boss me around?” Agatha shot back, her voice laced with sharp defiance.

Rio’s gaze remained unwavering, calm yet simmering with an intensity that made Agatha's pulse quicken.

“Agatha,” Rio answered, her tone almost exasperated, as if Agatha was missing the point of what she was trying to say. “I don’t want to just boss you around. That’s not the point. You’ll find that even when you are completely vulnerable to me, you still hold every ounce of your power that you’ve always had— especially over me. ”

She let the silence stretch, allowing the weight of her words to hang in the air between them.

“Just think about it, Agatha,” she murmured, each word a quiet pull as she reached up and touched Agatha’s face, cradling it like it was something precious. “You’ve carried power so well—commanded it, shaped it into something fierce, something no one else dares to touch.”

Her eyes searched Agatha’s face, intent, unwavering.

“But here... with me... what if you didn’t have to hold onto it so tightly?”

Agatha’s breath came shallow, her heart pounding as Rio’s words settled into her, dismantling her defenses one careful piece at a time.

She wanted to resist, to summon the sharp retort that would restore the distance between them. But there, under Rio’s hand, with her thumb brushing a tender line across her cheek, she found herself unable to move, unable to break away.

Rio’s eyes held hers, deep and steady, drawing her further in.

“Letting go doesn’t make you weaker, Agatha. It gives you room to experience something beyond what you’ve allowed yourself to feel.”

Her voice softened, almost a caress itself.

“What would it be like to surrender, just for a moment? To feel freedom instead of weight?”

Agatha’s head spun, her usual resolve faltering as Rio’s words seeped into places she hadn’t known were vulnerable. It was terrifying and magnetic, a thrill and a threat, every word coaxing her toward a choice she’d never considered.

Rio tilted her head, her gaze never wavering.

“You’d still be you, Agatha. Powerful. Resilient. But you’d also know... what it feels like to let someone else shoulder it, to give you something in return.”

She paused, her fingers slipping slightly down Agatha’s neck, her touch gentle but relentless.

She could feel every inch of Rio’s presence, the subtle strength in her fingers tracing along her neck, the intensity in her eyes, as if Rio could see through every wall she’d ever put up, every line she’d ever drawn to keep herself in control.

“I’ll... try,” she added, a touch of reluctance slipping through, as though she couldn’t quite surrender to the thought of surrendering.

Rio’s gaze softened, a glint of something both satisfied and understanding crossing her face, as though she recognized exactly how much it had cost Agatha to say those words.

“Any other rules, master ?” she mocked, quirking an eyebrow.

Rio let out a snort, shooting her an unimpressed look, though the slight curve of her lips betrayed a flicker of amusement.

“Yeah—one more. Rule Number Four: Don’t fall in love with me.”

The second the words left Rio’s mouth, Agatha laughed, unable to resist.

The cliché was almost too predictable, falling right into the box she’d expected.

This rule, she could handle with ease.

No problem at all.

There was no way in hell she’d fall in love with this woman.

This— whatever this was —it was purely physical, purely sexual, nothing more.

Before Rio could step out, Agatha smirked, leveling her gaze.

“Trust me, darling ,” Agatha drawled, savoring this moment. “That won’t be an issue.”

And with that, she shut the door, cutting off whatever response Rio might have had.

Turning, she strode toward her building, laughter still bubbling up as she heard the car door open behind her, the unmistakable sound of Rio stepping out, her footsteps close behind. Agatha didn’t have to look back to know Rio’s eyes were likely narrowed, her stare burning into Agatha’s retreating form.

She’d probably pay for that little move later, but at this moment, it was worth every second.

Her amusement faded, though, as she stepped into the lobby, the familiar walls of her high- rise suddenly closing in, as reality settled in. She pressed the elevator button, tapping her fingers against her purse, her mind racing as she thought of what might wait for her up in her condo. Of what Rio was going to do to her.

Had she underestimated this game with Rio?

Pushed just a little too far?

The elevator doors opened, and she stepped in, only to turn and see Rio follow her inside, moving in close, her gaze never leaving Agatha’s face.

As the doors closed, Agatha caught Rio’s eyes, dark and steady, a smirk lingering on her lips, but her gaze held a certain challenge, a quiet promise that made Agatha’s pulse skip.

The doors sealed shut, and Agatha swallowed, her mouth suddenly dry as Rio’s eyes bore into her.

She might’ve miscalculated.

This was her home— her haven , the one place she could unwind. But now, it felt different, as though every corner had eyes, watching and waiting.

Agatha's condo was anything but the typical whitewashed, lifeless space common in the building.

Instead, it exuded a character, just like her.

Deep, dark wood paneled the walls, while wrought-iron accents framed the tall, floor-to- ceiling bookshelves brimming with well-loved books. Plush leather armchairs and a wide sofa created an inviting atmosphere, and a grand iron chandelier cast warm, flickering shadows.

The space felt both opulent and lived-in, distinctly homey —a sanctuary for her and Nicky.

She was doing this on purpose.

She was letting the silence drag, deliberately letting the tension build, because she knew it was making Agatha uncomfortable, throwing her off balance.

It was a game—a silent, calculated play to keep Agatha on edge.

And damn it, it was working.

The words hit hard, a quiet promise that left Agatha’s pulse racing, her nerves fraying and her instincts telling her she was in way over her head. Ow. Agatha winced inwardly.
