Maiden, Mother, Crone

Friday morning found Agatha at the office, a stack of papers in front of her and a headache building as she read through a brief one of the second-year associates had submitted. It was, without a doubt, garbage. She scribbled in red ink, her frustration mounting with each line, making a mental note that she’d have to seriously reconsider this associate’s future here.

Once she’d finished tearing it apart, she set the brief aside, spinning her chair to face the window. The city skyline stretched before her, a vast expanse of silver and glass that used to offer her a few precious moments to shut off her mind, to breathe and just not think.

But now... every time she looked out at it, every time her mind drifted from work, like a rubber band, it snapped back to one thing.

One person.

Rio.

Which wouldn’t be a big deal if it were purely sexual.

If Agatha could limit her thoughts to all just Rio’s naked body pressed against hers, the way her hands and mouth ignited every nerve, the way Rio had a knack for pushing her past every comfort she thought she had, until Agatha found herself surrendering in ways she never imagined.

If it were just about the way Rio’s voice moaned in her ear, urging her on as Agatha touched her.

Or the way Rio tasted when Agatha finally worked up the courage to go down on her, the sounds she made, the way her fingers gripped Agatha’s hair, trembling under her touch.

Agatha could handle sexual.

Of course, it turned her on, leaving her part frustrated, part blissed-out mess, but that was fine — just that.

Sexual.

People were sexual beings.

It was natural.

It was simple.

What wasn’t simple was the way her mind now replayed moments that had nothing to do with sex and everything to do with Rio herself.

She kept seeing the color of her eyes, dark and earthy, like rich soil, matching the plants surrounding Rio's home.

Or hearing Rio’s voice as she spoke Spanish, her tone lighter, her words flowing with an ease that Agatha could listen to all day without understanding a single word.

She remembered Rio’s laugh— her real laugh —and how it was, to her surprise, her favorite sound to come out of her mouth, more than any moan or whispered filth.

And that damn smile —the one Rio had given her, soft and naked in her lap, post-orgasm— that smile made Agatha’s heart stutter.

Agatha knew exactly what it was, even if she refused to fully acknowledge it.

It was one thing to recognize that she was attracted to a woman. To let herself explore that attraction in the privacy of Rio’s capable hands, to indulge in the kind of intimacy that she always had always felt out of reach for her, reserved for someone else.

That was acceptable.

Hell— even embracing this newfound pull toward dominance and submission— especially on the submissive end, which she never would have thought herself drawn to—was somehow manageable, almost freeing.

But developing actual... feelings?

No.

That was something else entirely.

Feelings were messy, unpredictable, uncontrollable.

They tangled around reason and obscured lines.

And yet, she could feel them lurking, a nagging pull that had wrapped itself around her, subtle but insistent.

Rule Number Four: Don’t fall in love with me.

Rio’s final rule echoed in her mind.

She remembered the way indignation had flared up when she’d first heard it, a mixture of disbelief and defiance.

Agatha had laughed.

Actually laughed.

The idea of her, Agatha Harkness, falling in love?

Ridiculous.

It had seemed so absurd, so unnecessary—Agatha couldn’t imagine herself ever doing that.

After all, she didn’t really believe in it.

Love was too messy, too chaotic, too unpredictable.

She had her life carefully mapped out, every choice measured and weighed.

Love simply just didn't fit into her life.

The only exception was Nicky, whom she loved fiercely, as any good mother would. She loved him with the kind of love that would make her step in front of a bus without a second thought, the kind of love that overruled logic and self-preservation.

But this?

This was different.

She’d cared, somewhat , for the people she’d been with over her lifetime, but the closest she’d ever come to love was with James—and look how that had turned out.

No—love wasn’t real.

Or if it was, it existed for everyone except her.

At that thought—her mother’s words echoed in her mind, sharp and relentless, clawing at her from the past. Words she hadn’t allowed herself to think of in years but that lingered, buried deep down inside her where old wounds lingered.

“Something is wrong with you, Agatha. Inside. From the moment you clawed your way out of my body, I knew there was a darkness in you.”

The venom in her mother’s voice still rang in her ears, filled with the kind of cruelty that still cut her to the core.

Her mother was to put it plainly— a monster —a religious hypocrite who spat vicious words like scripture, yet truly believed she’d secured a seat in heaven for herself by attending church three times a week.

Agatha’s childhood had been a literal nightmare.

On the outside, their trailer had been well-kept, surrounded by carefully planted flowers, one of the nicest homes in the park. Her mother baked pies everyone adored, was the friendly teller at the local market, and, with the nearest ‘ doctor ’ miles away, was regarded as the town healer. She knew every home remedy and folk cure and was the person people went to when they were sick or hurt.

Evanora Harkness was the town matriarch.

Respected.

Kind.

Loving.

To everyone but Agatha.

Thousands of dollars of therapy, and Evanora Harkness still haunted her, like a ghost lurking in the shadows.

She was broken. Incapable of loving anyone but herself—of putting someone else's needs above her own. Agatha would always be selfish—cruel—unlovable.

That is what her mother had said.

And yet, here she was, feeling things that skated dangerously close to something that felt suspiciously like—

No , she told herself firmly.

This wasn’t love.

This was sex, nothing more.

That’s it.

Stop that.

Hell , Agatha didn’t even know what was happening to her.

“Let me show you,” Rio said, nodding back over her shoulder toward the war room.

With a nod, Agatha rose, hoping her face remained unreadable as she fell in step behind Rio, forcing herself to refocus on the case.

“Bad Guy #1:Brandon Vanguard, the grandson of the CEO and founder, William Vanguard. He’s technically listed as VP, but it’s purely a figurehead position. No real responsibility. Honestly, he’s a complete fuck-up—DUI arrests, drugs, barely scraped his way out of college. But his name and position alone gives him some authority in the company.”

She moved to the next man.

“Bad Guy #2:Harrison Smith. College roommate of none other than,” she paused before pointing back to the first picture, "Brandon Vanguard.”

She smirked as she started connecting the dots.

“Harrison, unlike Brandon, is actually smart. Comes from a middle-class family, no influential connections on his own. He works in logistics, and about five years ago, he was promoted to head of the department, thanks to his good buddy Brandon—despite there being far more qualified candidates.”

Finally, Rio pointed to the last man on the board, an older man with a severe expression.

“Bad Guy #3: James Hughes. Head of Security at Vanguard. Ex-military, special forces. He’s been all over the world, breaking up terrorist organizations, operating in covert ops. He has an intimate knowledge of how these organizations work, who the players are, and, most importantly, he knows the shipping lanes and paths closely monitored by the U.S. government. He knows the ports, the ins and outs of every security loophole—and how to get around them.”

Agatha’s eyes narrowed as she took in the details, her mind racing.

Rio nodded, loving that Agatha was following the bread trail se was leaving.

“Exactly. This trio creates the perfect storm. Individually, they’re scattered, inconspicuous even. But together? They’re capable of moving just about anything they want, completely off the radar.”

“Take a look at this,” Rio said, her tone shifting to something like restrained excitement. “Financial records. Hughes has a bank account that’s linked to a series of shell companies— none of them under Vanguard’s official control, but all with quiet ties to their logistics chain. Harrison Smith authorizes the transactions, and Vanguard’s name lends them legitimacy.”

Rio then pointed to another document—a shipping manifest.

“Here. These are shipments with items listed as ‘security hardware’ and ‘logistics supplies,’ on the Meridian Star authorized by Harrison but signed off by Hughes. And Brandon? He’s got his name on a series of transfers that look suspiciously like payments—probably to keep this under the radar.”

"So, they’re funding and moving... something . Under the guise of Vanguard’s operations.”

Rio nodded, her eyes gleaming with satisfaction.

“Likely weapons. And they’ve covered their tracks well enough that it only shows up in bits and pieces, but when you look at the whole picture...” She gestured to the whiteboards and stacks of paperwork.

This was meticulous, intelligent, and dangerous .

The whole web of deception that Agatha always knew was there was starting to unravel before her eyes, and she knew, with Rio by her side, they might just have the leverage they needed to take them down.

“That car—same license plate—was parked on Brooke’s street every night for four days before her death. Same spot, every time. And it hasn’t been back since.”

Agatha’s brows knitted together.

“Suspicious, but random cars on New York streets aren’t exactly rare.”

Rio nodded, acknowledging her point, but then clicked to change the timestamp in the corner to the night Brooke died.

It was James Hughes.

They had actual evidence that Vanguard’s Head of Security was seen on Brooke Sinclair’s street the night she died.

She actually did it.

Agatha rose from her seat, meeting Rio’s gaze.

“We can go to trial,” she echoed, the words seeming to hang in the air between them.

A smile broke across Rio’s face, bright and unguarded, and it was beautiful.

And Agatha hated the way her heart lurched at the sight.

She’d tasked Rio with securing affidavits from every source where key pieces of evidence had been gathered, and once she had those in hand, she’d be ready to submit the paperwork to the judge. Billy was standing by her office door, posture stiff, eyes wide with a rare kind of anxiousness she thought she’d trained out of him by now.

“What?” she snapped, feeling an unsettling weight settle in her stomach.

“There’s... a new security officer downstairs—he didn’t know,” Billy stammered.

Agatha blinked, not understanding a word of his cryptic explanation.

“Speak plainly, pet,” she demanded, her patience already thinning.

Billy swallowed hard, his eyes darting to the floor.

“Your mother,” he said, wincing as if he already expected the fallout. “Your mother is in your office.”

The words landed like a punch and Agatha went cold.

No.

She had cut her mother off completely when Nicky was born.

She’d made a deliberate choice to keep Evanora Harkness far, far away from her life. This especially rang true when Nicky was born. She refused to let her mother’s toxicity seep into his life the way it had poisoned hers. It was rule number one in the Assistant’s Handbook: Evanora Harkness was never to be in contact with Agatha—not a phone call, not an email, and certainly never in the damn building.

“I was making copies, and she... she was just there. I didn’t know what to do. She refused to leave, and I didn’t want to call security and make a scene. I’m sorry—”

Evanora Harkness didn’t get to hold power over her.

Not anymore.

Her mother was... unpredictable.

Agatha was unpredictable, too, but hers was a calculated kind, honed to her advantage.

Evanora, however, was unpredictable like a spark near gasoline—volatile, with a destructive potential.

She needed to be sharp, unreadable—she needed to win, for the sake of her soul.

New York, in her opinion, was a “ cesspool of godless heathens ,” a place where only the lost and the damned could thrive.

The fact that Agatha thrived here was all Evanora needed to prove that she was right, that Agatha was everything she always said she was.

Her mother looked older, of course, but that severity in her eyes hadn’t softened a bit. The lines around her mouth had deepened, making her look even more disapproving. She sat primly on the couch, her hands folded in her lap, taking in the office like the very air offended her.

“Agatha,” she said, her voice as cold as ever, drawing out the name with that same familiar bite.

Agatha met her gaze evenly, refusing to let a single flicker of discomfort show.

“Hi Mom. What are you doing here?” Her tone was professional, indifferent—she hoped impenetrable.

Evanora’s eyes narrowed.

“I was in the city for a church conference. Thought it would be... appropriate to stop by and see how my daughter is faring in this den of vice.”

Her voice dripped with the kind of sanctimonious condescension Agatha had long ago learned to ignore.

“Well, as you can see,” Agatha replied coolly, gesturing around her with a smirk, “I’m faring quite well.”

A faint, disapproving smirk tugged at the corner of Evanora’s mouth.

“Are you?” she asked, looking around the office, taking in the luxury with a raised brow. “Still chasing power and money, I see. Still choosing darkness over light.”

Agatha fought the urge to roll her eyes, keeping her face impassive.

“I’m choosing a career that I’ve built on my own terms,” Agatha replied, her voice carefully measured. “I don’t think that qualifies as ‘darkness.’”

Evanora shook her head slowly, a look of deep disappointment settling on her face. The gesture was painfully familiar, a move that Agatha had learned to brace herself against, even as a child.

“A career,” Evanora echoed, drawing out the word with a heavy layer of scorn. “And what good is that? Does it soothe the emptiness inside you? Because I can see it, Agatha. No matter how much you have, you’re still hollow, rotten to the core, just like everything you touch.”

The words sliced through Agatha, landing with brutal accuracy, but she bit back a response, refusing to let the hurt show. She knew Evanora wanted to see her flinch, to see the words sink in and take root.

Agatha wasn’t going to give her the satisfaction.

“If you’re here to judge, save your breath,” she replied, her tone icy. “You’ll find that I still don’t care about your approval.”

Evanora’s lips twisted into a smirk, her eyes gleaming with something dark, something almost triumphant.

“No, I’m sure you don’t,” she said, her voice low, dripping with cruelty. “But it’s not about my approval, is it? It’s about the truth. You can pretend all you want, but that darkness inside you, that rot? It seeps into everything you touch.”

Agatha felt the words like a weight settling over her, pressing against old insecurities, old doubts.

Evanora’s gaze was piercing, her expression cold and unyielding, and she held her pause deliberately, savoring the tension.

“I worry for that poor boy you’re raising,” she continued, her voice softening, adopting a feigned look of concern that only deepened the cruelty behind her words. “Nicholas, isn’t it?”

Her mother’s words landed like a knife to the chest.

Agatha felt her control slipping, a hot wave of anger and protectiveness rising in her chest.

“Leave Nicky out of this.”

But Evanora’s smirk only grew wider, her satisfaction intensifying as she pressed forward.

“Oh, I wish I could. But if he came from you... well, rot has a way of spreading.”

The words hit Agatha like a punch to the chest, but Evanora wasn’t finished. Seeing the crack in her daughter’s composure, she went for the heart— like she always did.

“I heard he was sick a few years back,” she continued, her tone almost mocking, the faintest hint of feigned sympathy twisting her lips.

Each word hit Agatha like a lash, dragging up pain she’d buried so deep she almost believed it couldn’t touch her anymore.

But as Evanora’s voice twisted into that mocking, feigned sympathy, Agatha felt old scars splitting open, raw and bleeding. Her mother’s words seeped into her like poison, feeding on every doubt and fear she’d worked so hard to silence.

“Cancer, wasn’t it?” Evanora’s tone dripped with faux concern, and Agatha’s stomach twisted violently, a familiar sickness creeping up her spine.

She fought to keep her composure, but it was like she was a child again, helpless under her mother’s scrutiny, feeling like a mistake, a failure in her eyes.

Her throat tightened, and for a moment, she couldn’t breathe.

She remembered the sleepless nights by Nicky’s bedside, the prayers she’d whispered to her mother’s all-powerful god, desperate, terrified he wouldn’t survive.

And now, hearing Evanora spin that agony into something ugly, something hateful —she could feel her heart breaking all over again.

“Tell me, Agatha,” her mother’s voice slithered into her thoughts, prying at her worst fears, “did it ever occur to you that perhaps God was punishing you through him?”

Agatha’s chest tightened, and her vision blurred. The suggestion pierced through her, flooding her mind with every terrible thought she’d had, every moment she’d doubted herself, every time she’d feared she wasn’t good enough for Nicky.

“Maybe it would have been better if you’d just let that illness take him,” Evanora whispered, her voice twisting around Agatha like a serpent, squeezing tighter, mocking her deepest love, her most fragile place. “While he was still innocent, while he still had a place in heaven.”

It was cruel, beyond anything Agatha could have prepared for, and she felt the old wounds of her childhood reopening, the shame, the fear, the awful feeling that maybe her mother had been right all along.That she was cursed, destined only to bring ruin to those she loved.

Agatha’s breaths turned shallow, and she could feel the cracks forming, her carefully constructed armor that years of therapy helped her build were now splintering under the weight of her mother’s words.

“He still has a chance at salvation, Agatha,” Evanora continued, her voice softening to a mockery of gentleness, each word deliberately placed to hurt. “A chance to escape this life you’ve built. But you couldn’t even let him have that. No, you had to drag him into this sin with you, to share in the rot you’ve let fester.”

She leaned forward, eyes narrowing with vicious satisfaction.

“One day, he’ll be just like you. Hollow. Godless. Destined for ruin. ”

The words seared into Agatha’s mind, reigniting every terrible thought she’d had in the darkest hours of the night. That she’d tainted Nicky, that maybe she was unfit to be his mother, that her own brokenness was a curse she’d unknowingly passed on to him. She could feel Evanora’s gaze, cold and dissecting, peeling away her defenses until she was exposed, vulnerable, the child she’d been, desperate for a love that was never given.

But there was a difference now. Agatha wasn’t that child anymore. Her mother’s cruelty couldn’t own her.

Agatha’s jaw tightened, and she forced herself to meet Evanora’s gaze, letting the simmering anger take root, filling the hollow ache her mother’s words had left behind.

She released her grip on her hands, feeling the sting of her nails in her palms.

“Get out,” she said, her voice steady, steely.

There was no tremor, no weakness in her tone, even though it raged through her body.

“And don’t ever come back.”

A flicker of irritation crossed Evanora’s face, but she masked it quickly, rising from her seat with a stiff, disdainful elegance, as if leaving were her choice.

She adjusted her coat, casting Agatha one final look of pure scorn.

“Enjoy your hollow little kingdom, Agatha,” she sneered, her voice dripping with contempt. “It will crumble. And when it does, there will be nothing left of you— or the boy . I am done praying for you. Let the devil take you. It is where you belong."

As the door closed behind her mother, Agatha felt her heart pounding, each beat like a heavy drum in her chest. Old wounds reopened, raw and aching, spilling over with pain she thought she’d conquered long ago. A wave of helplessness surged within her, her breaths coming in shallow, shaky bursts as her mother’s words circled in her mind, taunting her, gnawing at her deepest insecurities.

She blinked back tears, her vision blurring with frustration.

She was forty-eight years old.

Forty-eight , and still, her mother’s words could reach inside her and twist, leaving her feeling stripped bare, exposed, like a frightened child.

She hated it.

She hated that her mother still had this power over her.

Hated herself for letting it happen.

Suddenly, her office felt small, suffocating.

The air felt thick, pressing down on her, and she couldn’t bear another moment in this room where her mother’s presence still lingered. She needed to escape, to get away from the walls that felt as though they were closing in on her.

Without another thought, she headed for the door, moving quickly, her heels striking the floor in hard, purposeful steps.

She barely registered Rio calling her name, her voice edged with concern, but Agatha didn’t stop.

She couldn’t hear anything but her mother’s voice, those words echoing in her mind, haunting her, pulling her under.

Agatha clung to Nicky the moment she got home. He seemed to sense that something was off, that she needed this, and he didn’t pull away. Instead, he leaned into her, letting her hold

him, allowing her to be close in a way she hadn’t needed to be since he was sick.

Since she’d walked through the door, a single phrase had been running through her mind like a mantra, grounding her.

I am a good mother.

She kissed Nicky’s forehead.

I am a good mother.

She helped him with his homework, patiently going through each problem.

I am a good mother.

She read him Harry Potter , her voice shifting for each character, drawing giggles from him when she exaggerated Hagrid’s deep gruff tone.

I am a good mother.

She stayed with him long after he’d fallen asleep, fingers stroking his hair, feeling his small, steady breaths beneath her hand.

I am a good mother.

It had been a long time since she’d stayed the night in his bed. Not since the days he’d been sick, when she couldn’t bring herself to leave his side.

Now, here she was, curled up in his Buzz Lightyear bed, cramped and uncomfortable, yet unwilling to move, unwilling to let him go. The tightness in her chest slowly began to ease, soothed by the gentle rise and fall of his breathing.

I am a good mother, she told herself again, her fingers brushing gently over Nicky’s cheek.

And in the quiet of his room, she almost believed it.

Tears spilled down her face, and she quickly wiped them away, careful not to let them fall onto him.

Her phone vibrated in her pocket, the suddenness breaking the silence. She pulled it out, blinking back the last of her tears to read the message.

It was from Rio.

Are you okay?

Agatha sucked in a breath, feeling the words catch in her throat.

She started to type, her fingers moving and typing out instinctively: I’m fine.

But she hesitated before hitting send, staring at the words.

They felt hollow, too much like the carefully constructed lie she told the world.

She wasn’t fine.

Her mother had left her feeling shattered, vulnerable in a way she despised. Evanora had done what she always did—cut her down, left her questioning everything she’d fought to believe in herself.

Agatha deleted the message, her thumb hovering over the screen as she considered what to say.

After a long pause, she finally typed, and before she could second-guess it, she hit send.

No.

She watched as the message was delivered, the one word carrying a surprising vulnerability that Agatha had never really shared with someone before.

A moment later, her phone vibrated again. Rio’s response was swift, almost as if she’d been waiting, and her words made something tighten in Agatha’s chest.

What do you need?

Agatha stared at the screen, her heart pounding as she read the message over and over, feeling the weight of the question. It was so simple, yet so open—a lifeline she hadn’t expected.

Her fingers hovered, hesitant. She wasn’t used to being asked this, to having someone who genuinely wanted to know. The urge to reply warred with the fear of vulnerability, of letting someone see the cracks she worked so hard to keep hidden.

Finally, she took a shaky breath and typed.

Got any remedies for unresolved childhood trauma and a mother straight from hell?

It was honest, with just enough bite to mask the rawness beneath.

Her phone buzzed again, and Rio’s reply flashed on the screen.

Maybe.

A second later, another message came through.

Come open your front door and find out.

Agatha’s heart skipped. She gently untangled herself from Nicky, quietly padding out of his room, closing the door softly behind her. She made her way to the front door, hesitating just a moment before peeking through the peephole.

Sure enough, there she was—Rio, standing outside, arms crossed, her expression unreadable.

Agatha opened the door, a mix of surprise and relief tightening in her chest.

Rio stood outside her door, wearing sweatpants and orange faded Texas Longhorn hoodie.

“What are you doing here?” Agatha asked confused.

Rio looked her, her gaze locking in on Agatha’s face, no doubt noticing the red eyes and tear stains.

“I was worried about you.”

Agatha shifted, her voice coming out sharper than she intended.

“I’m fine.”

“No, you’re not.” Rio’s response was calm, cutting right through the façade with a simplicity that left Agatha feeling raw and exposed.

She swallowed hard, feeling the words catch in her throat. She didn’t know how Rio always managed to see her so clearly, to slice through every wall she put up.

“Let me in,” Rio said, her tone gentle but firm.

Agatha’s breath shook.

Her first instinct was to say no, to shut this down, to send Rio away before she let herself fall apart any further.

“My son is home,” she whispered, her voice barely above a murmur. “And I’m not... I’m not in the mood.”

Rio held her gaze, unrelenting, her eyes locked on Agatha.

"Let me in anyways."

There was something in Rio's tone, a calm insistence that made Agatha's resistance crack.

It felt like more than just a request to step inside her home—it felt like a request to step inside Agatha, beyond her walls—to let Rio in.

And after a long, hesitant pause filled with want and fears battling within her, Agatha stepped aside, allowing Rio to enter.

She wasn’t sure what to expect when Rio stepped into her home.

But what she certainly didn’t expect was for Rio to walk in, kick off her worn tennis shoes, and head deeper into the house without a word—as if she already had a plan in mind.

Agatha opened her mouth, ready to demand what the hell Rio thought she was doing, but the thought of waking Nicky stopped her.

Instead, she just followed, her curiosity and frustration growing with each step.

Agatha trailed Rio down the hallway, passing Nicky’s door and continuing to the very end of the hall—to Agatha’s room.

Rio didn’t hesitate for a second. She turned the doorknob and walked right in.

Agatha paused, staring at her open bedroom door, completely thrown by Rio’s audacity—the sheer gall of the woman.

A surge of irritation and disbelief moved her feet faster, ready to confront Rio about whatever bold assumption she was acting on.

But when Agatha stepped into her bedroom, she found it empty.

Confused, she looked around, her brow furrowed.

And then she heard it—the sound of running water.

Agatha turned her head toward the master bathroom, the door slightly ajar.

She stared at it, baffled.

What the hell was she doing?

Agatha stormed toward the bathroom, her mind set on calling Rio out, on demanding to know just what she thought she was doing. But as she stepped through the doorway, the words froze on her lips.

There was Rio, kneeling in front of the free standing bathtub, her hand testing the water. She reached up, grabbed one of the bottles on the shelf, poured a small amount into the water, and carefully placed it back where it belonged.

Immediately, the scent of lavender filled the air, soothing and familiar.

For a moment, Agatha could only stand there, watching Rio.

She hadn’t expected this.

She didn’t even know what to do with this.

Rio tested the water once more, making a small adjustment before turning to face her fully. She held Agatha’s gaze in that steady, grounding way of hers, then extended her hand.

“Come here.”

Agatha swallowed, her feet rooted to the spot, an unspoken tension tightening in her chest.

Rio’s eyes softened at Agatha's hesitation, and she took a step closer, her hand still outstretched.

“ Agatha ,” she said again, her voice gentler this time, “please... come here.”

The word please landed with surprising weight, sending a rush of warmth through her.

Agatha felt her chest tighten further, the smallest crack forming in her resolve, and before she could stop herself, she took a step forward, reaching out and slipping her hand into Rio’s.

Rio pulled her closer, before moving her hand moved up to cup Agatha’s cheek, her thumb brushing softly against her skin, as if she could wipe away the lingering traces of tears that had long since dried. Her touch was so gentle, so full of unspoken understanding, that it made something fragile and unguarded stir within Agatha.

Without a word, Rio’s hands moved lower, her fingers reaching the top button of Agatha’s silk blouse. She undid it with the same care, slowly working her way down, each movement respectful, unhurried. There was no intent beyond tenderness, no motive beyond offering a moment of comfort.

Agatha’s pulse quickened, not from desire but from the overwhelming unfamiliarity of being handled so carefully, as if she were something precious. It felt strange to be stripped bare this way, emotionally and physically, without the barriers she so often clung to.

And yet, she didn’t resist.

She allowed Rio to gently peel away the layers, until she stood bare in front of her, exposed but somehow not vulnerable.

When Agatha was free of her clothes, Rio held out her hand again, guiding her to the edge of the tub. She helped her step into the warm water, steadying her as she sank down, feeling the soothing embrace of the lavender-scented bath.

Rio gave a small, knowing smile.

“Can I trust you not to drown yourself in there?”

Agatha managed a weak chuckle, the unexpected question disarming her enough to respond honestly.

“I’m not suicidal... just sad.”

The words slipped out, surprising them both, a small truth admitted in the quiet safety of the moment.

Rio’s face softened, a sadness in her gaze that mirrored Agatha’s own, and she leaned down, pressing a gentle kiss to Agatha’s brow. The tenderness of it left Agatha feeling as if she’d been held, if only for a heartbeat.

“Good night, Agatha,” Rio murmured softly against her skin, straightening and preparing to leave.

But as Rio pulled back, a hollow feeling surged in Agatha’s chest, filling the space where Rio’s touch had been. She closed her eyes, a sudden panic tightening her throat of being left

alone, and before she could second-guess herself, her hand shot up from the water, fingers closing around Rio’s wrist.

Rio stopped, looking down at her, a flicker of surprise in her eyes.

“Don’t leave,” Agatha whispered, her voice barely audible.

Rio hesitated, her gaze lingering on Agatha’s face as if searching for an answer she wasn’t certain of.

Then, with a quiet resolve, she pulled her hand away and reached under her hoodie, slipping it off, stripping away her layers one by one. Her eyes stayed locked on Agatha, steady and unwavering, as she undressed until there was nothing left between them.

Without a word, she moved forward, placing a gentle hand on Agatha’s shoulder, a gesture for her to shift forward in the water.

Agatha did, her pulse racing.

She felt the warmth of Rio’s body as she lowered herself into the bath behind her, settling into the water. And then, without hesitation, Rio’s arms wrapped around her, pulling her back until Agatha was nestled against her, the weight of her hands resting protectively around her middle.

As Agatha sank back into Rio’s embrace, a surprising surge of emotion unfurled in her chest, warm and unexpected.

The simple act of being held like this— of being cared for so completely —was unlike anything she’d allowed herself to experience in a very long time, if ever. She had built her life on self-reliance, on walls so carefully constructed that even moments of closeness felt foreign, almost forbidden.

But here, with Rio’s arms wrapped around her, those walls felt softer, less necessary. The warmth of Rio’s body, the steady beat of her heart against Agatha’s back, and the quiet weight of her hands resting protectively around her were somehow exactly what she needed, even if she hadn’t known it.

And then, as soft as a whisper, she felt Rio’s lips brush against her shoulder, and then her neck. The kisses weren’t charged with desire; they were something else entirely— gentle .

A new wave of tears began to slip down her face, fast and unstoppable.

She wasn’t even sure what she was crying about anymore—the wounds her mother’s words had reopened, the pain of years of self-imposed isolation, or maybe the overwhelming feeling of safety that being held like this brought her.

Rio’s arms tightened just slightly knowing she was crying, her presence steady and unwavering, as if telling Agatha without words that she was safe here, that she didn’t have to hold everything together on her own.

And for the first time in her entire life, Agatha let herself believe it.

Wake Thy Power

Chapter Summary

There are multiple moments in this chapter that literally had me kicking my feet smiling. I hope you guys enjoy those moments as much as I enjoyed writing it.

Also I went back and renamed the lawyers of the Salem Seven to be clever. I introduced them first in Chapter 4.

I have renamed them to: Fox, Ratcliff, Coyotl, Wise, Crow, Orm, and Swarmen. (Fox, Rat, Coyote, Owl, Crow, Snake and Bugs)

Also I can't stress this enough, I am not a lawyer or work in the law. So I don't know if what I am writing is accurate. I took some moments, lines, and dialogue from some of more favorite law/cop tv shows and movies to try and mimic what a case at least on the tv looks like. I know it's not accurate, but I think it paints a decent picture.

Also, I know I have been cranking out these chapters. I don't know how long I can keep pace. I've been really slow at work and have been writing for like 6-8 hours a day lately. Eventually I will have to return to reality, and updates may slow.

Thanks for sticking with me.

Enjoy.

Agatha’s mind was back in her bathtub, to the way she’d crumbled in Rio’s arms. Her tears had fallen from her eyes, and with each drop, she’d felt the weight of years of pain begin to surface, like a countdown, ticking toward the inevitable.

And then, finally, she couldn’t hold back anymore.

The tears had reshaped into deep, wrenching sobs—sounds she barely recognized as her own —broken and raw, spilling from her mouth no matter how she tried to choke them back.

She’d tried to muffle them, bringing her hand to her mouth as if that could somehow contain it all, as if she could silence the flood of sorrow and rage and fear that surged up from somewhere deep in her soul.

But there was no stopping it.

The sobs—they just kept coming, tearing through her, each one leaving her feeling more wrecked, more stripped of the carefully constructed sense of self she had worn for so long.

It was one thing to break down; she hadn’t truly done it in years, not since Nicky had been sick.

And even before that, crying was something she avoided, something she despised.

She hated the feeling of vulnerability it left in its wake, the way it made her feel exposed raw. It was like ever nerve was exposed—every insecurity she’d buried beneath her carefully crafted armor.

She had always bottled it up, pushing it down because to her, tears meant weakness, and weakness was something she could never allow herself.

Not even in private.

But to break down like that in front of Rio...

Agatha could still feel the warmth of Rio’s arms around her, steady and grounding as she came undone. Rio hadn’t flinched, hadn’t looked away, hadn’t let go. She’d simply stayed there, holding Agatha as pain poured out, raw and unchecked.

Rio’s lips had brushed softly over her shoulder, her neck, murmuring gentle, soothing words into her skin.

“It’s okay.” “I’ve got you.” “It’s okay.”

She repeated the words like a mantra, each one sealed with a tender kiss, as if she could somehow mend the fractures with nothing more than her voice and touch. Each kiss, each whispered reassurance felt like Rio was trying to fill the cracks in Agatha’s heart, slowly and carefully, as if piecing her back together with a gentleness Agatha hadn’t known she craved.

Rio drew Agatha even closer, wrapping her arms around her fully and reaching down to take Agatha’s hand, cradling it against her own at Agatha’s stomach. She held her firmly, grounding her as Agatha’s chest rose and fell between breaths and broken sobs beneath their intertwined hands.

“It’s okay, baby,” she murmured softly into her ear, her voice a steady anchor. “I’ve got you.”

“Mama—did you hear me? ”

Nicky’s voice broke through her thoughts, pulling her back to the present.

Agatha startled, her mind snapping out of the memory and focusing forward, on the diner booth where Nicky sat across from her, his face etched with concern. He held a forkful of pancake halfway to his mouth, syrup dripping onto the table as he looked at her.

Mindlessly Agatha reached for a napkin, leaning forward to wipe up the sticky mess before he set his sleeve in it.

“I’m sorry, honey. I was thinking about something at work,” she lied smoothly, giving him a warm smile she hoped would reassure him, even if it didn’t quite reach her eyes. “What were you saying?”

Nicky studied her for a moment, his brow furrowed in that way he got when he was thinking hard about something. Then—only like a child could—the worry eased, and he returned to his food, putting the pile of pancakes in his mouth.

“I was just wondering if you were going to the office today?” he asked around the mouthful of pancakes.

Agatha scrunched up her nose in disgust at his manners but thought about his question.

It was Saturday.

Usually, work was a toss-up depending on what was happening.

Should Agatha be at the office, prepping for the Vanguard case?

Absolutely.

But would she be going in, knowing that Rio was likely there also prepping the case?

Absolutely not.

The thought of facing her after last night, after breaking down in front of her, felt impossible.

If she’d thought looking Rio in the eye after sleeping together had been hard, this felt like a whole new level of vulnerability she wasn’t ready to confront.

She managed a small, reassuring smile, focusing on Nicky.

“No work today,” she said, reaching over to ruffle his hair. “Just us.”

Nicky beamed at her, syrup smeared on his cheek and chunks of pancake hanging out of his mouth.

“Yes!”

“Nicky,” she feigned a gag, rolling her eyes dramatically. “Chew your food! Goodness — who raised you?”

He swallowed, his eyes sparkling.

“Umm... you did,” he said, pointing his fork at her, as if presenting solid evidence.

Agatha put on an exaggerated expression of surprise, holding back a smile.

“Did I?” she mused, pretending to think hard.

Then, with a mischievous glint, she grabbed her fork and reached across the table, stealing a giant bite of his pancake and forced it into her mouth. She chewed it dramatically, speaking around the mouthful.

“I am certain— I would’ve taught —you to chew your— food before talking. ”

Nicky erupted into giggles, his face lighting up.

“Mama!” he protested, barely able to contain his laughter.

“What?” she asked, feigning innocence, still chewing obnoxiously. "Do I have something in my teeth?” she asked, opening her mouth and showing him the chewed up pancake.

Nicky squealed with laughter, his giggles filling her heart.

Agatha’s chest swelled at the sound.

She wished she could live in this moment forever.

Her mother's words still haunted her, but they were quieter now.

She also knew Monday would come, that she couldn’t outrun Rio forever,

But right now, with Nicky’s laughter echoing around the diner and his face bright with happiness, she let herself sink into the present, holding tightly to this small, perfect moment for as long as she could.

She rested her chin in her hand, elbow propped on the table, and opened her mouth to show Nicky the chewed-up food again. He squealed in delight, covering his face with his hands but still peeking through his fingers.

Agatha felt a warmth spread through her, watching his pure, unfiltered happiness.

Fuck you, Evanora, she thought, the words settling into her heart like a quiet, reassuring truth.

I am a good mother.

Agatha spent the entire weekend with Nicky, letting him set the agenda. She tagged along to every place he wanted to go, soaking up his laughter, his boundless energy and joy. They went to the museum, the park, the zoo. They played board games at home, watched his favorite movies, and ate way too much junk food.

But she didn’t care.

He’d be with his father after school tomorrow, and she wouldn’t see him for a week. She was determined to fill every moment with his smile.

On Monday morning, she saw Nicky off to school. He gave her an extra-big hug, his little arms squeezing her tightly before he bolted from the car and towards the building.

“See you next week, Mama! Love you!” he called over his shoulder, his voice bright.

Agatha blew him a kiss, watching until he’d made it safely inside.

She lingered for a moment, feeling that familiar emptiness settle in—the ache that always crept in when he was gone. With a sigh, she rolled up her window and leaned back into the leather seat, closing her eyes and letting out a deep breath.

She couldn’t afford to linger in that feeling.

She had to switch gears, to focus.

Afterall, she had a white whale to harpoon.

Opening her eyes, she pressed the intercom button.

“To the office, Dan.”

“Yes, Ms. Harkness,” her driver responded smoothly, and the town car pulled away from the curb, heading towards a day that somehow both thrilled her and made her want to throw up.

Agatha walked briskly through the office, her heels clicking with purpose. She didn’t go straight to her office. Instead, she veered left, heading directly to the war room. If she was going to reclaim her footing, she needed to do it immediately, on her terms.

Rio was already there, as she’d expected, looking over documents pinned to the board, a pen tucked behind her ear.

She looked up as Agatha entered, her expression as calm and unreadable as ever.

No pity, no softness—just Rio being Rio, a touch of cockiness in her gaze but otherwise cool, professional.

It was as if nothing had happened, and Agatha clung to that professionalism Rio was extending towards her like a lifeline.

"Did you secure those affidavits?" Agatha asked, keeping her tone steady, controlled—not letting any of her internal anxieties seep through.

Rio nodded, her expression impassive.

"They’re on your desk."

"Good," Agatha replied, stepping forward to study the board—needing the distraction.

Her gaze landing on the photo of Brooke Sinclair at the center of the board.

She took in the young woman’s face, her features frozen in time, and felt a sharp, uncomfortable pang.

Brooke had been so young—just four years younger than Rio was now.

That thought had a painful ache echo through her chest, but Agatha forced it aside, focusing her thoughts back on Brooke’s case.

Brooke Sinclair had an entire life ahead of her, stolen without a second thought.

Agatha couldn’t bring her back, couldn’t undo the grief that had swallowed her family.

Death was one battle even she couldn’t win.

But she could make those responsible pay.

Agatha felt that familiar, steely resolve settle over her.

Vanguard had deep pockets, a reputation built on its wealth and power—and she was determined to see every cent of it go toward making sure Brooke’s death wouldn’t be forgotten.

Agatha felt Rio step up beside her, both of them facing the board in shared silence.

After a few moments, Agatha turned to her.

“You ready?” she asked, her voice steady but, laced with the thrill that always came with taking a case to court.

Rio met her gaze, her expression unwavering.

“Yes.”

With a nod, Agatha strode over to the door, opening it and calling out into the hallway.

“Billy! Get me a status hearing scheduled with Judge Marks on the Vanguard case. ASAP.”

She watched as Billy scrambled into action, a sense of satisfaction blooming in her chest as the wheels began to turn.

She turned back to Rio, feeling the familiar rush that always hit when a case was about to go live in court. Any lingering anxiety about them had vanished, as the feeling rushed through her.

“Now,” she smirked, her eyes gleaming with anticipation, “the real fun starts.”

Rio’s lips curled into a matching grin, her energy mirroring Agatha’s.

They were on the same page, and Agatha could feel it: they were ready for war.

The town car cruised through the city streets.

Agatha sat back against the leather, the courthouse growing closer with each passing block, her gaze steady but the flicker of excitement sparking inside her. She could feel the shift in energy, the familiar rush that always came before a courtroom showdown.

Beside her, Rio watched her, curiosity evident, her fingers tapping thoughtfully against her leg.

“So,” Rio broke the silence, her voice low but curious, “what’s the plan?”

She leaned in, her eyes sharp but curious, as she stared at Agatha.

“We still need to depose their witnesses, right? Get an idea of their defense before we request trial.”

Agatha turned, a slow, predatory smile forming on her lips.

“That is typically how it’s done,” she replied, the tone measured, almost teasing.

Rio’s eyes narrowed, sensing something off on Agatha’s choice of words.

“ Typically ...meaning?”

Agatha’s smirk deepened, a glint of challenge in her gaze.

“You are very smart, Rio,” she said allowing the compliment to leave her mouth. Rio deserved that much. “You’re a natural at pulling apart documents, at tracing every single thread in a web until you find something valuable. Your report writing is impeccable and your knowledge of case law is far beyond someone of your age and rank.”

She paused, letting her words sink in, her eyes never leaving Rio’s before reeling the overconfident rookie back to earth.

“But this job is more than paperwork. It’s more than strategy. It’s showmanship .”

As the car slowed, Agatha tilted her head toward the courthouse, the large building coming into view.

She raised her chin, her gaze drifting to the entryway as if picturing the stage that awaited her inside the courtroom.

“This,” she continued, her voice gaining an almost electric intensity that mirrored the feeling inside her, “ is theater. What separates the good lawyers from the great isn’t a well-written brief or even a solid cross-examination. It’s the ability to control the narrative. To own the

courtroom. To create a story out of every detail, every witness, every piece of evidence. And to do all of that while staying two steps ahead of opposing counsel.”

She leaned forward, relishing in the way Rio’s eyes were locked on her with an intensity.

“From the moment you step into that courtroom, you must command it,” stressed Agatha.

The moment hung between them, and then slowly Rio’s lips curled into a smirk, her gaze dancing with amusement, a spark of something that Agatha recognized all too well in her eyes.

“I think I’m pretty good at commanding— as you well know ,” she murmured back easily.

Agatha felt her breath catch.

She really couldn’t bother to be upset about it.

She had literally set Rio up for that one.

But today, Agatha felt just as emboldened, with the thrill of the case that laid ahead coursing through her, feeding her confidence. She met Rio’s gaze, allowing a dangerous smile to creep onto her face.

“Yes, you are,” she said, her tone cool, layered with a hint of playful intensity. “But this— this is different.”

She leaned closer, her voice dropping to a whisper, soft and charged.

“This isn’t the bedroom, darling. This is my arena. Here, I am in control. ”

She heard Rio suck in a breath at that, momentarily thrown by Agatha’s words.

And Agatha taking advantage of the rare feat, reached up and touched Rio's cheek lightly, before leaning in, purposely turning her tone turning low and intimate.

“ Watch mama work , and take notes,” she murmured into Rio’s ear, before pulling back and looking at her and giving Rio’s cheek a mocking pat. “There will be a quiz afterward.”

As she felt the car come to a stop, she released her and pulled herself gracefully from the car, stepping onto the pavement.

Her heels clicked against the stone steps as she moved toward the courthouse doors.

She didn’t look back, trusting that Rio would follow.

Agatha sat in the chair, tapping her fingers rhythmically on the desk as she waited for the judge to arrive.

Rio sat beside her on the right.

Agatha cast a glance to her left, where two members of the Salem Seven were seated, eyes sharp and unreadable as they scanned the room.

Madeline Fox and Greg Ratcliff.

They were stationed out of her firm’s New York office, both seasoned litigators, and Agatha knew well enough not to underestimate them. She didn’t need to be conceited to acknowledge good lawyers when she saw them—these two were skilled, calculated.

Fox, especially, had a reputation for ruthlessness that Agatha respected, even if she didn’t like it.

Fox was the real threat here.

Cunning and meticulous, Fox moved like a predator in the courtroom, dangerous because she didn’t let ethics cloud her strategy. She would exploit any weakness without hesitation, making her both effective and morally bankrupt.

Ratcliff, on the other hand, was a glorified paper-pusher, but he was annoyingly sharp when it came to case law. If there was a loophole, he’d find it. If there was a technicality to exploit, the little rat would certainly sniff it out.

“All rise,” called the clerk, snapping Agatha’s attention forward as she stood. “The Honorable Judge Harrison Marks presiding.”

Judge Marks entered the courtroom and walked up the steps to the bench, his expression as impassive as ever.

When she first filed the lawsuit against Vanguard three years ago, securing Judge Marks had been a quiet victory. Like many New York judges, he leaned liberal, but more importantly, he had a well-known aversion to favoring billionaire corporations.

Judge Marks's record was clear on his stance: while he upheld corporate rights, but he also believed corporations should also bear the same moral and legal responsibilities as citizens. His previous rulings, often forced companies to account for their impact on people and communities—a philosophy that worked in favor for her on Vanguard case.

What didn’t work in her favor, however, was Judge Marks — was not of a fan of hers.

The man had a memory like a steel trap.

Agatha had earned herself ONE contempt of court citation from him eight years ago in a particularly contentious case where she may have called a dirty police officer an " racist asshole " during questioning, and he hadn’t let her forget it since.

As Judge Marks settled into his chair, Agatha and the others took their seats. He reached for the case file, skimming it with a frown.

“This matter is here for a status hearing,” he began, flipping through the pages. “I was under the impression that this matter was closed?”

His eyes narrowed at the details.

“Am I reading this right? The suit was originally filed in 2021.”

Agatha expected this, and stood.

“Yes, your honor,” she replied smoothly, “and it’s taken us this long to get through the discovery process—courtesy of the defense’s, let’s say,” she paused to side long a glance at a smirking Fox, “ extensive cooperation after you granted our initial request.”

Judge Marks's gaze flicked up at her, one eyebrow arching skeptically.

“Three years... for discovery?” he said, skepticism lacing his voice.

“The defense discovery dumped us with over 5 million documents,” Agatha replied, maintaining her composure. “We particularly enjoyed the 40 years' worth of holiday cards they sent along with their documents.”

This time, Agatha didn’t hesitate to turn and fix Fox with a look, her gaze narrowing.

“Nothing quite brings a festive spirit to the review process like reminiscing about Vanguards yearly cheer,” she mocked smoothly.

Fox didn’t even blink, but Agatha could see the satisfaction in her own reflection. She knew Fox had enjoyed burying her under all that irrelevant nonsense—she could practically see the smirk hidden behind Fox’s professionally impassive expression.

Judge Marks sighed, a long-suffering sound, his gaze flicking between the two lawyers with a look that suggested he already knew this status hearing was going to be far from straightforward.

After a moment, he settled his eyes on Agatha, gesturing for her to continue.

Agatha felt a flicker of irritation at being nudged along but kept her expression smooth.

“Our firm has finally completed the exhaustive review of every document submitted, and we are— at long last —ready,” she said, measured with a certain dramatic she couldn’t help but use.

Then she paused, her mind running over the strategy she’d mapped out over the weekend with Nicky as they played a few rounds of Catan. The game required a deft hand at blocking opponents before they even had the chance to get their footing. And today, she had her own plan to throw the defense off balance from the very start.

Agatha glanced at Rio, catching her eye with a quick, confident wink before turning back to the judge, her expression sharpening with resolve.

“We call ready for trial.”

She felt Rio stiffen beside her, and she didn’t bother hiding the satisfaction that swelled as she watched Judge Marks's eyes widen, the barest flicker of surprise crossing his face.

Across the aisle, Madeline Fox shot up from her chair as if Agatha had pulled the lever herself.

“Wait—what?!” Fox’s voice faltered, and the crack in her usual cool confidence was music to Agatha’s ears.

Fox quickly gathered herself, drawing a steady breath as she fixed Agatha with a pointed glare before addressing the judge.

“Your Honor, we’re not ready for trial,” she protested, her tone firm but just shy of desperate. “We deposed their witnesses three years ago. They have deposed none of ours.”

Fox fell right into Agatha's trap, and Agatha relished every second of it.

“How can you possibly not be ready?” Agatha's tone was dripping with incredulity, her eyes locked on Fox. “What have you been doing for the past three years? You wouldn’t perhaps— I don’t know —be sitting on your hands—hoping my firm would just go bankrupt trying to get through the mountain of discovery you dumped on us?”

Fox opened her mouth, but Agatha didn’t give her the chance.

“Let’s stop wasting the court’s time, shall we?” Agatha cut in, her gaze fixed on Judge Marks, her voice calm but charged with finality. “We call ready for trial, Your Honor.”

A silence settled over the room, thick and heavy.

You could’ve heard a pin drop.

Judge Marks's eyes narrowed as he absorbed her statement.

“This is a dangerous game you’re playing, Ms. Harkness,” he said, his tone carrying both warning and intrigue. “You haven’t deposed a single one of their witnesses.”

Agatha shrugged, a hint of a smirk on her lips.

“I don’t need to. I have a pretty good idea what they’re all going to say,” she replied confidently, her voice as unwavering as her gaze.

Another blanket of silence covered the courtroom for a moment, before Judge Marks leaned forward, his gaze locked onto Agatha.

“Just so we’re clear, because your reputation does precede you, Ms. Harkness, and I will not have my courtroom turned into some kind of reality TV spectacle,” he said, his voice firm. “Are you truly ready for trial? Right now. Today .”

Agatha glanced down at Rio, who was watching her with an expression that bordered on awe, barely daring to breathe.

She looked back up at Judge Marks , her voice steady.

“Yes, Your Honor.”

Judge Marks leaned back, a mixture of shock and reluctant admiration crossing his face. He sat there, weighing her words, before slowly turning his gaze to Fox.

“Mrs. Fox?”

Madeline Fox looked like a fish out of water, her mouth opening and closing as she struggled to find her words, before she finally sputtered.

“This is ridiculous,” gesturing at Agatha with visible frustration. “This is a purely a stunt, Your Honor.”

Beside her, Ratcliff stood, pushing his glasses up his nose with an air of smug superiority that made Agatha’s hands itch to knock them clean off his face.

“Your Honor,” he said, his tone oily, “Ms. Harkness is alleging negligence against Vanguard, which necessitates further discovery with respect to duty of care.”

Duty of care.

Of course.

Trust the little rat to cling to that particular lifeline.

Ratcliff glanced at Agatha, his smirk practically daring her to try and sidestep the technicality.

“And naturally, that will take time.”

Agatha drummed her fingers on the desk, her mind working furiously. She’d anticipated pushback but hadn’t expected them to find a parachute so quickly. She felt a quick tug on her sleeve, and turned to see Rio looking up at her.

Agatha leaned down, and as soon as she did, Rio spoke.

“We could go after them for conspiracy,” she suggested, her tone careful but excited. “It’s a harder case to prove, and it opens us up to a counter-suit, but if this is the road you want to walk , then we need to shift from negligence to conspiracy.”

Agatha’s eyes lit up at the idea, as the thrill of a new tactic settled into her bones.

Rio and her big, beautiful fucking brain.

Straightening up, Agatha faced the judge with renewed confidence.

“Very well, Your Honor,” she said, her voice steady and razor-sharp. “Let’s forget negligence then. We’ll pursue wrongful act and conspiracy.”

The reaction was immediate.

Both Fox and Ratcliff shot up, their faces flushed with anger as they began talking over each other, their voices a mixture of outrage and panic.

“Your Honor, this is absurd—” Fox started, her voice shrill.

“This wasn’t in the original pleadings!” Ratcliff protested, his hands waving in disbelief.

Judge Marks banged his gavel, silencing the room as he gave them all a hard look.

Agatha kept her expression calm, but inside, she savored the chaos. The judge’s gaze turned to her, pinning her with a steady, scrutinizing look.

“Ms. Harkness, I want to ensure I understood you correctly. You’re willing to waive your negligence claim against Vanguard?”

“That’s correct, Your Honor,” she replied confidently.

Judge Marks's eyebrows rose, clearly taken aback.

“That is your strongest case, Ms. Harkness. Not to mention, pursuing conspiracy without negligence opens your firm up to a potential litigation suit should you fail.”

Agatha drew in a steadying breath, already imagining the look on Jen’s face when she heard about this decision.

“I understand, Judge,” she replied, her voice unwavering. “We will still be pursuing a conspiracy case against Vanguard.”

The look of shock on Fox and Ratcliff’s faces was priceless. Fox’s expression shifted from surprise to outrage.

“You’re really willing to waive the negligence claim?” she demanded, disbelief ringing in her voice.

Agatha gave a theatrical flourish of her hands, her tone calm and almost amused.

“I believe I just did.”

Turning her attention back to Judge Marks, she took a moment before speaking, letting her words settle over the room.

“The defense says Brooke Sinclair took her own life,” she began, her voice steady, clear. “ They claim the stress of her work caused a decline in her performance, which led to disciplinary action and, ultimately, to her alleged suicide.”

Her tone sharpened as she thought about Brooke, about the injustice to this young woman, and how the gaping hole her murder has left in her parent’s lives.

“We say Brooke Sinclair didn’t kill herself. We allege that she uncovered evidence suggesting Vanguard was illegally shipping weapons overseas. When she reported her findings to her supervisor, they disciplined her for the first time in her five-year career. And when she refused to back down, they had her killed to cover up their illegal acts.”

The room was thick with tension, Agatha’s accusation hanging heavy in the air.

Fox and Ratcliff sat their faces stoic, not even blinking at her accusation.

Judge Marks's gaze stayed on her for a moment longer before he turned to the opposing counsel, one brow raised in question—a silent prompt for their response.

Fox and Ratcliff immediately put their heads together, whispering urgently. Agatha drummed her fingers on the table, waiting with feigned patience as the seconds dragged into minutes.

Even Judge Marks's expression was turning impatient.

“Counsel,” he said his tone edged with warning.

Fox and Ratcliff murmured a few final words before Fox rose to her feet, her gaze flicking to Agatha.

The challenge in her eyes was unmistakable, and Agatha felt a flicker of satisfaction.

She knew what Fox was going to say even before she spoke.

“Your Honor,” Fox said, her voice steady, “we also call ready for trial.”

Judge Marks leaned back in his chair, momentarily taken aback by the unexpected turn of this status hearing. But then he seemed to collect himself, before gesturing to his court clerk.

“Call down for a voir dire panel, Beth,” he ordered. “Look like we have a jury to pick.”

The weight of his words settled over the room, and Agatha felt a surge of victory.

This was it —the case was officially moving forward, and every inch of her was ready to fight like hell.

Agatha paced the length of her kitchen, unable to shake the pulse of energy still thrumming through her veins.

The car had dropped her off nearly two hours ago, but the thrill of the day was alive, buzzing in every nerve of her body.

She’d won today.

She knew it.

Judge Marks knew it.

Hell, even Fox and Ratcliff knew it.

And Rio— god, the way Rio had looked at her afterward.

She definitely knew it.

The memory flashed through her mind, as vivid as if it were happening again. When they’d finally slipped into the privacy of the town car, Rio had looked at her like she was debating between pulling Agatha close, pressing her against the leather seats, or getting on her knees right there.

Agatha would have gladly taken either.

She always felt this way after a victory—this buzzing, restless energy that demanded release.

Good sex, the kind that left her wrecked, was the only thing that came close to calming her down.

She’d barely kept it together in the car as they pulled up to her building, turning to Rio with an uncharacteristic desperation she didn’t even bother to hide.

"Come over tonight?" she asked, her voice soft but intense, making sure to follow Rio’s rules and ask .

Rio’s eyes darkened, that unflinching gaze full of unspoken promises as she nodded.

“I need to go home first, get a few things straightened out,” she replied, her voice rough, low. “But I’ll be by as soon as I can.”

There was something about Rio’s voice, raw and edged with heat, that shot straight through her.

And yet, Agatha had an inkling that the woman had nothing pressing to handle. Knowing Rio, she was probably just letting Agatha stew—making her sit while being impossibly turned on.

But Agatha would take anything Rio offered right now.

She was that desperate.

She nodded, moving to get out of the car, but Rio’s hand wrapped around her arm, halting her.

“Do not even think about touching yourself before I get there,” Rio warned, her voice low and commanding.

The words sent a jolt through Agatha, her heart thudding hard in her chest. She hadn’t planned on it, but now that Rio had forbidden it, the idea was suddenly, achingly tempting.

Rio’s eyes narrowed, reading the mischief brewing in Agatha’s gaze.

“ Agatha ,” she warned, her tone steely.

Agatha scoffed, slipping out of Rio’s grasp with an air of nonchalance.

“Okay—fine!” she said, throwing her hands up in mock surrender, sounding almost like a petulant teenager being told they couldn’t go to a party. “No pre-game before the game. Vibe killer. ”

True to her word, she didn’t touch herself.

Instead, she was now on her third glass of bourbon and had hit her 10,000-step goal just pacing her apartment like a caged tiger. Every time she glanced at her phone seeing the clock — of valuable time being wasted —her anticipation flared hotter, her patience wearing thin.

Finally —a knock at the door.

Did she scramble embarrassingly fast to answer it?

Yes.

Did she pause outside the door to take a couple of steadying breaths so it wouldn’t look like she’d just sprinted across the room?

Also, yes.

Once composed, Agatha swung open the door and took in the sight of Rio. She was wearing dark jeans and a sleek black jacket, her casual look somehow only heightening the anticipation building in Agatha. But then her eyes narrowed as she noticed something unexpected.

She raised an eyebrow, her voice laced with mockery as she crossed her arms and stared at Rio.

“Why are you wearing a backpack? What are you, twelve?”

Rio’s eyebrow arched at the question, and that familiar, predatory smirk spread across her face, making Agatha’s confidence waver ever so slightly.

Agatha was beginning to recognize what that look meant.

Oh.

What the hell did Rio Vidal have planned for her tonight?

Chapter End Notes

I was hoping to get to the steamy part in this chapter, but I already hit 5,000+ words by the end, and I really want to do the next sexy scene justice and not rush it ;)

Primal Night

Chapter Summary

The world is falling a part, so here is my little attempt at trying to provide something to make the day better.

Agatha sat on her bed, nursing her drink, her eyes fixed on Rio standing in front of her.

There was a certain dramatic flair to Rio tonight, a kind of quiet performance that felt both irritating and magnetic. Agatha couldn’t help but wonder if her little speech from the town car —about commanding the “theater” of a courtroom, about wielding power through presence—had somehow inspired Rio to lean into her power even more, to become bolder, a little spicier than usual.

As always, Rio had entered Agatha’s home like she owned it, gliding through the doorway and making her way straight to the bedroom without a word. Agatha followed because she knew if she didn’t, Rio would just stand there waiting for her anyways.

As soon as she entered the room, Rio’s expression was unreadable, but the raised eyebrow and subtle tilt of her head said it all: Go sit down.

Agatha had rolled her eyes but complied, making her way to the bed, sinking down with her drink, her patience already wearing thin. She sat there, drink in hand, watching Rio’s every movement, the restless energy in her making it impossible to stay silent for more than twenty seconds.

With an exaggerated sigh, Agatha flicked her hand sharply, signaling her silent command: “Well? Get on with it.”

She wasn’t the least bit surprised when Rio didn’t budge, didn’t even blink.

She simply stood there, gaze unwavering, meeting Agatha’s impatience with steady calm. The silence stretched, lingering until Agatha realized the play, Rio was making it painfully clear —Agatha wasn’t in charge anymore, and would not be dictating when they started.

Agatha’s lips pressed together, frustration simmering beneath the surface. She busied herself with her drink, taking a slow sip as if the act itself could distract her from the tension Rio was creating.

She hated it , but she knew— unfortunately —that this was the game she’d agreed to play with Rio, and tonight, she was on Rio’s terms.

Finally, after what felt like an eternity, Rio moved.

She slipped the black backpack off her shoulder, and with a calculated toss, let it sail through the air and fall onto Agatha’s bed, landing beside her with a heavy thud that seemed to echo through the room.

Agatha’s gaze dropped to the bag, the weight of whatever Rio had brought settling heavily beside her—not just in its contents, but the energy of the moment she was creating.

Agatha looked up, meeting Rio's gaze, feeling her own curiosity twist with a hint of challenge.

But Rio's face betrayed nothing—there was however, a dark satisfaction in her eyes, almost smug, as though she was savoring the fact that Agatha was out of the loop, missing something important.

What the hell was in this bag?

For a split second, Agatha wondered if she was missing some secret signal, some unspoken code.

Finally, after what felt like an eternity of silence, Rio gave a small nod toward the bag, her eyes never leaving Agatha’s.

“Open it.”

The words were calm, almost too casual, but they landed with the weight of a challenge that hung heavy in the air.

Agatha glanced down at the bag, then back up at Rio, hating the thrill that shot through her.

She could feel the deliberate drama Rio was weaving around her, each second ticking by with excruciating slowness. Curiosity clawed at her resolve, gnawing away until she couldn’t help herself. She reached out, grabbing the bag, feeling its weight in her hands—not heavy, but something .

Slowly, she slid the zipper open, the sound slicing through the silence as she peeled back the fabric and peered inside.

Oh.

Her heart lurched as she realized what she was looking at, and then both a dark thrill laced disbelief moved through her chest.

She looked up at Rio, who was watching her intently, those dark eyes fixed on her like a predator waiting to savor every flicker of reaction crossing Agatha’s face.

Agatha swallowed, her fingers lingering on the bag before she set it aside, leaving it open. She took a slow, sip of her drink, trying to gather her scattered thoughts, steady her pulse, and find the right words.

What did one even say to that ?

Finally, she arched an eyebrow, her voice not as steady as she would have liked but made sure to lace with extra dry humor to mask it.

“Isn’t that a bit... redundant?” she said, gesturing dismissively toward the bag. “If I wanted that , wouldn’t I just... fuck a man?”

Rio tilted her head, one brow arching as she met Agatha’s challenge with a maddeningly calm expression.

“You like penetration, Agatha,” she replied, her tone dry and factual as if she were citing case law that was built on rock solid precedence. In this case, the precedence, being the sheer amount of times Agatha has cum while Rio’s fingers were buried inside her.

Agatha felt her skin flush at that.

“Most women do,” she shot back, finishing her drink and realizing too late that her glass was empty. She stared at it, as if sheer willpower might summon more, because god, she was going to need half a bottle to get through this damn night.

“So... what’s to say you won’t enjoy this too?” Rio asked, her voice low, her gaze flickering to the bag and then back to Agatha.

Her lips curled into a wicked smirk.

“Can you imagine it? Feeling me inside you like that , while I still have both hands free... nothing holding me back?”

The words, spoken with Rio's signature confidence, sent an involuntary shiver down Agatha’s spine. Her mouth went dry, and her defiance wavered under Rio’s steady gaze. She wanted to roll her eyes, to snap out a dismissive retort—but her mind betrayed her, already filling with images of exactly what Rio was describing.

But the words wouldn’t come.

Her throat was tight, her breath caught.

This wasn’t what she’d expected.

She was still getting used to normal lesbian sex—with Rio’s finger and mouth sending her over the edge, and vice versa.

This felt like a leap into something deeper, more consuming.

She could certainly feel herself drawn toward it, and yet the vulnerability—of allowing Rio that much control over her—caused an uncomfortable pull in her chest.

Rio seemed to read the turmoil on her face, as if Agatha’s thoughts were projected for her to see.

The smirk faded, her expression softening as she stepped forward. The intensity in her eyes remained, but it was gentled, like she was setting aside her predatory edge for something more sincere.

“Remember—you hold all the cards here, Agatha,” Rio murmured, her voice warm and reassuring as she closed the distance between them.

She reached out, taking the empty glass from Agatha’s hand and setting it carefully on the nightstand, never once breaking eye contact.

When she turned back, she cupped Agatha’s cheek with a tenderness that stole the breath from Agatha’s lungs, her thumb gently stroking her skin.

“I will never— ever —do anything to you that you don’t want,” she said softly, her voice barely above a whisper. “Say the word, and the bag goes away.”

Agatha glanced down at the bag, the contents still an undeniable presence between them. She swallowed hard, images of what she’d seen inside flickering in her mind.

“It just seems...like a lot,” she muttered, cringing slightly at how hesitant her voice sounded.

She hated sounding vulnerable.

“It’s above average,” Rio replied smoothly, without missing a beat.

It took Agatha a second to register Rio’s words, and when she did, a snort escaped her—an unexpected laugh breaking through her tension. She could feel the knot in her chest loosen, just a little .

She couldn’t help the smile that crept onto her face, as she swatted playfully at Rio’s hip.

“I didn’t mean the size, you asshole .”

Rio’s lips curved into that smile— the real one —and Agatha’s heart was hammering for a very different reason now.

Without breaking eye contact, Rio reached down, hooking her finger gently under Agatha’s chin, tilting her face up to meet her gaze. Dark eyes searched hers, steady and calm, a softness in them that sent a wave of warmth through Agatha’s chest.

“Would it be easier for you,” Rio murmured, her voice soft, “if you were the one wearing it?”

Agatha’s eyes widened, new images flooding her mind, and the suggestion caught her completely off guard.

Jesus—this woman was truly trying to kill her.

Her mouth opened, but the words didn’t come immediately, lingering as she grappled with her own surprise.

Finally, she managed, “You’d honestly let me do that to you?” she asked, her tone dripping with skepticism.

She needed to test Rio.

To call out what had to be a bluff.

But then that smile reappeared, that confident— real —knowing smile, and Rio’s fingers traced a light path along Agatha’s jaw, sending a shiver down her spine.

“ Oh, Agatha ,” Rio murmured, voice soft and low, like a promise. “There is very little I wouldn’t let you do to me.”

Agatha’s pulse quickened, Rio’s words wrapping around her, sinking into her chest.

The way Rio looked at her, like she’d hand over her control to Agatha without hesitation, sent both thrill and disbelief coursing through her. Agatha swallowed, trying to keep her composure, but the weight of Rio’s gaze made it nearly impossible.

She could feel Rio’s fingers still gently tracing her jaw, grounding her, and yet making her feel like she was teetering on the edge of something unfamiliar and thrilling.

Her breath came a little faster, the last shreds of her defiance slipping as she felt herself leaning into Rio’s touch.

“You’re serious about this,” Agatha finally managed, voice barely steady.

Rio gave her a look, that subtle smirk coming back.

“Have you ever known me not to be serious when we’re like this?” Rio murmured, leaning in close, her voice a low, intimate rasp, lips hovering just a breath away from Agatha’s ear.

“If you want to be control, Agatha...”

Her words were a challenge and a promise, slipping into Agatha’s skin like heat.

“Then you can be in control.”

She pulled back slowly, meeting Agatha’s gaze head-on, her eyes daring, intense.

“Is that what you want?” she asked, her voice dropping even lower, a velvet softness that seemed to coil right around Agatha’s heart— squeezing .

Agatha’s heart beat faster, as if both fighting against Rio’s hold on and responding to the question that hung in the air.

Before Rio, she wouldn’t have hesitated, wouldn’t have even considered another option. Control was her armor, her currency, her way of keeping the world and everyone in it exactly where she wanted.

But now?

Now, she hesitated.

Rio watched her intently, her gaze unwavering— waiting .

Agatha could feel that familiar thrill bubbling up, the one Rio always seemed to draw out of her, making her question the rules she’d lived by, the rules she’d made to protect herself.

Other Rio , the one who held her with quiet tenderness after the intensity, the one who looked at her like she was something precious—that Rio affected Agatha in ways she didn’t want to name, in ways that made her ache for something she hadn’t even known she wanted.

Then, a few seconds later, the glass shower door opened, and Agatha turned, momentarily breathless at the sight before her.

Rio stood there, bare and beautiful, her dark eyes locked onto Agatha’s, filled with a blend of intensity and something softer, unguarded. She stepped into the shower, her gaze never wavering, a hesitant smile playing at the corners of her mouth before she deadpanned.

"You couldn’t have asked me to join you before I got dressed?”

Agatha’s heart fluttered at that, a smile breaking across her lips as Rio closed the distance, sliding her arms around Agatha’s waist and pulling her close under the stream of water. Agatha brought her hands up, fingers tracing over Rio’s shoulders before threading through her now-damp hair.

“Now, Rio,” she murmured, voice a low hum as her nails raked gently along Rio’s scalp, her lips hovering just a breath away. “Where’s the fun in that?”

She leaned in, her lips brushing over Rio’s in a teasing whisper before deepening the kiss, feeling Rio huff against her, exasperated yet smiling as she kissed back, her grin never leaving, until she pulled back abruptly and looked at Agatha.

Rio reached up, her fingers trailing softly along Agatha’s face, tracing the steady paths where water streamed down her skin. Her touch was reverent, lingering, her gaze filled with a raw intensity that Agatha could feel down to her bones.

“Agatha,” she whispered, voice barely audible above the rush of water. “ What are we doing? ”

Agatha’s breath caught, her pulse quickening as she met Rio’s gaze.

Agatha stared back at Rio, momentarily speechless.

Rio was asking her ?

As if Agatha had the answers, as if she knew what they hell they doing.

She didn’t have a fucking clue.

She opened her mouth to speak, to say something, anything, but the words tangled in her throat.

Suddenly her heart lurched painfully, betraying her, the weight of feelings she’d been keeping at bay crashing forward, flooding her chest, threatening to spill out in ways she wasn’t ready to face.

Agatha shut her mouth, swallowing hard, forcing those unruly emotions back down.

She couldn’t bring herself to say it, to admit how Rio had begun to burrow past the casual, past the physical, into something she hadn’t wanted to name.
