She was terrified —terrified of exposing the truth of what this was becoming for her.

Agatha could give Rio power over her body—but her heart?

That is where she drew the line.

So, Agatha did what she always did when emotions threatened to consume her—she ran.

She is where Nicky got it from.

The urge to retreat, to push back when feelings got to intense.

But instead of rushing out of the shower, she ran back to the beginning—back to the simplicity of how it was when they started this game and and what she desperately needed them to continue to be.

Agatha slid her hands down to Rio’s hips, applying just enough pressure to guide her back, one slow, deliberate step at a time, until Rio’s back pressed firmly against the wall, her body caged by Agatha’s.

Rio watched her, eyes moving across her face—searching, waiting .

Agatha held Rio’s gaze, a fire simmering in her own, before slowly, deliberately, dropping to her knees.

And in an instant— that vulnerability Rio had shown moments ago vanished.

Her eyes hardening, guarded—reading Agatha’s move for what it was.

Agatha answered Rio’s question not with words, but with actions.

This was about sex.

That’s what it started as, and that’s what it needed to stay.

She had to keep it simple, keep it controlled.

After all, Rio had set the rules.

Don’t fall in love with me.

That is what Rio had said to Agatha.

Agatha had understood then, and she reminded herself now—if feelings got involved, she’d end up breaking Rio or vice versa— Rio would destroy her .

So, she dropped her gaze from Rio’s eyes—pushing down that ache in her chest, and leaned forward, her mouth moving between Rio’s legs, feeling Rio’s moan ripple through her.

Rio’s fingers tightened in her hair, her breath coming in quick, uneven bursts, but Agatha focused on her own control, on the movement, on the rhythm. She ignored the whispers in her mind, the pull in her heart that wanted more, that wanted the impossible.

Because this— this was safer.

This was familiar.

This was what they both needed.

Nothing more.

They were late to work. Rio, naturally, arrived even later, having to stop by her own apartment first. Agatha briefly considered making a show of Rio’s near-hour-late entrance— she could almost see the look on her face—but thought better of it. After all, Agatha was the reason for Rio’s tardiness.

When Rio finally slipped into the war room, she moved seamlessly, prepping files for the trial, and everything seemed to fall back into place.

Or so Agatha thought.

But as the day went by Agatha started noticing something unsettling.

Rio was still Rio—sharp, quick-witted, with that cocky edge—but something felt off.

Her smiles seemed dimmer, her teasing—forced.

And most noticeable, and something Agatha zeroed in on immediately, Rio had stopped doing something that had always set Agatha on edge: she no longer looked her.

It took Agatha 5 minutes during a prep meeting for voir dire to notice it.

And once she noticed it, it was glaring.

Agatha made it through nearly an hour in the war room without once feeling Rio’s gaze on her. Rio took notes, flipped through documents, spoke to her as if everything were perfectly normal—but didn’t look up.

Not once.

Then there was the most glaring sign that something was wrong.

Rio hadn’t touched her.

No casual graze of a hand.

No slipping into her space, daring Agatha to react.

And most importantly— no sex.

At first, Agatha thought it might be a game. Maybe Rio was keeping her on edge, building tension so that the next touch, the next moment, would be all the more intense.

But then one day slipped to one—then two, and then three.

And then last night happened.

Agatha decided to take matters into her own hands and asked for Rio to come over.

She actually fucking asked.

And she watched the moment Rio read her message.

And then—it just sat there just like that.

Nothing but silence.

She fucking left Agatha on read.

Agatha would love to think she didn’t stare at that message for ten straight minutes, willing a reply to appear. She’d like to pretend she didn’t toss and turn in bed all night , jolting awake at every phantom vibration, only to find nothing but silence staring back at her.

The next morning, Agatha felt every restless minute of her sleepless night weighing her down.

She’d slept like shit.

And now, she stood gripping the countertop, leaning over it with a heavy sigh, fighting the urge to check her phone.

But the urge won out.

She turned her head and stared down at it, finally reaching over, tapping the screen to bring it to life. Her fingers moved automatically, entering her code and opening her messages.

Her message to Rio still sat there, unanswered, glowing up at her mockingly.

A painful lurch twisted in her chest, sharper and more unsettling than anything she’d ever felt with Rio before.

This wasn’t the usual thrill or tension she could lean on to keep her somehow both on edge and steady.

Instead, this was a raw, anxious ache coiled inside her, making her stomach flip. Her hand came up instinctively, pressing against her chest, and she felt her heart hammering beneath her fingertips, each beat pulsing with that unfamiliar, relentless ache.

She let out a sharp breath, and ripped her hand from heart like she was burnt and flipped her phone over, as if that could somehow make the feeling go away.

It didn’t.

Agatha looked up, meeting her own gaze in the mirror.

As she stared at herself, the anxiety in her chest shifted, hardening, transforming into something hotter.

Anger .

Rio was playing a dangerous game.

With a very dangerous woman.

Agatha was a storm from the moment she stepped into the office. The office’s Defcon levels rose steadily with each passing hour. By midday, they were at Defcon 3—multiple associates hiding tears behind closed doors, Jen glaring at her from behind the safety of her glass door, and Billy visibly trembling every time he entered her office.

The only person unfazed, of course, was the one she most wanted to crack.

Rio barely batted an eye when Agatha shredded her meticulously crafted witness preparation report, throwing it back with a scathing remark about her “sudden lack of competence.”

Then, Agatha nearly threw her a stack of contracts into Rio’s hands—tasks she’d usually hand off to a contract specialist, given how grueling the work was. And not only that, she demanded they be completed by the end of the day, fully aware it was an impossible deadline.

Rio only frowned slightly at the pile in her hands, and Agatha didn’t miss the way her gaze lingered somewhere over her left shoulder, deliberately avoiding eye contact.

As Rio turned and walked back to the war room without a word, Agatha felt her jaw tighten, her teeth grinding as irritation flared inside her.

Agatha turned her chair away, staring out at the city skyline, her fingers tapping restlessly against the armrest. She barely managed twenty seconds of silence before a knock tapped on the glass behind her. Already bristling, she snapped, “WHAT?” before even turning around, only to find Billy standing there, swallowing nervously.

“Your reservation at Carmine’s with Summit Ventures is confirmed for 7:00 PM. I just wanted to check if you still wanted the emergency call set for an hour into the meeting?”

Summit Ventures —Agatha had almost forgotten.

The annual client meeting with her absolute least favorite group. Not because they engaged in any worse behavior than the average investment firm—they were plenty ethically questionable actions, but no more so than the rest.

The real issue was the team itself: a pack of overgrown frat boys who inevitably got drunk and spent the night making passes at her.

Her own personal nightmare.

That’s why she’d established a longstanding plan with Billy: an “emergency” call precisely one hour in. For five years running, they hadn’t caught on. By the time she made her exit, they’d always be too blissfully drunk to notice.

Agatha was about to confirm the usual plan when, out of the corner of her eye, she spotted Rio in the war room, brow furrowed as she stared down at a stack of contracts. Agatha could see she wasn’t struggling, per se, but Rio was clearly out of her element, and the frustration showed on her face.

A thrill sparked in Agatha.

Good.

If Rio wanted to play with her emotions, then Agatha would return the—

—suddenly, an idea struck her, bringing a wicked smile to her lips.

She remembered the look Rio had given her when she was casually flirting with a bartender back at the Red Light when they went to that drag night looking for Kelcie Baker. She remembered the dark, possessive look that marred Rio face that screamed that the woman didn’t know if she wanted to fuck Agatha right then and there or punch the bartender in the face.

And that had been before they’d ever slept together.

The thrill that shot through her now was almost enough to overpower the ache Rio had left her with after ignoring her message.

Agatha turned back to Billy, who had stopped in his tracks, wide-eyed at the sudden wicked smile on her face. He’d seen that look enough to know it meant T-R-O-U-B-L-E.

“No,” she said. “No call this time. I think it’s time I give my full attention to Summit Ventures.”

Billy blinked, visibly thrown off but nodded. He turned to leave, but Agatha held up a hand, stopping him.

“Tell Rio Vidal she’ll be attending the client meeting with me,” Agatha said smoothly, picking up a random sheet of paper on her desk and feigning interest in it. “The contracts can

wait till tomorrow. It’s time she gets her feet wet in client relations.”

Agatha heard Billy leave and pretended to study the already-approved report in her hand, holding the act for a few seconds before dragging her gaze up toward the war room.

Billy was standing in front of Rio, speaking to her, and Agatha didn’t miss the exact moment he mentioned the client meeting. Rio’s posture shifted, her shoulders stiffening, and after a heartbeat, she flicked her gaze toward Agatha’s office.

And for the first time in days, Rio met her eyes.

Agatha—refused to look away. She held Rio’s gaze, tilting her head slightly and jutting her chin forward.

The look she gave Rio said it all.

You want to play? Then put a fucking helmet on, because this is going to be a rough ride.

Chapter End Notes

Hello, this is your captain speaking. Please, fasten your seat belts, return the tray tables to their locked and upright positions, as we seem to be experiencing a little turbulence.

This Road is Wild and Wicked

From the moment Agatha met Rio Vidal, it was as if she’d been set on a path— a road crafted to challenge her at every turn.

The first forced her to confront her own sexuality, a part of herself she’d long buried in shadows, never believing it would come to light.

Then came the test of control, surrendering pieces of herself to someone else, allowing Rio to push her beyond her preconceived limits.

She’d barely made it through those first two trials. But once she’d cleared them, the freedom and peace she discovered on the other side made every moment of turmoil worth it.

It was as though this road was giving her parts of herself she hadn’t known were missing.

And now, as she stood outside the dark wooden door marked with a golden number 4, she recognized the weight of the next trial.

Just like before, she knew she had a choice—face it or turn around and walk away.

But this one— Agatha could feel it in her bones —was different.

This trial was bigger than the others, more dangerous , and if she was honest with herself, far more terrifying.

Every step on this road felt like she was gambling a part of herself.

And this one?

This one had the power to completely unravel her.

To break her in ways she’d never risked before.

As she stood there, staring at that unassuming golden number on the door, her heart hammered, and for the first time in a long time, Agatha felt genuinely afraid. It wasn’t just her pride or her carefully constructed walls at stake.

It was her entire sense of self, everything she had worked to build and protect.

And now, she was on the edge of a precipice, facing a choice that could either deepen the peace she’d found within herself—or destroy it entirely.

But Agatha made her decision last night. There was no backing down. Sink or swim, she was doing this.

And with that thought, Agatha squared her shoulders and moved to raise her hand to knock, only to realize with a frustrated sigh—that her hands were full.

She rolled her eyes at herself, mentally kicking herself for her own lack of foresight.

“Fuck it,” she muttered, straightening up.

Then, with a quick flick of her leg, she rapped the toe of her boot against the door in a few sharp, determined knocks.

And then—she held her breath.

12 hours earlier.

Agatha’s emotions were like jagged shards of glass, sharp and relentless, cutting deeper with every second she spent beside Rio in the back of the town car. Rio didn’t so much as glance her way. Instead, she sat stiffly, her body angled away, fingers absently tracing the hem of her sleeve.

It was as if the air around Agatha had grown toxic and Rio couldn’t bear to breathe it.

By the time they arrived at the restaurant, the silence was so thick it felt suffocating. Not a single word passed between them as they were led to their table, nor as they took their seats. Rio’s eyes roamed everywhere but toward Agatha, and her face was a perfect, unreadable mask.

When the server finally approached, breaking the silence, Rio ordered a water, her voice calm and detached.

Agatha’s chest tightened.

“I’ll have a double bourbon,” she said smoothly, her tone masking the raw edge she felt inside.

As the server left, Agatha kept her gaze fixed on Rio, who seemed suddenly engrossed in the menu, her eyes skating over the options with a practiced indifference. She didn’t flinch, didn’t so much as react to the way Agatha’s eyes bored into her.

This was a game, Agatha reminded herself—a game Rio had chosen to play. And if Rio thought she could keep Agatha at arm’s length and leave her questioning, raw and aching, she was sorely mistaken.

Agatha unable to help herself, leaned back, folding her arms, her voice dropping to a low, dangerous.

“It’s impressive,” she murmured, “how committed you are to pretending I’m invisible.”

Rio barely flinched, but Agatha saw the subtle signs—the tight clench of her jaw, the way her fingers gripped the edges of the menu just a bit harder.

Agatha wanted to push further, but the loud, brash laughter from the front of the restaurant pulled her attention away. Her eyes darted instinctively toward the source of the noise. She recognized it immediately. Five men walked in, their voices filling the space as they made their way toward the dining area.

The founding members of Summit Ventures.

Each of them was dressed in sharp, tailored suits, their hair and beards perfectly groomed. They were handsome, in that polished, almost-too-perfect way—if you didn’t know them, you might think they were the kind of men Agatha would be interested in. But she knew better.

They were absolute assholes.

Three out of the five wore wedding rings, and those three were the worst offenders—always the first to hit on her, with an overconfident smirk and a line that felt like it belonged in a frat house.

At the sound of laughter, Rio’s head lifted, her gaze following Agatha’s to the group of men approaching their table. Agatha watched Rio’s face as she took them in, reading them with those sharp, dark eyes, immediately sizing them up and seeing them for what they were. Then, just as quickly, her gaze snapped back to Agatha’s, and for once, she held her eye.

Agatha didn’t flinch, meeting Rio’s gaze head-on, her expression unyielding, confirming what Rio must have suspected.

Yes , her eyes and smug smirk seemed to say, that’s why I brought you here.

Agatha saw the moment Rio understood.

She waited, expecting that familiar spark of anger to flicker in Rio’s eyes, for that dark possessiveness to ignite, to rise to Agatha’s challenge.

But instead, a second passed, and then another. Rio’s expression didn’t harden or flash with anger.

Then Rio blinked, and something shifted—a quiet, raw hurt settled behind her eyes, unguarded and vulnerable, stealing the breath from Agatha’s lungs.

Oh .

Agatha felt the realization hit her_._

She hadn’t expected that.

She’d anticipated anger, maybe even a defiant spark or a subtle challenge.

But this?

This flicker of hurt, so raw and unguarded, caught Agatha entirely off guard. It lingered in Rio’s gaze, as if, just for a moment, Rio lost that iron grip over her emotions. And once it slipped free, she couldn’t push it back behind her usual emotionless mask.

For a moment, Agatha’s mind went blank.

She had orchestrated this whole setup as a way to push Rio, to make her feel the tension she’d been feeling, to draw out some reaction. But she hadn’t accounted for the possibility that her little game might cut deeper than she intended.

Agatha swallowed hard, her pulse quickening as she took in Rio’s expression.

Abruptly, Rio looked away, reclaiming her control piece by piece as her mask slid slowly back into place.

But Agatha found herself at a loss of words. She still parted her lips to speak—though what she intended to say, she couldn’t quite grasp. Her heart hammered against her ribs, each beat urging her to tell Rio to leave, to go home.

She wasn’t needed here.

First-year associates didn’t attend client meetings, and Agatha had only brought her along to force her hand, to draw her into this twisted game. She made a mistake by asking Rio to come here.

But her hesitation became her downfall.

“Agatha!” a voice called from across the restaurant, and the Summit Ventures men spotted her, their voices loud and brimming with confidence as they strode toward the table. Agatha forced herself to look away from Rio, swallowing down the emotions that threatened to rise, and slipped on her professional mask as she stood to greet them.

Rio stood as well, though the men’s attention was locked solely on Agatha, grins plastered on their faces as they approached. Each one went in for a hug, which Agatha reluctantly accepted, masking her discomfort with a carefully measured smile. One of the more forward men leaned in, pressing an all-too-familiar kiss to her cheek, punctuated by a wink as he pulled back and took his seat.

She managed a polite smile, but every nerve in her body buzzed with irritation—and somewhere beneath it, that ache in her chest where Rio’s pain now lived.

The dinner went exactly as Agatha had expected. Business talk was minimal, confined to a few perfunctory remarks about the upcoming quarter and vague mentions of “big

opportunities.” Drinks, on the other hand, flowed freely, with each man ordering another round as soon as his glass was even halfway empty.

With each refill, their voices grew louder, their laughter sloppier, and their tongues looser. Compliments became more brazen, slipping from polite to suggestive, punctuated by looks that lingered a little too long and gestures that edged just past appropriate.

Agatha kept her smile carefully measured, her gaze level, deflecting the comments with practiced ease. It wasn’t her first Summit Ventures dinner, and it wouldn’t be the last. But tonight, with Rio seated beside her, silent and observing, every comment grated just a bit more.

She could feel Rio’s presence, her quiet watchfulness. Out of the corner of her eye, she caught the way Rio’s jaw tightened each time one of the men leaned a little too close or let his hand brush Agatha’s arm. Yet, Rio stayed silent, her expression unreadable, offering no reaction beyond that simmering tension just beneath the surface.

Agatha’s own irritation flared with each passing moment, her patience wearing thin. She had thought bringing Rio here would spark something—a reaction, a confrontation, something— but now, it was a test of endurance, each second stretching longer as she navigated the dinner and tried to ignore the ache lingering just beneath her ribs.

Suddenly, Rio rose from her seat, murmuring a quick, polite excuse before heading to the bathroom. Agatha’s gaze followed her, the ache in her chest growing with every step Rio took away from the table, like a storm building within her.

Then she caught it—a flicker of movement as one of the men leaned back in his chair, his eyes following Rio’s departure, lingering shamelessly on the curve of her ass.

Something inside Agatha snapped, a hot, possessive anger flaring to life and consuming the ache that had been simmering just beneath her ribs.

She clenched her jaw, forcing herself to keep her expression neutral, though she could feel her pulse racing, every instinct screaming to put him in his place. She took a slow, deliberate breath, her eyes narrowing as she turned to the man, her voice steady but cold.

“Is there something particularly interesting about my associate’s departure?” she asked, her words laced with an edge sharp enough to cut.

The table went silent, the laughter and casual remarks evaporating as Agatha’s words sliced through the air. The man she’d called out raised his hands in mock surrender, a smirk tugging at his lips as he gave her a look that all but say, c an you blame me?

Agatha’s fingers curled into fists beneath the table, the urge to wipe that smug expression off his face pulsing through her. If these men didn’t collectively manage a portfolio worth fifty million dollars, she wouldn’t have hesitated.

Instead, she kept her expression cool, her eyes fixed on him with a warning that said enough. After a moment, the man cleared his throat, a slight blush creeping up his neck as he quickly

reached for his glass, avoiding her gaze.

The rest of the table shifted awkwardly, some of the men exchanging glances—not expecting Agatha to call them out. She never had before.

Agatha fought to steady her emotions, but control was slipping through her fingers.

Oh...how the tables had turned.

She’d brought Rio here tonight to provoke her, to make her jealous, maybe even possessive. Yet here she was, seething with the urge to tear that man apart for daring to look at Rio like that.

With a tight breath, she tossed her napkin onto the table.

“Excuse me, gentlemen,” she murmured, standing and striding away from the table, her steps quick and purposeful. But as she neared the bathroom, her pace slowed, the reality of Rio’s presence on the other side of the door suddenly pressing down on her.

She hesitated just outside, fingers flexing at her sides. She could still feel the men’s eyes on her from across the restaurant, watching, expectant. She couldn’t exactly turn back now. Gritting her teeth, she pushed the door open and stepped inside.

She didn’t know what she was about to walk into, but the moment her heels clicked from wood to tile, she froze.

The door swung shut behind Agatha with a soft thud, cutting off the restaurant’s noise and leaving her enveloped in a silence that felt thick, pressing, almost suffocating.

Her heart pounded, every nerve on high alert, as her eyes landed on Rio, standing at the sink, dabbing carefully beneath her eyes with a tissue. Rio looked up, catching Agatha’s reflection in the mirror. Her eyes widened briefly before she quickly looked away, crumpling the tissue in her fist.

Rio was... she was crying.

Agatha’s heart didn’t just lurch—it felt like it cracked open, the sharp pain so unexpected it left her paralyzed, as if her blood had turned to ice.

“Rio...” she started, but her voice trailed off, the words slipping away before they could fully form.

Rio’s jaw clenched, a flush rising to her cheeks as she looked anywhere but at Agatha, clearly not expecting her to walk in and definitely not wanting to be seen like this.

“Don’t give yourself too much credit,” Rio murmured, her voice soft but echoing in the quiet room. “This isn’t just about you—I’m just...frustrated with myself. That’s all.”

Agatha’s mind went blank. She didn’t know what to say, didn’t know if she even remembered how to speak. She stood there, frozen, staring at Rio like a complete fucking idiot.

Finally, she managed to snap out of it, but instead of replying, she reached into her purse, pulling out her phone. She unlocked it with a few quick taps, then brought it to her ear.

The moment the person on the other end picked up, she spoke, her voice quiet and steady.

“Bring the car around,” she said softly, then ended the call and slipped the phone back into her purse.

Agatha took a step forward, her gaze locked on Rio, even as Rio tried to salvage the last shred of vulnerability she hadn’t meant for Agatha to see.

“Rio,” Agatha said again, her voice steady this time, with no hesitation.

Rio surprised her by looking up, meeting her head-on.

“Go to the car,” Agatha said, not as a command but as a quiet offer, an out.

Rio sucked in a breath, clearly understanding what Agatha was giving her—a way to escape without saying a word. She stared at Agatha for a long moment, as if weighing her decision, before nodding.

She moved to step around her, but Agatha’s hand instinctively reached out, fingers pressing gently into Rio’s arm, stopping her by her side.

Rio kept her gaze lowered, but Agatha could hear the shaky breath that escaped her.

“I’m sorry,” Agatha murmured, the words surprising even herself.

She didn’t apologize often.

To apologize meant admitting she was wrong, and Agatha prided herself on rarely— if ever —being wrong.

But here, she’d misread everything.

She hadn’t once even considered that Rio’s silence wasn’t some calculated game to mess with her but something Rio needed for herself, her own space to deal with whatever she was going through.

Her fingers softened against Rio’s arm, and for a long moment, Agatha simply stood there, heart heavy, torn between the urge to reach bring her closer and the instinct to let Rio go.

Finally, Agatha lowered her hand, and it was as if that single gesture was all Rio needed. The moment her hand fell, Rio slipped away, crossing the room and disappearing through the door. The sounds of the restaurant flooded into the bathroom briefly, then faded again as the door swung shut, sealing Agatha back into the thick, pressing silence.

Agatha let out a heavy sigh, planting her hands on her hips and tilting her head back, staring up as if the answer to how she’d managed to mess this up so badly might be written somewhere in the ceiling tiles. She could be a self-centered piece of shit sometimes, and she

knew it. The moment Rio had gone quiet, she’d taken it as a personal affront, never once stopping to consider that maybe—just maybe—it wasn’t about her.

“What are we doing, Agatha?”

Rio’s question from that morning in the shower echoed in her mind, growing louder, taking on a haunting, almost ghostly presence that lingered in the silence of the bathroom.

Agatha turned to the mirror, her gaze hardening as she took in her own reflection. Outwardly, she looked the same—impeccably put together, her sharp suit pristine, her makeup flawless. But beneath that polished exterior, she could see the cracks, the strain she worked so hard to hide. Her heart hammered against her ribs, pulsing with a relentless urgency that seemed to echo through her entire body, demanding her attention.

She let herself really look this time, she saw the tension in her jaw, the faint shadows beneath her eyes, the guarded look she gave even to herself. This was more than just exhaustion; it was the weight of choices and regrets.

And as she stood there, Agatha couldn’t escape the feeling clawing its way to the surface—an insistence, almost a plea, urging her to confront the truth she’d been so carefully avoiding.

The thing between her and Rio was rapidly evolving into something else, something dangerous—feelings were getting involved. Clearly, based on Rio’s reaction these past few days, they already were. And, Agatha could admit, reluctantly, that it wasn’t one-sided.

But the real question was, what were they going to do about it?

What are we doing, Agatha?

When she’d returned from the bathroom, she feigned being on a call, flashing the men an apologetic smile as she claimed she’d been called in for an emergency meeting. She’d handed her credit card to the waitress, instructing her to keep the tab open, which the men appreciated. Thankfully, none of them had tried to touch her as she left, likely remembering the warning glare she’d shot their way before excusing herself.

Agatha made her way out of the restaurant toward her waiting town car. Dan was already there, holding the door open for her. She slipped inside, and he closed the door firmly behind her, sealing her into the quiet, confined space.

Rio sat next to her, eyes fixed out the window, her posture tense, clearly intent on ignoring Agatha’s presence.

Within seconds, the car pulled smoothly away from the curb, leaving the restaurant—but the unresolved tension was alive and well now in the back of the car.

Agatha’s fingers tapped anxiously against her leg as she searched for a way to begin. How did one start a conversation with a fuck buddy turned... something more?

She found the words several times, her lips parting to speak, but doubt crept in each time, silencing her, uncertainty twisting her thoughts.

Minutes dragged on, the silence twisting inside Agatha like a knife wedged deep, each beat of her heart driving it further in. She could feel the weight of it pressing on her chest, and finally, unable to stand it any longer, she blurted out the first thing that surfaced.

“Rio...” Her voice, softer and more vulnerable than she ever intended, sliced through the quiet.

Rio’s head turned slightly, just enough to show she was listening, though her gaze remained distant, her expression unreadable.

Agatha swallowed, feeling her pulse hammering in her throat.

“Rio... please.”

The words were raw, stumbling out before she could catch them.

That got Rio’s attention.

She turned her head fully, her dark eyes finally meeting Agatha’s, piercing, unyielding. Agatha felt herself unravel under that gaze, and her usual defenses crumbled.

Their eyes locked, the weight of everything unspoken hanging between them, thick and suffocating.

“Just... tell me what to do,” Agatha whispered, a thread of desperation slipping into her voice.

She wasn’t just asking—she was pleading.

“Tell me what to do, and I’ll do it,” Agatha said, her voice breaking, the words spilling out with a rawness she could barely contain.

For once in her life, Agatha was completely out of her element. She didn’t know how to bridge this rapidly increasing gap between them. The fear of losing Rio, of having damaged something that had quietly, deeply rooted itself inside her, made her feel exposed in a way that utterly terrified her.

Rio looked at her, her face softening, yet tinged with a sadness that cut straight through Agatha.

“I can’t, Agatha,” Rio said quietly, her voice almost a whisper. “I can’t tell you what to do, because I don’t know what to do either.”

Agatha’s breath hitched, the full weight of Rio’s words pressing down on her.

Rio was just as lost as her.

There was no script, no easy way forward.

They stood at the edge of something unknown, a place where power and control had no hold, a fragile, uncertain space that neither of them knew how to navigate.

Agatha needed a sign, something to assure her that she hadn’t destroyed this beyond repair.

Slowly, hesitantly, she moved her hand forward, her fingertips brushing against Rio’s where it rested beside her. The contact was delicate, tentative—almost as if Agatha were questioning whether she even had the right to reach out.

But the instant Agatha’s fingers touched Rio’s, Rio clasped them tightly, her grip instinctive and fierce, as if she feared Agatha might pull away and slip out of reach.

Agatha let out a breath she didn’t even realize she was holding, as she held Rio’s hand back with just as much intensity.

They rode in silence, hands entwined, the quiet pressing around them. Agatha was acutely aware that they weren’t talking, weren’t solving anything—but they were still holding each other’s hand.

That had to mean something, didn’t it?

The stillness stretched on until Rio’s voice broke through it, low and almost detached.

“When people first hear how my mind works, they think it’s a gift,” she murmured, her gaze fixed somewhere distant, as if she were speaking to the air in front of her. “It really isn’t. I think... I think it’s a curse.”

Agatha turned to her, caught off guard by the statement that seemed to come out nowhere, but Rio didn’t look back.

Agatha could see the tension in Rio’s grip, the way her fingers tightened as if she were holding on to Agatha’s hand as a lifeline, as if she needed it to keep going.

Agatha squeezed back, silently urging her forward, waiting.

“When I was thirteen,” Rio began, her voice steady but laced with a strain, “my parents and I were driving back from one of my soccer tournaments. We were hit head-on by a drunk driver. My dad... he died instantly.”

She paused, a tremor passing through her voice.

“My mom, though... she was hurt badly. I could see her, but I couldn’t get to her—my legs were pinned.”

Rio’s gaze drifted, as if the memory were pulling her back.

Agatha watched as Rio’s free hand drifted to her knee, fingers tracing slow, restless patterns back and forth.

“Sitting here, in this car,” Rio continued, her voice soft, hesitant, like she was speaking from a place buried deep within, “I can feel it, like I’m back there all over again. The weight pressing down on my legs, the tightness in my chest... the panic clawing its way up, the helplessness...”

Her voice trailed off, and she pressed her head back into the leather seat, squeezing her eyes shut, her jaw clenched so tightly Agatha swore she could hear her teeth grinding.

“And I can still hear her breaths,” Rio gritted out, the words strained, as if they were physically painful to release. “Each one... so wet, so— pained .”

Agatha sucked in a quiet breath, her chest tightening in response to the raw pain laced in Rio’s voice.

Jesus.

Why was Rio telling her this? Why was she putting herself through the agony of reliving it?

A sharp ache bloomed in Agatha’s chest as a startling realization hit her— she hated this.

Seeing Rio in pain, watching her struggle through memories that tore her apart piece by piece. Catching Rio quietly wiping tears away in the bathroom had been hard enough, but this... this was so much worse.

But Rio wasn’t finished. It was as if she were determined to reach the end, to push through this painful memory, as though it held something she needed Agatha to understand.

“My mom, she... she turned toward me,” Rio continued, her voice trembling, thick with emotion. “Even then, I could tell she was barely holding on. I knew— somehow, I just knew —that she was going to die. And there was nothing I could do to stop it.”

She swallowed hard, her jaw clenched as tears gathered in her eyes, shimmering in the dim light of the car.

Agatha’s chest ached as she watched Rio struggle to hold back the flood of emotions, her grip tightening around Agatha’s hand in a borderline painful grip.

“And then,” Rio’s voice broke, barely more than a whisper now, yet so loud in the quiet car. “She told me... ‘ Close your eyes, mija ,’ she said. ‘ Close your eyes and cover your ears. Can you do that for me, baby? ’”

After the words crawled painfully out of her mouth, she shook her head, as if trying to shake the sound of her mother voice from her ears.

“I didn’t understand why she was asking me to do that,” she continued quietly, her voice trembling. “But I was terrified, so I did what she asked. I closed my eyes, covered my ears, and sat there in the back seat, surrounded by darkness and silence that felt like it would go on forever... while she died just five feet away from me.”

Agatha’s chest tightened painfully, the weight of Rio’s words sinking deep.

Rio’s words lingered in the silence that followed, as if the weight of them took on a tangible presence, filling the car—pressing against them.

Agatha held her breath, watching as the tears finally slipped form her eyes and down Rio’s cheeks, silent but devastating.

Agatha’s throat tightened, as she felt the urge to say something, to reach out and wipe them away, to offer words of comfort, but nothing seemed adequate—she was trapped in this story just as much Rio was.

Rio took a shaky breath, wiping her cheek with the back of her hand, though her grip on Agatha’s hand didn’t loosen.

“It wasn’t until later, at the hospital that I realized why she told me to do that. She asked me to close my eyes and cover my ears,” Rio continued, her voice fragile, “because she knew I’d never forget the moment she died. She knew that memory would haunt me. So, she tried to shield me, even then. She died still trying to protect me— protecting me from own mind .”

Agatha’s heart ached at the depth of Rio’s pain, her fingers tightening around Rio’s hand in silent support. This wasn’t just a story—this was Rio’s way of opening a door to her heart, showing Agatha something she kept hidden from everyone.

“After that, I learned to keep everything separate,” Rio said, her gaze distant, lost in the past. “To keep my eyes shut and my ears covered—to keep my emotions apart from the memories. It was the only way I know how to survive... to stop them from consuming me.”

Agatha became dimly aware of the car slowing to a stop, catching a fleeting glimpse of Rio’s street outside the window, but she couldn’t tear her focus away from Rio. She was entirely caught up in the raw, unfiltered honesty spilling out before her.

Rio hesitated, her hand tightening around Agatha’s, then loosening, then tightening again, as though she were battling with something buried deep.

Agatha braced herself, sensing that whatever came next was going to be harder still—though she couldn’t imagine how Rio could possibly bear to share something more painful.

With a deep, aching sigh, Rio finally turned, lifting her gaze to meet Agatha’s. Her eyes shone with a vulnerability so raw that it made Agatha’s heart skip a beat.

And for the first time since she’d begun speaking, Rio looked her directly in the eye, and Agatha understood—whatever came next held everything Rio had been holding back.

“But I can’t keep my eyes closed with you, Agatha,” Rio whispered, her voice breaking, the words trembling on the edge of something raw and unguarded. Her gaze held Agatha’s, as if searching for a safe place to land.

She swallowed hard, her fingers tightening around Agatha’s as though trying to ground herself.

“It just hit me out of nowhere. And suddenly I... I feel everything ,” she admitted, her voice barely above a whisper, thick with emotion. “And I don’t know how to shut it off.”

The confession hung between them, raw and unguarded, a truth that reached deep, exposing wounds that had never fully healed.

Rio gave Agatha’s hand a gentle squeeze, her lips curving into a sad, bittersweet smile—and before Agatha could even process it, Rio was pulling her hand away. Agatha’s fingers twitched, the impulse to reach out, to hold on, almost overwhelming. She wanted to pull Rio’s hand back to where it felt like it belonged, but something in that smile, that quiet resignation, held her frozen. It was a smile that spoke of—

She realized with a start and Agatha sucked in a breath, panic tightening in her throat.

No. No. No.

Completely oblivious to the panic rising in Agatha, Rio let out a ragged breath, her sad smile wavering, cracking at the edges.

“I don’t think we should see each other like this anymore,” Rio said softly, her voice barely above a whisper.

Agatha’s world went still, her heart plummeting into a cold, hollow ache. Rio’s words settled over her like a lead weight, a punch that left her breathless.

“I know this isn’t what you signed up for,” Rio continued, her voice wavering slightly. “It wasn’t what I was expecting either. But this...”

She gestured vaguely between them, her hand falling away helplessly.

“I can’t... I don’t know how to do this .”

Agatha couldn’t think, couldn’t speak, couldn’t fucking breathe. Rio’s words seemed to echo in her mind, each one driving deeper, leaving her raw and defenseless. She opened her mouth, but nothing came out. Her throat felt tight, as if it sealed itself off.

She searched Rio’s face, desperate to find some hint of doubt, some sign that this was just a momentary lapse, something that could be fixed, salvaged. But Rio’s gaze was steady, painfully resigned, and it tore through Agatha in a way she hadn’t expected, hadn’t prepared for.

Agatha’s insides twisted painfully, a voice screaming from somewhere deep within her,

Just tell her! Just tell her you have feelings too. Tell her this isn’t a game for you, either.

Her heart pounded, beating wildly against her ribs, demanding she do something, anything to keep Rio from walking away. Every nerve was on fire, the urge to close the gap, to reach out, to lay it all bare pounding through her veins.

But her lips stayed pressed tightly together, the weight of her pride, her fear, chaining her to silence. She could feel herself cracking under the pressure, every instinct screaming to speak up, to stop Rio from slipping through her fingers.

Finally, she swallowed, forcing down the ache in her throat.

“Rio...”

Her voice trembled, her resolve slipping.

“I—”

But the words caught, tangled in all the walls she’d so carefully built. The truth lay just on the edge, a confession ready to be spoken, but she couldn’t get it out. Her hand hovered in the space between them, reaching, but afraid to close the distance.

Say it! H er mind roared, a desperate chant in her head.

Tell her you have feelings! Tell her she’s more than you ever expected! Tell her she matters!

But all that came out was silence.

Rio held Agatha's gaze for a moment, her eyes darkening with a sadness that seemed to settle deep within her.

She took Agatha’s silence for exactly what it was, her shoulders slumping ever so slightly as she nodded, resignation washing over her.

Without another word, she reached for the door handle, fingers wrapping around it with a sense of finality that made Agatha’s chest ache.

“Good night, Agatha,” she murmured, her voice barely audible, soft and weighted with hurt.

And before Agatha could summon the courage to respond, Rio was slipping out of the car, leaving her alone in the silence, her unspoken words echoing painfully in the empty space where Rio had been.

Later that night, Agatha lay in bed, staring up at the dark ceiling, her mind replaying every agonizing moment of her conversation with Rio. The silence in her bedroom felt suffocating, thick with everything she hadn’t said, everything she’d let slip away. Her chest felt hollow, the ache sharper now in the quiet hours of the night, each regret slicing deeper.

She tried to push the memory back, but her mind clung to it stubbornly.

She could still see Rio’s eyes, filled with sadness and hurt, the finality in her voice as she’d said, “Good night, Agatha,” as if she were closing a door on them both.

You should’ve just told her, her mind whispered, relentless. You should’ve just said it.

Agatha’s fists clenched in the sheets, frustration bubbling up inside her. She was Agatha Harkness for fucks sakes , a woman who never let anyone take control of her, who never faltered. Yet when it mattered, when she needed to let her guard down the most, she’d let her own fear and pride silence her. And now, lying alone in the dark, she felt the weight of that choice crushing down on her.

What are you so afraid of?

The question echoing in her head.

But deep down, she already knew the answer.

She was afraid of what Rio had unearthed in her, the vulnerability, the need, the feelings she’d long buried under layers of control.

But tonight?

Tonight, had shown her something else too.

Her walls didn’t protect her—they just left her more alone than ever.

Rolling over, Agatha buried her face in her pillow and wanted to scream into it, only to be hit by the unmistakable scent of forest and pine.

She froze, inhaling sharply, then reared back, staring down at the pillow as if it had attacked her. She’d washed the sheets, but not the pillows.

Rio had slept on this pillow, and it still smelled like her.

A wave of emotions crashed over her, tightening her chest.

She reached out, fingers brushing over the fabric as though if clinging to the remnants of Rio’s presence would ease the ache stirring inside her. But instead, the scent just made the loss feel sharper, more real, leaving her staring at the pillow in helpless frustration.

And then, suddenly, tears filled her eyes, hot and unwelcome, pooling with a frustration that ran bone-deep.

Not at Rio, but at herself —at her own stubborn pride, her own inability to say the things that mattered.

She swiped at her cheeks angrily, as if denying the tears could somehow erase the regret churning inside her.

But it was no use.

The ache in her chest swelled, pressing against her ribs, and she felt helpless under the weight of it. She’d let Rio slip away, let her silence push away the one person who’d ever made her feel something real.

Agatha’s mind drifted back, replaying their time together, how Rio had disrupted her life in ways she’d never expected.

The very idea of being with a woman had once seemed absurd to her, like a door seealed shut. But Rio had blasted Agatha’s closet door right of the fucking hinges, bringing out a side of her she hadn’t even known existed.

And the thought of giving up control in the bedroom? Letting someone else lead? That had felt even more ridiculous... until Rio.

And now, the idea that this thing between them could be something more, something real— that notion seemed the most outlandish of all.

But somehow, against all odds, Rio made her want it.

As she laid there, staring at the pillow, new tears started to spill.

Hot.

Frustrated.

Angry.

When had she become this hesitant, this unsure?

She’d built her life on bold moves, on taking exactly what she wanted without a moment’s hesitation. Second-guessing had never been in her nature.

Yes, she’d let Rio take the lead, allowed herself to surrender parts of herself she’d kept locked away. But that didn’t mean she had to stay on the sidelines, didn’t mean she had to let Rio dictate the terms of this... whatever it was between them.

She was Agatha fucking Harkness, for Christ’s sakes —a woman who’d built her reputation on control, on confidence, on always knowing exactly what she wanted and exactly how to get it.

She never waited, never hesitated, never let anyone force her by the hand.

Rio’s question echoed in her mind: What are we doing, Agatha?

But now, it twisted into something else, something more pointed and demanding.

What are you going to do, Agatha?

Back to the present:

Agatha waited, her heart pounding with anticipation as she stood outside the door. A few moments passed in silence before she heard movement behind the door, followed by the soft click of locks being undone.

The door creaked open, and there stood Rio, blinking against the dim hallway light, clearly still half-asleep.

Agatha sucked in a ragged breath.

She was wearing a pair of skimpy sleep shorts that revealed miles of toned legs and a deep green T-shirt that read “ Pawnee Parks and Rec Department .” Her dark hair was a mess, sticking out in every direction, and she rubbed at her eyes, eyes coming into focus on Agahta, before widening with shock.

“ Agatha ,” Rio sighed, her voice thick with the remnants of sleep as she looked down at her watch, then back up, raising a brow in exasperation. Her gaze was piercing, even through her disheveled, sleepy expression.

“It’s seven in the morning— on a Saturday .”

Agatha offered a sheepish smile.

“I know. I couldn’t sleep.”

Rio ran her hands through her hair messy locks, and threw Agatha a look.

“Well, I was sleeping,” she murmured, but Agatha didn’t miss the faint shadows beneath her eyes, the way her shoulders held a tension that said sleep hadn’t come easily to her, either.

Agatha held up a coffee cup.

“I brought you coffee,” she said, her voice softer than usual, knowing she would need this peace offering for the still surprisingly anti-morning Rio.

Rio blinked, clearly caught off guard, and for a moment, she simply stared at the cup as if she couldn’t quite believe it. Then, slowly, she reached out, her fingers brushing lightly against Agatha’s as she took the cup, her touch sending a small thrill down Agatha’s spine.

Rio looked down at the familiar coffee shop logo, her eyes widening in surprise.

“You actually went into a coffee shop and ordered your own coffee?” she said slowly, as if she couldn’t believe the words coming out her mouth.

Agatha rolled her eyes, though a faint blush crept into her cheeks.

“Just because I have an assistant who usually gets my coffee doesn’t mean I’m entirely helpless.”

Rio hummed softly, as if she didn’t quite believe Agatha’s words but was willing to let it slide. She brought the cup to her lips, taking a slow, deliberate sip. Her eyes closed briefly as

she savored the first taste, a quiet, appreciative hum escaping her.

As Rio took another sip, her gaze softened, and for a brief moment, the guarded look faded from her eyes. She seemed to relax, her shoulders loosening, as if Agatha’s unexpected gesture had somehow dissolved a little of the tension lingering between them.

In the soft morning light, with Rio’s hair tousled and her guard lowered, Agatha couldn’t help but think she looked beautiful in that moment.

And then Rio’s gaze shifted from Agatha's face to the other thing in Agatha’s arms—a large, leafy potted plant, hard to miss.

Agatha fought against the faint flush that threatened to creep up her neck as she adjusted the plant, holding it a little awkwardly in the crook of her arm before extending it toward Rio.

“I... I got you this too,” she said, attempting to keep her voice casual, though she could feel her composure slipping just a little.

Rio blinked, setting her coffee down on the small entryway table beside her before reaching out to take the plant. She looked down at it, her fingers tracing the elegant green-and-white leaves with gentle curiosity, her expression shifting to one of genuine surprise.

“Where did you get this?” Rio asked, her gaze flicking back up to Agatha, equal parts touched and suspicious.

Agatha gave a nonchalant shrug, though she knew she wasn’t fooling anyone.

“At a flower shop downtown,” she replied, trying to sound like she hadn’t just jumped through an inordinate amount of hoops to acquire it.

“A flower shop that opens before sunrise— on the weekend ?” Rio said with disbelief clinging to every syllable, as she raised an eyebrow.

Agatha hesitated, swallowing back her discomfort.

“The daughter of a client owns it. I, uh... called in a favor,” she admitted, her tone more defensive than she liked, but she didn’t like being called out.

Rio raised an eyebrow—and then, a faint smile curving her lips as she looked back down at the plant, then back up at Agatha, her eyes filled with something Agatha couldn’t quite place.

“This is a Monstera Albo Borsigiana,” Rio said, the mouthful of a name rolling off her tongue effortlessly.

Agatha blinked, momentarily thrown. She didn’t know the first thing about plants, let alone what this one was called. All she knew was that it fucking expense, and should be gold plated for what she paid for it.

“Agatha,” Rio sighed, a mix of exasperation and amusement in her tone. “Did you just buy the most expensive plant in the store?”

Agatha felt her cheeks warm under Rio’s knowing gaze. She should have anticipated this reaction.

With a huff, she threw her hands up in mild exasperation, gesturing at the plant.

“Look, I don’t know anything about plants!” she practically exclaimed. “I figured I’d treat it like bourbon—the more expensive, the better it is.”

Rio’s mouth quirked into a genuine smile, a small laugh escaping her. She glanced down at the plant, clearly touched, her fingers lingering on the leaves before meeting Agatha’s eyes again, softer now, and just a bit more open.

Rio’s gaze softened as she looked at Agatha, really looked at her, as if trying to piece together what was happening.

“Agatha— what are you doing? ”

Agatha took a steadying breath, a sly smile creeping onto her lips as she leaned casually against the doorframe, trying to convey enough outward confidence that it convinced herself internally that she was doing the right thing.

"Oh. I am taking back my control,” she answered.

Rio’s eyes went wide, surprise flashing across her face, as she looked at Agatha in shock.

“You’re what?”

Agatha offered a casual shrug, though beneath the surface, her heart pounded, her emotions a tangled mess.

“I have feelings for you, Rio,” she admitted, her voice steady despite the storm inside her.

She watched as the words landed, seeing Rio’s eyes widen slightly, her breath catching in a way that felt like a small victory.

“And since both of us have been acting like complete idiots,” Agatha continued, a hint of determination sharpening her tone, “I’ve decided to take control of the situation.”

Rio blinked, caught off guard, her fingers tightening at her side.

A mixture of surprise, uncertainty, and something else— something vulnerable —flickered across her face.

Agatha couldn’t help but feel a thrill of satisfaction at having left Rio momentarily speechless.

“You’re taking control of the situation,” Rio repeated, drawing out each word with a smirk, before arching an eyebrow and giving Agatha a pointed look. “Just to confirm— am I the situation you’re planning to take control of?”

Agatha’s lips twitched, fighting back a grin as her confidence surged. She took a deliberate step closer, her gaze locked on Rio’s.

“Yes, Rio,” she replied smoothly, her voice low and sure. “ You are absolutely the situation I’m planning to take control of.”

Rio’s eyes sparkled with a mix of surprise and—thankfully—something darker, her lips curving into a faint smirk as she set the plant carefully on the table beside her. Crossing her arms, she leveled Agatha with a look, a flicker of defiance lighting her gaze.

“You couldn’t have told me that last night?” she asked, a touch exasperated.

“Now where’s the fun in that?” Agatha deflected, raising an eyebrow playfully.

Rio narrowed her eyes, unimpressed. Agatha’s confidence wavered for just a second, and she took a breath, letting honesty cut through her tone.

“I was scared, okay?” she admitted. “But I went home, sorted out my shit, and here I am. And I even got you a pretty plant to make up for it.” She gestured to the monstera with a flourish.

Rio raised a brow, her expression softening. “I didn’t need the plant, Agatha. I wanted you .”

Agatha felt her breath hitch, Rio’s directness catching her off guard in the best possible way. She hadn’t realized just how much she’d missed this side of Rio.

“Well, now you have me... and a plant,” she said, flicking her hands as if to say, You’re welcome. “Seems like a win-win to me.”

Rio raised a brow, letting the moment stretch out as her piercing gaze held Agatha in place. Finally, she sighed, the sound equal parts exasperated and amused.

“You are something else, you know that?” she said, shaking her head just slightly.

Agatha’s smirk returned, the confidence in her voice unmistakable.

“So I’ve been told.”

Rio rolled her eyes, but a hint of a smile lingered on her lips as she reached forward, grabbing the lapel of Agatha’s jacket and pulling her close enough that their breaths met in air between them.

Just as Rio tilted her head, to close the remaining short distance, Agatha pulled back, just enough to keep Rio waiting.

Rio’s expression wavered, flickering with a hint of confusion as her eyes searched Agatha’s, uncertain yet intrigued.

Agatha felt a thrill pulse through her, igniting every nerve as she lifted a mocking brow, leaning in closer.

“Ask,” she murmured, her voice a soft but steady command, brushing the words tantalizingly against Rio’s lips.

She felt the subtle hitch in Rio’s breath, the slight tremor that traveled through her as her fingers remained clenched around Agatha’s lapels, holding her close.

Rio let out a small, half-exasperated sigh, caught between irritation and amusement. She huffed against Agatha’s mouth, clearly both annoyed and unable to hide the faint smile breaking through.

“How about...” Rio murmured, her voice low, laced with a teasing defiance, as she reached up, her fingers sliding into Agatha’s hair, nails scraping deliciously along her scalp. She buried her hand in Agatha’s hair, holding her in that possessive way Agatha loved.

“How about no more rules,” she whispered, her lips brushing against Agatha’s.

Agatha sucked in a ragged breath, her heart pounding at the weight of those words—at what they promised, at what they meant. The thrill of it, of shedding every last barrier between them, sent a shiver through her, and she knew there was no going back.

“ Deal ,” she murmured, her voice barely audible.

And then, with a fierce, undeniable certainty, she closed the distance, sealing her words with a kiss that held nothing back—no more rules, no more hesitation, just raw, unfiltered want.

And in that moment, everything else faded, leaving only the heat of the mouths pressed together and the thrill of stepping fully into the unknown.

She had completed another trial, stepped through it, and felt a piece of herself she hadn’t known was missing slot firmly into place. With each step forward, she found herself becoming something more, something fuller, as if this path were shaping her in ways she’d never anticipated.

This road would test her— she knew that much.

What lay ahead was uncertain, a mystery she couldn’t yet solve. But for now, she was exactly where she wanted to be.

And for now—that was enough.

Chapter End Notes

Big shout out to commenter who suggested Agatha get Rio a plant. I loved the idea and had been waiting of the right moment :)

Three of Swords

If someone had told Agatha that at nearly fifty years old, she’d be spending her entire Saturday tangled up in sheets, being thoroughly ravished by a woman sixteen years her junior, she’d have laughed them out of the room—and then probably sued them for defamation later.

And yet, here she was.

Face down on forest green silk sheets, her hair and skin damp with sweat, gasping into the fabric, as her legs trembled beneath her as yet another orgasm tore through her, leaving her breathless and spent.

She felt warm lips press into her shoulder, and then— there it was —the unmistakable smirk against her skin, that fucking smirk that seemed to sear right into her flesh. Rio Vidal was branding her with it, marking her the way a rancher brands their cattle—with an air of quiet, undeniable ownership.

Then she felt a hand tracing down her spine, each fingertip pressing slowly, deliberately, as if counting every vertebra, moving lower over the curve of her ass and lingering there, before daring to dip further and slide forward. Agatha’s body reacted faster than she thought possible, exhaustion forgotten, as she snapped her hand back, gripping Rio’s wrist firmly.

And then in one swift, fluid motion, Agatha rolled, flipping Rio onto her back and pinning her there, straddling her with an intensity that left no room for question. The wrist still caught in her hand was pressed firmly above Rio’s head, while Agatha’s other hand wrapped gently around Rio’s neck—a soft but unmistakable warning.

Rio’s eyes widened in surprise for a fleeting moment before that smirk returned, even deeper than before, as she looked up at Agatha with a glint of satisfaction, clearly savoring this unexpected shift in control.

“Do you have an off button somewhere?” Agatha growled, her gaze roaming over Rio’s glistening skin, now covered in a constellation of hickeys and marks from Agatha’s own teeth and nails.

Rio chuckled, a low, throaty sound that Agatha could feel vibrate against her hand.

“Maybe. Check between my legs,” Rio murmured, her voice a teasing purr.

Agatha snorted at that, but that didn’t stop her from increasing the grip on Rio’s wrist and throat slightly, leaning down until their faces were mere inches apart.

“You’re exhausting, you know that?” Agatha muttered, though the glint in her eyes betrayed her amusement.

“Pot calling the kettle, dear ,” Rio shot back smoothly, a wicked smile curving on her lips.

Agatha looked down at her, arching an eyebrow.

“Rio— dear . If I don’t get something to eat and drink...” Agatha began, her voice tinged with warning.

Rio opened her mouth, a glint in her eyes revealing exactly the kind of dirty response she had in mind.

Agatha clicked her tongue, tightening her grip just enough around Rio’s throat to cut the words off before they could escape.

“ Actual food,” Agatha bit out, her tone sharp but laced with a smirk, before loosening her grip once more, but not letting go.

Rio’s devilish smirk faded into a reluctant pout, but after a moment, she softened, giving a small nod.

Agatha started to pull her hand away, but Rio’s fingers caught hers, guiding it back to her throat and pressing it there, her gaze sparking again, like a fire that never really goes out.

“We’ll be exploring this later, though,” Rio murmured.

For a split second, Agatha’s thoughts scattered, her focus dissolving as she felt the warmth of Rio’s throat beneath her hand, Rio’s dark eyes fixed on her, filled with something that made Agatha’s pulse race.

The thrill of this unexpected role reversal sent a surge of excitement through her veins, and she couldn’t deny how absolutely beautiful Rio looked beneath her with her fingers wrapped possessively around Rio’s throat.

“Or now?” Rio teased, breaking Agatha from her thoughts.

Agatha blinked, suddenly aware that her fingers had tightened instinctively, and Rio’s smirk only widened. That knowing glint in her eyes told Agatha she understood exactly where her mind had drifted.

Agatha, never one to pass up the chance to toy with her prey, leaned down, capturing Rio’s lips in a kiss that started slow but quickly turned heated. She deepened it just enough, letting

her teeth graze Rio’s lower lip, savoring the little moan that escaped her.

Then, with a wicked smile, Agatha pulled back, watching the flicker of frustration in Rio’s eyes.

“No,” she murmured, her voice dripping with playful finality. “I’m hungry.”

Before Rio could pull her back, Agatha loosened her hold on Rio’s throat and rolled off, leaving her sprawled across the bed. Settling herself against the headboard, Agatha leaned back with a self-satisfied smirk, watching Rio with that teasing glint in her eyes, fully aware of the effect she was leaving behind.

Rio groaned loudly, not sparing Agatha a single glance as she swung her legs out of bed and strode out of the bedroom.

Agatha’s gaze immediately zeroed in on her, trailing up Rio’s bare back and catching sight of the deep, red claw marks running down her shoulder. She felt a surge of satisfaction mixed with surprise.

Jesus.

She didn’t even remember making those marks, though, in fairness, the entire day had been a blur. They’d been at it for God knows how long .

With Rio gone from the room, leaving no distractions—no smirk, no hands, no teasing remarks—Agatha let herself breathe, her mind finally catching up to the whirlwind that had been their morning and now afternoon. She sat back against the headboard, staring absently at the empty doorway, feeling the magnitude of what was unfolding between them settle in.

They were actually doing this.

No games, no rules, no hidden agendas.

Just two consenting adults, tangled up in something that felt more real than anything Agatha had allowed herself to feel in years. She couldn’t quite believe it—that she’d let herself cross this line with Rio, with feelings involved, no less.

This could go two ways: either really, really good, or— God —it could go so, so bad.

Agatha felt the weight of that thought settle over her, the uncertainty twisting in her stomach.

Not only that—here she was, trying to navigate what could very well be the first real relationship of her life—not only with a woman, but with someone sixteen years younger than her, and, just to complicate things further, her employee.

It was madness.

Complete and utter madness.

Her therapist was going to have a field day with this.

She heard footsteps approaching, and then Rio was there, holding out a bottle of water. Agatha took it, watching as Rio crawled into bed beside her, eyes quietly assessing, a hint of something more in her gaze.

“Want me to order in, or would you rather go out?” Rio asked, her voice casual, but her eyes searching Agatha’s with a loaded intensity.

Agatha fought against the urge to react to that—to keep her face impassive.

It was a simple question on the surface, yet it carried so much more weight.

Going out together—just the two of them, outside the familiar confines of work or the bedroom—was uncharted territory. Up until now, they had worked, they had fucked, and that had been the extent of it. Even the night they’d spent together at the gay club could be excused as just another part of their complicated work life as they searched for a lead on the Vanguard case.

But this?

This was different.

And judging by the way Rio held her gaze, she knew exactly what she was asking:

Are we keeping this behind closed doors or what?

Agatha’s mind raced, her thoughts colliding as she considered the implications of Rio’s question.

Going out together, where anyone might see them, where their dynamic would stretch beyond the confines of their familiar walls—was she ready for that?

It felt like peeling back another layer, acknowledging this thing between them in a way that wasn’t just between them but open to the world.

And yet, the thought didn’t scare her as much as it should have.

God. This really is madness.

Never one to show her cards too easily, Agatha forced a smirk, leaning back as if perfectly at ease.

“I think I need some fresh air,” Agatha drawled, casting a wry glance around Rio’s impeccably styled, plant-filled apartment. She gestured toward the greenery surrounding them. “Even with your personal rainforest in here, it doesn’t quite manage to filter out the... lingering scent of sex.”

Rio’s lips curved into a knowing smile, that slowly grew into that real one that had Agatha’s heart hammering.

“Out it is, then,” she said, the finality in her tone leaving no room for doubt.

Agatha nodded, feeling a thrill shoot through her at the thought. She wasn’t entirely sure why this felt like such a big deal—New York was enormous, after all. Millions of people lived here, and the chances of her running into anyone she knew were slim to none... right?

All worries about running into someone she knew evaporated the moment Agatha stepped outside. Anyone who knew Agatha Harkness would never— ever —expect to see her in public wearing gray sweatpants and a faded navy hoodie bearing the logo of some random farm in Texas. No one in her social or professional circles would even think to glance her way, much less recognize her.

Hell, she avoided her own reflection every time they passed a mirrored building, barely able to reconcile this version of herself with the impeccably polished woman she usually was.

“I still can’t believe you ripped my clothes,” Agatha hissed under her breath, shooting a sidelong glare at Rio.

Rio sighed beside her, clearly exasperated.

It was, after all, not the first—or second, or even third—time Agatha had brought it up. This had to be at least the fifth.

“I’ve already apologized,” Rio replied with a dry tone, but the hint of amusement in her tone wasn’t lost on Agatha.

She narrowed her eyes at Rio, fighting the urge to hip check her into oncoming traffic.

This woman had a death wish.

And to make matters even worse, Rio was dead set on getting this food truck near Central Park.

Agatha honestly couldn’t decide what was worse: the clothes, the fact that Rio was dragging her to an actual food truck, or the itch of the polyester-cotton blend she’d been forced to wear. Every part of this situation—sweatpants, street food, scratchy fabric—felt like an affront to her usual standards.

But wasn’t that the point?

Rio herself didn’t fit into Agatha’s usual standards.

She was everything Agatha didn’t expect, didn’t plan for, didn’t even know she wanted. Rio was spontaneous, unconventional, and entirely unapologetic—an impossible contradiction to Agatha’s carefully structured world.

And yet, here she was—standing on a busy city street in sweatpants, about to order from a food truck that looked like it had maybe a 50/50 chance of giving her salmonella—all because of Rio.

She felt Rio’s hand slip around her arm, giving it a gentle squeeze, and Agatha looked over to find Rio smiling up at her with that genuine, unguarded smile that had an annoyingly infectious effect. Despite herself, Agatha felt her own lips tugging into a smile.

She wanted to hate this.

Truly, every fiber of her being wanted to loathe the entire situation. The absurdity, the casualness of it all—it went against everything she thought she was. But as she stood there, feeling the crisp autumn breeze against her face, watching Rio scan the food truck menu with a bright, eager expression, she couldn’t deny that there was something oddly freeing about it.

She didn’t hate it.

In fact, deep down—in a place she rarely allowed herself to even acknowledge, a place that should probably stay hidden—Agatha Harkness could almost... possibly ... consider that she was starting to lov—

“Mama!”

It was Central Park. Children were everywhere, and it wasn’t the first time she’d heard a kid call out to their mother since they have been here. But this voice made Agatha freeze, because this particular voice wasn’t calling for just any mother.

Agatha immediately whirled around, her eyes scanning the park with a sudden, urgent intensity. Her heart pounded as her gaze swept over the busy scene, children playing, people chatting, until— there .

She spotted him.

Nicky was sprinting toward her, full of boundless energy, his bright smile lighting up his face as he tore down the asphalt path at breakneck speed, aimed straight at Agatha.

There was barely a second to process his unexpected appearance before he launched himself into the air, a move that made her heart seize in that familiar way. Instinct took over, and she caught him mid-leap with practiced ease, pulling him close against her chest.

Warmth spread through her as she held him, feeling his small arms wrap tightly around her neck, his laughter bubbling up as if he hadn’t a care in the world.

She set him down, and pulled back, running her fingers through Nicky’s dark hair before cupping his face.

“Hi, baby,” she greeted him, her tone light but her eyes scanning the area around him— because why, exactly, was her son sprinting through Central Park on his own? A spark of protective irritation flared in her chest. “Who are you here with?”

Nicky ignored the question, his small hands coming up to her face, tracing her features with the same endearing concentration he’d had since he was a baby.

“You were smiling. I saw it,” he whispered, like he was sharing a secret.

Her lips twitched.

“Was I?” she replied, feigning innocence as she fought back a smile.

He nodded enthusiastically, his grin widening—until his gaze flicked past her shoulder, and his eyes went round with excitement.

“Your mama’s pretty work friend!” he practically shouted.

And, fuck me, Agatha knew exactly who he was looking at. She had to resist the urge to wish for the ground to open up and swallow her whole.

Agatha could feel Rio’s gaze on her, practically boring into her back. She didn’t even have to turn around to know that smug, amused smirk was plastered across Rio’s face.

“What’s up, I’m Rio,” came Rio’s low, gravelly voice from behind her, casual and confident.

Nicky’s eyes went wide at that, glancing up at Agatha with a mixture of awe and excitement. He tugged on her sleeve, his voice a hushed whisper, though his excitement was unmistakable.

“Mama, she’s cool. ”

Agatha stifled a sigh, feeling her cheeks warm.

Of course, Rio would win over her son in an instant—no effort needed, just that damn natural charm.

Agatha straightened up, turning to face Rio, who was, predictably, wearing that infuriating smirk. But there was something else too—a raised brow, a flicker of genuine surprise in her eyes. Agatha opened her mouth, not even sure what she intended to say, when—

“Nicholas!”

Oh. The universe fucking hates me.

Agatha recognized that voice instantly. Turning, she saw James striding down the path toward them, all put together—and, naturally, his hand was entwined with that of a young blonde woman who looked like she’d just stepped off a runway.

Christ almighty, Agatha thought, suddenly all too aware of her own appearance.

Her grungy outfit, sweatpants and a faded hoodie, her hair thrown up in a messy bun, makeup long-since sweated off.

The discomfort was sharp and immediate.

Agatha turned and shot a glare at Rio—because, clearly, this was all her fault. Rio, unbothered as ever, barely raised an eyebrow before turning back to the food truck to collect their order, her expression infuriatingly casual.

Agatha let out a long, exhausted sigh, quickly composing herself as she plastered on a polite, utterly fake smile and turned to face James and... what was her name again?

James’s eyes went wide when he spotted her, and she saw him take in her appearance— sweatpants, messy bun, and all. He then shifted his gaze to Nicky, his expression softening as he stepped forward and crouched down to Nicky’s level, resting his hands on his son’s shoulders.

“Buddy, you can’t just take off like that,” he said, his tone a gentle rebuke.

Nicky looked mildly chastened but then glanced up at Agatha with a shrug, as if his next words would justify everything.

“It’s just Mom.”

Agatha’s forced smile tightened, and she shot Nicky a look, though she couldn’t entirely hide her amusement. Only her son could say something like that and manage to make her feel simultaneously exasperated and endeared.

James chuckled softly, shaking his head, and then stood up, glancing between Agatha and Rio with raised eyebrows. He cleared his throat, clearly choosing his words carefully.

“It’s... been a while, Agatha. Didn’t expect to see you here. With, um... friends?”

Agatha fought the urge to roll her eyes and opted for a more diplomatic response.

“Just grabbing some fresh air,” she replied, as casually as possible, though her eyes couldn’t help flickering over to the woman clinging to James’s arm.

The blonde—impossibly young and beautiful, of course—gave Agatha a polite smile, her gaze flicking over Agatha’s outfit with a look Agatha could only interpret as barely concealed judgment.

Finally, Rio turned around, food in hand, meeting James’s gaze with a relaxed, confident grin. She handed Agatha a plate of what were likely salmonella-infused nachos, then extended her free hand to James.

“Rio,” she said smoothly, her tone effortlessly polite but unmistakably self-assured. “Nice to meet you.”

James shook her hand, looking mildly surprised at her confidence and composure. Agatha watched as Rio’s gaze lingered on James just a beat too long, her smirk widening slightly, as if she were sizing him up.

“James,” he introduced himself, glancing at Agatha for some hint of explanation, but she gave him nothing.

Agatha fought the urge to laugh; even now, Rio somehow turned the moment into a game. And yet, oddly enough, it eased the tension, if only a little.

“Agatha,” James said, his voice strained but overly polite as he stepped back, wrapping a possessive arm around the blonde’s tiny waist. “This is Amanda.”

The blonde gave a graceful nod, her gaze flitting over Agatha with polite disinterest as she extended a perfectly manicured hand.

“Nice to meet you,” Agatha replied shaking her hand briefly, keeping her tone warm, aware of Nicky beside her, head on a swivel, watching them all closely.

An awkward silence settled over the group, thick and uncomfortable, and Agatha was at a complete loss for how to break it. Finally, James cleared his throat, his gaze landing on her with a slight frown.

“Agatha, can I talk to you for a moment?” he asked, tilting his head slightly to indicate they should step aside.

Agatha sighed, already dreading whatever conversation James was about to initiate, but nodded, handing Rio the death nachos.

Rio grabbed them and tilted her head toward a nearby bench, indicating where she would be.

James crouched down to Nicky, his tone softer.

“Buddy, stay here with Amanda, okay? I just need to talk to your mom for a moment.”

Nicky nodded, glancing between his parents with a faint look of concern, but obediently stood next to Amanda.

Taking a deep breath, Agatha followed James a few paces away, bracing herself for whatever he had to say.

“I’m... sorry about that,” he murmured, his voice low and a little awkward. “Not exactly how I pictured introducing you to Amanda for the first time.”

Agatha raised an eyebrow, folding her arms across her chest.

“Nicky mentioned her last week,” she said, offering him an easy out. “So, I wasn’t exactly surprised.”

James let out a small breath, visibly relaxing, and they both glanced back toward Nicky— who had, surprisingly, wandered away from Amanda and was now sitting beside Rio on the bench.

The sight stopped Agatha short.

She hadn’t really thought about Rio interacting with Nicky yet. Sure, she knew it would happen eventually if things continued to go well—a thought she’d held onto cautiously, given her own track record. But now, watching Rio lean down to whisper something that made Nicky stifle a giggle, her heart gave an unexpected lurch.

Nicky didn’t usually take to strangers.

Neither did Agatha.

Yet here was Rio Vidal, somehow bridging a gap neither of them typically allowed anyone to cross. And she was doing it with a quiet ease that surprised Agatha even more than she wanted to admit.

James, meanwhile, had noticed too, a slight frown creasing his brow as he looked from Nicky and Rio’s easy laughter to Amanda, who was standing awkwardly to the side.

“Is she a coworker?” he asked, glancing back at Agatha. “I don’t remember her from the firm.”

Agatha turned back to James, weighing her options carefully.

Technically, Rio was a coworker, and she could say just that, keeping things simple and sidestepping any complications. But a part of her, the part that reveled in defying expectations and catching people off guard, couldn’t resist the allure of honesty.

This was too good an opportunity to pass up.

Especially after every woman James had trounced in front of her over the past 3 years.

Still, there was a nagging hesitation.

If she said it out loud... if she actually claimed Rio as more than a coworker, then it would be real, wouldn’t it?

But then, as she glanced back at Rio with Nicky, who was now laughing with that unguarded joy she rarely saw, Agatha felt the words forming anyway. She looked back at James, a faint smile curling on her lips, and took a steadying breath.

“Actually,” Agatha began, her voice steady as she carefully tested each word, “Rio isn’t just a coworker.”

James’s brows knit together in confusion, and Agatha resisted the urge to roll her eyes.
