Was he always this dense?

“Rio is... someone I’ve been seeing,” she said, drawing the words out slowly, lifting her chin slightly as she held his gaze, watching his reaction unfold with a certain satisfaction.

For a moment, James simply blinked, his expression shifting as the realization settled in. He opened his mouth as if to say something, then closed it, clearly grappling with the unexpected news.

"Seeing," he finally repeated, his voice tinged with surprise. "As in... dating?"

Agatha fought to keep a smirk at bay.

"Yes, James," she replied, her tone deliberately calm. "As in dating."

She watched as he processed this, glancing back toward the bench where Rio and Nicky were still talking, Nicky looking more animated than he had with anyone Agatha had introduced him to in a long time.

James looked slightly thrown, maybe even a bit unsettled, and it was, Agatha had to admit, a rather satisfying sight.

After a pause, he cleared his throat.

“I didn’t... expect that.”

He looked at her, then back at Rio, his brows furrowing.

“How old is she?”

Agatha scoffed, crossing her arms and leveling him with an unimpressed look.

“Really?” she said, arching an eyebrow. “You’re actually asking me that?”

James held up his hands defensively, his face reddening slightly.

“It’s just... she seems young, that’s all.”

“And your girlfriend, doesn’t?” Agatha replied sharply, her gaze flicking pointedly toward Amanda, who was scrolling on her phone, oblivious. “What is she, twenty-five?”

James shifted, looking uncomfortable.

“Touché,” he muttered, clearly unsure how to respond.

James cleared his throat, visibly flustered.

“I didn’t know you were...” He trailed off, his gaze shifting awkwardly between Agatha and Rio, clearly at a loss for words.

Agatha raised an eyebrow, waiting for him to finish.

“Didn’t know I was... what, James?” she prompted, her voice cool and steady.

He fumbled for a moment, glancing around as if the right words were hiding somewhere nearby.

“I didn’t know you were... seeing someone. I mean, dating someone... like that ,” he finished lamely, his cheeks coloring slightly.

Agatha couldn’t help but smirk, crossing her arms.

“There’s a lot you don’t know, apparently.”

James looked away, his expression caught between surprise and something resembling discomfort.

She could see him trying to reconcile the Agatha he thought he knew with the one standing in front of him.

Get in line, buddy.

Because honestly?

She was still trying to reconcile it herself.

This was new territory—unfamiliar and terrifying in ways she hadn’t anticipated. Rio had somehow cracked through walls Agatha had once thought impenetrable. And yet, here she was, actually owning up to it, openly claiming the woman who had turned her world upside down.

She almost wanted to laugh at the absurdity of it.

“Okay,” Agatha said, clapping her hands together, desperate to wrap up this surreal encounter. “Is that all?”

James, still visibly processing everything, nodded blankly. But then something seemed to click, and he cleared his throat.

“Oh, right. Parent-teacher conference is next Thursday,” he added. “Nicky brought home a reminder in his bag yesterday.”

Agatha nodded, a flicker of relief grounding her.

“Got it,” she replied, slipping back into a more familiar rhythm. “I’ll be there.”

She glanced over at Nicky, still animatedly chatting with Rio on the bench, and felt an unexpected calm settle over her.

And then Rio looked up, catching Agatha’s gaze, and she smiled— that smile, the real one, the one that always managed to tug at something deep inside her.

A heartbeat later, Nicky turned and grinned at her, his face lighting up with the same warmth.

Agatha’s breath caught as she looked at them, side by side. She hadn’t noticed it before, but they shared the same easy, unguarded smile. And somehow, both of those smiles affected her in exactly the same way, stirring something fierce and protective within her.

It was a small moment, but it anchored her in a way she hadn’t expected.

Seeing Rio and Nicky together, their smiles mirroring each other, felt like something fitting quietly into place, like a missing piece she hadn’t even realized was gone.

Her heart skipped, and she took a breath, steadying herself.

This was her life now—messy, unexpected, so far from the pristine, controlled image she’d cultivated for herself.

And yet, somehow, standing here with Nicky and Rio, it felt more... real.

James’s voice snapped her out of her thoughts.

“Alright, well... we should get going,” he said, gesturing for Amanda to follow.

“Right,” Agatha replied, her tone light but her eyes lingering on Rio and Nicky.

James looked at her, his gaze softening just a bit.

“You look happy, Agatha,” he said quietly, almost as if he hadn’t meant to say it out loud.

Agatha glanced at him, surprised.

And for once, she didn’t have a biting comeback.

Instead, she gave him a small nod, an acknowledgment of a truth that she was only beginning to understand herself.

Back at Rio’s place, they’d barely managed to get through their food truck meals before collapsing onto the couch, too full and content to even think about moving. Agatha would never openly admit how good the food was, but Rio had caught her eyes widening at the first bite, the reluctant approval in her expression.

Agatha might’ve kept up the façade, but Rio knew better.

And now they were sprawled together on the couch, wrapped in the cozy lull of each other’s presence. To her surprise, Rio curled into her, tucking herself under Agatha’s arm with an ease that felt strangely natural. And, even more surprising, Agatha found herself liking it. She wrapped her arms around Rio, guiding her down to lay her head against her chest, feeling the warmth of Rio’s body settle into her own.

The room was dim, and a documentary about whales— of all things —played softly on the screen, courtesy of Rio’s pick.

Agatha found herself listening more to the rhythmic rise and fall of Rio’s breathing than the narration. It was quiet, peaceful, and something about it felt deeply intimate, a simple closeness she hadn’t known she’d ever want with someone.

Agatha’s hand moved through Rio’s hair almost absently, her fingers grazing her scalp as she traced small, soothing circles.

“Agatha,” Rio murmured into her chest, her voice soft, almost hesitant.

Agatha’s fingers paused, and she looked down, only to see that Rio wasn’t looking up at her. Instead, her gaze was fixed forward, as if she were reluctant to make eye contact.

“This... this feels really good— with you ,” Rio admitted quietly, her tone so soft it was as if she’d barely allowed herself to say it.

The vulnerability in Rio’s voice made Agatha’s chest tighten, and then warmth settled in there. For a moment, she simply watched Rio, feeling the weight of the admission between them as something tender filled the silence.

Finally, willing herself to action, Agatha reached down, hooking her fingers gently under Rio’s chin, lifting her face until their eyes met. She brought her other hand up, brushing a few silky strands of hair back from Rio’s face, her fingers lingering against her skin.

She searched Rio’s eyes, finding something there—vulnerability, maybe even a glimmer of hesitation—that made her heart ache. It wasn’t often she allowed herself to truly look at someone this closely, to let the walls drop just enough to see what lay beneath the surface.

Rio’s gaze held a softness that Agatha hadn’t seen before, a quiet openness that made Agatha’s heart stutter. For a moment, neither of them spoke; they simply looked at each other, the silence filled with all the unspoken things they’d both been too guarded to say.

Agatha’s thumb brushed lightly along Rio’s cheekbone, a small, tender gesture she hadn’t planned but couldn’t resist.

“It feels good to me too,” she murmured, her voice low.

Rio’s eyes softened even more at Agatha’s words, her lips curving into a small, almost shy smile that seemed so unlike her usual confident smirk. She leaned into Agatha’s touch, letting her hand rest over Agatha’s on her cheek, grounding them both in that quiet, fragile moment.

For once, words felt unnecessary.

Instead, Agatha let her thumb graze along Rio’s cheek, then slip down to trace the line of her jaw, savoring the warmth of her skin. She was surprised by how much she enjoyed just... this. No pretense, no need to prove anything to each other. Just the steady beat of her own heart, the comfortable weight of Rio lying against her, and the soft glow of the tv filling the room.

She wasn’t used to this—this quiet, steady intimacy that didn’t demand anything more than just being here, in this moment.

“Think you could get used to it?” Rio asked softly, her voice barely more than a whisper.

Agatha’s breath hitched at that, as she ran her thumb across Rio’s cheekbone, heart aching with a quite vulnerability in her chest.

“I think,” she replied, her voice a little rough as she forced the words out into the world—to Rio. “I think I already am.”

Rio’s eyes widened a little bit at the confession, but then—her lips curved into a smile at Agatha’s words, and—oh, that smile was dangerous, as Agatha felt her heart clench.

Before she could fully process it, Rio leaned down, her lips capturing Agatha’s in a soft, lingering kiss.

But then— knock, knock —a sharp rap at the door.

Rio paused mid-kiss, huffing in mild annoyance against Agatha’s lips before placing a quick peck there, her own frustration clear as she reluctantly pulled away.

“Sorry, it’s probably my neighbor,” she said with an exasperated sigh as she stood up. “She’s a sweetheart, but she has about zero concept of technology and probably messed up her TV again. She’ll be desperate to get back to her shows. ”

Rio shook her head with a wry smile before heading to the door.

Agatha let out a quiet laugh, settling back on the couch as she watched Rio head for the door, feeling a strange, unexpected fondness for the simple domesticity of it all.

She turned her attention back to the TV, waiting for Rio to return, but a few seconds later, she heard Rio’s voice calling out, her tone a mix of confusion and surprise.

“Um...Agatha?”

Agatha sat up, peering over the back of the couch to see Rio standing there, talking to some guy at the door. When Rio turned, her brow furrowed, and she looked at Agatha with mild bewilderment.

“He’s... actually here for you,” Rio said, confusion still evident in her expression.

Equally puzzled, Agatha tilted her head before getting off the couch and walking to the door. There stood a young man, clad in a hoodie and a backpack, unmistakably a bike messenger. He glanced at her with the detached look of someone just trying to finish his last delivery for the day.

“You...Agatha Harkness?” he asked.

“Yes,” she replied, eyeing him cautiously.

He gave a short nod, removing his backpack and pulling out a sealed manila folder.

“This is for you,” he said, holding it out.

Agatha’s gaze dropped to the folder, her name printed in bold letters across the front. Years in the legal world had trained her not to touch anything without first considering the source. And the fact that it had been delivered to Rio’s address instead of her own only made her more wary.

“Who sent this?” she asked skeptically, her eyes narrowing.

“Some guy named Billy,” he replied with a casual shrug.

Relief washed over her.

Billy had access to her location, and this wasn’t the first time he’d sent her something on a weekend or at some random location. She took the folder from him with a nod, and the messenger promptly turned to leave.

As Agatha weighed the folder in her hands, curiosity prickled at her.

What on earth could Billy have sent that couldn’t wait until Monday?

Rio closed the door, eyeing the folder with mild interest before stepping closer, her voice dropping to a low murmur.

“Looks like you’ve got some work to do,” she said softly, leaning in. “I’ll be in the shower. Consider it an incentive to get done with whatever that is... quickly.”

Her words brushed against Agatha’s ear, and before Agatha could respond, Rio flashed her a wicked grin and disappeared down the hallway, leaving Agatha with the folder—and a sudden, very intense motivation to make quick work of whatever this was.

Agatha sat down on the couch, slipping a fingernail under the tape and tearing it open. She pulled out the contents, her brow furrowing as she lifted a paper-clipped stack of photographs. At the top was a handwritten note, paper-clipped to the first page, and as her eyes scanned the words, a chill ran down her spine.

Drop the case, or face the cost.

Heart pounding, she stared at the note, then hesitantly flipped to the photos beneath it. The first few were of Rio alone—candid shots of her at a coffee shop, picking up groceries, browsing through a plant store. Each image felt uncomfortably close, intimate, as though someone had been following her at every turn.

Then came the photos of them together—Agatha and Rio walking side by side in Central Park, stepping into a town car, standing in the alley outside the Red Light. There was a shot of them kissing outside Rio’s door, another of them together in the office.

And the final, brutal image: Rio and Nicky, sitting on a bench in Central Park, smiling at each other.

Agatha’s mind raced, her thoughts a frantic blur.

Billy didn’t send these.

The bike messenger—the delivery— it was a setup.

Without another second’s hesitation, she jammed the photos back into the folder and bolted towards the door, running barefoot down the stairs, her pulse pounding in her ears as she flew down all five flights.

She burst out onto the street, her eyes darting around, heart hammering.

And then—she spotted him.

The bike messenger walking away from her, about half way down the street.

“Hey!” she yelled, her voice cutting through the noise of the street.

He turned, glancing over his shoulder, and her blood ran cold at the sight of his smirk. He gave her one last mocking look before slipping into car next to him. A chill swept over her as the car pulled away from the curb, gliding in her direction.

In slow motion, Agatha watched the black Cadillac roll past her, its tinted windows concealing whoever was inside.

But she knew that car.

The same make, model, and ominous presence as the one that had sat outside Brooke Sinclair’s apartment before her murder.

Agatha’s heart pounded as the realization crashed over her, each beat hammering against her ribcage like a warning siren.

Vanguard.

They were threatening her—no, they were threatening Rio to get to her.

They hadn’t just followed her.

They’d delivered the threat right to Rio’s door, right to the person Agatha had let too close, and who now, unknowingly, had been pulled into Vanguard’s deadly crosshairs.

Her pulse raced, her mind snapping from image to image—the photos of Rio alone, living her life, unaware of the eyes watching her every move; the final, brutal photo of Rio and Nicky in the park. And now this—the Cadillac lurking right outside Rio’s fucking building.

They knew exactly where Rio lived.

The gravity of it settled over her, sharp and suffocating.

Agatha’s breath came in short, jagged gasps, her vision blurring as panic clawed its way up her throat. She forced herself to reach into her pocket, her fingers trembling as she unlocked her phone. Her heart roared in her ears, drowning out nearly everything else, but she managed to hold the phone to her ear.

The second she heard the line connect, she spoke, her voice barely steady.

“Emergency partner meeting. Now .”

There was a pause, then an exasperated sigh on the other end.

“Agatha,” Jen said, her tone laced with disbelief. “It’s Saturday...”

“Jen,” Agatha whispered, her voice breaking as she pressed her hand against her chest, feeling her heart’s frantic, uneven rhythm beneath her fingers.

Tears stung her eyes, blurring her vision.

“Jen— please. ”

Silence.

She could almost hear Jen processing the gravity of that single word.

Please.

Agatha never said please.

“I’ll call the others,” Jen replied finally, her voice steady. “Be there soon.”

The line went dead, but the echo of her own panic reverberated, a tight, suffocating grip on her chest as she stood on the street, struggling to hold herself together.

Agatha moved as though detached from her own body, her steps automatic as she climbed the five flights back to Rio’s apartment. The door was still open where she’d left it, a silent reminder of the chaos she’d just fled. The ringing in her ears only grew louder, like the aftermath of a bomb blast, filling her mind and making her surroundings feel distant, surreal.

She barely registered her movements as she crossed the threshold, each step carrying her closer to the sound of running water. The steam drifted out from the bathroom, and through the fogged glass, she could see Rio’s form, hazy but unmistakably relaxed.

Agatha blinked back tears, her heart twisting painfully as she reached for the shower door.

Rio turned to her immediately, a playful smile lighting up her face.

“Done already?” she asked, running a hand through her wet hair as her smile morphed into that familiar, lecherous grin.

Agatha’s heart clenched, the panic thrumming beneath the surface, a fierce battle between her need to protect and the terror clawing its way up her spine. She fought with every ounce of control she had to keep her face calm, her voice steady, masking the chaos inside.

"I have to go into the office," Agatha said, forcing a disappointed smile she hoped would mask the tremor in her voice. "Client emergency."

Rio paused, her hands still in her hair, the playful glint in her eyes fading as her grin slipped away. She studied Agatha, a flicker of concern crossing her face as she took in the tension Agatha was trying so desperately to hide.

"Everything okay?" Rio asked, her tone softening, the concern evident in her gaze.

Agatha swallowed, nodding a little too quickly.

"Just... something that can't wait. You know how it is."

Rio didn’t look entirely convinced, but she simply gave a slow nod, her eyes searching Agatha’s.

"Anything I can help with?" Rio asked, her voice gentle but steady.

Agatha’s heart lurched, caught off guard by the simple offer of support. She swallowed, trying to steady herself.

“Um—yes, actually,” she replied, the words escaping before she could fully process them. “Can you stay here? Don’t go anywhere. I need you... on call.”

Rio’s eyes widened slightly, a flash of confusion crossing her face as she tried to understand Agatha’s request.

Agatha didn’t blame her; it didn’t make a ton of sense. But until she could figure out how to handle this, she needed Rio to stay put until she figured out what to do.

“Okay,” Rio murmured, her expression still puzzled but trusting, nodding slowly.

Agatha hesitated for a moment, her heart pounding as she looked at Rio. And then, without thinking, she reached forward, her sleeve soaking through as she gripped Rio’s arm and pulled her close, her mouth finding Rio’s in a kiss that was anything but gentle. It was fierce, desperate, a kiss that seemed to hold a thousand words Agatha couldn’t bring herself to say.

She poured everything into it—her unspoken fears, her need to protect Rio, and the quiet, terrifying realization of just how much Rio meant to her.

Agatha knew, deep down, that this was the kind of kiss you give someone when you’re not sure you’ll ever get to kiss them again. When she pulled back, Rio’s eyes opened slowly, and in that brief, vulnerable moment, Agatha saw the recognition there—Rio felt it too, the finality of it, even though Agatha hadn’t said a word.

“Agatha... don’t,” Rio whispered, a hint of panic slipping into her voice.

Agatha took a step back, her heart aching.

“I’m sorry,” she murmured, her voice breaking as she fought to keep the tears at bay.

“Agatha—”

But Agatha was already turning, heading for the door, her vision blurring. She heard the water shut off abruptly, and then the frantic shuffle of Rio moving to follow.

“Agatha, get your ass back here!” Rio’s voice rang out, filled with desperation.

But Agatha didn’t stop. She reached the front door, grabbed the file from the table, and slipped out, closing the door behind her as the first tear broke free. By the time she was on the stairs, her tears were falling unchecked, her heart splitting with every step she took away from Rio.

Agatha kept walking, her mind a whirlwind of chaotic thoughts, her heart breaking with every step. She barely registered the descent down the staircase, each step a dull echo in her ears. When she finally reached the street, she saw Dan already waiting by the curb, his expression impassive as he held the door open for her.

She slipped into the back seat, her hand immediately reaching for the intercom.

“Office,” she said, her voice barely steady, and as Dan pulled away, she leaned back, exhaling shakily.

But just as the car began to move, she caught a flash of movement out the window.

Rio had burst through the building’s front door, wrapped in a robe, her hair dripping wet, eyes wild and searching. Her gaze locked onto Agatha’s through the dark tinted glass, and Agatha’s heart twisted sharply, her throat tightening as she fought the urge to stop the car.

For a brief, excruciating moment, their eyes locked through the tinted glass, Rio’s gaze so full of desperation and hurt that it felt like a knife twisting deep inside Agatha’s chest.

Every fiber of her being screamed to stop, to go back, to let herself want this—to believe she could keep it, protect it.

As the car pulled away, something inside Agatha broke, a raw, piercing ache that ripped through her chest so fiercely she raised a hand to her heart, as though she could somehow hold it together.

But it was pointless.

She couldn’t ignore it anymore, couldn’t pretend her heart hadn’t already betrayed her.

She loved Rio Vidal.

Loved her with a ferocity that terrified her, loved her in a way that stripped her bare.

But it was only a matter of time, wasn’t it?

Agatha Harkness wasn’t meant to fall in love—she’d known that her whole life, had built her life around that certainty.

People like her didn’t get happy endings.

Love was never in the cards for someone like her, and maybe that was the way it had to be.

As the distance between them stretched further, the truth settled in, heavy and irrevocable—a raw ache pressing deep into her chest, as real as the person she’d just left behind.

She’d brought Rio into this mess—into the danger of the case, into her own chaotic life. If she wanted to keep Rio safe, to protect her from the storm gathering around the Vanguard case, then she had to sever the only thing tying Rio to Vanguard:

Herself.

Chapter End Notes

Don't hate me.

Coven True

Agatha despised Jen’s office. The soft hues of pastel pinks and greens, the strategically placed crystals glowing faintly in the dim lights, the faint scent of sage hanging in the air—it all screamed peaceful energy. And that energy always seemed to be at war with who Agatha was, especially today.

But she needed to be here, needed to force herself to be in this office because simply, she needed Jen.

She’d never admit it out loud— ever —but Jennifer Kale was a damn good lawyer. All this crystals-and-harmony nonsense might give the impression of softness, of someone who could be pushed around.

But Agatha knew better.

Underneath the serene, faux-spiritual exterior, Jen was as sharp as a scalpel and just as deadly. She didn’t just argue cases; she dissected them, layer by layer, until her opponents didn’t even realize they’d been gutted.

And she did it with a smile.

It was infuriating.

But, begrudgingly, Agatha respected it—even if the sight of an amethyst cluster perched smugly on Jen’s desk made her want to roll her eyes into next week.

Agatha paced the office, the heel of her boots sounding against the polished floor. She had arrived five minutes ago, and there was still no sign of the other partners.

Her eyes flicked down to the intricate rug in the middle of the room—no doubt some sacred handwoven artifact from a Tibetan monastery or whatever the hell it was. Agatha took a

small, guilty pleasure in working a deliberate line along the edge of it with every sharp twist of the heel of her boot.

If she twisted a little harder than necessary, well, it wasn’t like she could destroy anything else in the room.

And she really needed to destroy something.

Agatha’s pacing quickened, the deliberate grind of her heel against the rug becoming sharper, more forceful. She clenched her fists at her sides, her nails digging into her palms as a storm of emotions churned inside her.

Out of control.

Heartbroken.

And fucking terrified.

It was a cocktail of feelings she didn’t know how to handle, feelings that pressed against the very being of herself, with such a force that it borderline breaking her down entirely.

She hated it.

Hated how exposed she felt, how vulnerable.

Vulnerability wasn’t her thing—control was.

Power.

Authority.

And yet here she was, spiraling over things she couldn’t fix, couldn’t change, couldn’t control.

Her breath hitched as she stopped dead in the middle of Jen’s office, staring blankly at one of the soft pastel paintings hanging on the wall. The peaceful, meditative vibe mocked her, a cruel reminder of everything she was not. Everything she couldn’t pretend to be.

Her heart felt like it was caught in a vice, raw and aching in a way she couldn’t push aside. All those pictures of Rio—the danger she was in was weaving through her chest like a needle pulling sharp, stinging thread. And Nicky... God, she couldn’t even think about Nicky without feeling that protective fear flare hot and fast, adding fuel to the fire already burning inside her.

Agatha swiped a hand across her face, letting out a bitter laugh that sounded more like a broken exhale.

What the hell was she going to do?

Finally, voices reached her ears, pulling Agatha from her spiraling thoughts. She turned, and the wave of relief that coursed through her at the sight of the three women walking toward her was startling.

Because Agatha respected her partners— as colleagues but they were also the closest things she had to friends.

But Agatha had always prided herself on not needing anyone. She could fight her battles, just as she always had, alone.

That was who she was.

Who she’d always been.

And yet, standing there, watching Jen, Alice, and Lilia approach in their varying states of dress, something stirred inside her.

Alice, a season ticket holder to the Knicks, was wearing a jersey and sneakers, clearly having been dragged away from a game. Lilia, wore a full ball gown, as if she’d walked directly off a gala’s red carpet. And Jen— Jen —was surprisingly casual, in leggings and a loose-fitting sweater, the most dressed down Agatha had ever seen her.

The mismatched appearances were a dead giveaway. These women had dropped whatever they were doing, without hesitation, and come running the moment Agatha called.

That realization hit her harder than she expected.

For a moment, her throat tightened, and she fought the unfamiliar feeling threatening to overwhelm her.

They came for me.

It wasn’t something Agatha was used to.

Relying on others? Asking for help?

That wasn’t in her playbook.

Yet, here they were—showing up for her when she needed them most, without question.

And, for a woman who had spent her entire life convinced she didn’t need anyone, Agatha Harkness suddenly became— painfully —aware of just how much she needed these women.

Jen, Lilia and Alice walked into Jen's office, each of them coming to an abrupt stop as their eyes fell on Agatha. The varying degrees of surprise written across their faces were impossible to miss.

And that’s when Agatha realized— shit —she was still dressed in Rio’s clothes. Baggy gray sweatpants, an old, faded hoodie, and a makeup-less face, no doubt blotchy and red from the tears that fell earlier. The sight of herself reflected back at her in their reactions sent a flash of

heat through her cheeks, though she held her ground, forcing herself not to shrink under their scrutiny.

But she saw it in their faces—the shift.

The realization.

It was one thing to get called in for an emergency meeting on a weekend. They were partners, after all. This wasn’t the first time, nor would it be the last.

But Agatha’s state —disheveled and vulnerable was the glaring red flag.

It screamed that something was really, really wrong.

Jen was the first to recover, her sharp gaze softening slightly as she tilted her head.

“What happened?” she asked, her tone steady but laced with concern.

Agatha let out a loud exhale, the sound almost sharp in the otherwise quiet room. She didn’t even know where to start—didn’t have the words—so instead, she simply stepped forward and handed Jen the folder, letting the pictures and the note inside speak for her.

Without a word, she stepped back, crossing her arms tightly over her chest as if it could shield her from the wave of vulnerability creeping up on her. She hated this feeling—hated the way it made her feel exposed.

Jen opened the folder, her expression unreadable as her eyes flicked over the contents. Beside her, Alice and Lilia pressed in, craning their necks to see, their curiosity and concern palpable.

And Agatha just stood there, watching, feeling like her entire world was laid bare before them. Because this wasn’t just professional. This wasn’t just another case or a work emergency.

This was personal— deeply personal —and they were about to see it all.

Agatha stood stiffly, arms crossed, watching as they flipped through the images one by one. Her jaw clenched as their expressions shifted from confusion to shock, and then all three women’s eyes widened simultaneously. Agatha didn’t even need to look to know which photo they’d landed on— the photo of her and Rio kissing.

Jen’s head snapped up, her expression caught somewhere between disbelief and exasperation.

“You’re sleeping with a first-year associate?” she asked, her tone incredulous.

A flush of embarrassment prickled up Agatha’s spine. It was wildly out of character for her.

She knew it.

They knew it.

But she wasn’t about to let Jen or anyone else see her squirm. She forced herself to glare, planting her hands on her hips.

“Can we maybe just concentrate on the death threats for now?” she growled, her voice cutting through the tension. “You can report me to HR later.”

Alice let out a low impressed whistle, Lilia glanced sharply at Jen, and Jen— thankfully let it go—closed her mouth, though her raised eyebrows said enough.

“Go to the last one,” Agatha snapped, pointing at the folder.

Jen gave her a pointed look but complied, flipping through the photos until the final image came into view—the one of Nicky and Rio sitting together on the park bench.

The room went dead silent.

Agatha felt the air shift as they all took in the photo, the meaning of it sinking in. The sight of Nicky there, his smile so carefree, paired with Rio—someone who shouldn’t have been a target but now clearly was—hit differently.

“Jesus,” Alice muttered under her breath, breaking the silence.

Lilia’s face was tight with something that looked an awful lot like anger, her jaw set as she slowly looked back up at Agatha.

Jen’s head snapped up, her eyes locking onto Agatha’s with a mix of concern and anger simmering just beneath the surface.

“When did you get these?” she asked, her voice sharp and steady.

“Almost an hour ago,” Agatha replied, exhaling slowly, as though the words themselves were a burden. “A messenger, under the guise of delivering something from Billy, dropped them off at Rio’s front door. For me.”

Her jaw tightened, and she clenched her hands into fists to steady herself.

“They’re watching her. Watching her place. They knew I was there.”

The words hung heavy in the room, but Agatha wasn’t done. She swallowed hard, her throat dry, before continuing.

“Those pictures from the park,” she said, her voice catching for the briefest of moments before she pushed on, steeling herself. “ With Nicky .” Her chest tightened, and she had to take a breath to ground herself. “Those were taken today. Earlier today.”

The weight of her words dropped like a stone in the room, and Jen’s hand curled tightly around the closed folder, her jaw clenching as her gaze flicked toward Alice and Lilia, who were both uncharacteristically silent.

“It’s Vanguard,” Agatha said, her voice low but steady.

The words rang through the space like a bell, sharp and reverberating, leaving an unmistakable tension in their wake.

Jen’s grip on the folder tightened, her expression shifting to something darker, sharper. She moved forward and dropped the folders on the table between them, they scattered out, and Agatha had to force her eyes away from them.

“You’re sure?” Jen finally asked, her tone careful but urgent.

Agatha’s lips pressed into a thin line, but she nodded.

“Who else has the resources, the motive, and the audacity to pull something like this?”

She gestured sharply toward the pictures, her frustration laced with anger bleeding into her voice.

“This has Vanguard’s fingerprints all over it.”

She drew in a steadying breath, her gaze hardening.

“It’s not a coincidence that the second I finally get my jury trial they start threatening me. They know I have them. The evidence Rio uncovered is going to fucking bury them. ”

Her voice dropped, the weight of her words landing like a hammer.

“And judging by those pictures of us in the office...” She trailed off, her jaw clenching as she looked back at the folder. “We’ve clearly been breached. They know exactly what we have on them. They know they can’t explain what we found—so they’re trying to squash it before we even get to court.”

Jen exhaled sharply, her lips pressing into a thin line.

“You’ve got them on the run. They’re scared,” she said. “That’s the only reason they’d escalate like this.”

“Good,” Alice muttered darkly, her fingers curling into fists. “They should be.”

But Agatha ran her hands through her hair in frustration.

“Scared doesn’t make them any less dangerous. It makes them reckless. ”

“And desperate,” Lilia added, her voice low and measured, each word landing like the strike of a hammer. “A dangerous combination.”

She paused, her sharp gaze settling on Agatha, piercing through the tension like a blade. It was a look that always managed to unnerve Agatha, as though Lilia could see straight through her defenses to the vulnerable core beneath.

And yet, there was something steadying about it, too—something that made Agatha feel, for once, like she wasn’t alone in carrying the weight of this.

“What do you want to do?” Lilia asked.

The question lingered in the air, heavy with meaning.

Agatha met Lilia’s gaze, her mind racing as she considered the next steps, the risks, the consequences. This wasn’t just about her anymore—it was about so much more.

“The payout on this case...” Agatha began, instinctively reaching for the familiar ground of practicality, of numbers and logistics.

“ Fuck the payout ,” Alice interrupted sharply, her voice cutting through the tension like a knife. It was uncharacteristically blunt, even for her. “Our books are solid. We don’t need it.”

Agatha blinked, momentarily thrown off. It wasn’t like Alice to dismiss a financial gain so easily, and for her to do so now only underscored the gravity of the situation. This wasn’t just about money or winning a case anymore—this was personal, and they all knew it.

With the familiar slipping out of reach, Agatha instinctively curled her arms around herself, as if trying to hold something steady within.

What did she want to do?

Vanguard had been her white whale. The thing she’d been chasing for years, pouring her energy, her drive, her life into defeating.

It was supposed to be everything.

Her crowning achievement.

Her ultimate victory.

Or so she’d thought.

Because now, with this threat hanging over Rio and Nicky, it was like a cold light had been cast over everything.

Suddenly, Vanguard felt small—insignificant, even. What was winning against them compared to this ? Compared to the people who actually mattered?

It wasn’t even a choice.

Vanguard was nothing— nothing —compared to them.

But at the same time—could Agatha really let them get away with this? Let them silence her, just as they’d silenced Brooke Sinclair? The thought clawed at her, hot and furious.

She could still see Brooke’s parents, their eyes hollow with grief, their pain a tangible weight in the room as they mourned the daughter stolen from them. Agatha had promised them justice— sworn it.

And now, she was standing at the edge of a decision that could betray that promise.

The image of Brooke lingered, but it was Nicky’s face took her place. The memory of him so weak and frail in the hospital bed, of her nearly losing him—the suffocating fear, the pain she never wanted to feel again—made her chest tighten.

Brooke’s parents had lost their child.

Agatha had come terrifyingly close to the same.

She gritted her teeth, the tension curling through her body like a vice.

Letting Vanguard walk away, letting them silence her after everything they’d done, wasn’t just a betrayal of her work—it was a betrayal of Brooke’s memory. Of her parents’ pain. Of everything Agatha stood for.

She couldn’t— wouldn’t —let them win.

But the cost of fighting back?

That’s what truly terrified her.

Agatha swallowed hard, forcing herself to stand taller as she turned to Jen, her voice steady despite the storm raging inside her.

“That security company we had to hire,” she started, “for that environmental terrorist group threatening the firm when we represented Freeman Gas over those fracking violations—were they good?”

The room went silent.

Jen’s sharp gaze snapped to Agatha, understanding flickering to life in her eyes. She didn’t answer immediately, her lips pressing into a thin line as she considered the weight of Agatha’s question— and what it implied .

“Agatha... are you sure—”

“ Were they good? ” Agatha repeated sharply, her voice cutting through the tension like a blade.

There was no room for hesitation, no space for doubt.

Jen straightened, her shoulders squaring as she locked eyes with Agatha. Her expression was calm, but the weight of the moment hung heavy between them.

“They were good,” she answered.

Agatha nodded once, absorbing the answer, her mind already racing ahead to the next steps.

The die was cast.

There was no turning back now.

“This is my mess. I can foot the bill,” Agatha said, her tone firm but weary, the weight of responsibility pressing down on her shoulders.

Lilia clicked her tongue in disapproval, her expression hardening as she stepped into Agatha’s personal space—looking her dead in the eye.

“No,” Lilia said firmly, her voice carrying a finality that left no room for argument. “They come after one of us, they come after all of us.”

Agatha blinked, caught off guard by the unwavering solidarity in Lilia’s tone. She opened her mouth to protest, but the look in Lilia’s eyes made her stop.

It wasn’t just determination.

It was loyalty—unshakeable and fierce.

Jen and Alice followed suit, stepping forward to join Lilia, forming an unspoken wall around Agatha. None of them said a word, but their expressions mirrored Lilia’s resolve.

The message was clear: if they wanted Agatha, they had to get through them first.

For the first time in a long time, Agatha felt something unfamiliar but not unwelcome—a strange, quiet relief.

She wasn’t alone.

She swallowed hard, forcing down the swell of emotion that curled inside her. It was comforting in a way that made her uneasy, something she wasn’t used to letting herself feel.

The silence stretched, heavy but not uncomfortable, and Agatha shifted, her usual sharp edge creeping back in to steady herself.

“I swear to god, if one of you tries to hug me, I will hit you,” she deadpanned, breaking the moment.

Jen snorted, Alice let out a bark of laughter, and even Lilia’s lips twitched into the faintest hint of a smile.

“Don’t flatter yourself, Harkness,” Alice teased.

Agatha rolled her eyes, but the tension in the room eased, replaced by a quiet, determined unity. Whatever came next, she wasn’t facing it alone—and for once, she let herself accept that.

“What are we doing about Vidal?” Jen asked, breaking the moment, her eyes narrowing as she shot Agatha a look that made it clear she wasn’t letting go of the topic anytime soon.

Agatha met her gaze, a flicker of frustration crossing her features before she sighed, running a hand through her hair.

“She needs her own security detail. So does Nicky.” Agatha’s voice softened, a rare vulnerability slipping through her usually sharp exterior. “But I don’t want either of them to know.”

Jen raised a brow at that, giving Agatha a look.

“I understand not wanting Nicky to know,” she said cautiously. “But Vidal—she should know.”

“No,” Agatha growled, her tone brooking no argument. “This is my mess. She doesn’t need to know . I’ll take her off the case. She can report to you.”

“ Me ?” Jen asked, startled.

Agatha rolled her eyes, exasperation etched into her features.

“Don’t act like you don’t want her on your team,” she hissed. “She’s the best associate we’ve seen walk through these doors in years.”

Alice raised her hand, looking between them.

“Umm — why does Jen get her?” she asked, clearly offended.

Agatha pinched the bridge of her nose.

“I don’t care—you can share her for all I care. But she cannot work for me anymore,” Agatha said, her tone clipped, frustration rolling off her in waves.

“Oh yeah?” Jen shot back mockingly. “Did you come to that brilliant conclusion before or after you slept with her?”

Agatha’s eyes narrowed dangerously, and her middle finger shot up in a gesture that felt almost reflexive.

“Oh... real cute,” Jen muttered, matching Agatha’s glare with a pointed look of her own, her voice dripping with sarcasm.

Agatha opened her mouth to fire back, because, honestly, she needed this—the back and forth, the sharp exchange. It was grounding, familiar, almost comforting in its absurdity.

“Um... Agatha,” Lilia interjected, her tone hesitant but firm.

“What?” Agatha snapped, turning to her.

Lilia tilted her head to the side, subtly nodding toward the glass door. Agatha followed her gaze, and her heart nearly stopped.

Rio stood outside the door, arms crossed over her chest, her sharp eyes narrowed at Agatha. The weight of her gaze was enough to make Agatha feel like she was back in the principal’s office, caught red-handed.

“ Ohhh... someone’s in trouble ,” Jen sang, her delight barely concealed, leaning slightly toward Agatha with a smug grin.

“Jen,” Agatha hissed, whirling on her with all the fury she could muster. “I swear to god, I will break every single crystal in this fucking office.”

Jen’s eyes widened briefly before she composed herself, fixing Agatha with a serious look.

“That’s like... really bad karma, Agatha. So, just know—that’s on you.”

Agatha let out an exasperated growl, bringing her hands up in a mock-strangling motion, teeth bared.

“Nope!” Lilia interjected, stepping in like the seasoned peacekeeper she was. Her tone was calm but firm, cutting through the escalating tension. “We’re not doing this. We’re going to call the security detail. They have a rapid response team, and I’m sure they’ll be here shortly to discuss logistics.”

She paused, leveling Agatha with a look that was as unimpressed as it was pointed.

“You, however, clearly have...” she paused, her eyes drifting to the door where Rio stood waiting, “other things to work out.”

Without missing a beat, Lilia turned on her heel and began ushering Jen and Alice out of the office.

“Come on, you two,” Lilia said, waving them forward with a no-nonsense tone. “Let’s give her some space.”

“This is literally my office,” Jen muttered, crossing her arms, but she begrudgingly followed Lilia and Alice out.

As the three exited, Agatha felt a strange, uncomfortable pull in her stomach, a mix of relief and apprehension. Thankfully, they only gave Rio passing glances as they moved by, though the tension in the air was palpable.

And just as the door almost swung shut, Rio caught it and stepped inside.

She was dressed haphazardly—jeans and a seater that hung slightly askew, and Agatha couldn’t help but notice she was wearing two mismatched white sneakers. Her damp hair clung to her shoulders in uneven waves, and the darker patch on her sweater betrayed where the water had soaked in.

But it wasn’t Rio’s thrown-together appearance that made Agatha’s throat tighten—it was the look on her face.

Rio wasn’t just unhappy.

She was pissed.

"You were supposed to stay home," Agatha said, her throat tightening as the words slipped out, almost strangled.

Rio’s jaw clenched, her eyes narrowing into a sharp glare that seemed to slice through the space between them.

“Don’t,” Rio growled, stepping forward, her tone low and dangerous. “What was that? Huh? You just took off, Agatha. No explanation, no nothing. What in the hell is going—”

Her voice faltered mid-sentence, her eyes snapping downward. Agatha instinctively followed her gaze, and her heart sank.

The photos— those fucking photos —were scattered across the table.

Agatha let out a loud, exasperated sigh, her frustration bubbling over.

“ Fucking Jen ,” she muttered under her breath, pinching the bridge of her nose.

So much for keeping this under wraps.

Rio’s gaze darted over the images, her expression shifting from confusion to something darker—something colder, more focused.

She paused, then stepped up to the table, and Agatha could do nothing but watch, frozen as her heart lurched painfully in her chest.

Rio’s fingers ghosted across the handwritten threat first, her touch featherlight, before moving deliberately to the photos. One by one, she slid them aside, her movements slow and methodical, as if she were dissecting a case. Her jaw tightened with every new image revealed, but she remained silent, her focus razor-sharp.

Then, she reached the last photo—the one of her and Nicky sitting on the park bench.

Rio’s hand recoiled like the picture had burned her, her breath catching audibly as her eyes shot up, locking on Agatha’s.

“They threatened your son.”

Her voice was low, trembling at the edges, but there was no mistaking the fury behind it.

Agatha sucked in a sharp breath, her chest tightening. There were dozens of pictures on the table—all of Rio. Her privacy invaded, her every move documented, her very life threatened —and yet, Rio hadn’t so much as flinched.

But the moment she saw Nicky’s picture, her composure cracked.

The sharp edge of Rio’s protectiveness hit her like a freight train, leaving her momentarily speechless.

Her lips parted, but no words came out. What could she even say?

Agatha wasn’t sure what rattled her more—Rio’s fury or the undeniable fact that it wasn’t directed at her, but for her .

Her throat tightened, and she swallowed hard before nodding.

“And you,” she added, her voice quieter, pointing out the obvious with a gesture toward the photos.

Rio’s jaw tightened, her eyes flicking back to Agatha, dark and unrelenting.

“I am an adult. I can handle some threats,” she said, her tone firm, almost defiant. “But Nicky?” She shook her head, her hand pressing flat against the table as if anchoring herself. “This is crossing a line, Agatha.”

“I know,” Agatha murmured, her voice breaking slightly. “You think I don’t know?”

Rio didn’t flinch, her steady gaze fixed on Agatha, unyielding.

“Agatha,” she said again, and the sound of her name hit like a strike to the chest.

Agatha shut her eyes tightly. Only Rio could say her name like that—with reverence, like it was precious, but always tinged with so much exasperation, like it also annoyed the hell out of her.

It fit.

“You don’t get to use this as an excuse to push me away,” Rio said, her voice soft but firm, cutting through the tension.

Agatha’s eyes snapped open, wide with disbelief.

“An excuse?” she echoed, her voice rising with incredulity. The words barely left her mouth before anger flared hot and bright.

“ An excuse ?” she repeated, stepping closer to Rio, her hands flicking restlessly at her side. “They are threatening to kill you, Rio! Do you understand that? They’ve been following you for weeks— weeks ! They know where you live.”

Her voice cracked, but she pushed on, unable to stop the torrent now.

“The same black Cadillac that sat outside Brooke Sinclair’s house before they murdered her was parked outside your building today. Did you know that? Did you? ”

Her voice sharpened, raw with emotion.

“Do you have any idea how much danger you’re in? How much danger I’ve put you in just by being near you?”

Her chest heaved as the last words fell, her fury born from a place so deep she wasn’t sure if it was directed at Rio, the situation, or herself.

Probably all three.

Rio didn’t step back. She didn’t flinch or shrink from the fire in Agatha’s words. Instead, she stood her ground, her jaw tightening as she absorbed every word, letting the anger and fear wash over her like a storm she born to weather.

“Are you done?” Rio asked quietly, her voice calm, almost too calm, and that only made Agatha’s frustration burn hotter.

“ Done ?” Agatha snapped, her hands gesturing wildly. “No, I’m not done, Rio! I am trying to save your goddamn life, and you’re standing there acting like this is some—some minor inconvenience!”

Rio’s lips pressed into a thin line, and her eyes softened—just enough to make Agatha’s breath catch.

“I’m not standing here acting like this doesn’t scare me,” Rio said evenly, her voice steady but firm. “You think I’m not terrified? That I’m not thinking about what could happen? To you? To Nicky?”

Agatha’s mouth opened to respond, but Rio didn’t let her. She stepped closer, closing the small distance between them.

“But this?” Rio gestured between them, her voice softer now, but no less determined. “W e’re not running from it . You don’t get to decide for me that it’s over because you’re scared.”

“I’m not scared—” Agatha began, but Rio cut her off with a look so piercing it felt like a sliced right through Agatha.

“Yes, you are,” Rio said simply. “You’re scared, and you’re trying to protect me by pushing me away. But that’s not your call to make, Agatha.”

Agatha’s heart hammered in her chest, the weight of Rio’s words pressing down on her as the anxiety curled inside her. Her mind drifted—back to the last moment she felt like this—to the hospital room, to the smell of antiseptic and the relentless beeping of monitors.

She remembered how sat there, powerless, watching her son struggle to breathe, her hands trembling because there was nothing she could do. She didn’t have the power to protect him then. She’d been so helpless.

But now?

Now, she had the power. She could protect Rio. She just needed to walk away.

Because if something happened to Rio...

The thought slammed into her chest like a freight train, and her breath hitched.

If something happened to Rio, she would never forgive herself.

The idea was unbearable, the kind of loss that would shred her to pieces. She couldn’t lose someone she—

Her anxiety twisted and curled inside her. Her throat tightened, and she looked at Rio, standing there, refusing to back down. Refusing to let Agatha push her away.

Her voice, when she finally found it, was hoarse.

“Rio, if something happened to you...” She trailed off, the words caught in her throat, the weight of them too heavy to bear.

Rio stepped closer, her expression softening, her voice low but steady.

“If something happened to me, it wouldn’t be because of you, Agatha. It would be because of them. And I refuse to let them take this—us—away. Do you hear me? ”

Agatha swallowed hard, her chest tightening as emotions swirled like a storm, threatening to consume her. She turned her head, looking anywhere but at Rio, trying to muster the strength to do what she thought she had to do.

To push through this, to protect.

But then, softly, Rio’s voice broke through her resolve.

“ Agatha ,” Rio murmured, her tone gentle but firm. “Look at me.”

Agatha squeezed her eyes shut even tighter, her fists clenching at her sides.

She couldn’t.

She wouldn’t.

Because if she looked—if she gave Rio that moment—then every last shred of her defenses would come crashing down.

She knew it.

“ Baby ,” Rio said again, her voice coaxing and low, brushing against Agatha’s frayed nerves. “Just look at me.”

Her heart clenched painfully at the word, her breath catching in her throat. And before she could stop herself, her eyes snapped open, glaring at Rio with as much defiance as she could muster.

“You know I don’t like it when you call me that,” she snapped, her tone sharper than she intended, a desperate attempt to reclaim some ground.

But Rio didn’t flinch.

Instead, she smirked—that infuriatingly confident, knowing smirk that somehow both grounded and disarmed Agatha all at once.

“Yes, you do,” Rio said, her voice quiet, teasing. “You just don’t want to admit it.”

She reached up, her fingers brushing gently against Agatha’s cheek, tucking a stray strand of hair back behind her ear.

Agatha sighed heavily at the touch, the fight leaving her in one exhale.

“Rio—”

“I love you,” Rio interrupted, her voice cutting through the chaos with unshakable certainty.

The words hung in the air, a soft yet powerful truth that made Agatha’s heart skip and stutter. For a moment, all she could do was stare, her mind racing to catch up with the reality of what Rio had just said.

“You—” she stuttered. “You don’t...mean that,” she said softly, her voice trembling despite her best efforts to keep it steady. Her chest felt impossibly tight, her heart pounding in a chaotic rhythm.

Rio didn’t flinch.

“I wouldn’t say it if I didn’t mean it. You know that,” she said simply, her voice calm, her hand still brushing softly against Agatha’s face.

Agatha shook her head, trying to step back, trying to put distance between them, but Rio didn’t let her. She followed, stepping closer, her hand moving to cup Agatha’s cheek.

“I love you, Agatha Harkness,” said Rio, doubling down. “All of you. The good, the bad, and the incredibly stubborn. And I’m not going anywhere.”

Agatha swallowed hard, her throat tight as her eyes searched Rio’s, looking for any hint of doubt, of hesitation.

Unsurprisingly, there was none.

Rio was as she always was—steady, grounded, a calm force in the middle of Agatha’s storm.

And then, just like that, Agatha’s defenses crumbled.

“You’re impossible,” Agatha muttered, her voice cracking ever so slightly, though any attempt at irritation was overshadowed by the heavy surrender seeping into her tone.

Rio smiled, her thumb brushing lightly over Agatha’s cheek, her touch soft and grounding.

“You love it,” she teased, her voice warm and gentle, but laced with that playful confidence that always managed to make Agatha’s heart stutter.

Agatha closed her eyes, letting herself lean, just for a moment, into the warmth of Rio’s touch.

Letting the words linger in the air.

Letting the moment— just be .

“God help me,” Agatha found herself murmuring, her voice barely more than a whisper. She opened her eyes, meeting Rio’s gaze, her chest tight with something she could finally name.

The words tumbled out, unstoppable, even if she had wanted to hold them back.

“But I think I do.”

Rio’s eyes widened briefly in surprise, her lips twitching upward.

“Yeah?” she asked softly, the astonishment in her tone impossible to miss.

Agatha shot her a look, one that clearly said, Don’t push your luck. That’s all you’re getting.

Rio’s smirk deepened, mischievous and knowing, and she leaned forward, her lips brushing dangerously close to Agatha’s.

But just before they met, Agatha pulled back, her breath catching as her lips hovered over Rio’s.

“Rio...this is incredibly reckless,” she whispered, her voice trembling slightly, her words more of an observation than a protest.

“You’re Agatha Harkness,” Rio murmured in return, her tone low and brimming with a kind of want that sent a shiver down Agatha’s spine. “Isn’t that, like, your trademark?”

Agatha huffed softly, a mix of amusement and resignation slipping from her lips.

Whatever retort she might have had dissolved as she leaned forward, her movements instinctive, driven by something deeper. When her lips met Rio’s, the kiss wasn’t just heated —it was relief. Knock. Knock.

Agatha froze, her lips still brushing against Rio’s, her breath catching as her eyes darted over Rio’s shoulder.

And there they were.

Lilia, Jen, and Alice stood just outside the glass door, each wearing expressions ranging from barely-contained surprise to outright shock. Behing them, she could see men and women in suits filtering into the hamster cage.

Jen mouth was agape like she couldn’t believe what was she was seeing. Lilia’s face was carefully neutral, though her eyes sparkled with amusement. Alice, predictably , was grinning like an idiot.

Agatha let out a quiet groan, pulling her lips away and resting her forehead falling against Rio’s shoulder as she muttered, “I’m never going to hear the end of this.”

Rio chuckled softly, the sound low and warm, as Agatha lifted her head and met her gaze.

“Go to my office,” Agatha murmured, her voice firm but carrying an undercurrent of something gentler.

Her hand came up, squeezing Rio’s arm in reassurance.

“Wait for me there. I need to finalize the security arrangements, and then we’re going to talk —about your personal security detail and future assignments.”

Rio’s expression shifted, the humor melting away as the weight of the situation settled back in. She gave a solemn nod, understanding the gravity of Agatha’s words. Without another word, she stepped back, her gaze lingering on Agatha for just a moment before turning and heading out.

Rio didn’t so much as spare a glance at the other partners as she walked away.

" Te veo ," she said over her shoulder, her tone effortlessly self-assured.

Agatha couldn’t help but notice the way the seasoned lawyers seemed to completely lose control of their reactions. Their eyes widened, and like magnets, every head turned and tracked Rio as she walked down the corridor.

Agatha let out a slow, measured breath, taking advantage of their distraction. She squared her shoulders and stepped forward to meet them, her expression calm but her eyes sharp, already bracing for whatever comments or looks were coming her way.

Unsurprisingly, Jen was the first to pounce.

“In my office— my sacred temple —you bring your depravity?” she hissed, her voice dripping with outrage.

Agatha rolled her eyes at the theatrics, folding her arms across her chest.

“It was just a kiss, Jen,” she retorted, leveling her with a pointed look. “It’s not like I bent her over your desk and fucked her.”

Jen’s eyes widened, her mouth opening and closing as if she couldn’t decide whether to be horrified or begrudgingly impressed. Finally, she huffed, muttering something under her

breath about needing to burn more sage and cleanse the energy in her office as she stomped away.

Lilia, let out a poorly stifled laugh before stepping closer to Agatha. She touched Agatha’s arm lightly and leaned in as though she were about to share a secret, though her voice was far too loud for any pretense of discretion.

“I have a good feeling about you two,” she said, gesturing between Agatha and Rio’s retreating figure with a pleased smile. “I’m usually right about these things,” she added, tapping her temple for emphasis.

She started to walk away but paused mid-step.

“Oh—and don’t forget, you need to submit a workplace relationship disclosure to HR immediately,” she said, her tone slipping seamlessly into partner authority as she shot Agatha a pointed look. Then, with a satisfied nod, she followed Jen toward the conference room.

That left Agatha standing with Alice in a silence so thick it felt like a living thing.

Agatha waited, crossing her arms and glaring, but Alice just stood there, hands in her pockets, clearly enjoying herself. When the silence became too much, Agatha snapped.

“And you? What do you have to say?” she demanded, throwing her hands up in exasperation. “Go on—let’s hear it!”

Alice raised her hands in mock surrender, her face carefully neutral, though her eyes sparkled with barely contained amusement.

“I’ve got nothing,” she said casually, but as the words hung in the air, a sly smirk crept onto her face. “I mean—I get it. She’s hot. Good for you.”

Agatha’s eyes went wide, caught completely off guard by Alice’s casual remark.

“Oh—,” she stammered, the rare sensation of a blush creeping up her neck and heating her cheeks. “Umm...thanks?”

Alice nodded, and walked forward, with a little skip in her step, but then paused halfway down the hallway.

“Does she have an older brother— or a sister ? I’m not picky. Emphasis on the older though. I don't want to go to jail,” Alice quipped, her grin widening with that signature devilish delight.

And there it was.

Agatha groaned, throwing a sharp glare her way.

“I hate all of you,” she muttered, her voice low and drenched in exasperation, though the faintest hint of a smirk betrayed her true feelings.

Alice chuckled, clearly pleased with herself, before striding toward the conference room without another word, leaving Agatha standing alone.

Agatha sighed heavily, running a hand through her hair. A thousand thoughts swirled in her mind, too many for her to grasp all at once.

There was the trial—a battle years in the making.

A white whale to spear.

A family she had vowed to bring peace to.

And most importantly, Agatha had people to protect.

And of course, tangled somewhere in the chaos of it all, she had a relationship—a messy, maddening, exhilarating relationship—that she somehow needed to figure out.

For all of Agatha’s sharp edges and complications, for all the barriers she instinctively raised, there was no denying that what she had found with Rio was real.

Something worth fighting for.

Agatha straightened, her resolve hardening into something unbreakable, her thoughts razor- sharp as they honed in on a single, undeniable truth.

Vanguard had made a big fucking mistake.

Threatening her? That was one thing. A calculated risk they likely thought they could control.

But coming for the people she loved?

Oh, that unleashed something entirely different within her— a new monster , fiercer and more ruthless than they could have ever imagined.

She was the Witch of Wall Street, and Vanguard thought they had her tied to the pyre, flames licking at her heels, ready to burn her down.

But they had underestimated her.

They always underestimated her.

Agatha smirked, the kind of smirk that sent chills down spines and made people reconsider their life choices.

Because Vanguard didn’t realize one thing: Agatha Harkness didn’t burn.

She took every attack hurled her way, let it fuel her, transformed it into her power , and unleashed it back at them a thousand times stronger.

Vanguard had no idea what was coming.

But they would.

Oh, they would.

Chapter End Notes

Wasn't that fun? Still hate me?

Also, I loved the coven dynamic here. I watched the Marvel Studios Assembled: The Making of Agatha All Along, and Kathryn Hahn ends it with a quote, "for a a show about covenless witch, I sure need my coven." and I wanted to bring that same dynamic into this chapter. Agatha Harkness, even in the AU, needs her coven.

Also, the Jen/Agatha dynamic in this chapter had me literally kicking my feet while typing. So much fun to write!

Coven Two

Agatha jammed her key into the lock, the click echoing in the quiet hallway. She pushed the door open but stepped aside immediately, allowing the team of security agents to move past her like a tactical wave. They entered her home with precision, spreading out to sweep every corner for bugs and to install new surveillance cameras.

Agatha didn’t enter, instead she just leaned against the wall in the dim hallway, arms crossed as her head tilted back to rest against the hard surface. Her eyes fluttered shut, and for a brief moment, she allowed herself to sag, her body barely upright from sheer exhaustion.

The muted sounds of the team working inside her home echoed out into the hallway, but she barely registered it, her thoughts scattered and weighed down.

The security firm was, as promised , thorough and relentless. They’d swept the office earlier that evening, uncovering two bugs and a hidden micro-camera nestled in a potted plant just outside the war room.

Fucking Vanguard.

The anger flared momentarily before exhaustion snuffed it out. Because once the office was secure, the security firm turned the protection plan—one for Nicky, one for her, and one for Rio.

The meeting had been draining.

The team’s first suggestion was a safe house for all three of them. Agatha had shot that down immediately. She wasn’t about to uproot Nicky’s life or her own.

And that is when the conversation turned to Rio.

Her building had been clearly been compromised.

A hotel was suggested, but Rio’s silence had spoken volumes on what she thought of that. Agatha had seen the tension in her jaw, the stiffness in her posture.

And then Agatha had spoken before thinking it through.

"Would it just be easier if we were all in the same place?" she had asked, her tone weary but resigned.

Rio’s head had snapped toward her, surprise clear in her wide eyes.

“Yes,” one of the team members had replied. “Which is why we suggested the safe house.”

“Then Rio can stay at my place,” Agatha had said, the words tumbling out as if decided by some part of her she couldn’t control.

She’d ignored Rio’s startled look and, more importantly, refused to meet any of the other partners knowing smirk from across the table.

“I have three spare bedrooms,” she added matter-of-factly, as if that completely dismissed any thought of impropriety.

Jen had scoffed, her eyebrows shooting up in disbelief, but blessedly, she’d kept her mouth shut.

Smart.

Agatha had been teetering on the edge of her patience by the end of that meeting, and it wasn’t completely outside the realm of possibility that she’d lose her shit and launch herself across the table at her.

And now, as she stood in her hallway, listening to the faint buzz of the security team’s work, she replayed that particularly reckless moment in her mind.

Rio staying at her place.

Jesus. What in the hell was she thinking?

The sound of boots approaching the doorway brought her back to the present. One of the security agents stepped out, giving her a nod.

“It’s clear. We’ll need about an hour to finish installing the cameras.”

Agatha returned the nod.

“Everywhere but the bathrooms and bedrooms, as discussed.”

“Yes, ma’am.”

Her jaw tightened.

“Don’t call me ma’am.”

The security agent blinked, then recovered quickly, nodding again.

“Yes, Ms. Harkness.”

He turned and walked back into her home, leaving Agatha in the hallway once more.

She let out a heavy sigh, her head lolling to the side to the quite presence next to her.

Rio was standing there, leaning casually against the wall a few feet away. In her hand, she held an army green duffle bag, the strap loose and hanging from her fingers. Her dark eyes met Agatha’s, unreadable, and the sight sent a strange twist of emotion curling through Agatha’s chest.

This was such a terrible idea.

"You ready?" Agatha asked, her voice attempting confidence but landing somewhere closer to the sound of ice cracking across the northern icefields under the relentless weight of global warming.

Rio, of course, immediately picked up on it. Her eyes softened, her stance relaxing as she shifted the duffle to her other hand.

“You don’t have to do this,” she said quietly, her voice carrying the weight of both of their unspoken concerns.

Agatha straightened, forcing her shoulders back as if sheer posture could silence the war inside her head.

“ I do , actually,” she replied, her tone sharper than she intended.

She sighed, pinching the bridge of her nose before meeting Rio’s gaze.

“It’s not safe for you at your place. It’s not safe for you anywhere, really, except here.”

The words hung in the air, heavier than Agatha intended, as the anxiety that had been simmering all evening curled tighter in her chest. It wasn’t a gentle, passing storm anymore. It was the kind that rattled windows and snapped tree branches, building momentum just beneath the surface.

Not a full-blown tornado— yet —but the kind that left you constantly bracing for it and eyeing the basement door.

Agatha swallowed hard, forcing herself to push the storm back into its cage, even though it seemed like it was determined to claw its way out. She took a steadying breath, running her hand through her hair as she straightened her spine and pushed herself off the wall.

She turned her head slightly, just enough to glance at Rio over her shoulder.

"The hallway or the spare bedroom, your choice," Agatha said, her voice carefully measured, but teetering on the edge.

Agatha moved into her home, forcing herself to follow the usual routine that had always kept her grounded.

Shoes off.

Coat hung neatly in the closet.

Purse on the front table.

Cell phone in hand.

Each step was deliberate, mechanical—a lifeline to cling to in the chaos.

Behind her, she heard Rio following the same steps. After all, this wasn’t her first time in Agatha’s home— not her first rodeo.

But as Agatha stepped into the living room, her sanctuary, the place that usually greeted her such calm, everything shifted. Her breath quickened, coming out in short, uneven bursts as her fingers twitched at her sides.

There were so many people here.

Too many.

Moving around her house like they belonged there, speaking in low voices, the sharp whirl of power tools slicing through the air.

It felt invasive, unsettling, wrong .

The storm inside her chest swelled, clouds thickening, swirling faster and faster. She could almost hear the warning sirens wailing in her mind.

This was her home, her refuge —and now—now it was just another battlefield.

“Agatha.”

Her name, spoken softly but firmly, cut through the rising tide of chaos inside her. Like a small ray of light breaking through blackened clouds, it grounded her, pulling her back from the brink.

Agatha turned.

Rio stood there, watching her with that look—intense, unyielding, and somehow infinitely understanding. The kind of look that told Agatha that Rio knew—knew exactly what was going on inside her, even if Agatha didn’t have the words to explain it.

“What room?” Rio asked, her voice calm but purposeful, anchoring Agatha.

Agatha let out a shaky breath, her eyes flicking toward the hallway like it held some elusive solution to somehow get her life back under her control.

“Second door on the right,” she murmured, her voice quieter than she intended.

Rio nodded, turning to go, but then she hesitated. She stopped mid-step and glanced back, her expression softening.

“Come with me,” she said, her tone firm but not harsh, more of a directive than a request. And then, she seemed to remember they weren’t alone, and caught herself. She adjusted the bag on her shoulder, and she softened further.

“I need your help.”

Agatha hesitated, her mind caught in a swirl of thoughts, but before she could consciously decide, her feet were already moving. Her body acted on instinct, as if it had bypassed her mind entirely—like it knew what she needed before she even did.

Agatha followed Rio down the hallway, her teeth gritting every time she heard the sound of drills boring into her walls. Strangers brushed past her, their presence far too close in the already narrow space.

It made her skin crawl.

She hated this.

Her life was being invaded.

Her walls were breached.

Rio opened the door at on the right stepped inside, pausing to wait for Agatha to follow before quietly shutting the door behind them. The relative silence was jarring, but the sounds from outside the door still crept in, like a shadow she couldn't quite escape.

Agatha’s eyes swept over the room. She hadn’t been in here in ages. Why would she? It wasn’t a space she used. But it was exactly as she remembered—simple yet elegant, understated in a way that still felt inviting.

It was the third nicest bedroom in the house, but the last one with its own en suite, a choice Agatha had made deliberately. She knew Rio would appreciate having her own bathroom— her own space .

Then the sharp bang of a hammer echoed from elsewhere in the house, so loud it made her jump. Her teeth clenched hard enough to ache, her hands curling into fists at her sides.

The restless, anxious energy inside her clawed higher— louder .

Rio moved past her, tossing her bag onto the bed without ceremony, before heading toward the open bathroom door. She stopped in the threshold, turned on the light, and then shifted to face Agatha, her gaze steady.

For a moment, she simply watched Agatha, something unreadable flickering in her eyes. Then, with a small tilt of her head, she gestured toward the bathroom.

“Come here.”

Agatha stayed rooted where she was, her heels practically digging into the floor. She didn’t want to move. She didn’t want to be bossed around.

Not now .

Not with everything spiraling so wildly out of control.

Her jaw clenched as she fought against the wave of restlessness surging inside her. It was like holding back a dam ready to burst. Everything felt so precarious, like if even the smallest sliver of control was taken from her, she would shatter into a thousand pieces.

Rio saw it —the tension in Agatha’s stance, the way her hands fisted at her sides, her breath coming just a little too fast. And as she did the sharp edges in her gaze softened, her expression shifting to something gentler, something... patient .

“Agatha,” Rio said softly, her voice steady but pleading. “ Please , come here.”

Agatha’s shoulders slumped almost imperceptibly at the word.

Please.

It wasn’t a command.

It wasn’t a demand.

It was a request, and it reached her in a way nothing else could.

Her throat tightened, but she forced herself to move, her steps slow and deliberate, until she crossed the threshold.

The bathroom was the smallest in the house—just enough space for a single sink, a toilet, and a decently sized tiled shower. The moment she stepped inside, the walls seemed to close in, pressing against her.

The weight of everythin g—her office, her home, her family— being invaded, the constant noise, the fear and uncertainty—it built like a pressure cooker inside her chest. She felt like she was seconds away from snapping, seconds away from tearing into Rio, of letting the storm take control and consuming everything in its path.

And then, Rio reached past her and turned on the fan.

Agatha blinked, startled by the sudden— loud , mechanical hum filling the small room. The anger that had been teetering on the edge of exploding shifted to confusion, as her mind tried to catch up with Rio’s actions.

Then suddenly, the sound of the fan drowned out everything .

No voices in her house.

No drills or hammers.

No footsteps echoing through the halls.

Just the steady, rhythmic whir of the fan.

Agatha exhaled slowly, not even realizing she’d been holding her breath until that moment. The storm inside her didn’t vanish entirely, but it stilled— just enough —as the relentless chaos from outside was replaced by the steady, grounding hum .

Her gaze found Rio, torn between irritation and gratitude.

Agatha hated being read so easily, hated that Rio seemed to know exactly what she needed when she couldn’t even name it herself. And yet, she couldn’t deny the shift—that the suffocating grip on her chest had loosened, if only slightly.

Rio stepped back, the bathroom not allowing her much space, but she moved until she was pressed against the opposite wall—giving Agatha as much a space as possible.

They stayed like that for a few moments, the hum of the fan filling the small space. The noise helped— a little —but that restless energy inside her refused to settle. It curled tighter and tighter, like a cloud threatening to touch down the earth, and destroy everything in its path.

“Tell me.”

Rio’s voice broke through the haze, soft but unwavering, cutting through Agatha’s spiraling thoughts.

Agatha blinked, her gaze darting to Rio, who was watching her with that maddening mix of patience and understanding.

Tell me.

Agatha knew what she meant. Rio was asking about her. About what was wrong—what was clawing at her from the inside out.

Agatha opened her mouth, then shut it just as quickly.

How did she even begin to explain?

How did she put into words the relentless— the suffocating weight pressing down on her chest?

How her life felt like it was fracturing all around her?

Her fingers flexed at her sides, and she looked away, staring at the bathroom tiles as if they might offer her an answer.

But they didn’t.

So finally, she settled on the only words that seemed to fit, her voice raw and strained as hot tears frustration clouded her eyes.

“I feel completely out of control.”

Agatha continued to stare at the tile, her vision blurring slightly as her fingers curled and twisted, the tremble in them betraying the storm building inside her.

Silence greeted her words.

And then, softly—barely audible over the hum of the fan—Rio spoke.

“Okay.”

The word was simple, but the way she said it carried weight, a quiet understanding that wrapped around Agatha like a lifeline.

“ Okay ,” Rio repeated, even softer this time.

Silence settled between them, heavy but not oppressive, as if the stillness itself were giving Agatha permission to just exist in the moment.

Then out of nowhere, Rio’s voice cut through the quiet, low and steady.

“Take it back.”

Agatha blinked, her eyes snapping open to meet Rio’s gaze.

“Take what back?” she bit out, confusion transforming into anger.

Rio didn’t even blink an eye. She just tilted her head, letting it rest against the wall, her expression soft yet charged with a simmering intensity that burned behind those dark eyes.

“All of it,” she said simply. “Your control. Your power. Everything you think you’ve lost.”

The words lingered, heavy with meaning, pressing into Agatha with a force she couldn’t ignore, like a flame licking at the edges of turned over oil tanker.

“It’s right here, Agatha,” Rio continued, her voice roughening, taking on a raw edge. “The one thing you can control.”

Agatha’s breath hitched, the air in the room turning heavier, warmer, pressing against her like a tangible force.

A flush rose beneath her collar, creeping up her neck and spreading across her chest like wildfire. Without thinking, her hand shot up, tugging at the collar of the hoodie, desperate to relieve some of the pressure building within her.

Rio’s gaze flicked to the movement, her dark eyes catching on Agatha’s restless hand. The look she gave wasn’t smug or triumphant—it was something far more intimate, something knowing. A quiet, unspoken challenge lingered there, but not one meant to provoke. No, this was something gentler, coaxing, as if she were carefully reaching for the storm Agatha was trying so desperately to hold at bay.

“It’s okay,” murmured Rio, eyes flashing, as she gave a nod—like she was giving permission. “ Take it .”

And yet, Agatha held herself back.

The urge to act, to seize the control Rio was so willingly offering, clawed at her, relentless and sharp.
