She fought it with everything she had because she knew herself—knew the force of what simmered beneath her carefully maintained surface. Releasing it wasn’t something you unleashed on a person.

It needed containment.

Solitude, with a bottle of bourbon and dark thoughts.

Rio didn’t know what she was saying. Didn’t know what she was giving permission for Agatha to do. She couldn’t possibly understand the storm she was inviting in.

Agatha’s fingers twisted restlessly at her sides, betraying the battle raging inside her. Her breathing quickened, her chest tightening as the heat and tension grew unbearable, each second stretching impossibly thin.

“ Agatha ,” Rio murmured, her voice a low rasp that seemed to fill every corner of the small bathroom. Her gaze flicked down, honing in on Agatha’s restless, twisting fingers before lifting back to her face. There was no softness left in her expression now.

“All you have to do,” she continued, her words deliberate and laced with a challenge—daring Agatha to rise, “is take those restless, beautiful fingers of yours... and bury them—”

Agatha moved before the sentence could fully land. She surged forward, her hands shooting up to cradle Rio’s face, gripping firmly as their mouths collided in a kiss so fierce it was almost bruising.

And for the first time in what felt like forever, the storm inside Agatha was at rest.

Chapter End Notes

The bathroom scene was purposeful. I was really trying to build the same feeling from episode 1 where Rio helps Agatha out of the spell, and I feel like I got close. The dialogue from the show didn't fit it, but I feel like I captured it with just the tension alone.

Or maybe I am just delusional? lol

Also hope the storm analogy of Agatha's control slipping wasn't too repetitive. Once I found it I just stuck with it, and felt like I had to build upon it throughout the chapter.

Lastly, I loved the last scene. Kicking my feet and giggling at baby lesbian Agatha discovering something new and exciting, and feeling like a kid on Christmas morning lol

Familiar By Thy Side

Agatha sat at the dining room table, her eyes fixed on the steaming plate of breakfast in front of her. Perfectly scrambled eggs, bacon, and a slice of buttered toast. She inhaled, catching the comforting aroma, and her stomach rumbled despite herself.

But she didn’t pick up her fork right away.

Instead, she just stared at it.

She didn’t eat a real breakfast often. Her mornings typically consisted of an organic granola bar and an oversized mug of coffee—functional, quick, efficient. Nicky had cereal and toast.

It wasn’t because she didn’t like breakfast. In truth, she loved it. Pancakes, omelets, French toast—breakfast was a feast of comfort. It was her favorite meal.

The only crutch?

Agatha Harkness didn’t cook. She was terrible at it. Always had been.

And what did Agatha Harkness do when was bad at something? She avoided it. Like the fucking plague.

Thank god for Sonya.

Sonya, who was a god damn godsend wrapped in one miracle of a person. Nanny. Cleaner. And, thank everything holy, a phenomenal cook. Without her, Nicky and Agatha would have been surviving on a steady diet of takeout, pizza rolls, and whatever sad excuse for a meal could be microwaved in under three minutes.

There was something about a home-cooked meal that made a house feel like a home. Agatha found comfort in knowing she could provide that for Nicky—not directly, of course, but by hiring someone who could. She was self-aware enough to recognize her limitations, and cooking was one of them.

The only problem? Sonya had weekends off and didn’t arrive until 8:00 a.m. on weekdays, which left Agatha in charge of breakfast. This meant surviving on granola bars and cereal

during the week and resorting to takeout on the weekends. A far cry from the warm, satisfying meals Sonya churned out effortlessly.

At one point, she had briefly considered hiring a private chef to handle every meal, breakfast included. It had been tempting—a fantasy, even—but in the end, it had felt like too much. Too indulgent, even for her. Plus, there was something humbling about cereal and pizza rolls, a dose of reality she didn’t want Nicky to grow up completely removed from.

And if Agatha were willing to admit it, she didn’t want to give up pizza roll nights. Those nights, sitting on the couch with Nicky, laughing over the TV while munching on tiny, lava- hot bites, were sacred in their own way. Nicky loved them, and honestly, so did she.

Her gaze lingered on the plate in front of her, as a faint shadow of a memory flitted across her mind.

Evanora had been a terrible cook too.

Agatha could still recall the dry, tasteless slabs of meat Evanora would slap onto a plate, accompanied by canned vegetables. But even those meals were rare. Most of her childhood had been spent living off bologna sandwiches—cheap, cold, but dependable. There was always a pack of bologna in the fridge, next to the expired milk and whatever else Evanora had forgotten to throw out.

Agatha’s grip on her fork loosened as her gaze shifted to the steaming cup of coffee that had just been placed beside her plate. She glanced up, catching the subtle movement of Rio sliding the cup toward her without so much as a glance, already sinking into the chair next to her.

Rio didn’t say anything as she settled in, her own plate in front of her.

The one she’d cooked—for herself and Agatha.

In Agatha’s kitchen. After waking up in Agatha’s bed, in Agatha’s arms. After showering in Agatha’s bathroom.

Now here she was, sitting at Agatha’s kitchen table, holding Agatha’s fork, drinking Agatha’s coffee, from one of Agatha’s favorite mugs.

It was so... domestic.

Agatha hated it.

Agatha reached for the cup and took a sip.

She hated this quiet invasion of her life, this disruption of her carefully constructed routine. She hated how easily Rio had slipped into her world, rearranging pieces of it without even trying.

But most of all, she hated how it also felt strangely—comforting.

Good, even.

Her grip on the coffee cup tightened slightly as the thought sank in, uninvited and unwelcome. Agatha wasn’t supposed to like this. She wasn’t supposed to want someone else so deeply entrenched in her life, her space.

And yet...

The soft clink of Rio’s fork against her plate pulled Agatha from her thoughts.

She glanced over, watching as Rio took a bite of her food, completely at ease, like they’d been doing this for years.

The anxiousness coiled tighter in Agatha’s chest as she followed suit, and took the first bite of her eggs—and fuck —they were perfectly cooked, perfectly seasoned.

And she fought against the urge to groan. As if she needed another reason to love this woman?

That thought slammed into her, hard and unrelenting, and the ferocity of it made her drop her fork with a loud clang on the table.

Rio glanced up at the sound, one brow arching in question.

“I know it didn’t taste that bad,” she teased.

Agatha shot her a look, sharp but tinged with exasperation, before sighing heavily and running a hand through her hair. She fought to get a grip on the emotions swirling inside her.

“Doesn’t this feel weird to you?” she finally asked, gesturing vaguely around them.

Rio didn’t answer immediately, instead leaning back in her chair with a casualness that only irritated Agatha more. She sipped her coffee, her expression unreadable until she finally smirked.

“When life gives you lemons...” Rio trailed off, her tone light, teasing.

Agatha’s glare was immediate, sharp enough to cut glass, and thankfully straight through Rio stupid statement.

Rio sighed wearily at that, her smirk fading as she slouched slightly in her chair. The playful mask slipped, replaced by something quieter, more honest.

“Yes,” Rio said simply, meeting Agatha’s eyes. “It’s weird.”

Agatha flicked her hand up in a sharp exclamation.

“Thank you,” she muttered, needing the affirmation like air.

She sighed heavily, her gaze dropping back to her plate before picking up a piece of bacon and biting into it. She chewed it with deliberate force, as though trying to grind the entire absurdity of their situation into dust under her teeth.

“You know,” Rio began, her voice dripping with teasing intent, the kind that sent an instant ripple of irritation—and anticipation—through Agatha.

Agatha froze mid-chew, her eyes narrowing, already bracing herself for whatever nonsense was about to come out of the woman’s mouth.

Rio smirked, enjoying the moment far too much, and continued.

“This whole situation,” she said, pausing to take a languid sip of her coffee, her free hand gesturing lazily between them, “is like the epitome of stereotypical lesbian behavior.”

Agatha didn’t know what she was expecting to come out of Rio’s mouth, but it wasn’t that. She tilted her head in confusion at that, continuing chewing before finally swallowing.

“What are you talking about?”

Rio leaned forward, taking her time to spear a piece of egg with her fork. She popped it into her mouth, humming softly before finally meeting Agatha’s gaze with a teasing glint in her eye.

“U-hauling,” she said simply.

Agatha blinked, her brow furrowing.

What the fuck was Rio talking about?

“Like... the moving truck?”

Rio’s jaw dropped dramatically, as she gave Agatha an incredulous look, shaking her head in disbelief.

“You’ve really never heard the joke?” Rio asked, her tone brimming with amazement, her disbelief as playful as it was genuine.

Agatha’s brow furrowed as she racked her brain, searching for any context to latch onto, but came up with nothing. The frustration of not knowing—of being on the outside of an inside joke—pricked at her pride. She glared at Rio, her jaw tightening, and her tone sharpened as she spoke.

“I’m sorry,” Agatha deadpanned, the words somehow both a hiss and a mock. “I’m not well- versed in the ‘ vagina monologue ,’ Rio. Please, enlighten me.”

Rio’s grin widened, a devilish light sparking in her eyes. She leaned back in her chair, clearly enjoying every moment of Agatha’s irritation.

“I forget sometimes that you're a baby lesbian,” Rio said, her voice dripping with exaggerated sympathy, her grin widening as she clearly savored every second of this.

Agatha’s left eye twitched, a telltale sign that her patience was already wearing dangerously thin.

“Alright, listen,” Rio began in a tone so placating it could’ve been meant for a toddler. She even held up her hands, before bringing them together like she was telling a story with them. “When two mommies fall in love...”

Agatha growled, her fingers tightening around her fork as she leaned forward, her voice low and full of menace.

“You know I have enough connections in the upper echelons of New York society to kill you with my bare fucking hands and still get away with it, right?”

Rio didn’t even flinch. If anything, her smirk deepened, her mouth twitching with barely contained laughter as she took a slow sip of her coffee, letting the moment stretch just enough to test Agatha’s patience.

But then, just as quickly, the teasing faded. The smirk softened into something quieter, more reflective, as she set her cup down and looked at Agatha with a serious, almost resigned expression.

“Okay,” she murmured with a heavy sigh, pausing to collect her thoughts before continuing. “There’s this running joke about lesbians—how we move fast. Women bond faster. We just... get each other, you know? No hurdles, no walls, none of that emotional baggage that men seem to drag out for years.”

She paused, as if considering what to say next.

“Even for the truly emotionally stunted women—”

Agatha’s glare sharpened. She could feel the barb coming. Agatha’s mouth opened to retort, but Rio cut her off with a look that was more knowing than teasing.

“— like us ,” Rio finished simply, the weight of the words settling between them, as she claimed she had just as many problems as Agatha, before moving on. “Even then, it’s like running the 100-meter hurdles—with no hurdles. Straight to the finish line in record time while everyone else is jumping and stumbling behind us.”

Agatha blinked, processing Rio’s words, her mind working overtime to unravel the logic—or lack thereof—behind them. She sat back slightly, her fork clinking against the table as she waved her hand in mild disbelief, as if to wave away the nonsense.

“That cannot be true,” Agatha stated, her tone flat and edged with skepticism, as though sheer disbelief might somehow undo the absurdity Rio had just said.

Rio chuckled, leaning back in her chair with the kind of ease that set Agatha’s teeth on edge. Her eyes sparkled, full of amusement.

“Oh, but it is,” Rio replied, her voice light but unyielding. It was the kind of tone someone uses to drop bigger news. “One of my friends from Texas used to say lesbians date like dogs age—one year for a straight couple equals seven for us.”

Agatha blinked, as her mind stumbled over the analogy. Before she could form a retort, Rio raised a finger to chin, her expression turning mock-serious.

“Let’s do the math,” Rio said, pausing as though deep in thought. “We’ve been at this for a little over a month now, give or take.” She feigned looking up at the ceiling, mumbling theatrically, “Carry the one, divide by seven...”

Her gaze snapped back to Agatha, and the smirk that spread across her face was absolutely menacing, practically dripping with satisfaction.

“Congratulations, my love” Rio declared, her tone teasing but triumphant. “We just celebrated our one-year anniversary.”

Agatha’s jaw dropped, and for a moment, all she could do was gape at Rio, torn between indignation and outright disbelief.

“That—” she began, only to falter, eyes narrowing. “You’re just fucking with me.”

Rio met her gaze with a deadpan look, chewing her bacon like she was unbothered by the accusation.

“Unfortunately, no,” she said, using her strip of bacon like a professor gesturing with a pointer during a lecture. “It’s absolutely a thing. I mean, I’ve done my best to avoid the stereotype my entire life, but I’ve seen it happen with my friends. Stereotypes exist for a reason—they’re rooted in some kind of truth.”

She paused, giving Agatha a pointed look that was both teasing and resigned.

“And now, look at me,” Rio added, gesturing vaguely around them as if to highlight the absurdity of their situation. “You’ve ruined me.”

Agatha scoffed, straightening in her seat and gesturing between them.

“We are not like that.”

Rio raised an eyebrow, clearly unconvinced, as her smirk widened.

“Oh, we’re not?”

“No,” Agatha snapped, gripping her fork tightly and brandishing it like a weapon. “We’re not. For one, you’re not moving in. You’re here for safety reasons. Safety , Rio.”

She paused, frowning slightly as she tried to make her voice steadier, more commanding.

“And two, I barely even like you.”

The second the words left her mouth, Agatha winced inwardly.

Damn it.

Not as confident as she’d intended. The hesitation in her tone was a dead giveaway, and of course, Rio noticed it immediately.

Rio’s head tilted, a slow grin spreading across her face like she’d just been handed the best gift imaginable. Then she laughed—a loud, full-bodied sound that filled the room. She threw her head back, her dark hair catching the soft morning light in a way that made Agatha’s chest tighten despite herself.

When Rio looked back at her, her eyes were warm, playful, and entirely too knowing.

“Barely like me, huh?” she said, her smirk widening. “You’re so full of shit. You love me, Agatha Harkness. You can’t say it without choking, but you do.”

Agatha glared at her, though her heart betrayed her by doing an annoying little flip at the sound of Rio’s confidence.

“Did those exact words ever leave my mouth, counselor ?” she retorted, lifting her chin stubbornly, her grip on the fork tightening just slightly.

It was a strong argument, legally speaking. She hadn’t said those exact words—not directly, anyway. Sure, she would conceded that had told Rio she loved her, but not in a way that carried the full weight of saying it plainly. That admission still caused a twist of discomfort in her stomach, a vulnerability she wasn’t ready to lay bare.

Rio raised an eyebrow, giving Agatha a long, assessing look, the kind that said she was deciding just how much she wanted to push. Her smirk didn’t waver, though. If anything, it deepened, her amusement written all over her face.

Agatha wasn’t having it. She lifted her chin a fraction higher and shot Rio a pointed look of her own, her fork still in hand like a weapon of pure stubbornness.

“If it can’t hold up in court,” Agatha said, her tone clipped, her emphasis sharp as a blade, “it won’t hold up in my house.”

She added extra weight to the last two words, the “ my ” landing like a gavel striking a judge’s bench.

Rio blinked, clearly taken aback for a split second before recovering, her lips twitching into a full grin.

“Noted,” she murmured, leaning back in her chair, the picture of mock compliance. But her eyes betrayed her—dark and full of that damnable confidence that made Agatha want to simultaneously strangle and kiss her.

“Good,” Agatha said, stabbing her fork into her eggs with a precise jab, as if to solidify her point. Her tone was firm, her authority seemingly reasserted—or at least, she hoped.

One year anniversary. How ridiculous.

The rhythmic clacking of keys filled the living room by mid-day, blending seamlessly with the soothing narration of a documentary about mushrooms playing in the background. Agatha absently noted the pattern of Rio’s taste in TV—it was always nature-focused, calming, almost meditative.

She didn’t mind it.

At least it wasn’t some ridiculous reality show.

Sitting on opposite ends of the couch, Agatha glanced up from her laptop to the other side where Rio was seated, legs tucked underneath her, her fingers flying across the keyboard. Her posture was relaxed, but her focus was razor-sharp, her eyes scanning the screen like she was devouring every line of text. Whatever she was working on had her utterly engrossed.

Agatha leaned back slightly, narrowing her eyes as curiosity began to take hold. To the best of her knowledge, she hadn’t assigned Rio anything pressing—at least not anything that demanded the level of focus she was currently witnessing.

And she hadn’t been fully transitioned to Jen or Alice yet.

That shift wouldn’t happen until tomorrow.

So, the question lingered, gnawing at her: What was Rio Vidal working on with such intensity?

It had been eating at Agatha for hours, and finally, the question escaped her lips before she even realized she was speaking.

“What are you working on?”

Rio blinked, startled, as if she’d forgotten Agatha was in the room. Her eyes met Agatha’s, a flicker of surprise quickly masked.

“Nothing,” Rio said, a little too quickly, her tone nonchalant but unconvincing.

Agatha’s brows lifted, her expression unimpressed.

“That’s a bold lie,” she retorted, snapping her laptop shut and setting it aside. She crossed her legs, folding her hands in her lap as she gave Rio her full attention. “You’ve been glued to that thing for hours. So, what is it?”

Rio hesitated, her fingers hovering over the keyboard as if weighing her options. Finally, she let out a sigh and turned the laptop toward Agatha, the screen now angled for her to see.

Agatha frowned, leaning forward as her eyes scanned the display. It took her a moment to piece together what she was looking at: graphs, trend analyses, and an Excel spreadsheet filled with neatly marked money lines. Her gaze snapped up to Rio, her brows shooting upward in surprise.

“You play the stock market?” she asked, incredulous.

Rio smirked, leaning back into the couch and crossing her arms, clearly enjoying Agatha’s reaction.

“How else do you think I afford my place?” she replied, one brow arching in a teasing challenge. “Because let’s be honest—you pay your first-year associates barely enough to share rent with seven other people to rent a two-bedroom close enough to the office.”

Agatha’s jaw tightened, the accusation hitting harder than she cared to admit.

“Excuse me,” she retorted, her tone sharp and defensive. “We pay very competitive starting salaries.”

Rio snorted, shaking her head with a mix of amusement and exasperation.

“Competitive compared to what? Barista wages?” She arched a brow, letting the words hang for a beat before continuing. “I mean, let’s be real. You probably don’t see it, because,” she paused to gesture around her, “and most of my peers come from money. Don’t think I haven’t noticed the last names of my fellow associates.”

Agatha blinked, momentarily thrown off balance. She wasn’t used to hearing her firm—and by extension, herself—called out so directly.

“What’s that supposed to mean?” she asked, her voice clipped, though a hint of curiosity crept in despite herself.

Rio leaned forward, her elbows resting on her knees, and gestured casually with her hand.

“It means that for most of your associates, this job is a stepping stone or a resume builder, not a lifeline. They have trust funds, inheritances, or mommy and daddy footing the bill for their midtown apartments. But for people like me, though? This job is the lifeline. And trust me, it’s not enough on its own.”

Agatha opened her mouth to respond, then closed it, unable to form a rebuttal. She didn’t know what hit harder—Rio’s bluntness or the possible truth behind her words.

Agatha tucked that little nugget of information away, a mental note to dig into later. She knew inflation was up—rent was sky-high—but she hadn’t felt it the same way others might. Wealth shielded her from such realities. If her firm wasn’t paying their people a living wage, that was a serious problem. One that needed to be addressed.

Agatha’s gaze dropped back to Rio’s laptop, her eye immediately picking out the patterns. She’d represented enough investments firms and had a diverse enough investment portfolio

to be comfortable reading market data. And based on what she saw on Rio’s screen—this wasn’t the work of an amateur.

A series of scheduled trades were lined up for the next morning, each neatly organized and clearly optimized, given that the market was closed today. The precision of it all struck her— lines of numbers, detailed charts, and calculated orders that hinted at someone who wasn’t just playing the market but mastering it.

“You’re not just dabbling in this,” Agatha remarked, her voice laced with a mixture of surprise and genuine admiration. “You’re good.”

Rio’s fingers paused over the keyboard, and she looked up at Agatha with a sly smirk tugging at the corners of her mouth.

“Oh, come now, Agatha,” she said, her tone dripping with playful confidence. “You should know me well enough by now—I don’t just survive. I thrive .”

The audacity of the statement hung in the air, and yet Agatha couldn’t deny the truth of it. It was quintessentially Rio—unapologetically bold and utterly capable.

Agatha blinked, momentarily caught off guard. She tilted her head, studying Rio with a newfound curiosity.

“How do you even know how to do all this?” she asked, gesturing toward the laptop.

Rio turned the screen back toward herself, leaning into the couch with an almost casual grace. She gave Agatha a look over the top of the laptop, a faint smirk pulling at her lips.

“I double-majored in economics and statistics,” she said with a shrug, like it was no big deal. “Started dabbling in the stock market when I turned eighteen. Took my measly paychecks from a farmers’ market job and threw them into investments. I got good at it—fast. So, I decided to major in it during college. Almost went for my master’s in finance, but...” she trailed off, giving Agatha a pointed look. “Law school won out.”

Agatha blinked, the puzzle pieces of Rio slowly falling into place in a way that both impressed and mildly annoyed her.

“I can actually see that,” she said, shifting her position to lean her elbow against the couch, her head propped on her hand as she stared at Rio with a teasing smirk. “You certainly have the cockiness for Wall Street.”

Rio worked her tongue against her cheek, a smile playing at the corners of her mouth as she met Agatha’s gaze with a smirk of her own.

“I’ll take that as a compliment,” Rio quipped, her tone light and amused.

Agatha huffed, rolling her eyes but unable to suppress her own grin.

“Of course you would,” she muttered, her voice dripping with mock exasperation.

Her eyes lingered on Rio for a moment, quietly taking her in. She was beginning to pick up these little pieces of Rio—these fragments of a life so deliberately lived, filled with ambition, resilience, and unapologetic confidence. It was...disarming. Fascinating, even. And somehow, it left Agatha feeling like she was just beginning to scratch the surface.

Agatha leaned in slightly, unable to resist her curiosity.

“What made you choose law school?” she asked, her tone softer than before.

Rio’s smirk faded, shifting into something more bittersweet, her expression tinged with nostalgia.

“It was something my dad used to say to me growing up,” she began, her voice carrying a warmth that hadn’t been there before. “As you can imagine, raising a kid who remembers everything is... a real treat .”

A wry smile ghosted across her lips.

“Even as a kid, I’d call them out on the little fibs or stories parents tell to keep their kids in line. And every time I did, my dad would let out this loud, dramatic sigh and say, ‘ You should be a lawyer someday, mija. Nothing gets past you .’”

She paused, the memory seeming to hang between them, both tender and amusing. It softened Rio in a way that made Agatha’s chest tighten.

“I guess,” Rio continued, her voice heavier now, tinged with a depth that hadn’t been there before. “I applied to law school for him, and then...I fell in love with it. It just felt right after that—like he was guiding me still.”

The words settled into the air between them, soft yet weighted, carrying an emotional gravity that Agatha couldn’t ignore. For a moment, silence hung between them, and Agatha let it, sensing that anything she said might cheapen the sentiment.

Another puzzle piece fell into place in Agatha’s growing picture of who Rio Vidal was. And this one fit squarely into the bittersweet corner of her life. It was a small but significant piece of the whole—a glimpse into the things that shaped her.

“What about you?” Rio asked, her voice lighter, cutting through the air pulling Agatha from her thoughts. “Why did you go to law school?”

Agatha blinked, the question catching her off guard. But she welcomed the simplicity of her own story. It wasn’t heavy. It wasn’t tangled in emotion. It just... was.

“Oh, that’s easy,” she said, a faint smirk tugging at her lips. “I did it for the money.”

Rio snorted, her incredulous expression practically dripping with disbelief.

“Seriously?”

Agatha shrugged, leaning back into the couch like she didn’t feel the weight of Rio’s judgment.

“I grew up in a trailer park,” she began, the admission catching her off guard for a second, before recovering. “We were always scraping by, barely making it. When you grow up trying to rub two pennies together just to survive, you think about security—and money meant security.”

Her tone shifted slightly, darker, as she continued.

“My mom was a self-proclaimed medicine woman. Half home remedies, half religious healing, full delusion.”

She rolled her eyes, though the bitterness in her voice betrayed her effort to play it off.

“She destroyed any inclination for me to want to go into medicine. Law seemed... safer. Lucrative .”

Agatha met Rio’s gaze evenly, daring her to challenge the practicality of her choice. But Rio didn’t. Instead, a flicker of understanding softened her smirk, the humor in her eyes tempered by something gentler.

“Wow,” Rio finally said, her tone caught between teasing and genuine admiration. She paused, lips twitching like she was debating whether to say something witty.

“Inspiring,” she added dryly.

Agatha couldn’t help but smirk in return, the urge to lighten the mood outweighing any need to dwell on the past. After all, she had earned every ounce of humor that had come out of her messed-up childhood—might as well use it.

“Think I could host a TED Talk on it?” Agatha deadpanned, raising an eyebrow. “ Don’t follow your dreams, kids—follow the money. ”

Rio’s smirk widened, amusement dancing in her dark eyes as she leaned back into the couch, utterly at ease.

“I’d watch it,” she said lightly. “Might even take notes.”

Agatha scoffed, rolling her eyes.

“You don’t have to take notes. You remember everything.”

Rio’s smirk at that.

It wasn’t lost on Agatha that they’d just shared pieces of themselves that most people kept locked away. It wasn’t until the quiet settled back in that she fully realized what had happened—that she’d told Rio about her childhood, about growing up with nothing, about a mother who barely deserved the title. She hadn’t even told James any of that until they were engaged, and only because he’d asked if her family would be coming to the wedding.

Her chest tightened.

Fuck.

Maybe Rio had a point about the lack of hurdles between two women. How else could she explain sharing one of the deepest, most guarded parts of herself without even realizing she’d done it?

It wasn’t like her.

Agatha Harkness didn’t open doors that had been bolted shut for decades—not for anyone.

And yet, here she was...letting Rio in.

Her chest tightened, curling in on itself, the vulnerability clawing at her edges. She needed to break the moment before it swallowed her whole. With a sharp breath, she pushed herself upright, grabbing her laptop and flipping it open, her fingers finding the keys almost immediately.

The familiar screen lit up, and she dove back into work, letting the rhythm of typing steady her spiraling thoughts.

She could feel Rio’s gaze on her, lingering like a soft weight.

But Rio—being Rio—didn’t call her out.

Agatha heard the faint shuffle of movement from the other end of the couch, and moments later, the steady clicking of keys resumed, signaling that Rio had moved on too.

Agatha looked down at her computer, trying to read this report, but eyes began to ache, a dull strain creeping in as she squinted at the small text on her laptop screen. The brightness of the display didn’t help, and she let out an annoyed grumble, rubbing at her temples.

“Ugh,” she muttered under her breath, the faint acknowledgment of her own mortality tugging at her pride. She hated this—hated the reminder that age was creeping up on her, slow but unrelenting.

Grumbling again, she leaned over to her bag, fishing through its contents with a slight scowl until her fingers brushed against the familiar frame of her glasses. She didn’t need them often, but when she did, the relief was undeniable.

Pulling them out, she inspected them briefly. At least the wide black flames were fashionable.

Small victories.

She slipped the glasses on, the world sharpening into crisp clarity almost instantly. Agatha sighed softly, the tension in her eyes easing as she focused back on the report in front of her.

She managed to get through the first couple of paragraphs when a shift in the atmosphere caught her attention. The documentary had stopped running, the quiet that replaced it amplifying every other sound—or lack thereof. The absence of noise from Rio’s direction was what truly pricked at Agatha’s senses.

Not a single keystroke. Not a rustle of movement.

Her eyes flicked up over the rim of her laptop, and instantly, she was met with blazing dark eyes. Eyes she knew all too well.

Agatha’s breath hitched.

That look.

It was the kind of look that usually ended with her pressed against some surface, legs trembling, chest heaving, and body utterly wrecked.

Agatha blinked, her mind scrambling to keep up with whatever was happening.

“You’re wearing glasses,” Rio said, her voice low and gravelly, the sound sending a shiver down Agatha’s spine.

It took her a beat too long to connect the dots. Seriously? The glasses did it? Of all things.

“Really?” Agatha asked, her tone flat as she pointedly removed the glasses from her face, dangling them between two fingers. “This is what does it for you?”

Rio tilted her head, her smirk slow and deliberate, her eyes raking over Agatha like she was something to be devoured.

“I didn’t think you could get any hotter,” Rio murmured, her voice low and raspy. “And yet, here we are.”

Agatha felt a flush creep up her neck, unbidden and entirely unwelcome.

“You’re ridiculous,” she muttered, slipping the glasses back on and glaring at Rio over the frames.

Agatha sighed sharply through her nose and tried to focus, her eyes dropping back to the screen. She read the same sentence twice, then a third time, the words blurring together as her mind failed to process a single one of them.

Her fingers hovered over the keyboard, unmoving.

“Agatha.”

Her name, spoken low and deliberate, rolled off Rio’s tongue like a challenge.

Jesus.

The way Rio said her name.

It wasn’t just her voice—it was the way she dragged it out, low and rough, like it wasn’t just a name but a promise. Agatha felt it in her chest, curling low in her stomach and spreading outward.

“What?” Agatha finally bit out, not looking up.

“Look at me.”

Agatha hesitated, her pulse drumming in her ears. She didn’t want to look. Knew exactly what she’d find if she did.

“Rio,” she warned, her voice low and edged with exasperation.

She had work to do.

“Agatha,” Rio repeated, softer this time, but with the same damn tone—the one that felt like a hand reaching inside her chest and wrapping around her heart.

Agatha sighed, her resolve cracking as she finally lifted her gaze over her laptop screen.

Big mistake.

Rio’s smirk was wicked, her eyes dark and simmering, and the way she was looking at her— like Agatha was the most beautiful thing in the world—made her feel both utterly exposed and completely turned on.

Rio let the moment stretch, the weight of her gaze pressing down on Agatha until the air felt charged between them. Then, with a slow, deliberate tilt of her head, Rio’s lips curved into a smirk, her dark eyes gleaming with intent.

“Go to the bedroom and wait for me.”

The command was calm, but it struck with the force of a thunderclap. Agatha sucked in a breath, her chest tightening, her pulse quickening.

The audacity—the absolute nerve of this woman.

For a moment, she just stared at Rio, her pride warring with the heat pooling low in her stomach. She hated how easily Rio could do this, how effortlessly she could unravel her composure with just a few words.

But the look in Rio’s eyes—that searing confidence, that magnetic pull—it stripped Agatha of any desire to push back.

She let out a slow breath, feeling the energy crackling in the air between them, building inside her. The tension was palpable, pressing down on her, driving her every move.

And with that, Agatha closed her laptop with decisive click, setting it aside on the table. Her fingers brushed the edges of her glasses, ready to slip them off, when Rio’s voice cut through the heavy silence.

“No.”

Agatha froze, her eyes snapping to Rio’s.

“Keep those on,” Rio said, her tone low and firm that it sent a shiver coursing down Agatha’s spine.

Heat bloomed in Agatha’s chest, spreading outward, a warmth she didn’t even try to tamp down. She couldn’t fight the small smile that tugged at her lips as she moved to her feet.

Without another word, she turned, her steps deliberate and unhurried as she made her way toward the bedroom. There was a sway in her stride, one she didn’t bother to hide, her smirk growing with every step.

She paused at the doorway, just long enough to glance over her shoulder, catching Rio’s gaze still locked on her, dark and hungry. Agatha felt the heat rise further, but instead of feeling overwhelmed, it felt like power.

Who knew getting old could be this fun?

Chapter End Notes

Okay, wasn't that cute? Not a lot of plot here, just fluff. So I added some chapters at the countdown because I have things that need to happen between now and the end, and this chapter didn't move the plot like I needed. But I also felt like it was needed, a little fluff between these two idiots.

The whole u-hauling discussion had be rolling. Agatha being a baby lesbian is like my favorite thing ever. Her tipping a drag queen $100 bills, the fact that she didn't know what Rio carrying a backpack meant, the whole "it felt like a gift to me" thing last chapter, and now this U-Haul analogy...it's been so much fun to write.

The "Congratulations, my love," from AAA also made me smile. Love tying anything in from the show.

Also this my be favorite line in the whole story now: "“You’re so full of shit. You love me, Agatha Harkness. You can’t say it without choking, but you do.”

Also, I saw a meme of Agatha that said, "Do you know how much trauma you have to go through to get this funny? and I had to work it into this story because it is so real. So the whole scene was purposeful: Agatha couldn’t help but smirk in return, the urge to lighten the mood outweighing any need to dwell on the past. After all, she had earned

every ounce of humor that had come out of her messed-up childhood—might as well use it.

Also, notice the Aubrey Plaza tongue in cheek scene? I noticed she does that a lot and had to work it in.

Lastly, Kathryn Hahn in her glasses...is like chefs kiss so...lol

Tame Your Fears

Agatha's heels clicked sharply against the floors, the sound echoing as she crossed the invisible boundary separating the civilians from the gladiators. Her stride was steady, deliberate, every step a declaration of war as she moved toward her designated chair.

Settling into her seat, she reached into her bag, pulling out a stack of files and a pen. She placed them on the table in front of her, her fingers instinctively twirling the pen in a practiced, fluid motions—a quiet outlet for the restless energy humming just beneath her skin.

She wasn’t nervous.

Agatha Harkness didn’t do nervous—not when it came to court.

This wasn’t fear.

It was something sharper, more visceral.

The electric buzz that always thrummed through her veins before stepping onto the legal battlefield was alive and crackling. But now, it was something more. It wasn’t just about winning, about outmaneuvering the enemy.

No—this time, she wanted blood.

She wanted to rip their fucking throats out.

Her head snapped to the left at the sound of movement, her eyes locking onto Fox and Ratcliff as they sauntered over to the opposing counsel’s table.

Of course, Fox couldn’t resist. She turned toward Agatha with that insufferable, self-satisfied smirk, her eyes flicking over Agatha’s shoulder before landing back on her with a look of completely fake concern.

“Where’s your co-counsel, Agatha?” Fox purred, her tone dripping with mock sympathy. The facade lasted all of a second before her smirk turned devilish, her voice lowering just enough to twist the knife. “I hope she’s okay.”

The words hit like a thunderclap, the ringing in Agatha’s ears almost drowning out the rest of the room.

Fox knew .

She fucking knew about the threat against Rio, and now she was openly mocking her for it, throwing it in her face with calculated cruelty.

Something inside Agatha snapped. She shoved back her chair, already halfway to her feet, the fury in her chest roaring to life, but before she could take a step, a firm hand pressed down on her shoulder, pushing her back into her chair.

She looked up, ready to lash out, only to see Lilia standing behind her, calm and steady. Her sharp, knowing eyes met Agatha’s, not in warning, but rather in understanding.

Then, without a word, Lilia turned her head toward Fox.

Fox, to her credit, didn’t deflate entirely under Lilia’s piercing gaze, but the shift was there, subtle yet telling. The self-satisfied smirk wavered for just a moment, her mask slipping ever so slightly.

Lilia’s presence had rattled her, a hairline fracture in her carefully constructed confidence. And even the smallest crack could eventually cause a leak—and Lilia and Agatha knew it.

“Lilia,” Fox said, surprise flickering in her tone before she quickly masked it under her usual cocky bravado. “I didn’t know they let you out of the office anymore. I thought you were more of a figurehead these days.”

The faintest smile curved Lilia’s lips, but it was far from friendly. It was the kind of smile that promised pain.

Lilia’s faint smile didn’t waver as she stepped forward, her movements precise, deliberate. She stopped just short of Fox’s table, her gaze steady and sharp, cutting through the tension like a blade.

“Madeline,” Lilia said, her voice smooth and calm, but carrying the unmistakable weight of the authority that Lilia’s 30 plus years in law has earned her. “It’s always a pleasure to see you. Your theatrics never fail to entertain.”

She tilted her head slightly, her smile remaining, but her eyes cold and unyielding.

“Though I must say, threats of violence against a colleague feels a bit... desperate. Even for you.”

Fox’s smirk tightened, her posture stiffening as she tried to maintain her composure under Lilia’s scrutiny.

“I don’t know what you’re talking about,” she replied with a casual shrug, though the edge in her voice betrayed her.

Lilia leaned forward slightly, resting her fingertips on the edge of their table.

“Oh, I think you do,” she said, her tone dropping, quiet but lethal. “Mocking the personal safety of opposing co-counsel—particularly in light of certain recent threats—isn’t just tasteless. It’s dangerous, and unbecoming of someone who’s supposed to uphold the integrity of the court.”

Agatha’s heart thudded as she watched Lilia systematically dismantle Fox’s smug facade. She’d seen Lilia work before, but there was something about the way she wielded her words now, that made even Agatha sit a little straighter.

Fox’s smile finally cracked, her jaw tightening as she struggled to maintain her composure.

“I was simply making conversation,” she said, her tone strained. “Surely you’re not implying —”

“I’m not implying anything,” Lilia cut her off, her voice sharp. “I’m stating facts. And if you continue down this path, rest assured I will make sure those facts are formally addressed .”

For a moment, the courtroom seemed to hold its breath, the tension between them crackling in the air.

Then Lilia straightened, her gaze sweeping over Fox with an air of effortless dismissal, like she was beneath her. Her voice, when she spoke, was smooth and cold as steel.

“I suggest you focus on your own side of the aisle, Madeline,” Lilia said, her tone as sharp as a blade, each word measured for maximum impact. She let the silence linger just long enough to let it sting before delivering the final blow. “Because from where I’m standing... desperation does not look good on you. You’re getting wrinkles, darling.”

Her gaze lingered for a heartbeat longer, a calculated flicker of dismissal, before she turned on her heel and walked back to their table with the kind of calm, unhurried confidence that made every step feel like a statement.

Lilia settled into the seat beside Agatha, the weight of her presence as tangible as the heavy silence now emanating from the other side of the aisle.

Agatha exhaled a breath she hadn’t realized she was holding, turning to Lilia with a questioning glance, her voice low to avoid being overheard.

“Not that I didn’t enjoy every second of that,” Agatha murmured, “but what are you doing here?”

Lilia turned her head, a slow, satisfied smirk curling at the corners of her lips.

“Oh, Agatha,” she said, her tone almost playful. “You didn’t really think we were going to let you face this alone, did you?”

Before Agatha could respond, Lilia reached forward, tapping her hand lightly in an almost conspiratorial gesture. Then she leaned in closer, her voice dropping to a whisper, smooth and sharp.

“Let’s take these fuckers down, shall we? Like old times.”

A small smile tugged at the corners of Agatha’s mouth, despite herself. The chaotic energy that had been buzzing under her skin began to settle, calmed by Lilia’s steady presence. She hadn’t realized how much she needed her until this very moment, and though Agatha would never admit it aloud, she felt... surprisingly grateful.

Of course, she wasn’t about to show it. Old habits died hard, and honestly, Lilia always liked Agatha exactly as she was.

“Lilia—language,” Agatha said, feigning mock outrage as she theatrically placed a hand over her heart.

Lilia smirked, her posture casual as she leaned back in her chair with effortless confidence.

"Please, Agatha. I've heard worse from you before dawn."

Agatha parted her lips to retort, but just then, the door to the judge’s chambers swung open.

"All rise," called the clerk, instantly snapping Agatha's focus forward as she rose from her seat. "The Honorable Judge Harrison Mack presiding."

Judge Mack entered and took his place at the bench, prompting everyone else to follow suit.

Judge Mack settled into his chair, adjusted his glasses, and surveyed the courtroom with a weary expression.

“We’re here to voir dire and get ourselves a jury. Are you counselors ready to proceed?”

Madeline rose smoothly.

"Yes, Your Honor."

Agatha followed.

"Yes, Your Honor,” she said but not without casting a pointed look at Fox, her expression sharp enough to cut.

Judge Mack’s gaze shifted between them, the corners of his mouth twitching downward into a resigned frown. He exhaled heavily, the sound carrying a mix of exasperation and preemptive fatigue, as if he could already see the storm brewing between them and feel the inevitable migraine taking root.

“Alright,” he muttered, drumming his fingers briefly on the bench. “Bring in the prospective jurors.”

Six hours later, they had a jury. Surprisingly, the process had gone faster than expected— thanks to Lilia. She had an uncanny knack for reading people, a masterful intuition that made her jury selections feel almost surgical. It was a skill so precise it needed to be studied by scientists.

As they descended the courthouse steps, Agatha half-listened to Lilia ramble about the latest fiscal report. Around them, people moved in a constant stream, the steps to the courthouse bustling like a human highway.

Then, out of the corner of her eye, Agatha saw something—or rather, someone—that made her freeze mid-step. A man stood at the far end of the courthouse steps, casually leaning against a pillar. At first, the distance made it hard to be sure, the crowd moving between them like a living blur that forced her eyes to refocus again and again. But then the man smirked, and Agatha felt her blood turn to ice.

James Hughes. Head of Security at Vanguard.

The man who had killed Brooke Sinclair.

Her heart slammed against her ribs, pounding so hard she thought it might echo in her ears.

Suddenly, another large group of people passed between them, a chaotic wave of bodies chattering and bustling down the courthouse steps. Agatha’s line of sight was momentarily blocked, her breath caught in her throat as her eyes darted, trying to track him through the shifting sea of strangers.

But when the crowd thinned and her view finally cleared, he was gone.

Her chest tightened, the thundering pulse in her ears drowning out the world around her. She scanned the steps, her gaze flicking from pillar to pillar, but James Hughes had vanished as if he had never been there.

“Agatha?” Lilia’s voice cut through the haze, sharp with concern. “Are you okay?”

Agatha forced herself to swallow, nodding stiffly as she fought to steady her breath.

“Yeah,” she said, her voice a little too quick, too brittle. “I’m fine.”

But she wasn’t fine.

Not even close.

Agatha took a deep breath, as she worked to calm the erratic beat of her heart. The lingering image of James Hughes standing there still clung to her mind like smoke, but she shoved it aside, forcing herself to focus on the present. She turned to Lilia, her voice steady, if a bit subdued.

"You want a ride back to the office?"

Lilia glanced at her, really looked, her sharp eyes scanning Agatha’s face as if she could sense something was off. For a moment, it seemed like she might ask, but instead, she let it go, offering a casual shrug.

"No, I’ve got a meeting uptown."

Agatha nodded, taking a step to leave, but then hesitated. Surprising herself—and probably Lilia just as much—she turned back.

"Thank you for today."

Lilia blinked, caught off guard, but then her expression softened into a smile. Not the condescending, placating one Agatha used to loathe, but something genuine, something real.

"Of course," Lilia said, her tone warm. She started to turn away but suddenly stopped, her eyes widening like she’d remembered something important.

“Oh!” She reached into her bag and pulled out a blue folder, handing it to Agatha with a small flourish. “I took the liberty of getting that for you. I really must be going, though. Have a good rest of your day, Agatha.”

Before Agatha could respond, Lilia was already walking off, heels clicking against the pavement as she disappeared into the crowd.

Agatha glanced down at the folder, curiosity mingling with suspicion. She opened it, her eyes narrowing immediately as bold black letters practically leapt off the top of the single document inside.

RELATIONSHIP DISCLOSURE FORM

Agatha's lips thinned into a tight line as her eyes darted across the words.

With a sharp exhale, she snapped the folder shut and strode toward her car, muttering under her breath, a new frustration simmering just beneath the surface.

“You’ve got to be fucking kidding me.”

Agatha pushed open the office doors and strode inside, her heels clicking against the polished floors. She rarely ventured to this side of the building, the far end where the associates' offices were tucked away.

Associates came to her, not the other way around.

But today was different.

At the very end of the corridor, near the bathroom, sat the smallest office in the building—a space the firm reserved for the most promising first-year associate. Agatha had seen plenty of associates occupy it over the years, most of whom she’d ignored entirely. But this morning, Jen had sent out an email announcing the new occupant.

Rio Vidal.

Agatha had read the email over her coffee, her face impassive as her gaze flicked to Rio across her kitchen. She was making breakfast—again. French toast this time, as if they weren’t already walking a line that made Agatha’s stomach twist in ways she wasn’t ready to confront.

She hadn’t said anything to Rio. She didn’t want to ruin the surprise.

Rio deserved the office. After everything she’d done for the Vanguard case, she’d shattered every expectation of a first-year associate’s workload. And of course—there was another, more practical reason. The bullpen, where most associates worked, was too chaotic. Too hard to monitor.

Vanguard had managed to plant bugs and even a camera in the firm before. The idea that they could get to Rio out in the open was possible.

The black vehicles trailing Agatha’s town car at a respectable distance, paired with the severe female agent stationed just outside Rio’s door, were unmistakable indicators of the gravity of the threat—the danger Rio was in. The weight of it all sat heavily on Agatha’s shoulders, her mind flashing back to James Hughes outside the courthouse today.

She’d need to report his presence to the security team immediately.

Just in case.

It was likely nothing more than a calculated act of intimidation, Vanguard’s way of reminding her they were always watching. But Agatha wasn’t about to take any chances.

Not with Rio’s life.

That thought hit her harder than she expected, a pang sharp enough to make her pause. She clenched her jaw, forcing the feeling down into the recesses of her mind where it wouldn’t distract her.

Agatha drew a steadying breath, her hand brushing the cool metal of the door handle before she pushed it open and stepped inside.

She didn’t knock.

It may have been Rio’s office now, but technically, every office in this building was hers.

The moment she entered, Rio looked up from her desk, her sharp gaze locking onto Agatha. The tan tailored suit paired with a crisp white shirt had already caught Agatha off guard this morning when Rio had stepped out of the guest bedroom putting on her leather banded watch, moving toward her with an effortless confidence that left her momentarily speechless.

Now, even seeing it a second time, knowing what to expect, it still hit her like a punch to the chest.

She looked good.

Too good.

Agatha’s thoughts faltered for a moment, but she quickly regained her composure. She stepped forward and sank into the chair across from Rio’s desk, immediately regretting it. The chair was stiff and uncomfortable. Her mind drifted to logistics, already plotting how to have it replaced with something more suitable.

“You get your jury?” Rio asked, setting her paperwork aside and leaning back in her chair with an ease that seemed almost practiced.

Agatha leaned back as well, mirroring Rio’s posture.

“I did,” she replied simply.

The silence that followed felt weighted, pressing down on the space between them. They hadn’t really discussed it—not in any meaningful way.

Removing Rio from the case.

Rio had taken the decision in stride, not even flinching when the news came. But Agatha knew her better than that. They were alike in many ways, and if the roles had been reversed, Agatha would’ve been furious. But they were also strategic, calculated. Both of them knew how to play the game, and Rio understood that once the partners made a decision, there was no undoing it.

Still, understanding didn’t make it hurt any less.

After all, Agatha wouldn’t even have a jury—wouldn’t have a winnable case against Vanguard—if it weren’t for Rio.

“Rio,” she said softly, the words catching even herself off guard even as they left her lips. “I am sorry.”

Rio tilted her head, her sharp features softening as she regarded Agatha for a moment. Then, with a sigh, she leaned forward, resting her elbows on the desk.

“I know,” she said simply. “I’m just disappointed I won’t get to watch them go down. Or...”—she paused, her lips curving into a teasing smirk— “see you in your element. The showmanship of a trial and all that, you know?”

Agatha snorted, arching a brow as she leaned back in her chair.

“I thought I put on one hell of a show last night for you,” she shot back, her voice laced with dry humor.

Rio’s eyes sparked at that, and she bit her lip briefly, as if to suppress a grin, before letting a slow, deliberate smirk spread across her face.

“Yes, you did,” she said, her voice dropping into a low, almost purring tone that sent a flicker of heat course through Agatha.

Agatha felt the heat rise beneath her collar as her mind betrayed her, flashing back to last night—Rio utterly dismantling her and putting her back together for hours, all while wearing those damn glasses. Who knew a simple pair of frames could make someone so feral?

She forced herself out of that deep, dangerous gutter, lifting her gaze to Rio, who was watching her with a self-satisfied smirk. The kind of smirk that told Agatha, clear as day, that Rio knew exactly where her mind had wandered.

Agatha shot her a pointed look but quickly remembered why she’d come in. Straightening in her chair, she forced herself to focus.

“Look,” she began, the hesitation in her tone making her cringe inwardly. She hated how uncomfortable she sounded, but this was an uncomfortable conversation, one she’d been avoiding but could no longer dodge. “I’m going to work from home for the rest of the day.”

Rio straightened slightly at that, her playful expression replaced by a flicker of concern.

“Everything okay?” she asked, her voice soft but probing.

Agatha waved off the worry with a casual gesture.

“Yes,” she replied, though her throat felt tight as she forced the next words out. “I’m picking Nicky up from school. He’s coming back to me this week, and since he doesn’t handle change all that well—and there’s now a stranger living in his house”—her sharp gaze flicked pointedly at Rio—“ temporarily , I figured it was best to break the news to him in person. Prepare him.”

Rio leaned back in her chair, her expression softening as understanding settled across her features.

Of course, Rio knew about Nicky. She’d walked past his Toy Story -themed room more times than Agatha could count. His photos were everywhere—in the living room, the hallway, even on Agatha’s desk. And then there was the day at the park when Rio met him. They’d sat on the bench together, talking for a while, Rio’s easy demeanor putting Nicky at ease almost instantly.

Rio had to know this conversation was coming and judging by the calm, unshocked expression on her face, she had been expecting it.

“Okay,” Rio murmured softly, her eyes steady on Agatha. “What do you need from me to make this as easy as possible for him—and for you?”

And that did something to Agatha’s heart.

It was a small thing, maybe, but it struck a chord deep inside her—one she hadn’t expected. Rio’s sincerity, her lack of hesitation, and the simple, direct way she asked how to help Nicky settled over Agatha like a quiet warmth.

For so long, she’d been used to the people she saw romantically to sidestep the subject of her son, treating him like an obstacle in her life rather than the center of it. But here was Rio, meeting the moment head-on, no discomfort, no excuses—just understanding and a willingness to do whatever was needed.

Agatha felt her chest tighten, the sensation unfamiliar and uncomfortably tender. She cleared her throat, willing herself to push past the strange flutter it sent through her.

“Honestly,” she sighed, the word carrying the weight of her uncertainty, “I’m not really sure. He already took to you at the park—faster than I’ve ever seen—but he might be different in his own space. I guess...”

She hesitated, her eyes meeting Rio’s, searching for some reassurance.

“Play it by ear? He can be unpredictable sometimes.”

Rio nodded, her expression shifting into a weary smile.

“Wonder where he got that from?”

Agatha shot her a look, equal parts amused and exasperated, before letting out a resigned sigh.

“He is like a miniature version of myself,” she admitted. “Sometimes I wonder if I made him from scratch, with no help from James at all.”

Rio smirked, leaning back in her chair.

“Well, if anyone could pull off immaculate conception through sheer willpower and stubbornness, it would be you.”

Agatha rolled her eyes, but despite herself, a faint smile tugged at the corners of her lips.

The moment lingered in the air, delicate and charged, before Agatha felt that familiar itch beneath her collar—the one that made her shoulders tense and her composure falter. Every nerve in her body felt like it was vibrating as she reached into her coat pocket, her fingers curling around cool metal.

Without allowing herself to second-guess, she pulled the object out and slapped it onto Rio’s desk, her hand remaining firmly over it as she slid it toward her.

“I want this back as soon as this is over,” she said, her voice steady, but her heart pounding so hard she was certain Rio could hear it. Her gaze was sharp and pointed, determined to hide the storm of emotions swirling beneath.

Rio glanced at her hand, brows knitting in confusion before flicking her gaze back up to Agatha, her expression silently asking, And what exactly is this thing I’m not supposed to keep?

Agatha swallowed hard, her throat dry, before she lifted her hand, revealing the object beneath.

A spare key.

The silver gleamed starkly against the dark wood of Rio’s desk, catching the light like some sort of fucking beacon, screaming significance louder than Agatha would ever admit out loud.

“I realized,” she started, but her voice wavered, forcing her to pause and clear her throat.

She straightened her shoulders, steeling herself against the sudden wave of vulnerability.

“That you’re going to need it. There will no doubt be times when we won’t be on the same schedule, and you’ll need access to the house when I’m not there.” She hesitated, her voice softening. “Or even when I am. There’s no reason for you to knock.”

The weight of her words settled between them, heavier than the key itself, and Agatha resisted the urge to fidget, her composure hanging by a thread. She waited for Rio’s response, her heart pounding in her chest like a war drum.

Rio leaned forward, her movements uncharacteristically slow, and took the key from the desk. Agatha, still seated, watched as Rio turned the small piece of metal over in her fingers, her expression thoughtful, her discomfort flickering in the way her gaze avoided holding Agatha’s for too long.

It struck Agatha then—Rio was just as uncomfortable in this moment as she was. Somehow, that knowledge made her feel better, steadier. They were both on uneven ground here, both figuring out what this meant as they went along.

Rio seemed to take a breath, before reaching into her desk drawer to retrieve her keyring. Agatha watched, her chest tightening, as Rio slipped the silver key onto the ring alongside the others—a small, simple action that felt anything but.

There was something about the way it fit so seamlessly there, like it belonged, that stirred something deep in Agatha. Her heart thudded in her chest as she stared at the keyring, the key to her home now nestled among Rio’s other keys, as if it had always been there.

It wasn’t just a practical gesture—it was a statement. A quiet, unspoken acknowledgment of trust. And though Agatha wasn’t one to get sentimental about such things, she couldn’t shake the way it made her feel.

“Okay,” she said, rising to her feet, desperate to escape the conversation and the feelings boiling up inside her.

She sent Rio a glance and added, “I’ll see you later,” already regretting how stiff and awkward the words sounded.

God, this felt weird.

Thankfully, Rio didn’t push. She just nodded, giving Agatha the reprieve she needed.

Agatha turned to leave but froze at the sound of Rio’s soft voice calling her name.

“Agatha.”

Rio’s voice was quiet yet firm, the two syllables threading through the air with precision, stopping Agatha mid-step.

With her hand still on the door handle, Agatha turned slowly, her gaze locking onto Rio, who was watching her with an unreadable expression. For a moment, the room felt too still, the soft hum of the buildings heating system the only sound between them.

Rio stood, her movements unhurried, and rounded her desk with ease. She didn’t stop until she was just inches away—close enough that Agatha could feel the faint warmth of her presence and smell the faintest hint of a forest.

“Did you know I was getting the first-year associate office?” Rio asked, her voice steady, though her eyes searched Agatha’s face for something unspoken.

Agatha blinked, momentarily thrown by the question. She straightened her shoulders instinctively, as though bracing herself.

“Of course,” she replied evenly. “I got the email this morning during breakfast.”

Rio nodded, her lips curving into a small, knowing smile that made Agatha’s chest tighten.

“And do all new offices in your firm come with a Hoya Carnosa Madara ?” Rio asked, the name rolling off her tongue with just enough emphasis to make it sound both casual and pointed.

Agatha looked at her in confusion, her brow furrowing.

“A what?”

Rio tilted her head, glancing over her shoulder with a gesture of her thumb toward the desk.

“The several-thousand-dollar plant sitting on my desk,” she clarified, her lips tugging into a teasing smile that sent a ripple of warmth and unease through Agatha.

Oh.

That.

Agatha’s mind scrambled for a response, her expression carefully blank. She hadn’t left a card for a reason, and she wasn’t about to own up to it now.

“I wouldn’t know,” she said with a shrug that she hoped looked convincingly indifferent. “Jen handles the floral orders. You’d have to ask her.”

Rio’s lips twitched, her amusement barely concealed as the corners of her mouth pinched, her expression practically glowing with disbelief.

“Of course,” she murmured, her tone light but undeniably skeptical.

Rio stepped back then, her gaze softening into something gentler, giving Agatha the space to leave without pressing further.

Agatha inhaled deeply, steadying herself as her fingers tightened around the door handle. She turned, opened the door, and stepped forward, eager to escape the tension simmering in the room.

But just as she was about to leave, Rio’s voice floated after her, quiet and warm.

“Thank you for the plant, my love .”

The words pierced through Agatha’s back like an arrow, sharp and unrelenting, wrapping around her heart and squeezing tight. She froze, caught in the doorway, her hand still gripping the handle as if it could anchor her.

My love.

It wasn’t the first time Rio had said those words. Hell, even Agatha said the exact words in the bathroom, while three fingers deep inside Rio.

But this time, it wasn’t said mockingly or in the throes of passion—no, this time was different. This time, it hit her like a lightning strike, sudden and all-encompassing, pulling her completely off balance—because she liked it.

She liked it a lot.

Far more than she was willing to admit, even to herself. The way Rio said it—soft, unhurried, and full of quiet certainty—made something deep inside her ache.

It wasn’t just the words.

It was the weight behind them, the meaning woven into every syllable. Rio had told Agatha she loved her, and now this— my love —was different.

It wasn’t just a pet name tossed out to fill the air.

It wasn’t casual or fleeting.

It was deliberate, heartfelt, and so achingly real.

Agatha froze, her grip tightening on the door handle, her knuckles white as she fought against the urge to turn around or run out the door.

Her voice, when it finally came, was barely a whisper, trembling with the emotions she was trying so hard to suppress.

“You’re welcome,” she murmured.

And then she stepped out, letting the door close behind her with a soft, final click. But as she walked away, the echo of my love lingered, sinking deeper into her chest. It felt as though the words were taking root, settling into a place they belonged, as if Rio were carving out a home within her—with every intention of staying.

Agatha had braced herself for all sorts of reactions from Nicky—nervousness, a flurry of questions, maybe even a bit of resistance. She’d rehearsed explanations in her head during the drive, anticipating every possible "why" or "how long."

But when she picked him up from school and gently explained that Rio would be staying at their house for a while because of a work thing, Nicky just smiled at her and said, “Okay.”

Okay.

That was it.

No questions.

No hesitation.

Just okay.

Agatha blinked, momentarily stunned by his simplicity, her carefully rehearsed responses dissolving into irrelevance. She’d prepared for every possible question—except for none at all.

Of course, the reprieve didn’t last.

The moment they walked into the house, as Agatha leaned down to slip off her heels, Nicky’s voice broke through the quiet with a question that nearly sent her sprawling into the wall.

“Is Rio your girlfriend?”

Agatha barely caught herself, her hand shooting out to steady against the wall before she could faceplant into it. She stayed there for a moment, braced against the cool surface, her pulse thundering in her ears.

“Nicky,” Agatha began, her voice sharper than intended as she turned to face him, still steadying herself against the wall. “Where did that come from?”

Nicky sat on the floor, tugging at his sneakers. He looked up at her with wide, innocent eyes, the kind that only children could manage—pure curiosity written all over his face.

“She makes you smile,” he said matter-of-factly, like it was the most obvious thing in the world. “Remember? I saw it.”

Agatha blinked, caught off guard yet again, her breath hitching as his words settled over her.

He had saw it.

Agatha took a moment, her mind spinning as she tried to figure out how to navigate this conversation. She could deflect, redirect, or outright lie—but none of that seemed right. The truth was simpler, and besides, she and Rio hadn’t even talked about labels.

And girlfriend ?

The word alone made her shiver, a full-body cringe rippling through her. It sounded so...juvenile.

“We are not girlfriends,” Agatha said firmly, slipping off her other heel and straightening to look down at Nicky.

“We are...” She paused, searching for the right phrasing. “We’re friends who enjoy spending time together outside of work.”

Nicky finished taking off his last shoe, placing it neatly beside hers. He stood, tilting his head as he looked up at her with that same unrelenting curiosity.

“But she makes you smile,” he said again, his tone so simple, so certain. He scrunched his nose, adding, “You see Aunt Jen outside of work, and she doesn’t make you smile.”

Agatha huffed, crossing her arms.

“That’s because your Aunt Jen is annoying,” she shot back, narrowing her eyes. “And she’s not your aunt,” she added pointedly. “She just told you that to annoy me .”

Nicky shrugged as if the correction didn’t matter.

“I like calling her Aunt Jen,” he said casually, then paused, as though gathering his thoughts. “So, Rio doesn’t annoy you, and she makes you smile.”

Agatha sighed heavily, pinching the bridge of her nose.

Seriously, where was James’s boneheaded genetics in this kid?

She could tell James the same thing five times in a row, and he’d still forget it. Nicky, though? Nicky was all her—sharp, observant, and relentless—and she was paying the price for it now.

“Oh, Rio annoys me,” she muttered, giving him a playful glare at him for good measure.

Nicky blinked up at her, his lips twitching like he was trying not to grin.

“But she still makes you smile,” Nicky said, his voice brimming with that maddening confidence.

Agatha sighed, placing her hands on her hips as she stared down at him. She was losing an argument to a five-year-old, and it was infuriating. She pursed her lips, trying to maintain

some semblance of authority, but then Nicky, in all his tiny defiance, mirrored her stance— hands on his hips, chin tilted slightly upward in perfect mimicry.

And damn it if that didn’t do something to Agatha’s heart.

“Fine, yes!” she huffed, throwing her hands up in defeat. “You win. She makes me smile.”

Nicky’s grin grew into a full-blown, heart-melting smile—the kind that left Agatha powerless to resist. Before she could even process what was happening, he stepped forward and wrapped his arms tightly around her, burying his face against her stomach.

The suddenness of his hug made her stumble back a step, but Agatha quickly steadied herself, instinctively wrapping her arms around him. Her hand slipped into his messy dark hair, gently smoothing it as if it were second nature.

Nicky tilted his head up, his chin resting against her stomach, his big blue eyes— her eyes— meeting hers.

“I like it when you smile,” he said softly, his voice so full of sincerity it left her breathless.

Agatha felt her chest tighten, and before she knew it, she was smiling—how could she not? It was impossible to resist him.

She cupped his small face in her hands, her thumb gently brushing his cheek.

“I do too,” she whispered, her voice low and tender, as though sharing a secret just for him. And in a way, she was. It felt like a secret—an unspoken truth she didn’t often let herself admit.

For Nicky, though, she’d let it show.

Because if anyone deserved to see her like this, it was him.

Hours later, Agatha and Nicky were seated at the dinner table, about to dig into the lasagna Sonya had made. Agatha was mid-scoop, about to place a steaming piece on Nicky’s plate, when the unmistakable sound of the front door opening echoed down the hallway.

She froze, the serving spoon suspended in midair, her muscles going rigid.

It all seemed to happen in slow motion. Nicky’s head snapped toward the sound, his wide eyes lighting up. That smile—the one Agatha knew all too well, the one that meant trouble— spread across his face like wildfire.

“Don’t you—” Agatha began, but before she could finish the sentence, Nicky shot out of his chair like a rocket, all untamed energy and purpose.

“Nicky!” she growled, twisting in her seat as the lasagna scoop wobbled precariously in her hand. She could only watch as he darted down the hallway, his small footsteps echoing against the walls.

Her voice followed him, sharp and warning, but utterly ineffective. He was already gone.

With an exasperated sigh, Agatha slammed the spoon onto his plate, the lasagna splattering messily across the table. She shot to her feet, heart beating wildly in her chest as she chased after him.

“Hi, Rio!” Nicky’s voice rang out from the hallway, cutting through her and freezing her mid- step.

Agatha nearly tripped over her own feet, her heart skipping a beat as she came to a stop just shy of the hallway. She strained to listen, and after a brief pause, she heard it.

“Hi, buddy.”

Rio’s voice was soft, warmer than Agatha had ever heard it before. It held a tone that was... different, almost tender.

“Mama said you’re going to be staying with us for a little bit,” Nicky said, his words innocent but with that childlike straightforwardness that always caught Agatha off guard.

There was a long pause after that. Then Agatha heard the faint rustle of movement—Rio hanging up her coat, the closet door opening and closing that sounded so loud in the silence.

“Is that okay with you?” Rio asked, her voice still carrying that gentle warmth.

Agatha’s heart ached at the question, the vulnerability in Rio’s tone striking her unexpectedly. She could picture it—Rio looking down at Nicky’s, waiting for his response with the kind of care and patience that felt almost out of place in her Rio’s normally cocky demeanor.

Leaning against the wall, Agatha closed her eyes for a brief second, swallowing the knot forming in her throat. This was already more than she’d expected—and it was only the first night.

She took a deep breath, steadying herself before stepping into the hallway. As she rounded the corner, she found Nicky standing just a foot away from Rio, his head tilted back to look up at her. Rio had already hung up her coat and was crouched slightly as she met Nicky’s gaze with a faint smile.

“It’s okay with me,” Nicky said after a moment, nodding solemnly like he was granting some kind of official approval. “But you should know Mama burns toast sometimes.”

Agatha groaned softly.

“Nicky—”

Rio glanced up at her then, her expression shifting into something teasing, her eyes sparkling with amusement.

“Good to know,” she said, her tone light. “I’ll make sure to keep an eye on her when she’s near the toaster.”

Nicky giggled at that, clearly delighted, and Agatha could feel her irritation melting under the warmth of the moment. She rolled her eyes, crossing her arms as she leaned against the wall.

“He doesn’t need encouragement, you know,” she muttered, her voice half-hearted as a small smile tugged at her lips.

Rio straightened, her gaze flicking to Agatha with a look that was softer than she expected.

“He’s just telling me the important stuff,” she replied. “It’s good to know what I’m walking into.”

Nicky reached out then, grabbing Rio’s hand like it was the most natural thing in the world.

“Come on,” he said, tugging her gently toward the dining room. “Sonya made lasagna, and it’s really good.”

Rio let him lead her, casting a quick glance over her shoulder at Agatha, who lingered in the hallway, watching them go.

For a moment, Agatha just stood there, her arms uncrossing as she rubbed the back of her neck. The sight of Nicky holding Rio’s hand, so trusting and comfortable, tugged at something deep inside her. It was a strange mix of relief and vulnerability—like a door she’d kept locked was quietly creaking open.

Shaking off the thought, she followed them into the dining room, her voice calm but firm. “Nicky, sit down properly this time. And Rio, don’t let him con you into extra dessert.”

Rio raised a brow, a playful smirk tugging at her lips.

“Oh, I don’t know. He seems like a pretty good negotiator.”

Agatha sighed as she reclaimed her seat at the table, already regretting the inevitable chaos Rio seemed poised to encourage.

“You have no idea,” she muttered.

Nicky, already seated, grinned at Rio and gestured to the chair directly across from him. Rio moved forward, taking the offered seat without hesitation. Agatha, settling back into her spot next to Nicky, glanced at Rio across the table. She fought the urge to fidget—or worse, to smile—because Rio's presence at the table with her and Nicky was unsettling in a way that wasn’t entirely unpleasant.

With forced composure, Agatha leaned forward and scooped a generous helping of lasagna onto Rio’s plate.

“Thanks,” Rio said, her voice calm, but that infuriating smirk was back, lighting up her face.

Agatha narrowed her eyes at her, her glare doing nothing to erase the amusement playing on Rio’s lips.

The silence at the table was broken by Nicky, who, mid-bite, looked up and declared.

“Today my friend Sam told me that birds have hollow bones. That’s why they can fly so easily. They don’t weigh a lot.”

Both Agatha and Rio turned to him, their attention now on the small, sauce-smeared face smiling brightly as he continued to eat.

“That’s cool,” Rio said, nodding as she took her first bite of lasagna.

Before either of them could say more, the oven timer went off, its beep cutting through the moment. Agatha pushed her chair back and started to stand.

“That’s the bread,” she said, moving toward the kitchen.

“I’ll get it,” Rio said quickly, already rising and shooting her a look as if daring her to argue.

“They’re already cooked!” Agatha called after her, exasperation creeping into her voice. “I can’t ruin them!”

“Best not take any chances,” Rio quipped over her shoulder, disappearing into the kitchen.

Nicky giggled, his small shoulders shaking as he shoveled another forkful of lasagna into his mouth.

Agatha turned to him, her expression one of exaggerated betrayal.

“Et tu, Brutus?” she asked, placing a hand dramatically over her heart.

Nicky paused mid-chew, his brow furrowing in confusion.

“Who’s Brutus?”

Agatha snorted.

“Never mind, kid. Finish your dinner.”

Agatha glanced toward the kitchen, where Rio was pulling the bread from the oven and setting it carefully on the stove. Her movements were casual, fluid, as though she’d always belonged in this space. Agatha’s eyes shifted, catching sight of the blue folder sitting on the countertop island that separated the kitchen from the living room—the one she’d left there to discuss with Rio later tonight.

Her chest tightened. She hated the idea of using Nicky’s presence as a buffer, but she wasn’t above it. She’d already endured too many hard conversations today, and the thought of diving into another one—this one particularly fraught—made her stomach twist.

“There’s a document from work I need you to look at on the countertop,” Agatha said, forcing her voice into something she hoped sounded casual, even as her heart hammered in her chest.
