Rio turned, one brow lifting slightly in curiosity, but she didn’t say a word. She crossed the kitchen to the island, picked up the blue folder, and flipped it open with a practiced ease that sent a ripple of tension through Agatha.

Agatha stayed in her seat, gripping her fork tightly, the edges of the metal biting into her fingers. The room felt unnervingly quiet, the hum of the oven and the faint clink of cutlery the only sounds filling the space. Even Nicky, engrossed in his lasagna, seemed oblivious to the weight.

She watched as Rio scanned the document, her eyes moving steadily over the page. Agatha could practically feel the seconds stretching, each one tightening the knot in her chest. Then it happened—the exact moment Rio’s gaze landed on Agatha’s signature at the bottom of the Relationship Disclosure Form .

Rio’s expression shifted, subtle but unmistakable. She looked up then, meeting Agatha’s eyes across the space that suddenly felt far too small.

They stared at each other, the silence stretching taut between them, unspoken words and questions hanging heavy in the air.

For a brief moment, Agatha forgot how to breathe.

Rio held Agatha’s gaze for a long moment, her expression unreadable. Then, without a word, she reached over, picked up the pen resting beside the folder, and signed the document with a quick, fluid motion. She closed the folder, placing it neatly back on the countertop before turning to retrieve the bread.

Agatha watched as Rio rounded the kitchen island, her movements calm, almost too casual, as if she didn’t just sign her name on a legal document declaring they were in a relationship.

“Did you know owls can turn their heads all the way around, but they can’t move their eyes?” Rio said, her tone light and conversational, as though she were merely continuing a casual chat from Nicky’s earlier comment about birds.

Nicky looked up at her with wide, amazed eyes.

“No way, that’s so cool!”

Rio smiled at him.

Agatha, still clutching her fork, stared at Rio, blinking as she tried to reconcile the effortless ease in her tone with the gravity of what had just happened. Rio didn’t even glance her way, her focus entirely on slicing the bread with calm, precise movements.

“What else do you know about birds?” Nicky asked, his voice eager.

Rio shrugged, her expression casual.

“Quite a bit,” she replied. “I watched a documentary on them last year that was really good.”

Nicky’s eyes went wide with excitement, and he turned to Agatha, practically bouncing in his seat.

“Mama, can we watch the bird show after dinner?” he asked, his words tumbling out in a rush. “Then I can tell Sam all about it tomorrow!”

Agatha blinked at him, still half-rooted in the emotional whirlwind of moments earlier, but Nicky’s enthusiasm tugged ger back to the present. She sighed, finally setting her fork down, and gave him a small smile.

“Sure,” she said, her voice softening. “We can watch it after dinner.”

Nicky beamed, his joy infectious, while Rio set the bread on the table with a faint smile of her own. She slid into her chair, casually grabbing a slice of bread and buttering it as if this dinner were any other mundane evening.

Nicky’s excitement bubbled over as he launched into another story, his words tumbling over each other in an energetic rush.

As his voice filled the room, both Agatha and Rio looked up at the same time, their gazes locking across the table. For a moment, everything else seemed to fade—the chaos of the day, the weight of earlier conversations—leaving only the quiet between them.

Rio’s lips curved into a smirk, one that was both knowing and playful, and it sent a ripple through Agatha’s chest.

And God— it felt so right.

Her, Nicky... and Rio.

Chapter End Notes

What did you guys think?

Lilia showing up at court...loved it. Also her "taking the liberty" to secure the relationship disclosure form for Agatha had be rolling.

And James Hughes from Vanguard...showing up. Bum bum bum. (also I just realized that Agatha's ex-husband's name is James. So I am sorry for the confusion. Just caught that)

That whole scene in Rio's office had me melting into a puddle into the floor. Especially the "my love" and Agatha's little "Your welcome."

"Made from scratch" was just chefs kiss

And lastly, the whole domestic scene at home was everything.

Te Veo

Agatha was grumpy.

She slept like shit, tossing and turning in her king-sized bed. All night she’d wake up sprawled on one side, only to find herself on the other an hour later, tangled in the sheets. By the time the first few hours of this restless cycle had passed, she knew exactly what the issue was—and that realization made her mind just as restless as her body.

Her body was searching for Rio.

Every time she shifted in her sleep, her subconscious seemed to reach out, and every time it came up empty-handed, it jolted her awake.

But no matter how much she wanted to— God , how much she wanted to—Agatha couldn’t bring herself to go to Rio’s room. Every fiber of her being pulled her in that direction, but she stayed put, forcing herself to resist.

There were reasons, of course.

Practical ones.

Nicky, while a great sleeper, had a habit of sneaking into her room on occasion, and she couldn’t bear the thought of him waking up in the middle of the night and not finding her there.

And then there was the other reason, the one that made her chest tighten every time she thought about it.

To actually do it—to slip into Rio’s bed and wrap herself around her—that would be opening herself up too much. It wasn’t just about sharing a bed. It was about admitting something deeper—something far more terrifying.

To need someone—to need Rio, like that? It felt like a vulnerability too great to face.

Was this what love was?

Why did people willingly subject themselves to this feeling?

And more importantly, why the fuck did they romanticize it?

There was nothing poetic or beautiful about this gnawing, restless ache. It felt like a betrayal of everything Agatha had built herself into—everything she prided herself on.

And now here she was...not being able to sleep without Rio?

What was next?

Was she going to lose her ability to fucking breathe without Rio?

The town car came to an abrupt stop, jolting Agatha out of her thoughts as she instinctively braced herself against the partition, narrowly avoiding a headfirst collision.

“For fuck’s sake,” she muttered under her breath, her glare snapping to the barrier separating her from the driver.

“Apologies, Ms. Harkness,” Dan’s voice crackled through the intercom, his tone calm but edged with caution, as if he could feel the waves of irritation rolling off her. “Bike messenger cut us off.”

Agatha huffed sharply, settling back into the plush leather seat.

“Of course,” she muttered to herself, closing her eyes for a brief moment to gather her composure.

Just before she closed her yes, out of the corner of them, she caught Rio sitting next to her, frowning slightly.

She’d been giving Agatha that same look all morning—watchful, concerned, and just perceptive enough to be irritating. Rio had a way of sensing Agatha’s mood the way most people sensed the weather, and nothing—not even the fucking delicious apple cinnamon pancakes Rio had made for breakfast—had managed to shift it.

Nicky, on the other hand, had been a different story. He’d buzzed around the table like a tiny whirlwind, devouring his pancakes with questionable table manners and peppering Rio with nonstop chatter. Every moment between bites, he’d paused to confirm his “bird facts” from the documentary they’d watched last night, his little face lighting up every time Rio nodded in agreement or added another tidbit.

“You going to tell me what’s wrong?” Rio asked, her voice steady but probing.

Agatha closed her eyes, letting out a quiet sigh. She’d been expecting this moment, honestly.

Waiting for it.

It wasn’t a matter of if Rio would call her out but when.

Still, she was surprised Rio had lasted this long. She’d dealt with Agatha’s sharp edges and cold shoulder for hours without pressing, without pushing, giving her space to stew in her

own frustration. But Rio’s patience had limits, and it seemed they’d finally run out.

“I slept like shit,” Agatha sighed out, the honestly surprising her or maybe it was the exhaustion.

Either way, the words couldn't be taken back.

The silence from Rio was deafening, stretching long enough that Agatha almost regretted speaking at all. But then she heard the faint sound of shuffling, and a moment later, she felt the faintest slide of familiar fingers across her shoulder, trailing upward to her neck before burying themselves in the back of her hair.

Rio’s touch was firm yet soothing, her fingers kneading gently at the base of Agatha’s skull, massaging the tension Agatha hadn’t even realized she was holding there.

Agatha exhaled slowly, the tension in her shoulders easing as Rio’s touch worked its way through her defenses. She hadn’t even realized how much she needed this—needed her .

She’d been grumpy all morning, avoiding Rio’s touch like it was the plague, channeling all her frustration and shitty sleep into silent blame. It was petty, of course. She knew it. But she was not above pettiness, and most of the time, leaning into that pettiness felt a hell a lot easier than admitting what was really bothering her.

But now, with Rio’s fingers gently massaging the back of her head, it was hard to hold onto her stubbornness. Hard to hold onto anything, really, except the undeniable fact that somehow Rio always knew exactly what she needed.

“I didn’t sleep well either,” murmured Rio, in that lower timber that had a new shiver moving down Agatha’s spine. “I missed you last night.”

Jesus.

Agatha’s eyes snapped open, her gaze locking onto Rio. She was met with that soft expression—just a little slice of vulnerability—that always managed to leave her breathless.

Even under Agatha’s sharp gaze, Rio fingers didn’t stop. They continued their gentle path along Agatha’s scalp, as she met Agatha’s eyes head-on.

“You did?” Agatha whispered, her voice smaller than she intended.

Rio’s lips curved into a gentle smile, her eyes holding that steady, honest look that left no room for doubt.

“Yes,” Rio said, her voice calm and confident, as if the admission cost her nothing. “I like being held by you.”

Agatha blinked, caught off guard by the raw simplicity of Rio’s words. Her chest tightened, her throat suddenly dry as she struggled to form a response.

Rio’s fingers continued their slow, soothing path along Agatha’s scalp, grounding her in a moment that felt far too intimate—too real. The tension Agatha had been holding onto all morning seemed to crack and splinter under the weight of Rio’s words and touch.

“I...” Agatha started, but the words faltered, catching in her throat.

What was she supposed to say to that? To someone so unflinchingly honest, so open, when she felt like a storm barely contained behind walls she’d spent a lifetime building?

Rio didn’t push. She just kept her touch gentle and steady, waiting, her eyes never wavering from Agatha’s.

Agatha swallowed hard, her voice finally finding its way back to her.

“I’m not exactly the best at... this.” She gestured vaguely between them, her tone brittle.

Rio’s smile softened even further, her fingers pausing for a brief moment before sliding to rest at the nape of Agatha’s neck. Her thumb brushed gently against her skin, the touch impossibly tender.

“Agatha,” Rio said, her voice steady and warm. It was a tone that seemed to have the exacting ability to unravel something deep inside Agatha. “There’s no right way to do this. I think we’re just figuring it out as we go.”

Her eyes held Agatha’s for a moment longer before her smile transformed into that infuriating smirk—the one that always signaled trouble.

Agatha’s stomach sank preemptively.

“And,” Rio added, her tone teasing but sharp enough to land its mark, “if you want to save yourself some trouble in the future, you could just tell me what’s wrong instead of being a crab ass all morning.”

Agatha’s glare was immediate and sharp, her lips pressing into a tight line.

“Crab ass?” Agatha repeated, her tone teetering on the edge between genuine offense and mock indignation.

Rio’s smirk only widened, her confidence palpable as the hand resting on the back of Agatha’s neck tightened slightly, just enough to ground her, to make her feel held in more ways than one.

“Oh, I stand by it,” Rio said, her voice low but undeniably smug.

Agatha let out a deep exhale, the kind that seemed to come from somewhere deep in her chest, releasing a fraction of the tension she’d been carrying.

“Someone’s feeling brave today,” she muttered, giving Rio a pointed look.

Rio’s smirk only widened, her confidence radiating in that way that simultaneously irritated and fascinated Agatha.

“Well,” Rio said, her voice laced with teasing, “I figured why not push a little more since, you know... we’re in a relationship now .”

Agatha’s lips pressed into a thin line at that, her expression hardening slightly.

And there it was.

She’d been wondering when Rio would bring that up.

They hadn’t really talked about it last night. What signing that document meant.

After dinner, true to her word, they’d watched the bird documentary—a mind-numbingly dull experience for Agatha, but Nicky had loved every second of it. Apparently, even the second viewing was enough to hold Rio’s attention, though Agatha suspected she was just humoring Nicky.

The only thing remotely entertaining about the whole ordeal had been Nicky peppering Rio with question after question, each one more specific than the last. And somehow, Rio had answered every single one without missing a beat, as if she had an endless reservoir of bird facts tucked away.

After that came Nicky’s bedtime routine, which was always more challenging on his first night back. It took longer than usual, his energy winding down in uneven bursts, and by the time he was finally tucked in and asleep, Agatha was exhausted.

When she returned to the living room, Rio was gone, having already retreated to her room.

Agatha didn’t know how to feel about that

Was she disappointed?

Or was she relieved?

Maybe a little of both.

And now here they were, the unspoken from last night finally being spoken, as Rio’s words hung in the air like a dare.

“That was for protection—for the firm,” Agatha said, the words leaving her lips sharper than she intended, though she knew how weak the argument sounded even as she said it.

Of course, Rio saw right through it.

She always did.

Her hand slipped from the back of Agatha’s neck as she leaned back slightly, fixing her with a look. It wasn’t angry or mocking—it was worse. It was piercing and patient, the kind of

look that made Agatha want to squirm in her seat.

Agatha pursed her lips, irritation prickling under her skin as she felt the unraveling begin.

“What do you want me to say?” she huffed, throwing her hands up in exasperation. She knew she was being petulant, but she couldn’t help it. Her palms felt clammy, and she rubbed them against her pants.

Rio arched a single brow, her silence speaking volumes, pressing against Agatha like a weight she couldn’t shrug off.

“Okay!” Agatha snapped, throwing her hands up in frustration. “We are...” She started, but the words caught in her throat, refusing to cooperate.

Her lips parted, but nothing came out.

Rio snorted softly, the sound warm and unguarded, a teasing smile tugging at the corners of her mouth.

“You are absolutely ridiculous,” she said, her tone light but laced with affection and exasperation. Then, meeting Agatha’s gaze head-on, she added with quiet certainty, “ Agatha ... we are in a relationship.”

The simplicity of the statement made Agatha’s breath hitch, her chest tightening as the weight of it settled over her.

There it was—laid out in black and white,

No room for evasion.

Agatha stared at Rio, her jaw tightening as her mind raced to push back against the simplicity of it. But the steadiness in Rio’s gaze, the way her teasing smile softened into something more genuine pierced through Agatha, straight through her defenses.

“Okay,” Agatha finally said, her voice quiet, almost reluctant, but there.

Rio tilted her head, her teasing smile softening.

“Okay?” she echoed, her voice laced with a faint hint of amusement, like she couldn’t help but savor this rare moment of vulnerability from Agatha.

Agatha’s eyes snapped back to hers, her expression sharp but lacking its usual edge.

“Yes, okay,” she repeated, her voice louder this time. “We’re in a relationship. There. Happy now?”

Rio’s smile grew, slow and steady, and Agatha’s heart lurched in her chest.

Fuck.

They were in an actual relationship.

The thought hit her like a truck, the weight of it slamming into her all at once. She was in a relationship—with a woman. She was in love with a woman 16 years her junior. It should make her skin crawl, shouldn’t it? It should set off every alarm bell she had, make her recoil, reject this whole thing outright.

Everything about this should feel wrong.

And yet... it didn’t.

It wasn’t wrong.

And that, perhaps, was what terrified her most of all.

Thank fucking God the car chose that moment to stop, jerking slightly as it came to a halt in front of the office. The timing felt like divine intervention, yanking Agatha back from the edge of the spiraling thoughts she wasn’t ready to fully process.

Her hand shot toward the door handle, desperate for escape, for fresh air, for anything to shake off the weight pressing down on her chest. But before she could pull it open, a hand landed gently on her arm, stopping her in her tracks.

Agatha froze, her pulse skipping as she turned her head.

Rio’s dark eyes locked onto hers, steady and intense, and before Agatha could even process the moment, Rio moved.

Reaching up, Rio grabbed the back of Agatha’s neck, her fingers firm as she pulled her forward. And then Rio kissed her—searing, deliberate, and with enough heat to leave Agatha’s thoughts scattered like leaves in a high wind.

It wasn’t tentative, wasn’t soft, wasn’t polite. It was everything Rio was—bold, sure, and unapologetically direct.

Agatha’s breath caught, her mind blanking under the sheer force of it. She gripped the door handle as if were the only thing anchoring her to reality.

When Rio finally pulled back, her lips lingered for just a moment longer than necessary, she smiled—soft, knowing, infuriating .

“Have a good day, my love, ” Rio murmured against Agatha’s lips, the words soft and intimate, yet so confident they left no room for misinterpretation.

Agatha huffed in response, the sound more out of exasperation than anything else, though it did nothing to mask the way her heart fluttered in her chest, betraying her completely.

“Rio,” she muttered, pulling back just enough to meet her gaze, her own lips tingling from the kiss. Her tone was sharp, but the faint pink dusting her cheeks gave her away.

Rio’s smirk returned, playful yet laced with something deeper.

“Go on,” she teased, her hand lingering at the back of Agatha’s neck for a moment longer before releasing her. “You’ve got an empire to run.”

Agatha narrowed her eyes, giving Rio her best glare as she adjusted her jacket and reached for the door handle again.

“You’re lucky I like you,” she grumbled under her breath, though the words carried no real heat.

“You love me,” Rio shot back, her voice light and teasing as she leaned forward, starting to crawl after her.

But Agatha was quicker. She stepped out of the car with practiced grace, shutting the door firmly behind her—right in Rio’s face.

The faintest of smiles tugged at Agatha’s lips as she adjusted her bag, the lingering heat of the kiss still buzzing faintly beneath her skin.

And just like that, her mood had significantly improved.

Agatha’s mood carried her through most of the day. She finalized key elements of her trial strategy for the Vanguard case, set to begin on Wednesday. And then she held two client conferences, and a minor client emergency cropped up—a contract mishap that could’ve spiraled into something worse if she didn’t handle it personally.

But as she ran out of things to do, that nagging that she was putting something off was curling at her neck. She could avoid it, like she had been all day—but then she would have to deal with Lilia’s knowing glances that somehow found her multiple times today.

Which is why Agatha, against her better judgment, bit the bullet and now found herself standing outside one particular office she avoided like the plague. The godforsaken blue folder was clutched in her hands, her grip so tight the edges were beginning to crumple.

Closing her eyes, she let out a long, exasperated sigh.

First, she cursed herself for allowing this situation to spiral into what it had become.

Then, she cursed Lilia for being the catalyst that had forced her hand.

And lastly, and most of all, she cursed Rio—because, obviously, this was all Rio’s fault.

Agatha steeled herself, grabbing the door handle and pushing it open with more force than necessary. She stepped inside the HR office, which consisted of just one person—one person who, despite her size and age, somehow managed to strike fear into every partner, associate, and intern alike.

“Agatha, what a surprise,” came the high-pitched unmistakable voice from behind the desk, warm and welcoming.

Agatha pasted on a fake smile, one that didn’t even come close to reaching her eyes, and looked up at the woman. Nearly in her 70s now, she was the only person in the world who made Agatha feel like she was back in the principal’s office, awaiting a lecture.

Her blonde, shoulder-length hair was always tastefully styled, her posture was perfect, and her kind smile seemed almost too genuine to be real. The woman practically radiated a goodness that immediately set Agatha on edge, like she was walking into some kind of moral interrogation.

“Hi, Mrs. Hart,” Agatha said, her voice higher pitched and completely fake to mask her discomfort.

Mrs. Hart gave her a knowing look.

“Agatha, we’ve worked together for nearly 20 years. How many times have I asked you to call me Sharon?”

Agatha let out an awkward laugh, the sound more forced than genuine.

No, thank you.

“Old habits die hard,” she deflected, brushing off the request with a wave of her hand as she stepped forward and placed the blue folder on the desk, throwing caution to the wind. “I need to file this.”

And with that, she turned on her heel, fully prepared to make her escape.

“Wait,” Mrs. Hart called out, her tone calm but commanding.

Agatha froze mid-step, her shoulders tensing as she closed her eyes for a moment.

Of course it wouldn’t be that easy.

Sighing internally, Agatha turned on her heel, schooling her expression into a mask of neutrality as she faced Mrs. Hart again.

Mrs. Hart glanced down at the folder on her desk, her finger tapping against it with a hesitant rhythm, as if wary of what might be inside.

“Are we being sued by one of the first years again?” she asked, giving Agatha a pointed look.

Agatha bristled, crossing her arms tightly over her chest.

“No,” she said curtly. “And even if they tried, they wouldn’t have a leg to stand on. Their contract is ironclad.”

Mrs. Hart raised a brow, unimpressed.

“Did you cause bodily harm to any of our employees?”

Agatha scoffed, rolling her eyes.

“That was one time, and my coffee slipped, ” she hissed defensively.

Mrs. Hart didn’t miss a beat.

“Did you hold another company-wide meeting to present a PowerPoint ranking all the associates from ‘safe’ to ‘most likely to get fired’?”

Agatha glared, her lips thinning as she leaned forward slightly.

“No,” she said with exaggerated calm, tapping her chin in mock contemplation. “But now that you mention it, I do think we’re due for another one of those.”

Mrs. Hart opened her mouth to throw out another one of Agatha’s “questionable decisions” but Agatha stepped forward.

“No, no, and no,” said Agatha losing her patience. “Just open it,” she gestured to the folder.

Mrs. Hart gave her a knowing look, then grabbed the folder and leaned back in her chair, opening it with the deliberate care of someone who had seen it all but still expected a surprise.

Agatha held her breath, watching as Mrs. Hart scanned the document.

“Oh!” Mrs. Hart said, a note of surprise in her voice. She flicked her gaze up to Agatha, her smile widening. “You must be so proud! I always knew that son of yours was a smart one.”

Agatha blinked, her brow furrowing in confusion.

Was this woman going senile?

“What—” Agatha started, but Mrs. Hart cut her off by lifting the paper and holding it up for her to see.

“Look at all those gold stars!” Mrs. Hart exclaimed, delighted.

Agatha’s eyes dropped to the paper, her confusion turning to horror as she took in the childish chore chart. Written at the top in big, blocky letters were the words “I Listened Today,” followed by an obscene number of gold stars haphazardly stuck across the page.

It only took a second for Agatha to piece it together, and when she did, a deep flush crept up her neck and spread across her face, hot and searing.

Oh. Rio.

Agatha’s hands curled into fists at her sides as she bit down the stream of curses bubbling to the surface. She could already picture Rio’s smug expression, that infuriating smirk as she’d slipped the paper into the folder, knowing full well it what it meant.

Agatha’s teeth clenched, her jaw tight with fury.

She was going to kill her.

Slowly.

Agatha moved with a speed that was anything but slow, practically ripping the paper from Mrs. Hart’s hands in a motion so abrupt it bordered on embarrassing.

Mrs. Hart startled at the ferocity of it, her expression a mix of surprise and mild amusement.

“Yes,” Agatha hissed, catching herself mid-snap and forcing her tone into something more controlled. “I am very proud.”

She clutched the paper covered in gold stars in one hand, crumpling it slightly, while her eyes darted to the open folder now sitting on the desk. There it was—the Relationship Disclosure Form, practically flashing up at her. Mrs. Hart’s gaze followed hers.

The older woman’s eyes went wide as she took in the contents of the folder.

Agatha froze, watching in horror as Mrs. Hart’s eyes scanned the paperwork, her expression shifting from shock to something far more measured. Then, slowly, Mrs. Hart’s gaze moved back up to Agatha, a curious arch of her brow adding to the growing tension.

“You’re disclosing a relationship with...” Mrs. Hart paused, glancing down at the form again for confirmation, her voice tinged with incredulity. “Rio Vidal. A first-year associate?”

Agatha froze, her mind racing for a response, but in the end, she decided— fuck it.

“That’s what it says,” she replied coolly, flicking her hand toward the document as if it were nothing more than a minor inconvenience, and not something capable of giving Agatha a panic attack.

Mrs. Hart’s gaze didn’t waver.

“Isn’t Rio Vidal’s file the one your assistant returned to me last month with permanent marker scribbled all over it? Her company picture had a mustache and a beard”

Agatha fought hard against the smirk tugging at the corners of her lips, determined to keep her expression impassive. She remembered the moment vividly—letting Nicky draw the file purely out of spite toward Rio at the time.

But Mrs. Hart didn’t need to know that.

“I’ll speak to Billy about his negligence with personnel files later,” Agatha said smoothly, deflecting with practiced ease. “Now, are we done here?”

Mrs. Hart gave her a long, skeptical look, the kind that could see through just about anything. With a resigned sigh, she closed the folder, tapping it lightly against the desk.

“Have you removed her from your direct report?” she asked, her tone all business now.

“Yes,” Agatha answered, her voice sharp and to the point.

Mrs. Hart nodded, closing the folder with a soft thump and setting it neatly on her desk.

“Good,” she said briskly. “Then we’re done—for now.”

Agatha took that as her cue to leave, turning on her heel with practiced precision and heading for the door. Her pulse was still pounding, and all she wanted was to escape this office.

“Agatha,” Mrs. Hart called out just as her hand reached the door handle.

Agatha paused, stiffening slightly before turning back to face her.

Mrs. Hart’s expression had softened, and for a moment, Agatha saw something almost maternal in her warm smile.

“Congratulations,” Mrs. Hart said gently. “I hope it works out for you, dear.”

The words hit Agatha like a quiet wave, disarming her in a way she hadn’t expected. She opened her mouth to respond, but nothing came out, so she settled for a small, tight nod.

Without another word, she turned back to the door, stepping out into the hallway. Her footsteps were quick, her chest tight, but Mrs. Hart’s parting words lingered, trailing after her like a faint echo she couldn’t quite shake.

It wasn’t until Agatha was halfway to her office that she realized she was still clutching the piece of paper covered in gold stars.

She came to an abrupt stop in the middle of the hallway, glancing down at it. The sheer number of gold stars on it, and knowing Rio everyone was purposeful, marking the exact moment Agatha did listen, made her jaw tighten. Whatever lingering warmth she’d felt from Mrs. Hart’s unexpected blessing evaporated in an instant.

Rio.

Her name simmered in Agatha’s mind.

Without a second thought, she spun on her heel and marched toward Rio’s office with purpose. Judging by the way the associates practically leapt out of her path—side-stepping into cubicles and flattening themselves against the walls—her expression was likely a perfect reflection of the storm brewing inside her.

Agatha stormed into Rio’s office, ready to unleash the anger building in her chest, only to find it empty.

Her eyes darted around the small space as if Rio might somehow be hiding in one of the corners. When that proved fruitless, she turned sharply on her heel, her movements taut with irritation, before reaching into her pocket and fishing out her phone.

Her thumb tapped the screen with precision, dialing Rio’s number as she paced the office. She shut the door firmly behind her, the sound reverberating through the small space as she raised the phone to her ear.

It rang once. Twice.

Rio picked up on the third ring.

“Hello, my love,” Rio said, her voice low and raspy, that soft endearment curling around the words like it belonged there.

Agatha froze for a moment, her mind blanking at the sound of those two simple words. She hated it—hated how it hit her, unbalancing her just enough to make her forget why she was even mad in the first place.

Agatha’s grip on the phone tightened as she forced herself to snap out of the haze Rio’s voice always seemed to put her in.

“Where are you?” she demanded.

There was a pause on the other end, followed by the faint shuffling of movement and the low hum of traffic in the background.

“I’m with Mrs. Kale,” Rio said, her voice calm as ever. “She’s taking me to a deposition across town.”

Agatha froze at that, her heart giving a sudden, unwelcome lurch.

“Do you have security?” she asked, her irritation dissolving into something else entirely— concern .

“Yes,” Rio replied, her tone steady and reassuring. “Two very large bodyguards trailing us like shadows.”

“Good,” Agatha muttered, relief flooding through her.

For a moment, there was silence as she paused, catching her breath. Then she remembered exactly why she’d called.

“I found your little sticker chart,” she growled, her voice low and cutting.

There was a beat of silence on the other end, just long enough to let Agatha know Rio was composing herself.

“Did you now?” Rio remarked, her voice deceptively calm.

But Agatha could hear it—the faint edge of amusement she was trying—and failing, to suppress.

“Yes,” Agatha hissed, her grip tightening on the crumpled paper. The heat of her anger turned into something else entirely, a slow burn coursing through her, far more dangerous.

“When you get home,” Agatha growled, her voice dropping into a husky, dangerous tone, “ your ass is mine .”

Rio didn't miss a beat.

“That sounds like fun,” she responded, her professional voice slipping with a playful heat.

Agatha opened her mouth to respond, ready to deliver a biting retort, but the unmistakable sound of Jen’s voice cut through the line.

“Who are you talking to?” Jen asked, her tone dripping with suspicion. There was a brief pause before she added, sharper this time, “ Gross. Is that Agatha? Tell her no personal calls on company time!”

Agatha’s anger, already simmering, flared back to full force, snapping like a whip.

“Tell Jen she can fuck off,” she snapped, her voice cutting through the phone with precision.

The line went silent for a beat.

“I will not be saying that to my boss,” Rio replied, her tone dry but amused, though Agatha could hear the faint shuffling of movement in the background. “Look, we just got to the building. I have to go.”

Before Agatha could respond, Rio’s voice softened, a warmth threading through her words.

“ Te veo, ” Rio murmured, her voice carrying a gentleness that caught Agatha completely off guard.

The line clicked off suddenly, leaving Agatha staring at her phone, her breath caught somewhere between a huff of frustration and something deeper she refused to name.

It wasn’t until a moment later, as she stood there alone in Rio’s office, the ridiculous gold- star-covered paper still crumpled in her hand, that the realization struck her.

She had said, “when you get home.”

Not her home.

Not Agatha’s home.

Home.

As in Rio’s home, too.

She hadn’t even thought about it—it had slipped out so naturally, so unconsciously, that it hit her like a lightning bolt.

Fuck.

Agatha didn’t know how long she stood there, replaying those words in her head, her thoughts circling relentlessly. The realization had planted itself firmly in her chest, and she couldn’t shake it.

Suddenly, her phone vibrated in her hand, jolting her back to the present. She glanced down at the screen, letting out a huff as she rolled her eyes. Without hesitation, she answered, already heading for the door to leave Rio’s office.

“Jen, I am not in the mood—”

“Agatha.”

The way Jen said her name stopped Agatha dead in her tracks. There was something in her tone—something urgent, something wrong.

“What?” she demanded, her voice sharp, but it carried the faintest tremor.

Silence followed, stretching far too long, and then Agatha heard it—the unmistakable sound of sirens wailing in the background.

“Fuck—Agatha,” Jen’s voice was tight, panicked, unlike anything Agatha had ever heard from her. “You need to get to Mount Sinai. Now. ”

The sirens grew louder, piercing through the static of Agatha’s mind.

“It’s Rio.”

And Agatha— she forgot how to breathe.

Chapter End Notes

Chooo...chooo...all aboard the angst train. Hopefully this one will be a round trip back??

I have been sitting on Mrs. Hart being HR since like chapter 5 and I have been WAITING for this moment. Freaking loved writing her into the story. I could like picture her voice and smile during her exchange with Agatha.

Also, as a writer this just was so good to me. For Agatha to literally to question love, and think "Was she going to lose her ability to fucking breathe without Rio?" like it was impossible to even think of, that Rio did have that power over her.

Only for the last line to be: And Agatha—she forgot how to breathe.

Because she might actually be without Rio.

It is shit like that makes me fall in love with writing.

Darkest Hour

Agatha burst through the emergency room doors as manic as she felt, her heels pounding against the floor as she moved with a singular focus. Her chest was tight, as her breath came out in short, ragged bursts, her eyes darting around the crowded room.

Ignoring the line of people waiting at the front desk, she pushed past them with zero fucks given, slamming her palms onto the desk with enough force to make the nearby pens rattle.

“Where is Rio Vidal?” she demanded, her voice sharp, carrying the full weight of her panic.

The emergency nurse behind the desk—clearly a veteran at dealing with chaotic and frenzied people—didn’t so much as blink. She just looked up at Agatha with a raised brow.

“Ma’am, you’ll need to get to the back of the line,” she said exasperated.

Agatha’s rage boiled over instantly.

“If you don’t tell me where she is right now, ” she hissed, her voice dropping dangerously low, “I will sue this fucking hospital until I own it—and when I do, you’ll be the first person I fire!”

The nurse’s brow twitched, the only sign she’d been affected, but her calm demeanor held.

“Ma’am,” she said, her tone firm, “I need you to take a breath and—”

“Don’t tell me to breathe, ” Agatha snapped as she leaned closer, her entire body practically vibrating. “Rio Vidal. Where. Is. She ?”

Before the nurse could respond, another voice cut through the air.

“Agatha!”

Agatha whipped around, her heart seizing in her chest as she locked eyes with Jen.

She was standing about ten feet away, her usual polished appearance still intact but the tan coat she was wearing told a completely different story.

Even from this distance, Agatha could see it, the dark, unmistakable splatters of blood staining the fabric.

Agatha's breath caught, a sharp gasp sticking in her throat—and for a moment, her entire world tilted.

“Jen,” Agatha choked out, her voice barely audible. She moved to step forward, but her knees buckled, her legs giving out beneath her as the weight of everything crashed down all at once.

The ground rushed toward her, fast and unforgiving—but before she could hit it, arms caught her.

“Whoa, Agatha,” Jen’s voice was sharp but steady, her grip firm as she pulled Agatha upright. “I’ve got you.”

Agatha clung to her as the world spun and her chest heaved. Her eyes locked on the bloodstains on Jen’s coat, so vivid and stark against the light fabric, and her stomach twisted violently. Her hands tightened on Jen’s arms, her knuckles turning white as she fought to pull herself together but the panic clawing at her chest wouldn’t let go.

“Blood,” Agatha managed to gasp out, her gaze still locked on the stains as her voice trembled. “Is that... is that Rio’s?”

Jen hesitated, the pause just long enough for Agatha to catch it—and fuck it felt like someone punched her in the chest.

“Yes,” Jen finally admitted softly.

Agatha let out a ragged breath, her chest heaving as tears blurred her vision. One hand flew to her chest, clutching at her heart feeling like it was breaking— shattering into pieces inside her.

“Jen...” she cried out, the sound raw and pleading. Her knees buckled again, like her body was folding at the sheer weight of everything dragging her down.

“Shit,” Jen cursed under her breath, moving quickly to catch her. She gripped Agatha firmly around the middle, before steering her backward until she eased her into a chair.

As soon as Agatha sat down, her head dipped forward, trembling hands covering her face as though she could block out the image burned into her mind. The sight of Rio’s blood was still vivid, sharp, and utterly unbearable . Her body trembled as adrenaline and fear coursed through her veins.

“Agatha,” Jen said softly but insistent. She crouched in front of her, reaching out to gently peel back Agatha’s hands from her face, before firmly grabbing Agatha’s face and tilting it upward so their eyes met.

“Look at me,” Jen urged, her grip anchoring Agatha for a moment. “Rio is alive. Do you hear me? She’s alive. The doctors are patching her up right now.”

Agatha’s tear-filled eyes locked onto Jen’s. Her breathing was still ragged, but the words began to cut through the fog.

Alive.

The one word reverberated in her mind.

“She’s alive,” Agatha repeated in a shaky whisper, as though saying it aloud would make it real.

"Yes, honey," Jen said, her voice impossibly gentle as she held Agatha’s face, making sure their eyes stayed locked. "She’s alive."

Jen’s words broke something loose inside Agatha and a sob tore free from her chest, as her shoulders shook violently. The tension she’d been holding onto for dear life unleashed all at once, leaving her in an uncontrollable free fall as her emotions tore out of her.

Jen moved in closer wrapping her arms around Agatha and holding her tightly as the sobs tore through her.

“Breathe, Agatha,” she murmured softly, her voice calm and steady. “It’s okay. Let it out.”

Agatha’s sobs came in harsh, choking gasps as she struggled to pull herself together.

Jen held her steady throughout every cry, murmuring quiet reassurances.

Finally, with a shuddering breath, Agatha pulled back, her hands quickly moving to wipe at her tear-streaked face. Her face felt raw, and hot. The embarrassment of breaking down in front of Jen clawed at her, making her skin prickle uncomfortably.

But as the weight of her fear began to lift, it left something else in its place—anger.

A burning, unrelenting fury.

Her chest heaved as she fixed Jen with a sharp glance.

“What the fuck happened?” she demanded, her words dripping with rage, her hands still trembling in her lap.

Jen hesitated for a fraction of a second, her jaw tightening before she quickly composed herself, straightening to a stand as she spoke.

“Someone tried to mug me,” she said, disbelief lacing her words. “One second, we were walking into VitaCore headquarters, and the next, this random guy comes out of nowhere and tries to grab my Prada bag. Rio stepped in, there was a scuffle, and then...”

Her voice faltered as her eyes flicking away for a moment as if she didn’t want to say the words, and then back to Agatha.

“Then there was a gunshot.”

Agatha felt the air leave her lungs as the world tilting on its axis.

“Wait,” she whispered, her voice trembling as she gripped the arm of the chair with white- knuckled intensity. Her vision swam for a moment, and she forced herself to focus on Jen’s face.

“She was shot?”

The words came out in a breathless—fragile whisper, as if saying them aloud would make them more real.

Jen nodded, jaw clenching as her own hands trembled slightly before she crossed her arms.

“She was shot the shoulder,” she added quickly, her voice urgent as she rushed to explain. “But it just grazed her.”

Agatha barely heard her.

The words she was shot echoing in her mind, growing louder with each repetition. Her chest heaved as she tried to breathe, the weight of the revelation pressing down on her chest like a fucking boulder, leaving her feeling somehow both hollow and filled with rage.

“I—” Agatha started, her voice catching as the words tangled in her throat. Nothing coherent came out.

It took a moment, but when she finally found her voice, fury surged forward, filling the void.

“Where in the hell was security?!” she raged, her voice cutting through the air like a whip. “How in the hell did this even happen?”

Jen flinched slightly at the outburst, her composure faltering for a fraction of a second before she steadied herself.

“They were there, Agatha,” Jen said, her voice calm but heavy with exhaustion. “It happened so fast. One second, it was just some guy grabbing my bag, and the next... everything spiraled.”

She hesitated, her eyes clouding like she was replaying the memory in her mind.

“They’re the only reason Rio and I are still alive,” she continued, her voice softening. “They tackled the mugger just as he was aiming at Rio. They stopped him—but not before the gun went off...”

Agatha froze, the words hitting her like a physical blow. Her breath caught as her body going rigid as the implications sank in. And with it, the rage flared hotter—searing through her veins.

“And the shooter?” Agatha asked, her voice low and cold.

Jen’s expression tightened and a grimace flickering across her face.

“He got away,” she admitted.

“He got away ?” Agatha spat, the words slicing through the air. “You’re telling me the man who shot Rio is out there right now?!”

Jen winced but tried to explain.

“Agatha, it happened so fast—”

“I don’t care how fast it happened!” Agatha snapped, her voice rising. “How the hell does someone walk away from this?!”

Jen held her ground as she shot Agatha a look.

“Security prioritized getting us to saftey, Agatha. It was chaos. By the time they secured Rio and me, he was gone.”

Agatha’s fingers twisted in her lap. The thought of the shooter still at large— walking free— it was like a knife twisting in her gut. Her breath came out in heavy puffs as she tried to focus on anything other than the blinding rage threatening to take over her.

“I need to see her!” Agatha demanded, her voice trembling under the weight of her barely contained emotions.

But as her words hung in the air, her anger suddenly ebbed, giving way to something far more deeper. Desperation crept into her tone, cracking it at the edges, and her eyes filled with fresh tears as she looked at Jen.

“ I need to see her ,” she repeated, the plea in her voice so quiet— so vulnerable , it startled even herself.

Jen’s eyes widened at that before softening as she looked at Agatha, then really looked at her.

“Okay—okay,” Jen murmured after a moment, her voice impossibly gentle. She reached out briefly and her hand squeezed Agatha’s arm. “I’ll see if I can find a doctor. I’ll be right back.”

She turned toward the front desk, her stride carrying her through the bustling chaos of the emergency room.

Agatha watched her go, the panic still clawing at her chest as she waited—every second feeling like an eternity.

She leaned forward, resting her elbows on her knees and burying her face into her hands. She took a deep, shaky breath, as the sharp scent of antiseptic flooded her senses. Her stomach twisted in revulsion, a visceral response she couldn’t suppress.

She fucking hated hospitals.

Her mind reeled back to the year she had spent in one—by Nicky’s side, watching him endure round after round of chemo, the machines beeping relentlessly around him, the sterile walls a constant reminder of how close she’d come to losing him. There had been a surgery too, the hours stretching endlessly as she sat praying to a God she didn’t even believed in for him to pull through.

He’d come so close to dying... so fucking close .

And now, here she was again.

With Rio.

Another person she loved.

Her breath hitched at the thought as her fingers digging into her temples as if she could block out the overwhelming weight moving from her brain to her chest.

Why does the world keep trying to take away the people she loves?

The question hit her like a hammer— heavy —over and over again. And then, as if summoned by her pain, another voice crept in—one that had haunted her since she was a child.

Did it ever occur to you that perhaps God is punishing you?

Evanora’s cruel words echoed in her mind, sharp and venomous, worming their way between her thoughts. Agatha shook her head violently, as if she could physically shake them loose, but they clung to her insides like a fucking leech.

Agatha pulled at the roots of her hair, her teeth gritted as though the pressure might somehow force her out of the nightmare inside her head. Her breaths were shallow, and her chest tightened as her mind spiraled further into a place she didn’t want to be.

Suddenly, there was movement beside her—two people sitting down, one on either side. Then, warm hands rested gently on her back, steady and grounding.

Her head shot up, startled, her wide eyes darting to her right.

Lilia.

Agatha’s gaze shifted to her left.

Alice.

She didn’t say a word, her throat too tight, her mind too frayed. Instead, she brought her gaze forward, staring blankly ahead. The tension in her body began to ease—just a fraction, as she let their hands rest on her back, their presence surprising but so goddamn needed .

She inhaled deeply, the steady weight of their touch anchoring her, keeping her from spiraling further as the minutes ticked by. The chaos of the hospital around her dulled, and for the first

time since she’d walked through those doors, Agatha felt like she could breathe—even if just barely.

But then, movement in the distance caught her attention.

Jen.

And walking beside her was a female doctor in a white coat, her expressions serious.

They were heading directly for her.

Agatha’s body reacted before her mind fully registered what was happening. She shot out of her seat, her knees trembling as she stood as her heart pounded wildly in her chest.

“Is she—” Agatha started, her voice catching before she could finish.

Jen raised a hand, a small gesture that managed to calm her just enough to stay rooted in place.

The doctor stopped in front of her, looking between Agatha and the others.

“Ms. Harkness?” the doctor asked, her tone calm but direct, meeting Agatha’s sharp, unblinking gaze.

“Yes,” she said quickly.

The doctor exhaled softly, nodding once before speaking.

“Ms. Vidal is a little banged up,” she began, their words steady but kind, “but she’s fine.”

Agatha’s breath hitched, her knees nearly giving out as a wave of relief crashed over her.

The doctor offered a small, reassuring smile before continuing.

“She’s asking to see you.”

Those words— she's asking to see you —sent a different kind of tremor through Agatha. She nodded quickly, her voice catching.

“Take me to her.”

The doctor nodded and gestured for Agatha to follow, stepping aside to clear the way.

Agatha moved forward instinctively, but then paused, her eyes darting back to Jen, Alice, and Lilia. She hesitated as her insides curled, making her feel like she needed to say something — anything— to acknowledge their support.

“Go,” Lilia said gently, nodding toward her with a small encouraging smile. “We’ll be here.”

Agatha took a shaky breath, the gratitude she felt too heavy for words, and nodded back to them. Without another word, she turned and followed the doctor, her steps unsteady as they

entered the labyrinthine of halls of the ER.

The sharp scent of antiseptic was stronger here, mingling with the faint tang of something metallic that turned Agatha’s stomach. The corridors were bustling with people—nurses rushing between stations, patients groaning in pain, and the nightmare wouldn’t be complete of course without the sharp, distant cry of a child echoing through the halls.

Agatha’s skin prickled at the sound, her shoulders tensing. The noise pulling at painful memories she didn’t want to resurface. She forced herself to focus on the doctor’s back, the white coat guiding her through the chaos like a lifeline.

“This way,” the doctor said over her shoulder, leading her around another corner. The hum of activity dimmed slightly and the hall grew quieter, more secluded.

Agatha’s pulse quickened and the anticipation built with every step.

Finally, the doctor stopped in front of a closed door and turned to her, offering a small, reassuring nod.

“She’s inside,” she said softly, stepping aside to give her a path to enter.

Agatha’s hand hovered over the door handle for a moment, her breath hitching as her emotions swirled—relief, fear, and the overwhelming need to see Rio for herself. With a steadying breath, she turned the handle and pushed the door open.

The moment she stepped inside, she was met with the sharp, clipped sound of Rio’s voice, practically vibrating with frustration.

"I told you, I’m not letting another person touch me until I see Agatha Harkness!"

Rio’s pacing was relentless, her steps agitated as she moved back and forth across the small recovery room. She didn’t even glance at the door, her words clearly aimed at the empty air —or the medical staff she’d presumably entered her room.

Agatha’s breath caught as her eyes took in the sight before her.

Rio was still in her black dress pants, but now paired with a plain white T-shirt. Her hair, was pulled back into a messy ponytail. The collar of the shirt was stained with dried blood.

When Rio turned to pace the other way, Agatha’s gaze locked onto the torn shoulder of her white shirt, the fabric roughly cut away to accommodate the thick white bandage wrapped around her upper arm. The sight sent a sharp pang through Agatha’s chest, but it was nothing compared to the jolt of emotion that hit when her eyes traveled up to Rio’s face.

A jagged cut through Rio’s brow had been stitched shut with and the angry bruising around it was already darkening into deep purples and blues. The contrast against her pale skin made the injury look even worse, and Agatha’s stomach twisted painfully.

It didn’t matter that Rio was upright, pacing, or even shouting—because seeing Rio like this —bruised, cut, stitched back together, made Agatha’s breath hitch, the full weight of

everything crashing down on her all over again.

The sharp hitch of Agatha’s breath must have been louder than she realized, because Rio froze mid-step, her head snapping toward the door.

Her gaze landed on Agatha, wide at first, her body tensing as if bracing for something. But then, in a single heartbeat, the tension melted from her frame, her shoulders sagging slightly as relief flooded her features.

“Agatha,” Rio said softly, the frustration and anger that had laced her earlier tone now replaced with something achingly tender. She didn’t move right away, as if the sight of Agatha in the doorway had momentarily rooted her in place.

Agatha didn’t speak.

She couldn’t.

Her eyes were locked on Rio, scanning every bruise, every bandage, every speck of blood dried on her skin and shirt—and her chest tightened so painfully.

Neither of them spoke.

They just stared at each other.

Then, as if pulled by an invisible thread, they both moved at the same time. Agatha stepped forward, reaching up as her fingers threaded into Rio’s messy hair as she gripped the back of her head and pulled her forward. Her arms wrapped tightly around Rio’s frame, holding her as if letting go wasn’t an option.

Rio followed instinctively, her own arms circling Agatha’s waist, her fingers curling into the fabric of Agatha’s coat with a desperate sort of grip. She buried her face into the curve of Agatha’s neck, and Agatha felt the warm rush of Rio’s breath against her skin as she inhaled deeply, like she needed Agatha as much as Agatha needed her.

All that mattered was that Rio was here, alive— breathing , and most importantly, back in her arms.

Agatha closed her eyes, her own breath hitching as she leaned into her even further. Her fingers moved gently, raking through Rio’s hair, her touch slow as if trying to calm them both.

She buried her face in Rio’s hair, the faint scent of forest mingling with the sterile, metallic tang of the hospital, and inhaled deeply. As if the act of breathing her in could stitch back together the parts of herself that had shattered at the thought of losing her.

Rio’s fingers curled tighter into Agatha’s coat, a silent plea for her to stay close. Agatha’s hand shifted slightly, her fingertips tracing the base of Rio’s neck, her touch light but constant as she offered reassurance without words.

Agatha held her for a few more moments, her fingers still raking gently through Rio’s hair, before she murmured softly.

“Let me see your face.”

Rio exhaled a shaky breath against Agatha’s neck, the warmth of it lingering on her skin, but she pulled back, her movements slow and deliberate.

Agatha’s hands moved instinctively, rising to cup Rio’s face. Her palms rested against her cheeks as her thumbs brushing lightly over the curve of Rio’s cheekbones. She tilted Rio’s head slightly with a mix of tenderness and pain etched into her expression.

Agatha’s gaze lingered on the stitched cut above Rio’s brow, the dark bruising spreading out like a painful bloom around it. Her jaw tightened, muscles flexing as she fought against the wave of emotions threatening to consume her.

She reached up slowly, her fingers trembling slightly as they traced the edge of the bruise. Her touch was light, barely there, as she followed the jagged line of the stitches running through Rio’s brow and extending up her forehead at least an inch.

The sight of it sent a fresh ache through Agatha’s chest.

“God damn it, Rio,” she murmured, her voice trembling, the words carrying equal parts frustration and aching concern.

Rio let out a soft breath, warm against Agatha’s skin, and a faint smirk tugged at the corner of her lips.

“I know,” she murmured, her voice low and teasing. “I’m turning into one giant lesbian cliché.”

She tilted her head slightly, the smirk widening as a playful glint lit her tired eyes.

“My eyebrow hair probably won’t grow back normal and people are definitely going to think I gave myself an eyebrow slit on purpose.”

Agatha’s jaw tightened, her grip on Rio’s face firming but still being careful.

“Don’t make jokes right now,” she said, her voice tense, the words edged.

Rio’s smirk faltered, fading entirely as she stared at Agatha. The teasing light in her eyes dimmed, replaced by something softer—more serious. She held Agatha’s gaze for a long moment, no doubt, taking in every deepened line etched into Agatha’s face since the moment she heard Rio was hurt.

Finally, she nodded.

“Okay,” she murmured, her voice steady but subdued, the weight of the moment settling between them again.

Rio reached up slowly, her hands gentle as they cupped Agatha’s face. She leaned in, closing the small distance between them until their foreheads touched.

Agatha let out a shaky breath, their exhales mingling in the small space between them.

“ Agatha ,” Rio murmured, her voice trembling in a way Agatha had never heard before.

Agatha’s heart clenched at the sound.

“Yeah?”

Rio closed her eyes, her fingers curling around the back of Agatha’s neck, stroking the skin there.

“I want to go home,” she said, her voice breaking ever so slightly. “Please take me home.”

Agatha swallowed hard, the lump in her throat threatening to choke her, and she nodded against Rio’s forehead.

“Okay, my love,” she whispered, her voice filled with a love that she couldn’t contain—not anymore. “Let’s go home.”

Agatha twisted the door handle and stepped into the familiar embrace of her home. The soft quiet of the house washed over her—such a stark contrast to the chaos of the hospital. She turned, holding the door open for Rio, who walked slowly behind her.

It had taken hours to get discharged, the entire ordeal a marathon of paperwork and negotiation. The combined influence of all four partners had been the only thing that made it happen.

Lilia had pulled strings with the hospital’s leadership.

Alice, wielding her former experience as a prosecuting attorney, had managed to delay the police interview until tomorrow.

Jen, ever the coordinator, had handled the rest with precision.

And Agatha?

She had done something rare for her—she let them take over. She’d sat silently, letting them handle the logistics, trusting them to take care of everything she couldn’t, but most importantly, trusting them to take care of Rio.

And now, finally, they were home.

The late hour draped the house in a heavy darkness and stillness. Nicky was already asleep, no doubt, disappointed that Agatha hadn’t been home in time to tuck him in. Agatha had resolved herself she’d find a way to explain everything to him tomorrow, to tell him about Rio’s injuries without scaring him.

She didn’t like lying to him—it wasn’t how she parented—but the instinct to protect him far outweighed the weight of a little lie.

Agatha stepped aside, her eyes fixed on Rio as she shuffled into the house, her movements careful and slow. Once Rio was inside, Agatha quietly shut the door behind her as the soft click of the lock echoed in the stillness.

They walked down the hallway together in silence, the weight of the day settling into the quiet between them. Agatha toed off her shoes with practiced ease, setting them neatly to the side. Rio hesitated for a moment before bending over to do the same, but Agatha’s hand landed firmly on her shoulder, stopping her mid-motion.

Agatha gave Rio a pointed look before crouching down to handle it herself.

“Agatha,” Rio sighed. “I can take off my own shoes.”

Agatha’s narrowed eyes shot up at her.

“You have a concussion,” she said, her voice low but firm—the tone leaving no room for argument.

Rio opened her mouth to respond, but the look Agatha gave her cut her off before a single word escaped. Instead, she sighed again, this time softer, and let her shoulders relax slightly, as Agatha took off one shoe, and then the other. Setting them aside right next to her heels before standing.

Agatha reached forward, her hand slipping into Rio’s, and gently guided her through the house. She felt the faint hesitation in Rio’s steps as they passed the guest room door but Agatha didn’t stop—she gave a light, insistent pull, leading her past it and toward her own room.

“Agatha?” Rio murmured, her tone questioning.

Agatha didn’t respond right away. She kept walking, pulling Rio into her bedroom and stopping by the edge of the bed. Without a word, she pressed a hand to Rio’s shoulder, coaxing her to sit.

Rio sank down with a faint frown, watching Agatha as she turned and moved back to the door.

Agatha quietly shut it, the soft click sounding louder in the stillness. She rested her hand on the handle for a moment, her back to Rio before finally speaking.

“You’re sleeping in here tonight,” she said, her voice firm but low, still not turning around.

Silence hung heavy behind her.

“What about Nicky?” Rio asked.

Agatha sighed, finally turning to face her. Her eyes met Rio’s before flickering up to the stitches on Rio’s head, and her breath caught at the flood of emotions rising in her chest. Her voice wavered, but she didn’t look away.

“Rio,” she said softly, her words almost a plea, “I need you to stay in here tonight— with me .”

For a moment, they just looked at each other.

Rio’s expression softened with understanding before slowly, she nodded, her lips curving into a faint but reassuring smile.

“Okay,” she whispered, her voice gentle. Her eyes flickered toward the bathroom, and she hesitated before adding, “I’m going to go clean up first.”

Agatha nodded, unable to trust her voice to respond.

Rio stood up and took a small step forward, pausing to glance back at her.

“Do you mind grabbing me something to wear from the spare bedroom? I put all my comfy clothes in the dresser.”

Agatha nodded again, her throat working against the lump that had formed there.

Rio’s lips twitched into a shaky smile. Without another word, she turned and made her way to the bathroom, closing the door softly behind her.

Agatha stood still for a moment, the quiet of the room pressing down around her like a heavy blanket. Her hands fidgeted at her sides, restless and unsure, until she exhaled slowly, the tension in her chest loosening just enough for her to move.

She turned toward the door, her steps soft and deliberate as she made her way to the spare bedroom. The room was dim, lit only by the faint glow from the hallway. Agatha moved to the dresser.

It didn’t take long to find what she needed: a clean set of underwear, a pair of soft, worn shorts, and a faded gray Texas college soccer T-shirt. The name Vidal was printed across the back in bold letters, the number 9 below it in bright red.

Agatha’s fingers lingered on the letters, the faded print rough beneath her touch. Her heart pounded, each beat echoing the thoughts swirling in her mind. This shirt—this simple, ordinary thing—was a piece of Rio’s life, a reminder of everything that made her who she was.

A life Agatha had almost lost today.

The thought was like a punch to the chest, stealing the breath from her lungs. She closed her eyes briefly, steadying herself against the surge of emotion. She didn’t want to think about how close it had been.

With a deep breath, she pulled her hand away and carefully folded the shirt, as though treating it gently could somehow keep Rio safe. She gathered the rest of the clothes, cradling them to her chest, and turned back toward the door.

The walk back to her room felt longer than it should have, the quiet of the house amplifying the sound of her own footsteps. When she reached her room, she pushed the door open and stepped inside, and then closed it behind her.

The faint sound of running water from the bathroom filled the room, a soft, steady hum that broke the silence but did little to ease the heaviness pressing down on Agatha. She set the clothes on the edge of the bed and sat down next to them, her elbows resting on her knees as she stared at her hands.

Her eyes drifted to the hospital bag on the floor.

Rio’s clothes.

Without thinking, she reached for it, her fingers curling around the handles as she picked it up.

Her intentions were simple—take out the clothes, toss them in the laundry, and try to create some semblance of normalcy. But as she reached inside and pulled out the first item, she froze.

Rio’s white collared shirt—the one she had worn this morning—hung limply from Agatha’s hands, its fabric now a horrifying patchwork of red. The collar was soaked in blood, a dark, dried stain that spread across the chest. The sleeve had a jagged tear, surrounded by more blood that had dried into a sickening rust color.

Agatha’s breath hitched, and her stomach twisted violently at the sight. The sheer amount of blood sent a wave of nausea crashing through her.

She couldn’t move, her hands trembling as they clutched the shirt. Her eyes stayed locked on the bloodstains, her mind replaying the same haunting images she hadn’t even seen but couldn’t stop imagining.

The chaos.

The gunshot.

Rio crying out in pain.

Her throat tightened, and before she could even register it, tears began to blur her vision.

Still, she didn’t move.

She couldn’t.

The tears spilled over, warm and unchecked, trailing silently down her cheeks.

Even then, she didn’t lift a hand to wipe them away.

All she could do was watch helplessly as her tears fell, landing softly on the bloodstained fabric. Tiny droplets seeped into the dark crimson already there, merging into the dried blood. The sight of her tears mixing with Rio’s blood felt like an invisible hand tightening around her heart—squeezing until it was felt like it was going to burst.

The sound of the bathroom door opening broke through the fog in her mind, pulling her attention back. She blinked rapidly, the tears still falling, and looked up to see Rio standing in the doorway.

Rio stood there wrapped in a towel, her eyes locking on Agatha instantly. They widened as they took in the tears streaming down Agatha’s face, the anguish etched into every line of her posture. Then Rio’s gaze shifted, landing on the bloodstained shirt clenched tightly in Agatha’s trembling hands.

Her jaw tightened, her expression hardening for a brief moment before softening.

“Agatha,” Rio murmured, her voice gentle, but Agatha couldn’t look at her. Her gaze fell back to the shirt, her knuckles white around the fabric and her breath unsteady.

Soft footsteps sounded, and then Rio was crouched in front of her.

Agatha barely registered it until Rio’s warm hands covered hers, gently prying at her fingers, until Agatha let go of the shirt, letting it fall the ground as Rio intertwined their hands together.

“Hey,” Rio said, her tone soothing as she squeezed Agatha's hand, “look at me.”

Agatha reluctantly lifted her eyes to meet Rio’s.

The emotion in Rio’s dark brown eyes struck her like a blow—concern, tenderness, and something so deeply reassuring that it made Agatha's tears fall harder. Agatha’s chest tightened painfully, and she opened her mouth to speak, but the words caught on a sob.

She swallowed hard, forcing herself to push through the knot in her throat.

“I almost lost you,” Agatha whispered, her voice breaking on the words, so quiet they barely made it past her lips.

Rio’s expression softened further, and her grip on Agatha’s hands tightened just slightly

“But you didn’t,” Rio said gently, her voice firm and steady, a lifeline in the storm Agatha was drowning in. “I’m here, Agatha. I’m right here.”

Rio untangled their hands, reaching up to cup Agatha’s face, her thumbs brushing away the tears with a tenderness that nearly broke her all over again.

“Hey,” Rio murmured, her tone unbelievably soft, wrapping around Agatha like a balm. “Let’s get dressed and go to bed, huh? You can hold me all night. How’s that sound?”

More tears spilled down Agatha’s cheeks at those words, and she let out a shaky breath, her heart clenching painfully.

God. That’s all she wanted.

“Okay,” she whispered, her voice so small she almost didn’t recognize it, and she hated it— hated how raw and vulnerable she sounded. She followed it with a shaky nod, trying to regain some semblance of control.

Rio gave her a soft, reassuring smile, her hands lingering for a moment to swipe away the last few tears before she rose to her feet.

Agatha wiped at the tears Rio hadn’t caught, letting out a slow breath as she forced herself to stand. Her movements felt mechanical as her legs carried her almost numbly to the bathroom. She moved through her nighttime routine, skipping the non-essentials, her mind too clouded to focus on anything more.

When she finally stepped back into the bedroom, her breath caught for a moment. The hospital bag and the bloodstained shirt were gone, and for a fleeting moment she wondered what Rio did with them but it vanished just as quickly.

Rio was already in bed, nestled under the covers, waiting for her.

Agatha crossed the room in silence, her steps soft but purposeful. She slipped into the bed beside Rio without a word.

The moment her head hit the pillow Agatha reached for Rio.

Rio shifted closer without hesitation, nestling against her as if it was the most natural thing in the world.

Agatha’s arms wrapped around her tightly, pulling her in as though holding her any looser might risk losing her altogether.

“See?” Rio murmured softly. “You’ve got me.”

Agatha’s grip tightened instinctively, her chest constricting as fresh tears welled in her eyes. She buried her face against the back of Rio’s neck, her breath hitching as she inhaled deeply.

“Yeah,” Agatha whispered, her voice thick with emotion. “I do.”

They lay in silence, and Agatha could feel the gentle rise and fall of Rio’s chest against her own.

It was everything she needed and yet it made the ache in her chest deepen.

The words hovered in Agatha’s mind, unspoken but insistent.

I love you.

She tightened her hold around Rio, the thought growing louder with every heartbeat.

“Rio,” she whispered, her voice barely audible.

“Yeah?” Rio murmured back her voice soft but drowsy.

“I—” Agatha began, her breath hitching, but the words caught in her throat.

Just say it.

Say I love you.

You almost lost her today.

Say it.

“I—” she tried again, her voice faltering as the words refused to come.

Before she could spiral any further, Rio’s hand reached down, brushing against Agatha’s. Rio grabbed the hand wrapped around her middle and intertwined their fingers, holding on tightly.

“I know you do,” Rio whispered.

Silence stretched between them again.

“Go to sleep, baby,” Rio murmured, her words gentle and reassuring.

And with that, Agatha exhaled a shaky breath, her eyes fluttering shut as she held Rio closer. The weight of the day didn’t ease, but she let herself drift off with Rio safe in her arms. Chapter End Notes See...I am not a complete monster!

Time is an Illusion

Chapter Notes

Thanks for being patient with me. The holiday was crazy, and I had no time to write. So here is a nearly 10,000 word chapter to make up for the wait. Also...peep the additional chapter I had to add. So we are up to 31. I know you guys want me to go beyond 31 but I am starting to lose gas. This chapter was already so hard to write, and I am feeling like I need to take a break from writing soon lol I will of course, finish this story but I am sticking with the gameplan and outline I already have. So 31...maybe 32 if I can't get the plot moving between now and then end.

As always, I appreciate your guys.

Agatha’s internal alarm honed by years of early mornings stirred her awake. She blinked against the soft morning light filtering through the gap in the curtains, her mind still hazy with the edges of sleep. She shifted slightly moving to sit up but suddenly realized she couldn’t move.

Her eyes shot open, and she looked down.

Two heads of dark hair were curled into her—one on each side.

Rio lay on her left, her long hair slightly mussed from sleep with her ear pressed against Agatha’s heart.

On her right, Nicky was tucked in close, his smaller body curled into her side with his short hair sticking up in all directions like it always did when he slept.

Agatha froze, her chest tightening. It took her a long moment to process what she was seeing —what she was feeling—as her heart began to swell with something achingly warm.

Her gaze flickering between them, and it hit her all at once.

Their hair.

She had never noticed it before—how similar the shades were. The deep, dark tones that mirrored one another so perfectly made her breath hitch.

Agatha swallowed hard, her hand resting wrapping around Rio’s back, her other hand brushing through Nicky’s hair. She could feel the steady rhythm of their breathing, the soft rise and fall of their chests against her.

This.

Her eyes stinging with unshed tears.

This is what whole feels like.

The thought had Agatha’s fingers trailing lightly over Rio’s back and Rio stirred slightly, nuzzling closer to her chest. On her other side, triggered by Rio stirring—Nicky let out a soft sigh in his sleep, his tiny hand curling into the fabric of Agatha's night shirt.

Agatha closed her eyes briefly.

The fear, the exhaustion, the chaos of the day before—all of it faded away in the face of this simple, quiet moment.

And for the first time in a long time, Agatha didn’t feel the need to move or rush out of the bed and conquer the day.

She didn’t want to break the spell.

So, she just stayed there holding them both, letting herself savor the feeling of holding the little boy she loved most in this world, and the woman she was starting to love with just as much ferocity.

Agatha let nearly ten minutes pass, savoring every second before the reality began to creep back in. It was a school day and while Rio wasn’t going to work and Agatha had arranged with the other partners to work from home—Nicky still needed to stick to his routine. Any deviation from that routine was a surefire recipe for a meltdown, something Agatha was well aware of and hoping to avoid at any cost.

And, as much as she hated to admit it, she needed to pee.

Badly.

Carefully, she began the delicate process of detangling herself from them both. Nicky grumbled first, a soft, sleepy noise that made Agatha’s lips twitch into a smile. Rio followed a second later, her own sleepy mumble warm and unintelligible.

It took a few minutes, but Agatha finally managed to extract herself without fully waking either of them. She moved to the end of the bed, before standing. Looking back her breath caught in her throat.

Rio and Nicky were still asleep with an Agatha-shaped gap between them. The sight from this perspective had her stomach flipping and her heart fluttering wildly at the image. It was so simple, so perfect, and yet it left her feeling raw and exposed.

With a soft sigh, Agatha slipped into the bathroom and relieved herself. As she washed her hands, she caught her reflection in the mirror and paused.

How was she going to navigate this?

Waking Nicky without disturbing Rio wasn’t impossible, but that wasn’t what had her stomach twisting.

It was the collision of her worlds—Rio, her—what?

Girlfriend?

Lover?

And Nicky, her son.

Two people who held such enormous parts of her heart, who until now had existed in their own spaces.

But this morning, they’d both been there— together.

The image of them sleeping on either side of her resurfaced in her mind, her chest constricting with something so tender it almost hurt. Yet, the complications of it all loomed. Rio was so new to her Nicky’s life, and while he had already taken to her in ways that surprised Agatha, this was still uncharted territory.

Would Rio be okay with Nicky climbing into bed like that?

Would she feel overwhelmed?

Or worse, suffocated by the instant intimacy of family life?

Agatha shook her head, trying to push the thoughts away.

Rio had made her intentions clear—she wanted this, wanted her and she knew that Nicky was part of that package. But that didn’t make it any less terrifying to let these two worlds blend so seamlessly.

Taking a steadying breath, Agatha stepped out of the bathroom and back into the bedroom but she stopped short in the doorway, her breath catching in her throat.

At some point while she’d been gone, Nicky had moved across the bed and curled into Rio’s side. His small body was tucked against her with his head nestled beneath her chin like it was the most natural place in the world for him to be.

And Rio, still deeply asleep, had instinctively draped an arm over him, her hand resting lightly against his back, holding him close.

Agatha stared, her chest tightening as warmth flooded through her. The sight was so unexpectedly tender that it rendered her momentarily speechless.

She took a step closer, moving slowly as if afraid to disrupt the scene in front of her. Her eyes roamed over them and her heart twisted at how peaceful they both looked. Nicky’s little face was relaxed in a way that only happened when he felt completely safe, and Rio’s features, softened by sleep, looked just as content.

The sheer rightness of it all nearly undid her.

Her gaze lingered on them, and for a fleeting moment she let herself imagine a life where this wasn’t an exception but ordinary—a life where mornings like this were the norm—where this was just a part of their everyday life.

The thought terrified and thrilled her in equal measure.

Nicky shifted, grumbling softly in his sleep as he nestled closer into Rio’s side. His small head bumped against her chin, the light jolt rousing her from sleep.

Agatha froze, watching as Rio stirred, taking a deep breath as her eyes fluttered open. She blinked a few times, her gaze unfocused, as if trying to make sense of where she was. Then her eyes flicked around the room until they landed on the small figure curled into her chest.

Her body tensed briefly in surprise, her eyes going wide as she realized it was Nicky.

Agatha held her breath, waiting to see what Rio would do.

And then, the tension in Rio’s shoulders eased. The surprise melted away, replaced by an expression so soft it made Agatha’s chest ache.

Rio’s gaze lingered on Nicky with a tenderness that seemed to fill the entire room. Her hand moved slowly, brushing a lock of his messy hair back from his forehead, her touch gentle.

Nicky let out a small sigh at her touch, his body relaxing further into her.

Agatha didn’t move, her feet rooted to the spot. She hadn’t expected this, hadn’t anticipated how seeing them together would feel. Her world—two pieces she’d kept so carefully separate —had collided in the most beautiful way.

And somehow, it didn’t feel chaotic.

It felt complete.

Almost as if sensing Agatha’s gaze, Rio looked up and when her eyes locked onto Agatha’s they widened slightly, like she’d been caught.
