The silence between them was heavy, stretching for what felt like forever. Neither of them moved, their eyes locked as if the world around them stopped to give them this moment.

Finally, Agatha stepped forward. She walked around the bed, slipping in on the other side, careful not to disturb Nicky. She positioned herself against his back, her head propped on her arm as she settled in, her eyes still fixed on Rio.

Rio didn’t look away, her expression open but tentative, as if she were afraid she was overstepping.

Nicky remained nestled into Rio’s side, blissfully unaware of the emotions filling the room.

Rio finally broke the staring match, her eyes flicking down to Nicky, curled against her, before returning to Agatha’s. She swallowed, her throat working as she finally whispered.

“You okay with this?”

Agatha stayed quiet for a moment, her eyes still lingering on the two of them—the way Rio held her son, the way it looked so natural—like they belonged together.

Finally, Agatha spoke, her voice soft but steady.

“I was about to ask you the same thing.”

Rio blinked, her lips parting slightly in surprise.

For a moment, she didn’t respond, her gaze dropped back down to Nicky, still curled against her, his small body tucked securely under her arm. Her hand rested gently on his back, her fingers barely moving. When she looked back at Agatha, her eyes were softer, more thoughtful, as if she were carefully weighing her words.

“I’m okay with it,” Rio said after a moment, her voice a little unsteady but sure. “Are you?”

Agatha didn’t answer right away. Instead, she reached out, her fingers threading gently through Nicky’s messy hair, smoothing it back with slow, deliberate strokes. His quiet, rhythmic breathing filled the space, steady and soothing in a way that anchored her.

Her hand lingered there, resting lightly, as she turned the question over in her mind. Was she okay with this? It seemed like such a simple thing—Nicky curled up against Rio like it was the most natural thing in the world—but the reality was anything but simple.

“I think so,” she said finally.

Rio tilted her head and really looked at Agatha.

“You think so?” she echoed gently, her tone carrying no judgment.

Agatha sighed, letting her hand slip from Nicky’s hair to rest on the bed.

“This,” she said, gesturing faintly toward the two of them, “this wasn’t something I expected. Seeing the two of you together...like this...it’s—”

She hesitated, the words catching in her throat as she tried to put her feelings into something coherent.

“It’s a lot,” Rio finished for her.

Agatha nodded, a small, wry smile tugging at her lips.

“It’s a lot,” she agreed. “But not in a bad way. It’s just... unexpected.”

Rio looked down at Nicky at Agatha’s words.

“I get that,” she said, her voice quiet and thoughtful. “I never thought this was something I even wanted.” Her eyes were locked on Nicky, her expression softening further. “But it feels right. Doesn’t it?”

Agatha’s chest tightened as she watched Rio look at Nicky with so much care, the same tenderness she’d seen in those dark eyes when they were focused on her. The weight of the moment pressed against her, but instead of overwhelming her, it steadied her.

Agatha swallowed, as she reached out tucked a strand of Rio’s unruly bed head behind her ear, fingers lingering on her cheek.

“It does,” she murmured, thumb stroking Rio’s cheek. “It really does.”

Rio’s shoulders softened at Agatha’s words, the tension she’d been carrying visibly melting away. She leaned into Agatha’s touch, her hesitant smile shifting into something more genuine, more at ease.

They laid there in silence, their eyes meeting across the small space, with Nicky nestled soundly between them.

Agatha felt as if the room was steeped in a rare and precious stillness, the kind that made everything else fade away. And for a moment, it felt like the world had paused just for them.

But eventually, reality intruded, as it always did because the world hadn’t stopped turning, no matter how much it felt like it had.

Agatha let out a heavy sigh.

“I have to get him up for school,” she said, reluctant to disturb the peace.

Rio nodded at that, but Agatha caught the slight downturn of her smile as if she didn’t want the moment to end either.

Agatha leaned forward, carefully slipping her arms under Nicky’s small body and lifting him. Slowly, she detangled him from Rio without waking him fully, cradling him close to her chest.

Nicky stirred, mumbling something incoherent, but he snuggled closer into her, his cheek pressed against her shoulder. Agatha shimmied to the other side of the bed and stood, adjusting his weight in her arms.

He was getting bigger— too big to carry like this for much longer. But as she looked down at him, his face relaxed in sleep, she felt a pang in her chest. She thought of how small he used to be, how easily she’d carried him everywhere. That ache she knew too well threatened to rise, but she pushed it down. She would carry him for as long as she could, until the day she physically couldn’t.

For a fleeting moment, the thought crossed her mind—of having another. Maybe a little girl with dark hair and deep brown eyes. The idea sent an unexpected warmth through her chest, her heart flipping with a longing she hadn’t anticipated.

But the sound of movement behind her broke through that dangerous line of thinking.

She glanced back, catching Rio shifting, her body language making it clear she was about to attempt to get out of bed.

“Where do you think you’re going?” Agatha asked her voice still low enough not to startle Nicky but sharp enough to stop Rio in her tracks.

Rio froze, then looked up at her, attempting to raise an eyebrow, only to wince slightly as the stitches on her brow pulled. She touched them briefly, then gave Agatha a knowing look.

“I was going to make him breakfast,” she said casually, as though her idea wasn’t completely absurd.

Agatha huffed, shaking her head as she shot Rio a glare.

“Absolutely not,” she said firmly. “You are not getting out of this bed today. You will stay horizontal—all day. Do you hear me ?”

Rio’s lips twitched with a faint smile as she leaned back into the pillows, hands raised in mock surrender.

“Yes, ma’am,” she murmured.

Agatha held Rio’s gaze for a moment longer, her stern look softening before she turned her attention back to Nicky. Gently, she adjusted him in her arms and carried him out to the living room, settling him onto the couch. His small body laid against the cushions, and she reached out to smooth his hair back, her voice quiet and soothing.

“Honey, it’s time to wake up for school,” she murmured.

Nicky stirred slightly, grumbling under his breath as he shifted. Agatha smiled faintly, rubbing his back in slow circles until his eyes began to flutter open.

She watched him closely as his blue eyes adjusted to the light, scanning the room before landing on her. The sight of him, eyes still hazy with sleep made her heart ache in the best way.

“Mama,” he croaked softly, his voice still heavy from sleep.

“Good morning, baby,” she whispered, brushing his messy hair back from his forehead.

He blinked up at her, rubbing the sleep from his eyes with his small hands before his gaze settled on her, curious and a little worried.

“Where’s Rio? Why didn’t you come home last night?” he asked, his voice tinged with worry and with a hint of blame.

The question sent a warmth through her chest, but it was shadowed by unease. She hated lying to him—always had—but the full truth was far too harsh for his little world. Her hand

smoothed over his back again as she carefully chose her words.

“I’m sorry I wasn’t home last night,” she said softly, meeting his gaze. “Rio tripped and fell at work and had to go to the hospital.”

Nicky’s eyes went wide.

“But she’s home,” he said quickly, his words tumbling out as he sat up. “She was in bed with you. I saw her. She held me—I felt it.”

Agatha’s breath caught, her chest tightening at his words.

Of course, he had noticed.

Of course, he had felt Rio’s arms around him.

He always picked up on everything.

“Yes, honey” she said gently, keeping her voice steady despite the lump in her throat. “She’s home now, but she hit her head and needs to stay in bed today to rest.”

Nicky frowned, his small brow creasing as his gaze flickered toward the open bedroom door down the hallway, then back to Agatha. His voice was quieter when he spoke again.

“Can I go see her and tell her I hope she feels better?” he asked, his earnestness shining through.

Agatha felt her heart warm by the sheer kindness in his words. No matter how many times he surprised her with his thoughtful nature, it never failed to leave her in awe.

“Let’s get ready first,” she said, deciding to give him a little incentive to power through the morning routine. “Eat, get dressed, brush your teeth—and then you can see Rio. Deal?”

Nicky scrunched his nose at her words, his lips pursing as his eyes darted back toward the hallway. She could almost see the wheels turning in his head as he weighed his options, his expression so serious for such a small boy. Finally, he looked back at her and gave a decisive nod.

“Deal,” he said.

Agatha narrowed her eyes slightly, watching him closely.

That was too easy.

Her instincts prickled, but she chose not to call him out just yet, opting instead to pat his back gently.

“Good,” she said with a small smile. “Let’s get moving.”

Even as she spoke, though, she made a mental note to stay one step ahead.

He was her son after all.

Nicky managed to get dressed in record time, his uniform neat enough to pass inspection without much fuss. Agatha, meanwhile, busied herself in the kitchen, though her focus was split between the coffee pot sputtering to life and a piece of toast she was determined not to burn— again .

The first attempt had been a disaster, the smell of burnt bread still faintly lingering in the air despite her efforts to air it out. She grumbled under her breath as she plated the second round, this time only slightly burnt alongside a simple bowl of cornflakes. With a satisfied nod, she poured herself a mug of coffee, setting it on the counter just as Nicky padded into the kitchen.

He climbed onto the stool at the kitchen island before looking down at the plate in front of him. He sniffed once, his little nose wrinkling slightly, and then shot Agatha a pointed look— a look that plainly said, I know you burnt the first toast. I can smell it.

Agatha caught his expression and arched a brow, her own look saying just as clearly, Don’t push it. Just eat.

It was a routine they had perfected over time, one that needed no words. Nicky held her gaze for a moment longer before shrugging and picking up the slice of toast. He took a bite, his face carefully neutral as if judging whether it was worth commenting on.

Agatha, meanwhile, sipped her coffee, a small smirk tugging at her lips.

Maybe— just maybe —she could make it through the morning unscathed. She pushed the toaster down again, to make Rio some toast as well.

“So, is Rio your girlfriend now since she’s sleeping in your bed?”

Agatha choked on her coffee. The hot liquid burned down the wrong pipe, and she sputtered, hitting her chest as she coughed, her eyes watering.

When she finally managed to catch her breath, Agatha set her mug down with a loud thud, wiping at her mouth with the back of her hand.

“Nicky!” she rasped, her voice half incredulous, half wheezing.

Nicky watched her calmly, chewing his toast as though he hadn’t just almost killed her.

She opened her mouth, then shut it, her brain scrambling for a way to handle this line of questioning.

“She’s sleeping in my bed because she’s hurt, Nicky,” Agatha finally said, her voice measured. “And because it’s the most comfortable place for her to rest.”

Nicky frowned, clearly weighing her explanation.

“But you slept with her.”

Agatha blinked. She knew he meant actually sleeping but the words were loaded and it caused her mind to stutter for a second. She stood there trying to think of a suitable response, but all she managed was a weak.

“She needs someone to keep an eye on her.”

Nicky wasn’t buying it. He gave her a look—an unblinking, skeptical look that seemed far too knowing for a child his age. They stared at each other in silence, the air between them thickening.

Finally, Agatha sighed, setting her coffee mug down with a thud. She pushed herself away from the counter and stepped closer to Nicky, placing her hands firmly on the countertop in front of him. She leaned forward slightly, meeting his gaze directly, her heart hammering anxiously in her chest.

This wasn’t how she had envisioned the conversation going, but there was no way around it now. It was happening.

Taking a steadying breath, she squared her shoulders and spoke, her voice clear and deliberate.

“Yes,” she said, nodding slowly. “Rio is my girlfriend.”

The words hung in the air for a moment, and Agatha braced herself for his reaction.

Nicky’s expression didn’t change immediately, his big blue eyes locked on hers, processing what she’d just said.

Then, with all the innocence of a child and the precision of a fucking bullet, he asked.

“Do you love her?”

Agatha sucked in a sharp breath, her stomach flipping.

Could this kid ever just give her a fucking inch?

Agatha’s chest tightened as she stared at her son, his earnest gaze boring into hers. It felt like the room had shrunk, the weight of his question pressing down on her. Her first instinct was to deflect, to steer the conversation away, but something in Nicky’s face stopped her.

He deserved honesty—he always had, and since she already lied to him once this morning, she couldn’t do it again.

She let out a shaky breath, her hands gripping the edge of the countertop as she steadied herself. Her voice, when it came, was barely above a whisper.

“Yes,” she said, her eyes softening as she looked at him. “I do.”

The words had barely left her mouth before Agatha’s nerves got the better of her. She began pacing in front of the counter, her thoughts spilling out faster than she could organize them.

“I know it’s a lot, buddy,” she said, her tone rushed, as if she needed to get ahead of whatever reaction he might have.

“Mom,” Nicky said, his voice calm but clearly trying to get her attention.

“I know it’s really fast,” she continued, her words tumbling over his, interrupting him. “And I understand if it’s confusing or... or overwhelming.”

“Mom,” Nicky tried again, his voice a little louder this time.

“And I also know it’s different ,” Agatha added, pausing as she struggled to find the right words. “With your mom... being with another woman.”

She winced, the awkwardness of her phrasing making her cringe.

“Mom,” Nicky said again, more insistent, but Agatha barely noticed.

“I know it’s a lot of changes,” she pressed on, turning to face him, her hands gesturing as if to emphasize her sincerity. “But if you need to talk about anything— anything at all —I’m here to listen, okay? I want to make sure—”

“Mom!” Nicky’s voice finally cut through, louder and firmer, stopping her mid-sentence.

Agatha froze, her hands falling to her sides, and she stared at him, her chest heaving slightly from her nervous ramble.

“What?” she asked, blinking as though only now realizing how much she’d been rambling.

Nicky didn’t say anything at first, just gave her a look, then casually pointed behind her.

“The toast is burning,” he said simply.

Agatha froze, her confusion holding her still for a beat—until the smell hit her.

Shit.

She whipped around and darted to the toaster, slamming the lever up. A plume of smoke rose as two charred slices of bread popped up, blackened and unrecognizable.

“Damn it,” she muttered under her breath, grabbing a dish towel to fan away the smoke as she glared at the ruined toast like it had personally betrayed her.

Behind her, Nicky snickered, and when she turned to him, he was smirking around a bite of his slightly less-burnt toast.

“When is Rio feeling better?” he asked, his eyes sparkling with amusement.

Agatha shot him a faux-glare, wagging the burnt toast in his direction.

“Watch it, kid, or this is your lunch.”

Nicky giggled, his grin wide and mischievous.

“I don’t even take a lunch.”

Agatha tossed the charred toast into the trash and leaned back against the counter, crossing her arms as she looked at him, her expression softening.

“You sure you’re okay with all this?” she asked gently.

Nicky popped the last bite of toast into his mouth, chewing thoughtfully as he slid off the chair. He carried his plate and bowl to the sink, setting them down with a clink, then turned back to her.

“I’m okay with it,” he said, his tone light but certain.

Then, without hesitation, he walked over and wrapped his small arms around her waist, looking up at her with a smile that made her heart squeeze.

“It’s nice.”

Agatha’s breath caught as she looked down at him, her own arms wrapping around him instinctively. She rested her chin lightly on the top of his head for a moment before pulling back enough to meet his gaze.

“You’re sure?” she asked again, searching his face.

Nicky rolled his eyes in an exaggerated manner, shaking his head with mock exasperation.

“Yes,” he said with a huff, his tone implying she was the one being ridiculous.

Agatha narrowed her eyes at his little display of attitude, but the corners of her mouth betrayed her, twitching upward.

Nicky grinned sheepishly, clearly knowing he’d won this round. He continued grinning up at her, unbothered, before tilting his head.

“Can I go see Rio now?”

Agatha sighed, shaking her head as she ruffled his hair.

“Go on, but be gentle.”

Nicky didn’t need to be told twice. He was already halfway down the hall, his small feet padding quickly toward the bedroom. Agatha watched him go, feeling a surprising lightness settle in her chest—a small but undeniable relief.

She turned back to the counter, eyeing the toaster like it was like her personal nemesis.

With a quick motion, she grabbed two fresh slices of bread and slid them into the slots. Her finger hovered over the lever for a second before she pressed it down with a click.

Her eyes narrowed at the toaster, lips pursed.

“I’m watching you, motherfucker,” she muttered under her breath.

A few minutes later, Agatha made her way down the hallway, balancing a plate with perfect — not burnt —toast in one hand and a mug of coffee in the other. As she approached the bedroom, the sound of Nicky’s excited voice floated down the hall.

“Did you know that flamingos are pink because of what they eat?” Nicky asked, his enthusiasm practically vibrating through the walls.

“Oh yeah?” Rio replied, her voice warm. “What do they eat?”

“Shrimp!” Nicky declared, followed by a pause. “But not, like, the kind we eat with pasta. I think it’s tiny shrimp. Or maybe different shrimp? I’ll have to look it up.”

“The tiny shrimp are called Brine Shrimp,” answered Rio said.

Agatha rolled her eyes fondly, shaking her head as she continued down the hall. When she reached the bedroom doorway, she stopped short, hovering just outside the doorway, the plate and mug balanced in her hands.

She moved to enter but then Nicky’s voice had changed—softer, tinged with a sadness that tugged at her heart that her feet cementing in place.

“Rio,” he said, quieter now, almost hesitant.

Agatha froze, her ears straining as the silence stretched. She could sense the shift in the room, feel it in the heavy pause that followed.

“Yeah, buddy?” Rio finally replied, her voice gentle but cautious.

There was a faint rustling sound—someone shifting on the bed. Agatha imagined Nicky sitting up straighter, his small frame moving closer to Rio.

“If you’re gonna be part of this family,” Nicky began, his tone serious in a way that only a child’s honesty could be, “you have to be more careful. Mom... she doesn’t like it when the people she loves are hurt.”

Agatha’s breath hitched, her chest tightening as Nicky’s small voice carried through the doorway, raw and full of innocence. She didn’t need to see them to feel the weight of his words pressing down on the room.

“Dad says it makes her scared,” Nicky continued, his voice even quieter now, barely above a whisper. “Because I got really sick when I was three—and I almost died.”

Agatha gripped the plate and mug in her hands tightly, her knuckles whitening as a flood of emotions washed over her: love, fear, and a fierce, protective ache for her son. It was a part of her life she didn’t talk about often, even with herself.

But hearing Nicky say it out loud, hearing him explain her fears so simply, moved through her in ways she hadn’t expected.

The silence that followed felt like an eternity before Rio’s voice broke it, soft and steady.

“I didn’t know that,” Rio said gently, her voice tinged with something Agatha could only describe as shock. “That must’ve been so scary—for both of you.”

Nicky didn’t respond right away, but Agatha could imagine him nodding.

“I don’t remember a lot,” he said finally. “But I remember Mom was always with me. She wouldn’t leave me.”

There was a pause, then he added.

“She loves me like that. And I think she loves you like that too.”

Agatha stood frozen just outside the doorway, her breath catching as Nicky’s words reached her ears, soft but full of the earnestness only a child could muster.

“So, you have to make sure your shoes are tied,” he said, his small voice carrying an unexpected weight. “And you need to watch where you’re going, so you don’t fall and get hurt again.”

There was a pause, the kind that seemed to stretch time. Agatha could almost feel the wheels turning in his little head before he spoke again.

“We take care of Mom by taking care of ourselves,” Nicky said, his voice steady but so heartbreakingly wise for his age.

The words hit Agatha like a punch to the chest, her grip tightening on the plate and mug she held. Her knees threatened to buckle as she let out a shaky exhale, the lump in her throat nearly suffocating.

How could a five-year-old carry so much understanding?

So much awareness?

Inside the room, Rio’s voice broke the silence, soft but steady.

“You’re a smart kid, you know that?” she said, her tone filled with affection. “And you’re absolutely right.”

Nicky hummed in acknowledgment, and Agatha could hear the rustling again.

“Will you promise?” he asked, and his voice was quieter now, almost shy.

Rio didn’t hesitate.

“I promise to always take care of your mom,” she said, and her voice held a quiet sincerity that caused Agatha’s chest to tighten further.

Agatha couldn’t take anymore and finally stepped into the room, her steps feeling heavier as she forced herself to move past the emotional weight threatening to anchor her to the spot. She leaned lightly against the doorframe, clearing her throat just enough to announce her presence.

Both Nicky and Rio turned to look at her. Rio was still in bed, and Nicky was sitting next to her in the middle. Nicky’s face broke into a wide smile, while Rio’s expression softened.

“Breakfast delivery,” Agatha said, lifting the plate and mug as she walked in. Her voice was steady, but her emotions churned just beneath the surface. “What’s going on in here?”

“Just making sure Rio knows the rules,” Nicky answered.

Agatha raised an eyebrow, setting the plate and mug down on the nightstand next to Rio as she glanced between them.

“Oh, and what rules are those?” she feigned.

“That she has to tie her shoes and not fall anymore,” Nicky said, his tone so serious that Agatha couldn’t help the smile tugging at her lips.

Agatha casted a look at Rio who was looking at Agatha with a bemused smile, before coming back to Nicky.

“Well, those sound like very good rules to me,” Agatha said softly, brushing her fingers through Nicky’s hair as she crouched beside the bed, her voice straddling warmth and teasing. “Maybe we should get her some velcro shoes to make things easier for her. What do you think?”

She smirked as her gaze flicked to Rio, whose eyes immediately narrowed.

“Velcro shoes?” Rio repeated, her tone incredulous, though her lips twitched as though fighting a smile. “Do I look like I’m five?”

Agatha tilted her head, her smirk growing.

“Considering a five-year-old just gave you a lecture about responsibility,” she said giving Rio a pointed look that said play along, even though she could barely contain the smile on her face.

“Maybe it’s not a bad idea,” Agatha finished.

Nicky’s giggle filled the room, his face lighting up as he looked between them.

“Velcro shoes are cool, Rio,” he chimed in enthusiastically. “They are so easy! I have some! A couple of them even light up.”

He turned to Agatha, his eyes wide with excitement.

“Can we order some light-up velcro shoes for Rio?”

Agatha had to bite the inside of her cheek to keep from laughing outright. She shot a sidelong glance at Rio, who was watching the exchange with amusement that was now giving wake to horror.

“That sounds like a really good idea, sweetheart,” Agatha said, her voice perfectly serious as she carefully avoided Rio’s narrowed gaze. “We can check Amazon when you get back from school. Maybe even find matching pairs for you two.”

Nicky’s grin stretched impossibly wider as he practically bounced in place.

“Cool!”

“So, cool,” Agatha echoed, giving him a small nudge toward the door. “Now go grab your shoes and backpack. School’s waiting.”

Nicky stood up on the bed and jumped off with an excited yell before dashing out of the room as the sound of his little feet echoing down the hall.

Agatha let her smirk unfurl, tilting her head as she turned back to Rio.

Her eyes came to rest on narrowed dark eyes and a tight jaw, clearly unimpressed by the exchange.

“I promise,” Agatha said mockingly, her tone dripping with faux sincerity, “I’ll find you a really stylish pair.”

Rio’s eyes narrowed even further as she stared daggers at Agatha.

“ Agatha ,” she said, her voice low and warning.

The single word was laced with enough quiet menace to send a delicious shiver down Agatha’s spine. Her smirk only deepened as she stepped forward.

Rio shifted on the bed, moving to sit up straighter, her movements careful but determined.

“Ah, ah, ah,” Agatha tutted, her eyes narrowing in return as she placed her hand on Rio’s shoulder and putting gentle pressure to push her back down into the mattress

“Horizontal,” Agatha reminded firmly, leaning down to press a quick kiss to Rio’s lips.

Rio huffed against her mouth but returned the kiss, her annoyance melting just slightly.

When Agatha pulled back, Rio gave her a look that was equal parts frustration and affection as she sank back into the pillows.

“You’re insufferable,” she muttered, though the faintest smirk tugged at the corner of her lips.

Agatha straightened, her own smirk softening as she stepped toward the doorway.

“Rest up. I mean it. I’ll be back in an hour.”

Rio sighed but leaned back fully, surrendering to the inevitable. As Agatha moved to leave, Rio’s voice called out.

“You’re lucky I love you.”

Agatha froze for the briefest of moments, her heart doing a little flip before she turned back and sent Rio a playful wink.

“I know,” she said with a smirk, walking out the door with her heart feeling inexplicably lighter.

Agatha sat at her desk, her home office bathed in the golden glow of afternoon light filtering through the windows. Papers that Billy dropped off this morning were spread haphazardly across the surface, her desktop computer’s three monitors were glowing brightly, each competing for attention. Her phone buzzed incessantly next to her coffee cup, now cold after hours of neglect. And with no assistant to bring her a fresh cup, Agatha just powered through.

The day, which she had intended to spend quietly, had spiraled into chaos.

Of course, it would be the day clients decided their entire legal futures hinged on her immediate intervention. Despite the other partners stepping up and fielding most of the crises, there were still calls and emails that demanded her personal touch. Every time she thought she was done, her inbox or phone would ring with another urgent message.

Then there was the security firm.

Agatha had spent an hour on the phone with the head of their operations, letting loose a tirade that would probably go down in their record books. Her voice had been cold, measured, and deadly—every word a calculated reminder of their monumental failure. How a mugger had gotten close enough to Rio to even pull a gun was beyond unacceptable. Their excuse of “ trying not to impede on her life ” and “ maintaining a safe but distant watch ” had been laughable.

“That’s changing now,” Agatha had snapped, her voice razor-sharp. “From now on, I want someone glued to her side. A shadow. Someone who doesn’t even breathe without knowing where Rio is. And if I so much as suspect you’ve let your guard down again, I’ll make it my personal mission to see your entire firm buried in lawsuits.”

The head of security had tried to assure her that changes were already being implemented, but Agatha wasn’t convinced. The thought that this “ mugging ” might not have been random —that it could have been Vanguard making another calculated move, just like they had with Brooke Sinclair’s suicide—sent a chill down her spine.

The possibility was too real, too plausible to ignore.

Agatha exhaled sharply, leaning back in her chair as she pressed her fingers to her temples, willing the tension away. The clock on her desk caught her attention, and her eyes widened slightly as she realized just how much time had passed. Hours had slipped away since she’d last checked on Rio.

To her credit, Rio had actually listened to her. She’d stayed horizontal, following Agatha’s orders without much protest. The last time Agatha peeked in on her, Rio had moved from the bed to the couch, bundled under a blanket, her attention fixed on a documentary about black holes.

Agatha was just about to stand and check on Rio when her phone rang, the sharp tone slicing through her thoughts. She glanced down at the caller ID and let out a resigned sigh before picking up.

“Russell,” she greeted, her tone already carrying the sharp edge she reserved for her most demanding clients.

Russell Grossman was one of her oldest clients, a cantankerous millionaire who owned a chain of high-end real estate and hospitality businesses. His penchant for litigation over zoning laws, tenant disputes, and contract squabbles kept Agatha perpetually busy. He also had a maddening insistence on dealing only with her. If he weren’t such a consistent source of billable hours—and one of the firm’s most lucrative clients—Agatha would have happily dropped him years ago.

“Agatha,” Russell barked on the other end, his tone grating with impatience. “I need you to deal with these zoning commission idiots. They’re dragging their feet, and I don’t have time for their nonsense.”

Agatha opened her mouth to respond, but the door to her office creaked open. Her words died on her lips as she watched Rio stroll in, not even sparing her a glance. Instead, Rio made her way to the couch on the far end of the room and sprawled across it with the kind of ease that said she wasn’t going anywhere soon.

“Agatha!” Russell snapped in her ear, pulling her focus back to the phone.

She jumped slightly, casting a pointed glare at Rio, who looked thoroughly unbothered.

“Yes, Russell,” she said tightly, forcing her tone to remain professional. “I’m here.”

Russell launched into one of his signature tirades, his voice droning in her ear. Agatha barely registered his words as she muted the phone and turned her attention fully to Rio.

“What are you doing?” she asked, her voice low and sharp, her annoyance bubbling just below the surface.

Rio tilted her head lazily in Agatha’s direction, a smirk tugging at her lips.

“I’m bored,” she said simply, her voice languid. She gestured to her reclined body with an exaggerated flourish. “And look—I’m horizontal, just like you ordered.”

Agatha’s glare deepened, her lips thinning into a line. She stared at her for a moment, then sighed, shaking her head as she unmuted her phone.

“Russell,” she cut in, her tone clipped as her patience rapidly wore thin. “I’ve already sent the documentation to their legal team, and I have a follow-up call scheduled this afternoon. We’re ahead of schedule on this.”

Rio raised a brow at her from across the room, clearly entertained by the exchange.

Agatha shot her another look, but Rio just smirked, settling further into the couch as if daring her to react.

She exhaled sharply through her nose, her focus snapping back to Russell's tirade on the other end of the call.

“I’m pulling up the document now,” she said tightly, clicking through her email and opening the zoning report his assistant had sent.

The words on the screen blurred slightly as her headache throbbed at the edges of her mind, a clear warning sign of her caffeine deficiency. She grumbled under her breath, reaching for her glasses and sliding them on. Leaning forward, she scanned the opening paragraphs, her mind automatically shifting into work mode.

But then, out of the corner of her eye, she caught movement from the couch. Agatha’s gaze flicked sideways, and there Rio was, shifting slightly, her body languidly stretching as she adjusted her position. And then those eyes—dark, rich, and utterly captivating—locked onto her.

Agatha froze, her throat tightening as heat surged through her.

She recognized that look instantly.

The smoldering heat in Rio’s gaze pinned her in place, and for a moment, the room seemed to shrink around them.

And then Rio’s lips curved into a slow, deliberate smirk, her eyes dropping to Agatha’s face, lingering in a way that made Agatha’s pulse spike.

“You see what those bastards are claiming?” Russell’s voice roared in her ear, jolting her out of the trance.

Agatha blinked rapidly, tearing her gaze from Rio and glaring at the zoning document in front of her as though it had personally offended her.

“Yes,” she replied crisply, though her voice came out slightly uneven.

“I see exactly what they’re claiming, Russell. Let me...” She trailed off, adjusting her glasses and trying to focus, but the lingering heat from Rio’s gaze made her heart thud in an infuriatingly erratic rhythm.

Across the room, Rio’s smirk deepened, clearly enjoying every second of Agatha’s flustered state.

Agatha’s lips pressed into a thin line, her jaw tightening as she forced her attention back to the call.

Russell, oblivious to Agatha’s increasingly frazzled state, continued his tirade on the other end of the call.

“I want a comprehensive rebuttal, Agatha. Don’t hold back. These clowns think they can push me around, but they’re about to find out who they’re dealing with!”

“Yes, Russell,” Agatha said through gritted teeth, her focus fracturing as she caught movement from Rio again out of the corner of her eye.

Her gaze flicked toward the couch, her attention split between the zoning report and the casual sprawl of Rio’s body. But this time, Rio wasn’t looking at her. Her eyes were closed, her head tilted slightly back against the armrest. She looked almost peaceful—except Agatha’s breath caught as she noticed Rio’s hand.

Under the waistband of her shorts.

And moving.

Agatha’s grip on her phone tightened as her heart skipped violently. She nearly dropped the phone entirely, her knuckles going white around it. Heat flared across her skin, rushing up her neck and flooding her face as she froze in place.

What the actual—

“Are you listening to me, Agatha?” Russell’s booming voice shattered her thoughts like glass, and she blinked rapidly, yanking her eyes back to her computer screen.

“Y-yes, Russell,” she stammered, her voice catching in a way that made her wince. “I’m listening. I’ll handle it.”

Across the room, Rio remained completely unbothered, her movements slow and unhurried, as if she had all the time in the world as she touched herself.

Agatha’s stomach flipped, her mind racing between indignation, shock, and— goddammit — desire.

“Good!” Russell barked, thankfully oblivious. “I want those updates by three. Don’t let me down!”

“Of course,” Agatha replied, her voice higher than usual. “You know who I am, Russel.”

She ended the call with a hurried tap, tossing her phone onto the desk and glaring daggers at Rio.

“What the hell are you doing?” she hissed, her voice breaking.

Rio’s eyes opened lazily, and that smirk— damn that smirk —curved her lips as her hand continued moving.

“I’m staying horizontal,” she drawled, voice low and smug. “Just like you told me.”

Agatha’s nostrils flared, her entire body tensing as she stood rooted to the spot. She was caught between fury and a deep, primal hunger that she didn’t know whether to fight or surrender to. Her jaw clenched as her gaze flickered to Rio’s hand, still moving beneath the waistband of her shorts.

And then she heard it—a low, husky moan that escaped Rio’s lips, soft but devastating.

“You’re supposed to be resting ,” Agatha snapped, her voice rough, betraying her with the unmistakable growl beneath it.

Rio’s smirk widened, her tongue working against the side of her cheek. The deliberate motion sent a bolt of heat straight through Agatha, who tightened her grip on the edge of her desk as though it could keep her from launching across the room.

“I have been resting,” Rio purred, her voice dripping with defiance and seduction. “All. Day.”

Her words hung in the air, charged with a teasing edge that made Agatha’s pulse roar in her ears.

“I’ve been a good girl, haven’t I, Agatha?” Rio’s breath hitched slightly as her hips arched upward, just enough to make Agatha’s gaze zero in. “Don’t you think I deserve a reward?”

“Rio,” she growled, her tone low with warning.

“Yes, my love?” she murmured, her words deliberately innocent, but her actions anything but.

The bruise blooming across her forehead.

The bandage on her arm peeking out from her t-shirt.

The memory of how fucking close she came to losing her.

Rio opened her eyes and caught the expression, rolling her own in exasperation.

“You’re too damn good at that,” she muttered, though there was no mistaking the warmth in her tone.

“You taught me well,” she replied, her voice low and teasing.

Rio let out a soft laugh, her head tilting back against the couch cushions.

“Too well,” she said, before turning her gaze back to Agatha. Her eyes gleamed as a playful smirk curved her lips. “Now come here.”

Agatha paused, her confidence faltering for a moment. It was one thing for her to take the lead, to pour all her focus into Rio’s pleasure—but the thought of Rio returning the favor, especially now, had her hesitating. She glanced at Rio’s injured arm, the tension creeping into her shoulders.

Rio’s eyes narrowed slightly, seeing straight through her. She stared at Agatha for a long moment, her gaze sharp and knowing, before the corner of her mouth tugged into an amused smirk.

Because, god— she fucking loved this woman.

Don't Steal Her Struggle

Agatha jolted upright in bed, her breath ragged and her heart pounding against her ribs. Her mind raced as the realization hit her like a freight train—the cameras.

The cameras in her office.

The ones that had definitely caught her and Rio fucking on her couch.

Beside her, Rio stirred, her hand instinctively reaching for Agatha.

“What is it?” she murmured, her voice low and rough with sleep.

Agatha's fingers pressed against her rapidly beating heart, her voice a shaky whisper.

“The cameras... in my office...”

Rio let out a heavy sigh, pulling herself closer to Agatha. Without opening her eyes, she slid an arm around Agatha's waist and tugged her back down against the pillows.

“Relax,” she muttered into Agatha’s neck, her breath warm against her skin. “I texted Sam. She wiped the footage.”

Agatha’s heart was still racing, but her mind struggled to catch up with the calm certainty in Rio’s tone. The panic, sharp and clawing, refused to let go. Her thoughts spiraled, picturing every humiliating frame of what might have been captured—most notably, the moment when she’d ridden Rio’s face like a championship bull rider, clinging on for dear life and determined to last more than eight seconds.

Agatha let Rio's words settle over her, soothing her nerves just enough for her breathing to steady. But her mind latched onto something she couldn’t let go of. Her brows furrowed as she finally voiced the question clawing at the edge of her thoughts.

“Who the fuck is Sam?”

Rio groaned into her neck, a low, sleep-heavy murmur of frustration.

“Of course you had to wait until 3 AM to have this conversation,” she grumbled, tightening her hold on Agatha as she adjusted her head against the pillow, clearly trying to drift back to sleep. “Sam’s the security agent on my detail. The one always standing outside my office and following me around like a shadow.”

That was all Rio said, like it was the most ordinary thing in the world. But for Agatha, sleep was now a distant dream. Her mind—razor-sharp even in the dead of night, a trait that made her an exceptional lawyer—kicked into overdrive. She conjured the image of the woman, piecing together every detail like solving a puzzle.

Agatha didn’t like categorizing people—she found it reductive, lazy. But as the vivid memory of Sam sharpened in her mind, there was one label her brain had slapped on the woman immediately: gay .

Short-cropped hair with that was perfectly tousled with a the messy look. A tattoo of a flower creeping up her neck, just barely hidden by the high collar of her suit. Numerous piercings sparkling in her ears. And beneath the professional attire, the unmistakable build of someone strong—probably ex-military.

Sam radiated an aura of danger, like someone who could kill you and then look good doing it.

At the time, Agatha had focused on the dangerous part, appreciating that Rio had someone so clearly capable of protecting her.

But now?

All she could think about was the gay part.

And the fact that Rio had her number and they texted.

Agatha’s stomach churned.

“Do you text often...” she began cautiously, trying to keep her voice nonchalant.

Rio huffed, as if sensing the direction Agatha’s thoughts were heading.

“Relax,” she mumbled, her lips brushing lazily against Agatha’s neck. “She keeps me safe. That’s it. She’s not my type.”

Agatha’s heart pounded, a restless drumbeat she couldn’t ignore as she pressed her lips into a tight line, trying—and failing—to maintain a semblance of composure.

Safe?

That was debatable.

Sam had obviously failed in that department. The jagged line of 12 stitches running across Rio’s brow, and the bullet graze on her shoulder was evidence enough of that.

But fine. She let that part go.

What she couldn’t let go was something else entirely.

“And what is your type, exactly?” Agatha asked, her tone sharp but betraying a flicker of vulnerability.

Gods .

She could feel Rio smile against the skin of her neck, the curve of her lips warm and teasing as her arms tightened around her waist.

Rio’s voice was low, rough with sleep, and impossibly smug as she grumbled.

“Uptight lawyers who wake me up at three in the morning to interrogate me about women who delete security footage... of her riding my face.”

Agatha groaned, burying her face in her hands as her cheeks flushed, a mix of exasperation and embarrassment making her want to throttle—and kiss—Rio all at once.

“I hate you,” she muttered, her voice muffled.

“No you don’t,” Rio countered, the grin evident in her voice as she pulled Agatha closer. “Now, go to sleep, cowgirl. You have a trial to win tomorrow.”

Agatha exhaled, the panic about the cameras and Rio texting other women beginning to quiet in her mind. But in the silence left behind, another storm stirred—the ever-present buzz of her work brain.

The Vanguard trial.

It started tomorrow.

Agatha’s jaw clenched as the weight of it settled over her like a familiar blanket—but this one suffocated, heavy with far more than legal briefs and courtroom strategy. This wasn’t just another case. It wasn’t even just the biggest case of her career.

This was personal.

They had come for her.

For Nicky.

For Rio.

The security firm couldn’t confirm the mugging was connected to Vanguard, but Agatha knew . It was the kind of deep, marrow-deep certainty she couldn’t explain, but couldn’t

deny. They tried to kill Rio.

This trial wasn’t just a trial.

It was war.

Life and death, balanced on the edge of every argument she’d make tomorrow.

Her mind flashed to Brooke Sinclair.

Dead.

Murdered.

Another casualty in Vanguard’s long, bloodstained history. Brooke didn’t get justice in life, and now the burden of delivering it in death rested squarely on Agatha’s shoulders.

She was the only one left who could hold them accountable. The only one standing between Vanguard and the countless others they’d destroy if they weren’t stopped.

Behind her, Rio’s arm tightened around her waist, her breath steady and warm against Agatha’s neck.

She was alive—thank the gods, alive—despite Vanguard’s attempt to change that.

Agatha closed her eyes, her hand covering Rio’s where it rested against her stomach.

The trial wasn’t just about justice.

It was about making sure Rio stayed alive.

Making sure no one else had to pay the price Brooke had.

Tomorrow wasn’t just about winning.

It was about survival.

The morning passed in a blur.

Agatha had allowed Rio to be vertical for the day—begrudgingly. Which meant Agatha and Nicky were treated to omelets. Nicky, thrilled to see Rio up and moving, had been in high spirits, happily chatting away between bites. It was a good morning for him, which meant he actually listened to Agatha, leaving on time with his security detail for school.

That left Agatha alone in the kitchen, sipping her coffee with a blessed ten minutes of quiet. She used the time to review her opening statement, the words etched into her brain as she silently recited them, ensuring every phrase landed with the precision she needed.

The sound of approaching footsteps pulled her from her thoughts.

Agatha glanced up—and her heart lurched in her chest.

Rio was walking down the hallway, strapping a black leather watch onto her wrist. She was wearing black loafers paired with a tailored light gray suit, cinched at the waist with a sleek black belt. A high-necked black turtleneck hugged her torso, accentuating her lean frame, while her hair cascaded down in soft, effortless waves. Even with makeup just barely concealing the bruises—dark, angry shadows blooming across her temple—Rio looked devastatingly good.

Too fucking good.

It took Agatha a moment to process the sight, her mind struggling to reconcile the bruised and battered woman she’d insisted rest with this polished version striding down the hallway.

And then it hit her like a kick to the chest—Rio looked like she was going to work.

Which was insane.

Agatha set her coffee down narrowing her eyes. She kept her voice measured and calm, though an edge of warning laced her words.

“Why are you dressed like you’re going to the office?”

Rio finished fastening her watch, the strap clicking neatly into place before she looked up. Her expression was cool, casual—completely unbothered.

“Because I am,” she said simply, as though it were the most obvious thing in the world.

Agatha blinked, stunned by the sheer audacity. The disbelief quickly gave way to anger, sharp and immediate.

“Like hell you are,” she snapped, her voice slicing through the calm of the morning.

Neither moved.

Neither blinked.

The air between them felt like a taut wire, ready to snap.

And then her voice came out sharp, unwavering.

“You are not going to work,” she said, enunciating each word with measured force. “You were just shot at, for Christ’s sake! You have twelve stitches in your head and another fifteen in your arm. You are not leaving this house.”

That one landed.

She always did.

Not anger, not frustration, but raw, unguarded hurt.

She had caused that.

“You don’t get to do that, Agatha,” Rio finally said, her voice low but sharp, each word slicing through Agatha like a knife. “You don’t get to use our relationship as blackmail to get me to do what you want. You don’t get to twist what we have into another weapon in your arsenal.”

Her hands trembled at her sides, and she reached behind her to clutch at the counter behind her, desperate for something solid to hold onto, something to ground her.

“Rio...” she started, her voice cracking, but the words faltered and died in her throat.

Maybe you don’t love me like I thought you did.

The sentence echoed in Agatha's mind, reverberating with a cruel, relentless clarity. Her heart gave a sharp, painful twist, and she felt tears prick at the corners of her eyes.

Of course I love you.

That is what she wanted to say.

She wanted to scream it, to grab Rio by the shoulders and make her understand.

But the words wouldn’t come, and the silence that stretched between them felt damning.

“Don’t say that,” Agatha finally managed, her voice barely above a whisper, shaky and broken. “You know that’s not true.”
