“Then say it,” Rio said quietly, her voice trembling just enough to betray the depth of her emotions.

Agatha’s breath caught in her throat. Her mouth opened, but the words refused to come out. They sat there, heavy and jagged, caught on the edge of her pride, her fear, her own maddening inability to be vulnerable in the way Rio needed her to be.

“I—” she started, but the sound faltered, thin and brittle.

Rio’s shoulders sagged just slightly, a flicker of defeat crossing her face.

Still she waited, giving her the space to speak—to say it.

Agatha’s chest heaved as her heart raced, her pulse thundering in her ears.

She wanted to say it.

She needed to say it.

But the fear, the walls she had spent a lifetime building, wouldn’t let her.

“Rio...” Agatha’s voice cracked, her hands trembling at her sides.

Rio let out a slow, steady exhale, her expression closing off as though she had finally accepted the answer Agatha couldn’t give. She took another step back, and Agatha’s heart snapped inside her chest.

“Right,” Rio said softly, her voice breaking just slightly before she masked. “I’m going to work.”

She turned her back to Agatha and walked away.

She made it about five steps, before pausing at the edge of the hallway, her shoulders stiff as if she were holding the weight of the moment in place.

Agatha’s breath caught in her throat, her chest tight with the desperate hope that Rio might turn around, might look at her, might give her just one more chance to fix this.

But Rio didn’t look back.

“I know you will be worried so I will text you when I get there,” Rio said, her voice flat, hollow, a shell of its usual warmth. “Good luck at your trial.”

And then she walked into the hallway, leaving Agatha’s line of sight.

Agatha couldn’t move.

She stood frozen in place, her body rigid, her mind screaming at her to do something, to call out, to stop Rio from leaving. But she stayed rooted where she was, unable to tear herself free from the weight pressing down on her.

She listened instead, every sound amplified to an unbearable degree. The muffled shuffle of Rio’s footsteps on the hardwood floor. The sharp creak of the closet door opening. The rustling of fabric as Rio pulled on her coat. Each sound hit like a drumbeat, so fucking loud , as if the world itself was conspiring to force Agatha into action.

But she didn’t move.

The metallic clink of keys being lifted from the bowl on the table cut through the silence, followed by the faint jingle as Rio carried them to the door. Then came the soft click of the lock turning, the faint creak of the door hinges as it swung open.

And then Rio’s voice, low and unsteady but so goddamn loud it seemed to fill every corner of Agatha’s home.

“I love you, Agatha,” she murmured, the words carrying a weight that made Agatha’s chest ache.

She said it.

The words Agatha couldn’t.

And they now hung in the air, lingering and heavy.

And then the door closed with a soft but final click, sealing Agatha inside with her regret and Rio’s love.

The house was quiet again, so quiet it felt oppressive. Agatha’s legs trembled, but she couldn’t make herself move. She stood there, staring at the empty space where Rio had just been, her mind racing and her heart pounding as her emotions clawed at her from the inside out.

She just wanted to protect Rio.

But now, as she stood there alone, and felt the first fall of tears, she couldn’t help but realize the only thing she had succeeded in protecting was the walls she had built to keep her fear inside—and Rio out.

The fight with Rio replayed in Agatha’s mind on an endless, punishing loop. Every word she’d said, every defensive step she’d taken, every sharp retort and unspoken plea from Rio —she could see it all as clearly as if it were still happening. Her chest ached, a gnawing emptiness settling deep inside her, and she cursed herself for how fucking stupid she had been.

Why couldn’t she just say it?

Why couldn’t she tell Rio how much she loved her?

She knew the answer, of course.

It wasn’t about Rio, not really.

It was about her.

The tangled mess of her own trauma, the years spent convincing herself that vulnerability was a weakness, that love was a risk she couldn’t afford to take. It was the need to protect herself, the overwhelming certainty that she didn’t deserve what Rio gave her.

And the fear—that sick, twisted fear—that the moment she said it out loud, everything would fall apart.

God .

She needed to see her therapist.

She needed to figure out what the hell was wrong with her.

And more than anything, she needed to fix what she had broken.

She needed Rio.

"Ms. Harkness, are you ready?"

The words barely registered, faint and distant in the fog of her thoughts.

Then came a sharp jab to her ribs, startling her out of her spiral. Agatha snapped her head to the right to see Lilia, staring at her with wide eyes and a look that screamed what the fuck are you doing?

"Ms. Harkness, are you ready?" repeated Judge Marks, his tone clipped and impatient, the frustration of having to repeat himself evident in every syllable.

Agatha’s gaze shifted forward, and her body stilled as the gravity of the moment hit her.

Fuck.

She was in court.

Her surroundings came into focus—the heavy oak bench, the jury watching her with silent curiosity, the courtroom buzzing faintly.

She swallowed hard, forcing herself to take a breath. She needed to get out of her head and be present. She couldn’t afford to let her personal life bleed into this, not here, not now.

Agatha inhaled deeply, straightened her shoulders, and forced her voice into steadiness. “Yes, Your Honor,” she said, her tone calm, collected, even as her chest still ached with everything she hadn’t said.

And then, she stood, smoothing her hands over her suit, and stepped forward. Whatever personal turmoil she was drowning in would have to wait. Right now, she needed to be the person everyone else thought she was: unflappable, precise, and always in control.

Even if she felt like she was falling apart.

Agatha straightened her jacket as she stepped to the center of the courtroom, her heels clicking softly against the floor. She inhaled deeply, pushing down the storm of emotions swirling inside her. She could feel Brooke Sinclair’s parents in the front row, their grief a tangible presence that made her chest tighten.

She couldn’t fail them.

Not now.

She cleared her throat, her voice steady as she began, the words she had practiced for a week burning into her mind like a script she had memorized down to the punctuation.

“Ladies and gentlemen of the jury,” Agatha started, her tone calm and commanding. “The case I will present against Vanguard is simple. They are responsible for the death of a young woman who had the courage to stand up for what was right. Brooke Sinclair.”

She gestured toward the front row, where Brooke’s parents sat. Her voice softened slightly as she spoke.

“Brooke was raised in a small community in Ohio by two incredible people who taught her to always stand up for what was right, even in a world that so often turns a blind eye.”

Her gaze lingered on Brooke’s parents, their tearful eyes locked on her.

“She did that. She stood up. And it cost her everything. It cost her—her life.”

Agatha’s voice tightened, and she paused for a beat, the weight of her words hanging in the air. She could feel the eyes of the courtroom on her, the quiet tension as everyone waited for her to continue.

“Vanguard must be held accountable,” she said, her voice firm but beginning to waver as her thoughts flickered, unbidden, to Rio.

What about you, Agatha? What are you accountable for?

The question stabbed at her, sharp and unrelenting.

It wasn’t Brooke’s case that filled her chest with guilt and regret in that moment—it was Rio.

What she had said to her.

What she hadn’t said to her.

Her practiced words faltered, the speech she had designed to be powerful slipping away like sand through her fingers. Instead, something else rose to the surface. Something unfiltered, and painfully honest.

She took a step closer to the jury box, her hands gripping the lectern, her eyes scanning the room, though her mind felt a million miles away.

“Brooke Sinclair was brave,” Agatha said, her voice quieter now but no less steady. “She knew the risks. She knew that standing up for what she believed in might cost her everything. And yet, she did it anyway. Because she believed in truth. She believed in justice. And she believed that doing what was right mattered more than fear.”

Her voice trembled slightly, but she pushed through, the words tumbling out as though they had been waiting to escape.

“Fear...fear can be paralyzing. It can make you lash out, make you say things you don’t mean, make you hesitate when you should act.”

She paused, exhaling slowly as her gaze dropped for a moment before lifting again.

“But fear doesn’t excuse us. It doesn’t absolve us of responsibility. We are all accountable for the choices we make—even when we’re afraid. Especially when we’re afraid. ”

Her throat tightened as she thought of Rio, of the look on her face when Agatha said the words she couldn’t take back. She swallowed hard, forcing herself to focus, to tie it back to the case.

“Vanguard’s fear of exposure, their fear of losing power— of money —that drove them to make decisions that cost Brooke Sinclair her life,” Agatha said, her voice gaining strength again. “And now, they must face the consequences of those decisions. Because accountability isn’t optional. Not for them. Not for any of us.”

She stepped back slightly, her eyes scanning the jury, her chest heaving with the effort of keeping her composure.

“Justice is not about perfection. It’s about doing what’s right, even when it’s hard. Even when it hurts. That is what this case is about. That is what Brooke stood for.”

She looked back toward Brooke’s parents, her voice softening as she addressed the jury one final time.

“And that is why we must hold Vanguard accountable. Not just for Brooke. But for everyone who deserves to live in a world where doing what’s right doesn’t cost you your life.”

She stepped back, her chest heaving as she finished, her heart pounding in a way that had nothing to do with the trial and everything to do with Rio.

The words she had spoken weren’t just for the jury.

They were also for her.

A promise to herself to fix what she had broken, to take responsibility, to be better.

And as she returned to her seat, she knew that when this trial ended, her real fight—the one for Rio—was only just beginning.

Chapter End Notes

That fight was so brutal for me to write. Poor Agatha. Poor Rio. Here is to hoping Agatha pulls her head of her ass by the next chapter.

If I Can't Reach You

Chapter Notes

Prefacing this chapter to say once again, I am not a lawyer. The only thing I know about the law is what I see on the TV while watching The Good Wife and Suits lol

Second, this is a long ass chapter. 11,000 words. God damn. It was pretty much written, just needed the ending to wrap up. So that is why the turn around time was quicker. Which was honestly nice, because I felt bad leaving you guys hanging after the last chapter.

Third, I had to add...another chapter because I didn't get to some stuff I needed to in his chapter. So now we are up to 33.

Lastly, enjoy!

The trial had started just as Agatha anticipated—Fox and Ratcliff were a well-oiled machine, and they’d started strong. The defense paraded their high-profile witnesses, corporate heavyweights who spoke about Vanguard’s contributions to national security and humanitarian causes. On paper, Vanguard looked like a beacon of corporate responsibility.

Agatha had known she wouldn’t win against those witnesses. They were polished, untouchable. She couldn’t poke holes in their testimony because, frankly, it wasn’t the time. She needed to bide her time, to wait for the moment when she could peel back surface and and expose the rot beneath.

And that moment had come with Brandon Vanguard, the company’s Vice President and namesake.

The courtroom had been buzzing when she called him to the stand, expecting another corporate heavy weight that would only lend to Vanguards great reputation.

However, Agatha knew better.

Brandon was an Achilles’ heel disguised as an asset, and she was about to slice right through Vanguards tendon and send the companies case staggering.

She’d started slowly, building the foundation.

“Mr. Vanguard,” she had begun, her tone calm, “how would you describe your role in the company?”

His answers were predictable, rehearsed. He talked about overseeing operations, maintaining relationships with key partners, and ironically —ensuring the company’s integrity.

Agatha had let him talk.

She let him feel comfortable.

Then she turned up the heat.

“You’ve been arrested twice for DUIs and have one documented possession charge for cocaine,” Agatha said, her tone purposely sharper. “Would you say those incidents reflect the integrity you’ve mentioned?”

Unsprisingly, Fox sprang to her feet.

“Objection, Your Honor. Relevance.”

Agatha resisted the urge to roll her eyes, her control slipping just for a fraction of a second before she caught the steady gaze of Judge Marks over his glasses. His expression was neutral, but she knew better than to test his patience.

“Ms. Harkness,” Judge Marks said, his tone dripping with warning, “you’d better have a good reason for this.”

Agatha masked her features with a practiced calm, turning to face the bench.

“Your Honor, it’s relevant to establish a pattern of recklessness that extends beyond personal behavior,” she explained. “It speaks to his judgment as a leader within Vanguard.”

Her argument was clear and undeniably valid, but she knew it wouldn’t stop Fox from pushing back.

As expected, Fox immediately asked to approach the bench.

The sidebar was tense.

Fox argued passionately defending Brandon and, by extension, Vanguard’s reputation. After all, his last name was the company’s name—a cornerstone of its brand. Allowing Agatha to tie him to any impropriety was dangerous.

Agatha, in contrast, countered with practiced precision, dismantling each of Fox’s points with her usual cutting but methodical approach.

Judge Marks finally raised a hand, silencing them both. He glanced between the two attorneys, his lips pressing into a thin line.

And then his gaze settled on Agatha.

That was all it took.

One look, and she knew she had won.

So did Fox, whose loud puff of frustration that was impossible to miss as she stalked back to her table.

“Answer the question, Mr. Vanguard,” Judge Marks said.

Agatha didn’t suppress her smirk as she turned on her heel, heading back toward the center of the courtroom. Just for show—and because she couldn’t resist tweaking Fox and Ratcliff— she shot them a quick, mocking wink.

She didn’t need to see Fox’s reaction to know it landed.

Turning her attention back to Brandon Vanguard, she tilted her head slightly, her smile faint but predatory, like a cat toying with a bird with a broken wing.

“Do you need me to repeat the question, Mr. Vanguard?” she asked, her voice deceptively sweet.

Her lips ticked upward just a fraction, amusement flickering in her eyes as she watched him shift uncomfortably.

The jury was watching.

The gallery was watching.

Everyone in the courtroom was waiting for Brandon’s response and Agatha was going to make sure they remembered every second of this moment.

“I’ve made some mistakes in my past,” Brandon began, his voice humble, his eyes scanning the jurors as though addressing each one personally. “But those mistakes don’t define me, and they don’t define the work we do at Vanguard. I’ve grown, I’ve learned, and I’m proud of the strides I’ve made, both personally and professionally.”

Agatha didn’t bother hiding the pointed glance she sent Fox’s way.

Fox was perched in her seat smiling like a proud parent, clearly pleased to see her rehearsed damage control coming to life on the stand.

Agatha let out a slow breath and stepped forward towards Brandon.

“Would you agree,” she began, her tone measured—careful, “that these incidents reflect poor judgment?”

Brandon’s smile faltered, the confidence in his voice wavering slightly.

“I’ve already acknowledged that those were mistakes,” he replied, his tone still polished but not as sure as before. “Mistakes I deeply regret.”

Agatha nodded, tilting her head as if she were about to let it slide. Then, she pivoted, her voice sharpening just enough to turn the room’s attention back to her.

“And would you agree,” she said, her words deliberate, “that these incidents also suggest a pattern of recklessness?”

The creak of Fox’s chair as she stood was almost as loud as her sharp.

“Objection, Your Honor! Counsel is badgering the witness,” Fox responded, her voice clipped, “and attempting to smear his character without establishing relevance to the case.”

Agatha didn’t even flinch at her objection—she expected it.

“Your Honor,” she argued back fighting to keep her tone calm, “the witness’s pattern of behavior is directly relevant to this case. It speaks to his judgment and leadership, both of which are central to the actions of Vanguard and the events that led to Brooke Sinclair’s death.”

Judge Marks leaned back slightly, his lips pressing into a thin line as he considered the argument. His gaze flickered to Brandon, who was clearly growing more uncomfortable by the second, before settling back on Fox and then Agatha.

“I’ll allow it,” Judge Marks said finally. “But tread carefully, Ms. Harkness.”

Agatha inclined her head in acknowledgment.

“Of course, Your Honor.”

She turned back to Brandon, her gaze locking onto his.

“Mr. Vanguard,” she said, her voice steady, “let’s clarify. Would you agree that a leader’s decisions and personal behavior set the tone for the organization they lead?”

Brandon’s Adam’s apple bobbed as he swallowed.

“Yes,” he said slowly, carefully.

“And would you agree,” Agatha continued, her tone hardening just slightly, “that a pattern of recklessness—whether personal or professional—can have consequences for the people who depend on that leader?”

Brandon hesitated, his hands gripping the sides of the witness stand.

“I... I suppose so,” he admitted, his earlier confidence now visibly waning.

Agatha let the silence hang for a moment, the tension in the room palpable. Then she stepped closer, her voice soft but cutting.

“Mr. Vanguard, let’s move on to your role at the company. As Vice President, you’ve signed off on numerous financial reports, correct?”

“Yes,” Brandon said, his tone careful now.

Agatha returned to her desk, picking up the folder of documents Rio had prepared.

“Specifically, this series of expense reports,” she said, holding them up for the court to see before sliding one to Brandon for him to look at it. “These reports total millions of dollars over three years. Each one bears your signature, and yet the payments cannot be tied to any known accounts at your company or its affiliates. Can you explain that?”

Brandon shifted in his seat.

“I—uh, I don’t typically handle accounting,” he said. “That’s usually managed by department heads. I must have signed off without—”

“Without knowing where millions of dollars were going?” Agatha interrupted, her tone incredulous.

“I—”

“Do you typically sign off on payments, Mr. Vanguard?”

“No,” he admitted, looking distinctly uncomfortable now.

Agatha tilted her head, her expression a mixture of feigned confusion and disbelief.

“Then please explain,” she said, stepping closer to the jury as she held up the stack of documents for them to see, “why your signature is on this same invoice account, every two weeks, for three years. Are you seriously telling this court you don’t know where this money is going?”

Brandon’s face reddened, his gaze darting toward Fox.

Agatha noticed immediately and pounced.

“Eyes on me, Mr. Vanguard,” she said sharply, her voice cutting through the tension as Brandon’s eyes shot to her—as did every other person's eye in the courtroom. “Why are you looking at your counsel? Do you think they have the answers? Are you not the Vice President of this company? Why don’t you have the answers?”

“I—I don’t know,” Brandon stammered, his composure starting to unravel under the weight of Agatha’s relentless questioning.

Agatha’s eyes narrowed, seeing the cracks starting to form. She leaned forward slightly, her voice sharp and precise, each word landing like a hammer to those cracks.

“Would you like to add perjury to your already extensive criminal history, Mr. Vanguard?”

“Objection!” Fox’s voice cut through the courtroom as she snapped top her feet, her face flushed with barely contained anger. “Counsel is badgering the witness and making inflammatory statements. Move to strike!”

Judge Marks raised his hand to silence her, and his expression turned stern as he looked at Agatha.

“Ms. Harkness, watch yourself. This is a court of law, not a theater. The objection is sustained, and the jury will disregard that last statement.”

Agatha stepped back slightly, raising her hands in a gesture of mock surrender.

“Of course, Your Honor. My apologies.”

The judge’s eyes narrowed further.

“Be careful, Ms. Harkness. You’re already treading on thin ice.”

Agatha nodded at that but thin ice is where she thrived and this exactly where she wanted to be.

She turned back to the jury, and could feel the tension in the room, the way the jurors leaned forward, their attention fully captured. She knew that Brandon’s hesitation, his inability to answer, was already far more damning than anything she could say outright.

She walked deliberately to the witness stand, placing the folder in front of him with a quiet thud, its contents splayed open to reveal stacks of documents bearing his signature.

“Mr. Vanguard,” she began, her tone calm but deliberate, gesturing toward the folder. “These payments—totaling,” she paused for effect, tapping her chin as if calculating, though the number was burned into her mind, “three hundred sixty-one million dollars over three years —bear your signature every two weeks. Are you seriously telling this court you have no idea where this money went or what it was for?”

Brandon swallowed hard, the movement visible in the tightness of his throat. His jaw clenched as he shifted uncomfortably in his seat.

“I—I don’t recall,” he said finally, his voice uneven, barely audible over the hush of the courtroom.

Agatha arched an eyebrow, her skepticism practically dripping off her expression. She tilted her head slightly as if studying him, the pause amplifying the weight of his answer.

“You don’t recall signing off on millions of dollars? Or you don’t recall where the money went? Or what it was used for?”

Her voice rose slightly as she leaned closer.

“What exactly don’t you recall, Mr. Vanguard?”

“All of it,” Brandon muttered, his voice cracking.

“All of it?” she repeated, her tone incredulous, turning the phrase into a weapon. She stepped closer, lowering her voice just enough to force the jury to lean in. “Or are you just saying that

because you know the truth would be even worse?”

“Objection!” Fox barked, practically leaping to her feet.

“Withdrawn,” Agatha said quickly, raising her hands in a gesture of surrender before Judge Marks could admonish her.

She cast a glance at Judge Marks, whose glare told her she was nearing his limit, and nodded with a brief, apologetic smile. But the faint curve of satisfaction at the corner of her mouth betrayed her real feelings.

Turning slightly, she let her gaze sweep over the jury.

She didn’t need to say another word.

Their faces told her everything.

The seed of doubt was already blooming.

Brandon’s polished facade was cracking, and the jury was beginning to see him for what he was.

Agatha’s voice softened as she grabbed the documents from in front of them and held them in her hands.

“Final question, Mr. Vanguard. And I want to take you back to my earlier question. Now that we’ve established you authorized the transfer of three hundred sixty-one million dollars to an unknown entity, would you agree that this behavior aligns with what we could call a pattern of recklessness?”

Brandon opened his mouth, but the words that came out were garbled, a disjointed mess.

“I—I mean, no—you see—”

Agatha let him flounder for a moment before offering him a placating smile that barely masked her disdain.

“Question withdrawn,” she said smoothly, giving him an out while simultaneously underscoring his incompetence.

The damage was already done.

As she turned back to her table, she allowed herself a brief glance at Fox, whose tight-lipped expression spoke volumes.

Fox knew it too.

And Agatha knew she was finally on the board.

“No further questions, Your Honor,” Agatha said, her tone final as she walked back to her seat.

Fox— of course , wasted no time, standing immediately for redirect.

She clawed back what she could, framing Brandon as a high-level executive inundated with documents, signing hundreds of reports daily for a company worth ten billion dollars. She argued that three hundred sixty-one million, while significant, wasn’t unusual in the scale of their operations. She added that Vanguard’s nature as a government contractor meant security clearances could restrict even the VP from knowing certain details. The money might not appear in standard accounts because it was tied to classified work.

Agatha frowned as she listened.

Fox was good—very good.

She knew how to spin the narrative and patch the holes. But as Agatha watched the jury, she could see it.

The doubt till lingered.

It was subtle, but it was there, and that was all she needed.

Doubt was her opening, and she would widen it even further tomorrow.

Finally, Fox returned to her table, shooting Agatha a look that was equal parts frustration and warning.

Judge Marks nodded curtly.

“The witness is excused.”

Brandon stepped down stiffly, his once-confident swagger replaced with rigid movements. The charm he’d exuded earlier was nowhere to be found.

Agatha watched him retreat, a faint smile playing on her lips.

Judge Marks adjusted his glasses, his expression unreadable as he surveyed the courtroom. With a quick glance at the time, he rapped his gavel once.

“We’ll reconvene tomorrow at 9 a.m.,” he announced, his tone final. “Court is adjourned.”

The courtroom buzzed to life almost immediately. Lawyers shuffled papers, the jury began filing out, and the spectators broke into quiet conversations. Agatha exhaled a controlled breath, straightening her posture as she gathered her notes into a neat stack.

Beside her, Lilia was already packing up the case files.

“Well,” Lilia muttered under her breath, glancing at Agatha, “that was... something.”

Agatha smirked faintly but didn’t reply. She slid her folder into her briefcase, snapping it shut before nodding toward the door. Together, they rose from their seats, stepping into the steady stream of people filtering out of the courtroom.

Before heading into the hallway, Agatha made her way over to Brooke Sinclair’s parents, who had been sitting quietly in the first row throughout the trial. Brooke’s mother stood as Agatha approached, her eyes glassy with unshed tears.

“Mr. and Mrs. Sinclair,” Agatha said, her tone soft but steady. “I’m happy with how today went. We made progress, and tomorrow we’ll push even harder.”

Mrs. Sinclair nodded, her lips trembling as she reached out to squeeze Agatha’s arm.

“Thank you,” she whispered. “For fighting for Brooke. For giving her a voice.”

Agatha’s throat tightened, but she managed a faint smile.

“We’re not done yet. Rest tonight—we’ll keep fighting tomorrow.”

The Sinclairs exchanged a grateful glance before Mrs. Sinclair said,

“We’re heading back to the hotel for the night. But we’ll be here first thing in the morning.”

Agatha nodded.

“Take care of yourselves. I’ll see you tomorrow.”

With a final squeeze of her arm, they left, their steps slow and heavy as they disappeared into the crowd.

The corridor was crowded, a mass of lawyers, reporters, and onlookers bustling about. Agatha and Lilia maneuvered their way through the throng. The hum of conversations surrounded them, snippets of whispered speculation about the trial and Brandon’s testimony.

“Agatha,” Lilia said, her voice low and laced with amusement as they maneuvered through the bustling corridor, “I had forgotten how absolutely entertaining it is to watch you in court.”

Agatha smirked, the compliment pulling her momentarily from her thoughts.

“Entertaining, huh?”

Lilia chuckled, shaking her head.

“Oh, don’t be modest. You know exactly what you’re doing in there. Watching you dismantle Brandon Vanguard piece by piece? That was art.”

Agatha’s smirk widened slightly as the memory surfaced, but it wasn’t just the thrill of today’s performance that lingered. It was the history between them, the way their paths had first crossed.

Over a decade ago, they had been on opposite sides of the courtroom—a true David versus Goliath matchup. Lilia had been Goliath, leading a powerhouse firm with resources Agatha couldn’t dream of at the time. But David—Agatha—had come out on top, not only winning the case but also earning Lilia’s respect.

That victory had led to the most surprising turn of her career. Lilia offering her a spot on the partnership track at her firm. Agatha had taken the opportunity without hesitation, and the rest, as they say, was history.

But as Lilia continued to praise her courtroom theatrics, Agatha’s mind drifted to a different battle, one she wasn’t sure how to win.

Rio.

Even though she still felt the high of finally making headway in the Vanguard case, the nagging ache in her chest reminded her that she was behind— way behind —when it came to Rio.

Work was easy.

She understood how to read a courtroom, anticipate a move, counter a play. It was all second nature.

But bridging the gap she had caused in her relationship with Rio?

That was foreign terrain.

And unlike court, there were no precedents in her arsenal to lean on because simply—she never had a relationship like she had with Rio.

She never loved someone as much as she loved Rio.

The thought of groveling—a necessity, she knew—made her stomach churn.

And emotional conversations? That was a minefield she had spent her entire life avoiding.

The thought of laying herself bare, of voicing the words she had always kept locked away, sent a ripple of anxiety coursing through her. Vulnerability was not her strength, and the prospect of confronting her own fears felt like voluntarily stepping into a pit of her worst nightmares.

But she had, for all intents and purposes, royally fucked up this morning.

And now, she needed to do whatever it took to make it right.

To unfuck what she had so spectacularly fucked up.

Lilia’s voice brought her back.

“You’re quiet. That’s not like you after a win.”

Agatha glanced at her, forcing a small smile.

“Just thinking about tomorrow,” she lied smoothly.

Lilia’s eyes narrowed slightly, but she let it go.

“Well, if tomorrow is anything like today, Melanie better be on her toes.”

Agatha opened her mouth to respond, but before a single word could leave her lips, a body crashed into her, shoulder slamming into hers with enough force to send her stumbling.

The impact knocked the air from her lungs, and she fought for balance. Of course, today had to be the day she chose to wear her highest heels—a statement piece for court that also doubled as torture device. They were difficult enough to walk in on a good day, let alone when she was literally thrown off her feet.

She staggered, arms flailing slightly, but before she could hit the ground, a hand gripped her arm, yanking her upright with surprising strength.

“Jesus, Agatha, are you okay?” Lilia’s voice was sharp, cutting through the commotion with genuine concern.

Agatha barely registered her words as another voice, low and venomous, was speaking directly into her ear.

“Sorry about your girlfriend’s face,” the voice murmured, quiet but dripping with malice. The words slithered around her like a snake, tightening with each syllable.

The hand on her arm squeezed painfully, making her wince.

“She had such a pretty face. Next time, I’ll tell my guys to aim lower, so you can give her an open-casket funeral.”

Agatha froze, every muscle in her body locked as the words sank in.

The air around her seemed to thin, and the bustling hallway faded into a muffled hum. Her mind reeled, instincts screaming at her to react, but for a moment, she was paralyzed.

The chill running down her spine was soon consumed by a surge of molten rage, white-hot and blinding.

She turned slowly, her heart pounding in her chest, and there he was—James Hughes, Vanguard’s Head of Security.

He stood there so fucking cocky, a smirk tugging at his lips. His eyes gleamed with smug satisfaction, his posture relaxed as though this was just another day for him.

Agatha’s mind raced.

This man is unhinged.

Not just bold—fucking insane.

He had confessed to Agahta_._ Right here in public, in the middle of a courthouse hallway. Threatening her, admitting to orchestrating the attack on Rio.

It wasn’t a mugging. It had been a hit.

And now, he was promising to come after Rio again.

Her chest tightened, terror and fury battling for dominance. The image of Rio’s bruised face, her wounded arm, the blood—it all flooded back, consuming her.

James released her arm and began to turn away, his smirk widening as if he’d already claimed victory.

And then it snapped.

The rage boiled over, feral and uncontrollable. A guttural sound tore from Agatha’s throat, primal and raw, before she even realized it was hers.

James paused mid-step, his smirk faltering as he turned back at the sound, amusement flickering in his eyes. But he didn’t have time to say anything because Agatha’s fist collided with his face with brutal force.

The crunch of bone echoed in her ears, followed by a sharp, stabbing pain in her hand. She didn’t know if she’d broken his nose, or her hand, or both—but she didn’t care.

“Agatha!” Lilia’s voice was sharp and panicked, cutting through the chaos.

But Agatha didn’t hear her, didn’t register the commotion erupting around her. Her vision tunneled on James, who staggered back, clutching his bleeding nose.

“You bitch! You broke my nose!” he snarled, stepping forward, his face twisted with fury. Blood seeped between his fingers, staining his cuff.

Before Agatha could respond—or throw another punch—the security team assigned to her stepped in. Two burly men moved swiftly, positioning themselves between her and James, hands raised in warning.

Chaos erupted.

The corridor buzzed with shouts—accusations, expletives, gasps of shock.

Agatha wasn’t silent.

Her voice joined the fray, rising above the rest as she hurled her own expletives.

“You fucking coward!” she roared, her body trembling as she strained against Lilia’s grip and her security team’s restraint. “You tried to kill her! You fucking tried to kill her!”

Out of the corner of her eye, she saw Fox and Ratcliff rushing toward the scene, their faces etched with disbelief and something close to horror.

Ratcliff moved to James’s aid while Fox looked at Agatha with wide eyes.

“Agatha, have you completely lost your mind?” she shouted at her.

James started to lunge forward, but the security team shoved him back firmly.

“Stay back, Mr. Hughes,” one of them repeated—warning edging his tone.

The fact that this man was still trying to come after her, only added fuel to Agatha’s already burning rage.

“You are a coward! You want to come after me then come after me, you piece of shit! You stay the fuck away from her! You hear me!”

And then a voice cut through the chaos.

“Enough!”

The single word echoed in the hallway, silencing everyone instantly.

Heads whipped around toward the source.

Judge Marks stood at the door to his office, likely hearing the panic and stepping out. His face was a storm of fury and disbelief as he took in the chaos outside his chambers. His eyes flickered to the security team restraining James, the blood dripping from his nose, and Agatha —her hand smeared with blood, her chest heaving, wild-eyed as she locked eyes with the judge.

The judge’s gaze narrowed on her immediately.

“Counsel,” he said sharply, his voice laced with icy authority. “In my chambers. Now .”

The judge’s chambers were thick with tension as Agatha stood there, her shoulders stiff and her chest still heaving with residual fury. She could feel her teeth grinding together, her body practically vibrating with adrenaline and rage. She was trying to focus on the moment, but the burning sensation in her hand pulled her attention.

“Fuck,” she hissed, looking down at her bloody knuckles, which were rapidly swelling and starting to throb in time with her heartbeat.

Lilia, already beside her, grabbed Agatha’s wrist gently, her brow furrowing as she inspected the damage.

“I think you broke your hand,” Lilia said, her voice filled with worry.

Agatha gritted her teeth, pulling her hand back from Lilia’s prodding.

“I’m fine,” she snapped, her tone clipped, though the pain begged to differ.

Before Lilia could argue, the sound of the door slamming shut made everyone in the room jump. Judge Marks stood by the now-closed door, his face set in a thunderous scowl.

“Does anyone want to explain what the hell is happening?” he barked, his voice echoing in the small space.

Agatha swallowed hard, the sharpness of his tone cutting through her lingering rage. She’d pissed off Judge Marks before—plenty of times, if she was honest—but she had never seen him this mad. Suddenly, she felt like she was back in high school, standing in the principal’s office after she’d kneed the star quarterback in the balls for grabbing her ass. She’d gotten a week-long suspension for that one.

But this wasn’t high school, and Judge Marks wasn’t a principal. He was the presiding authority over the most important case of her career, and she had just jeopardized it.

“I’d like to know that myself,” Fox interjected, her voice tight with barely restrained anger. “Your Honor, my client’s head of security was assaulted in the hallway by opposing counsel. This is unacceptable—”

“Your client’s head of security threatened me, ” Agatha shot back, laced with the fury still raging in her body.

"Enough!" Judge Marks bellowed.

His glare snapped between Agatha and Fox, leaving no room for argument.

"Both of you. Sit."

Agatha reluctantly dropped into the leather chair. Lilia remained standing behind her, a grounding presence with one hand firmly on Agatha’s shoulder. Across the way, Fox sank into her chair beside her with a flourish of irritation, while Ratcliff chose to stand, mirroring Lilia’s stance behind her.

Judge Marks began pacing behind his desk, his hands clasped tightly behind his back as though restraining himself from slamming them onto the table. He was clearly searching for the right words, his jaw clenched as his frustration radiated off him.

"Let me get this straight," he said finally, his voice low but thick with disbelief. "Opposing counsel physically assaulted someone in the middle of my courthouse? Do you have any idea what this could do to my courtroom’s reputation, let alone this trial?"

Agatha’s jaw tightened, the urge to defend herself bubbling up, but before she could speak, Lilia’s hand tightened on her shoulder—a silent warning.

"Judge Marks," Lilia said, her voice calm and controlled, the very picture of composure— everything Agatha wasn’t in this moment. "Last week, Ms. Harkness received photos from an unknown entity threatening her son and her partner. The photos were taken both in public and in private settings, clearly showing her family was being monitored. Accompanying the

photos was a note warning Ms. Harkness to drop the case against Vanguard—or her family would be harmed."

Marks froze mid-step, his sharp eyes locking onto Agatha, the anger in his expression softening slightly as concern edged in. He straightened, his tone less biting as he addressed Lilia.

"Why wasn’t this reported?"

Lilia’s lips pressed into a thin line before she answered.

"We could not substantiate whether the threat definitively came from Vanguard, so we took precautions on our side. We hired security to protect Ms. Harkness’s family. However," her voice dropped, her gaze steady, "two days ago, Ms. Harkness’s partner, Ms. Vidal, was shot at in what was framed as an attempted mugging."

Fox scoffed loudly, leaning forward with a dismissive wave of her hand.

"This isn’t a spy thriller, Lilia. My client had nothing to do with this alleged ‘ mugging .’ Let’s not turn this courtroom into a conspiracy theory playground."

The growl that tore from Agatha’s throat was low and feral, her self-control hanging by a thread.

"Tell that to James Hughes," Agatha snapped, her voice sharp enough to cut. "The man just shoulder-checked me in the hallway, admitted to orchestrating the shooting, and threatened to do it again!"

Fox’s eyes widened, the briefest flash of unease flickering across her face before she smoothed it back into her practiced facade.

"Did anyone else hear this alleged ‘ confession ,’ Agatha?" Fox retorted, her voice dripping with condescension. "Because I call hearsay. You’re just grasping at straws to win this case by spinning wild accusations."

Agatha shot to her feet, ignoring Lilia’s attempt to keep her seated. Her injured hand slammed onto the table, sending a sharp jolt of pain through her arm, but she didn’t care.

"That son of a bitch threatened my family!" Agatha roared, her voice cracking under the weight of her fury.

"Enough!" Judge Marks thundered, his voice cutting through the room like a whip. His patience was visibly fraying, his knuckles white as he gripped the edge of his desk.

He leaned forward, his piercing gaze boring into Agatha.

"Ms. Harkness, sit down. I am already fining you $10,000 for your actions—warranted or not, I will not tolerate violence in my courthouse."

Agatha let out a sharp scoff, the rage still boiling under her skin.

“Only $10,000?” she retorted, her voice dripping with venom as she gestured to the door. “Bring that asshole back in here so I can hit him at least ten more fucking times.”

“Agatha,” Lilia hissed in warning, her fingers gripping Agatha’s shoulder like a vice as she forcibly pushed her back into her chair.

Judge Marks’s lips pressed into a thin line.

“That’s another $10,000, Ms. Harkness,” he said, his voice icier than before.

Agatha opened her mouth, but before she could fire off another retort, Lilia reached over and flicked her ear hard enough to sting.

“A fine she will pay,” Lilia interrupted smoothly, her tone calm and authoritative.

Agatha turned to glare at her, but Lilia didn’t so much as glance in her direction. Her focus was entirely on Judge Marks.

The judge’s eyes narrowed as he regarded Lilia, the tension in the room thickening. There was a history between them—anyone could see it.

Mutual respect, yes, but also something deeper, something unspoken.

If Agatha didn’t know better, she’d suspect there had been a flicker of romance between them long ago.

Judge Marks exhaled heavily, pinching the bridge of his nose as though willing himself to regain control. Finally, he shifted his attention to Fox, his expression darkening to something far more severe.

"And you, Ms. Fox," he said, his voice cold and deliberate, "if I find out your client’s people are involved in even half of what’s being alleged here, I will personally see to it that this trial doesn’t just sink your case—it will destroy your career."

Fox bristled, her jaw tightening, her fingers twitching against the arm of her chair, but she wisely kept her mouth shut—for the moment.

Judge Marks straightened behind his desk, looking as though the weight of the trial, and now this debacle, had aged him ten years in the span of five minutes. His eyes moved between the attorneys, heavy with exasperation before he finally sat down in his chair.

“Thankfully,” he said, his tone sharp, “the jury was deliberating at the time, so they did not witness any of this mess. From where I stand, the trial can continue as planned.”

Fox’s head snapped up at that, her carefully maintained composure slipping for a fraction of a second.

“Your Honor,” she began, her voice smooth but tinged with barely concealed frustration, “this situation has irreparably compromised the proceedings. The actions of opposing counsel—

physically assaulting my client’s employee in the courthouse, no less—are grounds for dismissal. How can we expect a fair trial under these circumstances?”

Agatha scoffed audibly, her fury bubbling to the surface as she opened her mouth to retort.

“Oh, please—”

But Lilia cut in smoothly.

“Your Honor, opposing counsel’s claim is absurd,” Lilia said, her gaze fixed on Judge Marks, ignoring Agatha and Fox entirely. “Ms. Harkness responded to a clear and imminent threat made against her family. While her response may not have been ideal, dismissing the case would reward the very intimidation tactics being used against her. That would set a dangerous precedent.”

Silence descended over the room.

Judge Marks leaned back in his chair, his eyes narrowing as he studied Lilia, then Agatha, and finally Fox.

“I agree with Ms. Caldru,” he said, his tone leaving no room for argument.

Fox stiffened, her jaw tightening further, but she didn’t dare interrupt.

“Here’s what’s going to happen,” Judge Marks continued, his voice authoritative.

He turned to Agatha, his expression sharp.

“Your firm will provide me with all evidence regarding these threats by tomorrow morning. If you’re alleging someone admitted to a crime, I expect a formal report filed with courthouse security before you leave this building. Am I clear?”

Agatha’s lips pressed into a thin line, but she nodded.

“Yes, Your Honor.”

Marks’s gaze shifted to Fox, his tone turning colder.

“And you, Ms. Fox—you will get your client’s people under control. If I hear even a whisper of harassment or intimidation from Vanguard or anyone associated with this case, I will not hesitate to issue sanctions that will cripple your defense.”

The silence that followed was deafening.

Judge Marks straightened in his chair, his final words cutting through the tension like a blade.

“You’re all dismissed. And let me be perfectly clear—if I hear about another incident like this, neither of you will like the consequences. Get out .”

Lilia was the first to rise, placing a firm hand on Agatha’s arm to guide her up. Agatha followed, her body still humming with adrenaline and fury, but she bit back any further comments.

As the heavy door to Judge Marks’s chambers slammed shut behind them, Agatha’s mind raced, her thoughts a chaotic swirl of anger, pain, and lingering fear. Her hand throbbed mercilessly and her jaw ached from grinding her teeth.

Lilia was on the phone speaking beside her, her voice low, undoubtedly dispensing orders to someone on the other end of the line, but the words barely registered. Agatha’s focus was consumed by the storm of emotions roiling inside her. The memory of James Hughes’s smirk, the venom in his voice, and the weight of his threat all played on a loop, fueling the fire in her chest.

“Lilia! Agatha!”

The sharp voice jolted Agatha from her spiraling thoughts. She recognized it immediately and turned to see Alice hurrying toward them from the elevator, her wide eyes locked on Agatha.

Lilia ended her call abruptly.

“Yes, Jen—I will keep you informed,” she said curtly before lowering her phone.

Agatha rolled her eyes, irritation sparking. Of course, Lilia had told Jen. She’d never hear the end of this from Jen— ever . She opened her mouth to call Lilia out for being a tattletale, but before she could get a word in, Alice reached them.

“Are you done with your motion hearing?” Lilia asked briskly, her tone all business.

Alice nodded but didn’t take her eyes off Agatha, her expression a mix of concern and disbelief as she no doubt took in her disheveled state.

“Good,” Lilia said, her tone clipped as she gestured toward Alice. “Take Agatha to Mount Sinai. She’s broken her hand.”

Alice’s eyes widened in alarm as she turned to Agatha.

“You what ?”

Agatha ignored her.

“I’m not going to the hospital,” she growled.

Lilia stopped abruptly, spinning to face her.

“You will get your ass to the hospital right now,” Lilia hissed, her voice low but filled with warning, “or I will drag you there by the ear.”

She stepped closer, she was a good 6 inches shorter then Agatha right now due to the heels, but still somehow made Agatha feel small on her glare.

“You want to test me, Agatha Harkness? Try me. Let’s see how your unshakable reputation handles getting dragged out of the courthouse like a misbehaving child. Because I will do it.”

Agatha’s mouth fell open, and for a moment, she was too stunned to respond. But when Lilia reached toward her face, as if she were genuinely about to grab her by the ear, Agatha batted it away with her good hand.

“Okay, mom!” she said, her voice dripping with sarcasm as she stepped back. “Jesus! Fine!”

Lilia didn’t respond, merely crossing her arms and arching an eyebrow in silent triumph.

Alice snorted, her initial concern giving way to a faint smirk.

But before the moment could stretch, Lilia turned her sharp gaze on her, and any trace of humor melted from Alice’s face.

“Do you still have that contact at the FBI?” Lilia asked.

Alice straightened, her lips pressing into a thin line. As a former district attorney, Alice had an extensive network of criminal justice contacts, a resource the firm often relied on to stay ahead of the competition.

“I do,” Alice said, her voice cautious as her gaze flickered between Agatha and Lilia.

“Good,” Lilia replied. “Have them meet you at the hospital. We’re turning over everything we have on Vanguard— now .”

Agatha bristled at that, her body stiffening as a surge of unease coursed through her. She shot Lilia a sharp look, her voice cutting.

“No—” Agatha began.

“It is not up for debate,” Lilia interrupted, her voice rising just enough to convey finality. Her piercing gaze locked on Agatha. “Jen agrees. A line was crossed today, and now that we know the attempt on Rio’s life was tied to Vanguard, we’re done taking risks. We’re turning over everything to the FBI—effective immediately.”

Agatha clenched her good fist, biting back her instinct to argue further. She hated this, hated the idea of handing over all hard-won evidence Rio found to an agency that might not handle it with the same care. Vanguard had deep pockets, influence, and undoubtedly eyes everywhere. If the FBI had it, there was a very real chance it could find its way back to Vanguard’s hands, compromising their entire case.

It was of course always the plan to turn over the evidence after the case, but never before.

But as much as she hated it, Agatha knew Lilia was right. Vanguard had escalated the stakes, and this wasn’t a game anymore—it was war.

Her jaw tightened, and after a beat, she gave a single, reluctant nod.

“Fine,” she said through gritted teeth, her voice clipped with frustration.

Alice exchanged a glance with Lilia, her expression grim as she pulled out her phone.

“I’ll make the call on the way to the hospital. They’ll likely meet us there.”

Lilia nodded curtly.

“Good. I’ll stay behind to fill out the report for courthouse security and ensure Judge Marks gets all the documented threats he’s requested. We can’t afford to push him any further when he’s already on edge.”

Agatha narrowed her eyes, crossing her arms as her hand throbbed painfully at the movement.

“Speaking from personal experience, Lilia?” she quipped, her tone biting.

Lilia arched an eyebrow, her lips twitching with the faintest hint of amusement.

“Wouldn’t you like to know,” she replied smoothly, moving her eyebrows suggestively.

Agatha’s face twisted in mock disgust. The mental image that flashed in her head was like imagining her parents having sex—something she wanted to erase immediately.

“Actually, no. Keep it to yourself,” she muttered, fake gagging for effect.

Alice leaned closer, her grin wicked.

“For the record—I definitely want to know.”

Agatha rolled her eyes, letting out a dramatic huff.

“Of course you do, you little freak,” she mocked, shaking her head. She flexed her swollen hand slightly and winced as a fresh wave of pain shot through it. “God, I can’t believe I’m saying this, but get me to the damn hospital. My hand feels like it’s about to explode.”

The humor vanished from Lilia’s face, replaced with worry. She stepped back, nodding at them.

“Go,” she said firmly. “I’ll handle everything here.”

Alice and Agatha nodded back, and without another word, they turned and headed toward the elevator. As they waited, Alice glanced down at Agatha’s hand, her brows furrowing at the sight of the swelling and smeared blood.

“Jesus—what did you do?” Alice asked, her voice filled with both shock and curiosity.

The elevator dinged, the doors sliding open, and they stepped inside. Alice hit the button for the ground floor, her gaze flicking back to Agatha, waiting for an answer.

Agatha leaned against the elevator wall, her tone dry.

“I punched Vanguard’s head of security in the face,” she said, almost flippantly.

Alice froze, her jaw dropping as her eyes widened in disbelief.

“You what ?!” she shouted, just as the elevator doors slid shut, sealing them inside.

Agatha gritted her teeth as the orthopedic surgeon carefully examined her hand, the dull throb of pain intensifying with each subtle movement. The sterile scent of the hospital room and the bright overhead lights only added to her growing irritation.

“Based on your X-rays, you’ve definitely broken the metacarpals in your hand,” the doctor said, frowning as he released her hand and gave her a pointed look. “I’m going to need to reset the bones to restore blood flow, and then we’ll get you into a cast.”

Agatha huffed, her jaw tightening further.

Fuck.

This day just kept getting worse.

“I’ll grab the materials for the cast and get you a prescription for some painkillers,” the doctor added. “Fair warning—the reset is going to hurt.”

Agatha nodded mutely, watching as he stepped out of the room. Her gaze flickered to the doorway, where Alice stood just outside, deep in conversation with two FBI agents. They were nodding along as Alice filled them in, gesturing occasionally to emphasize a point.

Agatha had already gone over what had happened at the courthouse in excruciating detail, and she trusted Alice to handle the rest. But her stomach churned as she watched the interaction. Suddenly, Alice turned at the sound of a voice, and another figure stepped into view—Jen.

Agatha instinctively held her breath.

Alice and Jen exchanged a few quiet words, their expressions unreadable from where Agatha sat. Then, Alice tilted her head toward the room, indicating in Agatha’s direction.

Jen’s gaze snapped toward her, and Agatha froze under the weight of her eyes. It was a look balanced precariously between relief—likely at seeing Agatha was okay—and frustration, undoubtedly at the situation that had landed her in this hospital to begin with.

Agatha braced herself, already expecting the barrage of criticism she knew Jen would deliver. Jen took a step toward her, her expression saying that she was about to rip Agatha a new one.

But then she stopped abruptly, her eyes darting down the hallway to her left. Her posture stiffened, and for a split second, her eyes went wide before narrowing again and then she turned back to Agatha her lips twitching into what could only be described as a pleased smirk.

Agatha’s brow furrowed.

Why does she look so smug?

Jen lifted her hand and gestured toward Agatha, pointing directly at her.

“What the hell?” Agatha muttered under her breath. She had no idea what was happening, but then—

Oh.

Rio stood in the doorway, her dark eyes immediately locking onto Agatha like a laser.

She didn’t look happy.

To be fair, Rio hadn’t looked particularly happy when she left this morning either, but this was different.

This was intense.

Agatha opened her mouth to say something— anything —but the words refused to come. She snapped her mouth shut, her mind scrambling.

What was she supposed to say?

Should she apologize for this morning?

For now?

Or should she just be grateful that Rio even bothered to show up?

The silence stretched, heavy and suffocating.

Rio, unsurprised by Agatha’s floundering, rolled her eyes and let out a loud, exasperated sigh before stepping into the room. She moved forward coming to stand beside the bed.

She stared down at Agatha, her gaze sharp and searching. For a moment, she said nothing, her eyes sweeping over Agatha’s face, lingering there for a moment. Then, her gaze dropped to Agatha’s hand—the swollen, clearly broken mess that rested in her lap.

Rio’s lips pressed into a thin line, and she exhaled through her nose, the sound quiet but loaded.

“You mangled my favorite part of your body,” she murmured.

Agatha’s heart lurched painfully in her chest. Memories surged forward, of the first time Rio had touched her, the way she had traced her fingers over Agatha’s hands, massaging them, worshiping them like they were sacred.

She swallowed hard, her throat tight with emotion.

“Well,” she said, her voice unsteady, “at least I have two.”

She raised her uninjured hand and wiggled her fingers weakly, trying for levity, though the gesture felt hollow.

Rio moved faster than Agatha anticipated, snagging her uninjured hand out of the air and cradling it gently in her own. Her fingers traced Agatha’s palm, mapping the lines and curves, her thumb brushing softly over her knuckles. It was intimate and grounding, and it made Agatha’s breath hitch.

When Rio finally looked up, the weight of her gaze hit Agatha like a punch to the chest. The depth of emotion in those dark eyes was overwhelming—worry, anger, affection, and so much god damn love that it felt tangible.

“Are you okay?” Rio murmured, her voice so soft it was barely audible.

Agatha stared at her, momentarily stunned by the tenderness in Rio’s tone. Her throat worked, but the words caught. She blinked rapidly, swallowing around the lump that had formed.

“I’ve been better,” Agatha admitted quietly.

Rio nodded slowly, her expression unreadable but her eyes softening. It was as if she was silently agreeing that she, too, had seen better days. They’d both been through hell—and all of it, Agatha knew, was thanks to her.

“Did you really punch someone at the courthouse?” Rio asked after a beat, her tone laced with disbelief and a flicker of curiosity.

Agatha grimaced, her lips twitching in a wry half-smile.

“Jen didn’t tell you?” she asked, surprised.

Jen usually jumped at any opportunity to report Agatha’s antics, especially to Rio.

It was very much a Jen move.

Rio shook her head, her dark eyes narrowing slightly.

“No,” she said. “But it’s all over the office. ‘Agatha Harkness punched a guy after court.’ You know something like that spreads like wildfire. Then the Sa—” She paused, clearing her throat as if catching herself. “Security said you were at the hospital, so I came right here.”

It wasn’t lost on Agatha that Rio had deliberately avoided saying Sam’s name—like she was trying to avoid the fight this morning—at least for now.

“Agatha,” Rio said slowly, her hand intertwining with Agatha’s. “What happened?”

Agatha frowned, her gaze dropping to their joined hands. She squeezed Rio’s fingers, as if drawing strength from her touch, and exhaled heavily.

“It was James Hughes,” she admitted.

Rio’s eyes widened at the name, recognition flashing across her face.

“Seriously?” she asked, her voice sharp with alarm.

Agatha nodded grimly.

“He shoulder-checked me in the courthouse hallway, and then...”

She hesitated, her throat tightening as the memory resurfaced.

“He admitted it, Rio. The mugging wasn’t random. He orchestrated it. He was trying to kill you.”

Rio stiffened, her free hand clenching into a fist at her side.

“And then,” Agatha continued, her voice faltering for a moment before she pushed on, “he said he’d come after you again.”

Her words burned as they left her mouth, her chest tightening painfully as the weight of them settled between them. Agatha squeezed Rio’s hand tighter, as if that alone could anchor her, remind her that James hadn’t succeeded—that Rio was still here, alive and in front of her.

Rio’s expression darkened, her jaw tightening as her gaze flickered briefly to the doorway where Jen and Alice were still deep in conversation with the FBI agents. Her eyes lingered there for a moment, her mind clearly working through the implications, but then her focus shifted back to Agatha.

Agatha hesitated under Rio’s sharp gaze, then grimaced, a flicker of something almost sheepish crossing her face.

“I may have lost my temper,” she admitted. “And... punched him.”

Agatha’s sheepishness didn’t last long. Her expression shifted as a sly smile tugged at her lips, the memory of the moment blooming vividly in her mind.

“Pretty sure I broke his nose,” Agatha added, a flicker of pride slipping into her tone despite the throbbing pain in her hand. The image of James Hughes’s face, contorted with shock as blood poured from his nose, replayed in her mind like a highlight reel.

She couldn’t help but savor it.

Rio’s expression shifted, caught somewhere between surprise and the urge to scold Agatha for her recklessness.

Finally, Rio let out a quiet sigh and reached forward, her fingers gently cupping Agatha’s face. The tender gesture melted the last of Agatha’s tension, her shoulders relaxing as she leaned instinctively into Rio’s touch.

“Agatha—” Rio began.

But before she could finish, the door swung open, and the doctor walked in, his arms loaded with supplies. He froze mid-step, his eyes widening slightly as he registered the moment he’d interrupted.

His lips quirked into an awkward smile.

“Uh... ready to get your cast on?” he asked awkwardly, shifting the supplies in his arms.

Rio pulled her hand back quickly, stepping away from Agatha with a subtle clearing of her throat. The absence of her touch was immediate, and Agatha had to fight the impulse to reach out and grab her hand again.

Instead, Agatha let out a huff of frustration, casting a sidelong glance at Rio before nodding.

“Let’s just get it over with.”

The doctor nodded, stepping toward a nearby tray and beginning to organize the materials with practiced efficiency.

“Can I stay?” Rio asked, her voice steady but quiet, her gaze fixed on the doctor.

The doctor barely looked up before nodding.

“Yes, of course,” he said, his tone matter-of-fact.

Both Agatha and Rio exhaled audibly, their relief almost comical in its synchronicity.

Agatha glanced at Rio again, her lips twitching with a faint smile despite herself. Having Rio there—despite everything —felt like a balm to the frayed edges of her nerves.

The doctor finished setting up his supplies, arranging the splints, bandages, and casting materials with well practiced hand. Then he turned to Agatha, moving to stand beside her as he gently took her injured hand in his own. His touch was firm but careful, and his fingers began to press along her swollen knuckles and radiating pain points.

Agatha winced, her breath hitching at each probing movement.

“Okay,” the doctor said after a few moments, his fingers pausing on a particularly sensitive spot. He lingered there, his touch light but deliberate. “I need to reset the fracture. This is going to hurt.”

Agatha exhaled sharply, her shoulders stiffening as she mentally braced herself. The pain was already bad— how much worse could it get?

Suddenly, she felt another hand slip into hers.

Startled, she glanced down to see Rio’s fingers entwined with her own.

Rio’s dark eyes stayed locked on her.

Agatha’s chest tightened, a flicker of appreciation cutting through the haze of pain and frustration. She looked back up at the doctor, her voice firm despite the knot in her throat.

“Just do it,” she said.

The doctor nodded, positioning her hand carefully.

“I’ll count down,” he said, his voice calm, almost soothing.

He began to count.

“Three... two—”

Before he reached one, he pressed.

The pain shot through Agatha like a lightning bolt, and she let out a sharp hiss, gripping Rio’s hand like a lifeline.

Rio didn’t flinch. She just squeezed Agatha’s hand tighter, her thumb brushing gently over the back of her knuckles.

“Fuck,” Agatha groaned through gritted teeth, glaring up at the doctor. “What’s the point of counting down if you’re not going to go on one ?”

The doctor didn’t even blink, his attention on her hand.

“Because going on two is better,” he said simply, as if it were the most obvious thing in the world. “People brace too hard on one, makes it harder to reset properly.”

Agatha rolled her eyes, but before she could retort, the doctor pressed one last time, setting the bone fully into place. The sharp pain made her hiss again, her grip on Rio’s hand tightening reflexively.

“And... done,” the doctor said, stepping back and pulling off his gloves. “You’ll need to keep this hand immobilized for a few weeks. I’ll get the cast on now, and we’ll go over aftercare instructions.”

Agatha let out a shaky breath, her body slumping slightly. Her hand still throbbed, but at least the worst of it was over.

Rio’s grip on her hand didn’t loosen, and Agatha didn’t pull away. She looked over at Rio, their eyes meeting for a brief moment that felt like an eternity.

“Thanks,” Agatha said softly, her voice barely audible as the lingering pain throbbed in her hand.

Rio gave her a small, almost imperceptible nod, her dark eyes meeting Agatha’s with that quiet intensity she seemed to master. Her thumb continued its soothing rhythm, brushing lightly against Agatha’s knuckles, grounding her in the moment.

“Of course, my love,” Rio murmured, her voice so gentle it almost broke Agatha.

God, those words.

Rio’s ‘ my love ’ wrapped around Agatha heart, easing the ache in her body far more effectively than anything the doctor could prescribe.

Hours later, Agatha and Rio stepped through the front door, the soft click of it closing behind them echoing in the quiet house. The nighttime nanny glanced up from the book she was reading on the couch, her gaze quickly shifting between Agatha’s cast and then Rio, both of them clearly new to her. She raised an eyebrow but didn’t comment.

“Nicky went down okay,” the nanny said, setting the book aside and rising to her feet. “He was, of course, sad you weren’t here, and also he kept mentioning someone named Rio. But after a couple of chapters of Harry Potter, he was out like a light.”

At the mention of Nicky asking for Rio, Agatha’s eyes flicked to her, and she didn’t miss the small quirk of Rio’s lips.

“I’ll leave you to it, Ms. Harkness,” the nanny said with a polite nod before grabbing her things and heading out the door.

As soon as the door closed, the silence in the home was deafening. It pressed in on Agatha, heavy and suffocating. She made a beeline for the kitchen, heading straight for the liquor.

Her movements were awkward, her left hand fumbling to grab the whiskey from the high perch had frustration bubbling up inside her. Using her non-dominant hand for something so simple felt infuriatingly clumsy, and the ache in her cast didn’t help.

Before she could fumble further, she felt fingers at her back, light and steady.

“Let me do it,” Rio said softly, her voice calm and steady.

Agatha sighed, the tension in her shoulders easing as she sagged into Rio’s touch for a brief moment. She nodded wordlessly and stepped aside.

Rio reached up and pulled down the bottle of bourbon. She grabbed two glasses from the other cabinet, her ease in the space so sure and effortless it made Agatha’s throat tighten. Rio

poured a generous amount into each glass, clearly understanding that both of them needed this tonight.

Agatha didn’t hesitate, grabbing her glass, before putting some distance between them and taking a long drink. The bourbon burned as it slid down her throat, the sensation grounding her, pulling her focus away from the chaos of the day.

She caught sight of Rio taking a sip from her own glass, her movements slower, more controlled. Rio nursed her drink, her dark eyes thoughtful as they lifted to meet Agatha’s.

Their gazes locked, and neither of them looked away.

And then finally, Agatha sighed because she had things she needed to say—things she needed to own up to.

“Rio,” Agatha said softly, her voice steady but strained as she made sure to look Rio in the eye. “I’m sorry about this morning.”

Rio’s jaw tightened, the muscle flexing just slightly—a small but telling sign that the fight from this morning still lingered, tender and unresolved.

She didn’t respond.

She didn’t say it was okay—because it wasn’t.

What Agatha had said wasn’t okay, and they both knew it.

Instead, Rio stood silently, her dark eyes fixed on Agatha, giving her the space to say more.

Because an apology, Rio’s silence made clear, wasn’t going to cut it.

Agatha swallowed hard, respecting the unspoken demand and hating it all the same.

This woman—this maddening, beautiful, unrelenting woman—was never going to give her an inch.

Letting out a slow breath, Agatha set her glass down on the counter and leaned back against it, crossing her arms over her chest as she tried to figure out where to even start. How did she explain herself—explain why she was so damn emotionally stunted?

“I’ve mentioned it before,” she started haltingly, her voice quieter now. “My childhood. And I’m not trying to make excuses—I’m not. But my mother... she really fucked me up.”

The words came out raw, almost brittle, but Agatha forced herself to keep going.

“By the time I was Nicky’s age, I knew every form of neglect there was. Starved, beaten, degraded...”

Her voice faltered, and she let out a shaky breath.

“I didn’t have a home, Rio. I had a rotting trailer where survival was a daily battle. And love?”

She let out a bitter, broken laugh.

“Love wasn’t something I ever received and if you asked my mother—it wasn’t something I deserved.”

Her gaze dropped to the counter, the fingers of her good hand tracing the edge absently as the vulnerability crept up her chest like an itch she couldn’t scratch.

“Growing up like that— fuck —it changes you,” she admitted, her tone heavy. “It carves something sharp and hard inside you. And as much as I hate to admit it...”

Her lips twisted into a wry, self-deprecating smile.

“Evanora Harkness may have completely fucked me up emotionally—but her cruelty is part of what made me the lawyer I am today. It made me ruthless enough to climb higher than anyone thought I could. I didn’t care whose body I had to step over to get my power. When you grow up powerless... power is everything. And I wanted it. I needed it. And I fucking have it.”

Agatha inhaled deeply, the air feeling thick and heavy in her lungs. The silence stretched between them like a chasm, and she knew— knew —that the next words she spoke would either build a bridge or send them tumbling into the void that Agatha created this morning.

Rio’s dark eyes were steady, piercing, and unreadable.

It wasn’t anger, but it wasn’t softness either.

It was patience.

Waiting.

Rio was the one giving her space, and somehow, that made it harder.

Her chest tightened, and she had to look away, her eyes falling to her hands—one now in a cast, the other trembling slightly. She swallowed hard, trying to gather herself, trying to figure out where to start.

“And then Nicky came along,” she said softly, her voice almost too quiet for the room. A bittersweet smile flickered across her lips. “And he cracked something open in me. Something I didn’t even know was still there.”

She let out a shaky laugh, glancing down the hallway where his room was, her mind painting an image of him safe in his bed, his tiny body curled up, lost in dreams—safe and knowing nothing but unconditional love.

“He’s my heart, my every breath. And I’ve sworn to him— to myself —that he’ll never know the childhood I had. Never .”

Agatha felt the weight of Rio’s gaze on her, and it burned. She forced herself to meet it, her voice soft but firm.

“I love my son,” she said, the words spilling out like a prayer. “I love him with every beat of my heart, with every breath I take. From the moment I first felt him move inside me, I loved him. Completely. Instantly.”

Her lips pressed into a thin line as her thoughts shifted, the warmth in her voice cooling into something more vulnerable.

“That love— motherhood —it came so naturally to me. I didn’t even have to think about it. He’s mine. My blood. It made sense.”

Her throat tightened as she reached the place she had been dreading, the place she knew she had to go. Her hands shook, and her gaze faltered for a moment before she forced herself to keep going to look Rio in the eye as she spoke.

“But with you,” she began, her voice breaking slightly, “it’s different. What I feel for you—it doesn’t come naturally, and it doesn’t make sense to me. And it scares the hell out of me, Rio. It makes me question everything I thought I knew about myself.”

She paused, her chest rising and falling as she fought to steady her breathing. The words clogged her throat, but she pushed through, her voice trembling.

“You terrify me, Rio,” she admitted, her voice cracking. “You make me feel things I’ve spent my whole life trying to avoid. You’re not something I can control. You’re not something I can predict. And for someone like me... that’s the most terrifying thing in the world.”

The tears came then, hot and fast, spilling over before she could stop them. She let out a broken laugh, swiping at her face with her good hand, but the tears kept coming.

“But you’re also the most beautiful thing I’ve ever had,” she pushed, voice cracking. “You’re my home, Rio. And for someone who grew up thinking a home was nothing more than a cruel joke, you’ve given me something I never thought I could have. And now that I have it, I’m so fucking scared of losing it. Of losing you. ”

She finally looked up, her eyes red and glistening, her heart in her throat.

“I don’t know how to love you the way you deserve,” she admitted, her voice hoarse and broken. “But I want to. God, I want to. And I’m sorry—so fucking sorry—that I can’t say those words. That I can’t—”

Her voice cracked, and she exhaled shakily, her hands trembling as she swiped at the tears on her cheeks.

“I’m trying, Rio. I’m trying so damn hard to be what you deserve, but I’m so scared. Scared that if I say it—if I admit how much you mean to me—that it’ll all fall apart.”

Her shoulders slumped as the weight of her words settled over her, the silence between them deafening.

“I’m sorry,” she whispered again, the words barely audible but carrying every ounce of her aching regret.

Rio stood still for a moment, her expression unreadable, her gaze steady and locked on Agatha. Then, without a word, she set her drink down on the counter with a soft clink and stepped forward, closing the distance between them.

She didn’t stop until she was so close that Agatha could feel the faint warmth of her body, her presence grounding and overwhelming all at once. Agatha froze, her breath hitching, her heart hammering in her chest as Rio reached up.

Gently, Rio cupped Agatha’s face with both hands, her touch impossibly tender. Her thumbs moved slowly, swiping away the tears that had been steadily falling down Agatha’s cheeks.

The softness of her touch, the care in the gesture—it broke something in Agatha, something fragile and hidden that she hadn’t even realized she’d been holding onto.

Agatha’s lips parted, but no sound came out. Her whole body seemed to lean into Rio instinctively, craving the closeness, the connection, even as the vulnerability in her chest screamed at her to retreat.

But Rio wasn’t retreating.

She wasn’t walking away.

She wasn’t leaving after hearing how fucking broken Agatha was, how much of a mess she’d made of her emotions, of her past, of her own damn heart.

And that realization hit Agatha like a freight train.

Her breath hitched again, her eyes fluttering closed for a moment as she leaned into Rio’s touch, her good hand coming up to rest lightly on Rio’s hip, pulling her closer.

And when Agatha finally opened her eyes, they met Rio’s, and the raw emotion she saw there almost stole her breath.

It wasn’t pity.

It wasn’t judgment.

It was something so much deeper— understanding .

Agatha’s chest tightened, and her voice came out as a whisper, trembling and so fucking fragile.

“You’re still here.”

Rio’s lips curved into the faintest smile, her thumbs brushing over Agatha’s cheekbones as she replied softly.

“You’re my home too, my love,” she murmured, her dark eyes holding Agatha’s gaze with an intensity that made Agatha’s heart stutter. “And I’m not going anywhere.”

Hexenbesen

All day, the thought had clawed at her—relentless, unbearable —that she had pushed Rio too far. That the woman she loved might not come back to her, that she might never feel Rio’s lips against hers again.

But Rio was here.

Still here.

That fact sent a tremor through Agatha, one she couldn’t contain.

The kiss wasn’t like the others.

Rio’s lips moved against hers with a softness that stole the air right out of Agatha’s lungs. For a moment, Agatha didn’t know how to respond—the tenderness was so unfamiliar. This wasn’t the kind of kiss they typically shared, the ones that burned hot with passion and defiance, where they pushed and pulled, each daring the other to surrender.

No, this kiss was different.

It was quiet.

It was careful.

And it was filled with something deeper—something fragile, precious, and impossibly tender.

This kiss didn’t feel like just forgiveness.

It wasn’t just reassurance.

It felt like healing.

“What’s wrong?” she murmured, her voice rough around the edges.

Agatha groaned in exasperation, letting her head thud lightly against the cabinet behind her.

“This,” she snapped, holding her casted arm up. “I swear to God, I didn’t regret breaking my hand on Hughes’s face for a second, but now—”

Rio’s lips quirked into a crooked smile, despite herself, her hands still steadying Agatha at her waist.

“Second thoughts, Mayweather?” she teased softly, though her gaze stayed tender.

Agatha narrowed her eyes but couldn’t help the corner of her mouth twitching upward.

“ Only because now...I have to teach my left hand how to do what my right hand just learned.”

She pulled back just slightly, her thumb brushing over Agatha’s bottom lip in a slow, deliberate sweep.

“I’m sure you’ll manage.”

That was Rio.

All pure power and untamed energy, like a nuclear reactor, always toeing the line between control and implosion, threatening to consume everything in her path.

“Fuck.”

And judging by the feral gleam in her eyes, Agatha knew—she just knew —that whatever Rio was thinking, whatever Rio was planning, it was something Agatha would never be prepared for.

Because Agatha understood exactly what they were dancing around—what they had been circling since the very beginning.

The power Rio had when Agatha gave it to her. The control Rio could wield with a look, a touch, a word.

And the way Agatha would let her .

They had only just cracked the surface of this—this thing between them. This dynamic, this balance of power that felt so fragile and yet so right . There was so much more to explore, to unearth, to lose themselves in.
