Oh, she was in trouble.

Really looked at her.

Agatha frowned, her brows knitting together in confusion as she watched Rio straighten.

And then Rio walked out of the room.

She didn’t say a word.

Not one.

She just... left.

Agatha blinked, stunned into silence, her mind stuttering to catch up.

What the hell?

For a moment, she sat there, still perched on the edge of her bed, listening to the distant sound of Rio’s footsteps padding down the hallway.

Then, she heard it—the soft creak of a door opening.

Her door.

Rio’s room.

Her stomach plummeted.

Was she leaving Agatha?

Was Rio seriously leaving her like this, after kissing her senseless, after working her up and then— what? —walking away?

And then there she was.

That fucking backpack .

This woman.

Chapter End Notes

Hope you liked it! Also, the chapter title had be cracking up. They exchanged "brooms" lol

Also, if you didn’t get the Christmas reference at the end of the chapter it was a call back to the end of chapter 23: Coven Two.

Breaking The Fourth Wall

Chapter Summary

Happy Holidays everyone!

Well, this chapter got truly away from me. Before I knew it was was at 9.000 words and I wasn't even close to finishing what needed to be done. So...another chapter added. I hope you like it. I feel like this whole chapter has a sprinkle of everything.

Chapter titles comes from Wanda Vision.

The following morning, Agatha found herself sitting on the couch. Still clad in her purple silk robe and her hair a mess. She hummed, as her hands cradled a warm mug of coffee emblazoned with the words " Big Witch Energy ." It was a Christmas gift from Jen, who had thought herself particularly clever.

The couch shifted beneath her as a body slid into the seat next to her. Agatha turned and her gaze landed on Rio. She was wearing Agatha’s mink kimono robe—the one with a botanical print that stopped mid-thigh. And when Rio crossed her legs, Agatha’s traitorous eyes followed the movement, tracing the bare expanse of skin exposed. Her mind immediately flooded with memories of how soft that skin felt—against her hands, her lips, her tongue.

Rio cleared her throat.

Agatha’s eyes shot upward, and she froze—caught.

Rio’s dark eyes were locked on hers, amusement dancing in them, and her lips curved into a slow, knowing smirk as she sipped from her mug—a mug that said “ Dissent” in bold letters, featuring an illustration of Ruth Bader Ginsburg flipping a double bird.

The look in Rio’s eyes told Agatha she knew exactly where Agatha’s mind had wandered.

And suddenly, the warmth blooming in Agatha’s chest wasn’t just from the coffee.

Before she could say anything, a loud bang broke through the quiet. She jumped, startled, as a child’s voice rang out in dramatic authority.

“I call this family meeting to order!”

Agatha sighed, long and heavy.

Of course, her son had inherited her flair for dramatics.

She turned her attention away from Rio and toward the dining chair that Nicky had dragged into the middle of the living room. He sat perched on it in his Bluey pajamas, holding a bright yellow plastic hammer that he was enthusiastically banging on her coffee table.

Bang. Bang. Bang.

Agatha winced.

There not enough coffee in the world making that sound bearable at 6:00 AM.

“Nicky, you’re going to dent the table,” she said, her tone more matter-of-fact than scolding, though she arched her eyebrow in warning.

Nicky, in true Agatha fashion, completely ignored her. But he did— by the grace of god— set the hammer down. Nicky leaned back in his chair, crossing his arms his blue eyes moving between Agatha and Rio with a look so reminiscent of Agatha’s own that it was uncanny.

Out of the corner of her eye, Agatha saw Rio’s lips twitch as a small snort of laughter escaped. She masked it quickly, coughing into her mug, but it was too late. Both Agatha and Nicky turned sharp, narrowed gazes on her at the same time.

“Sorry—frog in my throat,” Rio murmured innocently, though the amusement in her eyes betrayed her.

She took a slow sip of her coffee, then gave Nicky an encouraging nod.

“Please, Judge, continue.”

Nicky straightened in his chair, visibly puffing up with importance at Rio’s acknowledgment.

Agatha couldn’t decide whether to laugh or roll her eyes at the display.

“It has come to my attention...” Nicky began, his voice serious.

God help her.

The kid was six.

Who even talks like that?

“...that safety procedures are not being followed,” he finished, his sharp gaze shifting between Rio’s stitched brow and Agatha’s casted arm.

Agatha barely resisted the urge to groan.

The second Nicky saw her arm in a cast this morning, he had, of course, been worried. But once she’d explained— lied —and told him she fell at work, his concern quickly morphed into the complete opposite end of the spectrum.

Enter: the family meeting.

Agatha was no stranger to these meetings—after all, she’d called a few herself to talk through big things with him—his diagnosis, the divorce, bad days at school, his favorite tv show being cancelled. But she certainly hadn’t expected him to pull an uno reverse card and not only schedule one for her but make Rio attend as well.

Rio shot Agatha an amused side-eye as she took another sip of her coffee, clearly enjoying every second of this.

Agatha pinched the bridge of her nose, already feeling the weight of her son’s righteous indignation bearing down on her.

“Nicky... they were accidents, honey—”

Her attempt at reasoning was immediately cut off by her son’s dramatic retort.

“When I cut my knee open at the playground this summer, you gave me a whole speech on way home about responsibility,” Nicky reminded.

He leaned forward, his voice shifting into an exaggerated impression of hers.

“‘ You only get one body, Nicholas—you need to take care of it. ’ Remember that, Mom? Because I do.”

Agatha blinked at him, a mix of disbelief and begrudging admiration flickering across her face. The little monster had not only an impeccable memory but also a talent for turning her own words into ammunition.

“Okay—yes,” Agatha conceded, lifting her hand in mock surrender. “Rio and I need to be more careful. And we will be.”

She nudged her elbow into Rio.

“Won’t we, Rio?”

Rio to her credit, and Agatha’s relief, seemed to wipe all humor off her face as she looked at Nicholas seriously.

“Yes,” she said with a nod. “My shoes have been tied, and I have been carefully watching where I am going.”

Nicky’s eyes narrowed, his small face filled with the gravity of someone twice his age as he gauged the sincerity of their statement. After a long, dramatic pause, he gave a single nod, clearly satisfied with their pledge.

He shifted, looking ready to climb down from his makeshift judge’s chair, but Agatha wasn’t about to let her six-year-old son walk away with the upper hand.

She had a reputation to uphold, after all.

“Ah. Ah. Ah,” she tutted, holding up a single finger and gesturing downward in a firm “ sit back down ” motion.

Nicky paused, giving her a suspicious look, but plopped back into the chair with a huff, crossing his arms over his chest in defiance.

“Since we’re all here,” Agatha continued, her tone light but edged with that unmistakable mom power , “and since safety procedures seem to be the hot-button topic of the day ...”

She let the words hang, savoring the way Nicky’s little eyebrows furrowed in confusion, before dropping her own version of a hammer down.

“I think we should discuss the packet of Oreos I found under bed this morning. You know, the ones I keep on the top shelf for special occasions?”

Nicky’s eyes went wide, and his mouth fell open in a guilty gasp.

Rio immediately covered her mouth with her hand, muffling a laugh that threatened to escape.

“Last I checked, your doctor said you were 46 inches tall, correct?” continued Agatha.

Nicky froze, his confidence faltering for the first time.

“Yes—I grew two inches,” he answered.

“Ah, yes,” Agatha said, her eyes narrowing as she leaned back against the couch. “So, tell me, Nicholas—how does a child, even with those extra two inches , reach the top shelf that’s at least ten feet off the ground?”

She paused, savoring the tension, taking a sip of her coffee before setting it back down on its coaster with an almost theatrical flourish. Then, she leaned forward, elbows on her knees, her gaze locking onto his.

“Unless, of course,” she continued, her voice dropping into a sharp, almost conspiratorial tone, “someone thought it was a good idea to climb onto the countertop, then step on top of a soup pot—which, by the way, was conveniently left out the following morning as evidence of said crime—and then smuggle said cookies into their room in the middle of the night. Hmm?”

Agatha arched a brow, her tone sharp as her gaze bore into Nicky.

“Does standing on the countertop, balancing on a soup pot, sound like following safety protocols to you?”

Nicky’s eyes widened, panic flickering across his face as he desperately searched for an escape route. Agatha didn’t miss the way his gaze darted toward Rio, locking onto her with a pleading look so pitiful it could have softened stone.

Rio shifted uncomfortably under the intensity of his puppy-dog stare, her once-smug smirk dissolving into thin air. The amusement that had danced in her eyes moments ago was now replaced with a subtle, wide-eyed plea of her own as she glanced toward Agatha.

“ Help me, ” her expression seemed to say.

Agatha let out a quiet sigh, her lips twitching in mild exasperation.

She knew this game all too well—the power of those big, innocent blue eyes was practically weaponized by her son.

“Eyes on me, Nicholas,” she said firmly, saving Rio from melting under the pressure. “Rio can’t save you here.”

Nicky let out a huff, his little chest rising in exaggerated defeat, but he brought his eyes back to Agatha.

“Anything to say for yourself?” she asked, her brow arching higher, savoring the moment as she waited for him to crack.

For a moment, Nicky looked well and truly cornered, his tiny gears visibly turning as he weighed his options. Just when Agatha thought she had him backed into a victory, he shot another quick glance at Rio.

She watched as son’s eyes flickered with confusion before he returned to Agatha, his expressions still confused.

“Umm... five?” he said cautiously.

Agatha blinked, momentarily stunned by the odd response. Her gaze flickered toward Rio, and that’s when she caught it—five fingers held up towards him.

It took her a beat to connect the dots, and when she did, her jaw dropped. She turned sharply to Rio, disbelief etched into every line of her face.

“Are you seriously trying to get him to plead the Fifth?” she demanded, her tone hovering somewhere between exasperation and incredulous amusement.

Rio smirked, her cockiness returning in full force.

“What’s the Fifth?” Nicky asked, his voice full of curiosity.

“The Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution,” Rio explained smoothly, as if she were back in law school. “It protects people from self-incrimination, meaning they can refuse to answer questions or provide information that might get them into trouble.”

Nicky’s eyes grew comically wide, his lips parting as he processed this groundbreaking revelation. He turned back to Agatha, jabbing a finger in Rio’s direction.

“I do that!” he declared triumphantly.

Agatha groaned, throwing her head back against the couch as Rio erupted into laughter, her smirk now a full-blown grin.

“Of course you do,” Agatha muttered, pinching the bridge of her nose. “ Unbelievable .”

Agatha narrowed her eyes at Rio, a warning in her gaze that was met with nothing but a small, unbothered smirk. Finally, she let out a resigned sigh, turning her attention back to Nicky.

“Okay—look we’re all going to make better choices, okay?” she said softly, her tone serious but still maintaining warmth.

Nicky looked up at her, his small face thoughtful as he absorbed her words. Then, with a serious nod, he repeated.

“Because we only get one body.”

Agatha’s chest tightened at his words, her heart aching with a pang of bittersweet emotions. She remembered those terrifying nights when he was so sick, the fear that gripped her, the helplessness. Her eyes flicked to Rio, and another wave hit her—this time, the memory of how close that bullet had come.

She had come so close to losing them both.

“Yes,” she murmured, her voice steadier now but still laced with tenderness. “We only get one body. So, we need to make sure we protect it. No more unnecessary risks, even for cookies, okay?”

Nicky nodded earnestly, and without another word, he crawled forward and nestled himself between the two women on the couch.

“Sorry about the cookies,” he said in a small voice, his head dipping slightly. “I knew it was naughty.”

Agatha smiled, her fingers running gently through his hair.

“Next time, just wake me up and ask, sweetheart. I would’ve let you have some.”

Nicky nodded, the three of them falling into a comfortable silence for a moment, before his head tilted back, his wide eyes gazing up at her curiously.

“Did you hurt your hand in your bedroom?” he asked suddenly.

Agatha blinked, caught off guard by the question, her hand stilling in Nicky's hair.

“No, honey. I hurt it at work,” she said carefully.

“Oh,” Nicky replied, but his little brow furrowed in a way that Agatha instantly recognized as dangerous. “I could’ve sworn I heard banging last night and a loud cry coming from your room when I was walking back to my room after I got the cookies.”

Agatha stiffened, heat rising up her neck. She opened her mouth to respond, but Rio was already on her feet.

“And on that note,” Rio interjected, her voice a little too chipper, “I’m going to make breakfast.”

She bolted to the kitchen with such speed that her coffee nearly tipped over, and Agatha’s jaw dropped as she watched her retreat.

Traitor.

She flicked her gaze down to Nicky, whose curious blue eyes were locked on her—waiting.

“Rio didn’t tie her shoes and fell again,” Agatha blurted, pulling the excuse out of nowhere. “That’s what you heard.”

Nicky’s eyes went wide.

“Rio—you said you were being careful!” he called out, twisting around on the couch to peer over its back.

From the kitchen, Rio’s voice rang out, incredulous and dripping with betrayal.

“ Agatha! ”

Agatha feigned innocence, turning her head slowly to look over her shoulder. Rio stood there, a frying pan in hand, staring at her like she couldn’t believe what she’d just heard.

Agatha shrugged, her expression smug.

“ Rio... ” Nicky sighed shaking his head at her as his little voice adopted the same exasperated tone Agatha often used herself.

He turned back to Agatha with a serious expression.

“We really need to order her those velcro shoes, Mom.”

Agatha grinned, her lips twitching into a full smile as she shot a look at Rio that practically screamed take that.

“Excellent thinking, honey,” she said, reaching for her phone and unlocking it with a flourish. She handed it to him, the Amazon app already open. “I’ve got a couple matching pairs in the cart. Pick which ones you like for you and her.”

Nicky’s face lit up as he grabbed the phone, and Agatha leaned back with a victorious smirk, her eyes locking with Rio’s.

“Ohh...I like these Marvel superhero ones!” exclaimed Nicky.

Rio narrowed her eyes at her from the kitchen, but Agatha only winked, her grin absolutely wicked.

Nicky was off to school, leaving the house quiet, and Agatha found herself standing in her closet, still wrapped in her purple silk robe. Her makeup was flawless, her hair styled to perfection—but the outfit, the pièce de résistance , was still undecided.

Today was pivotal.

The final day of the Vanguard trial, barring any surprises from the FBI leaking their evidence to the opposing party. She needed something sharp, commanding, and unmistakably Agatha Harkness.

Her gaze swept across the rows of her expansive walk-in closet, every inch meticulously organized with designer clothes hung in neat, color-coordinated lines. Not her doing, of course. Without the help of a professional organizer, the space would look like a luxury bomb exploded.

Agatha knew herself.

Professionally, she was controlled chaos, but personally?

She was just chaos.

And this closet? It wasn’t just a wardrobe—it was an investment. Enough designer labels were packed into this space to purchase a chic condo in an up-and-coming neighborhood. The least she could do was pay someone to treat them with the respect they deserved.

Still, as she stared at the array of choices, she felt the stirrings of indecision. Power suits, elegant dresses, tailored trousers—all weapons in her arsenal, but none of them felt quite right.

Not yet.

Not for today.

Agatha crossed her arms, her manicured nails tapping lightly against her cast—another thing she had to figure out how to hide, scrutinizing her options. Today needed the perfect balance: sharp enough to remind everyone in the courtroom who they were dealing with, but not so severe as to give off power bitch vibe and spook the jury.

It was a fine line to walk, but if anyone could do it, it was her.

Suddenly, she felt hands slide over the silk at her waist, and her body tensed instinctively before softening as she recognized the touch. She let out a breath she hadn’t realized she was holding, tension melting away as Rio’s hands circled her waist.

The press of Rio’s front against her back was grounding, and Agatha practically sagged into her, her head tilting to rest on Rio’s shoulder. She closed her eyes as Rio buried her face in the curve of Agatha’s neck, breathing her in deeply.

“You’ve been in here for ten minutes,” Rio murmured against her skin, her voice low and warm, sending shivers down Agatha’s spine.

Agatha sighed, the sound soft, almost involuntary, as if Rio’s presence had unlocked a tightly coiled spring inside her. She barely had a moment to register the relief before Rio’s lips pressed against her neck, trailing kisses slowly upward.

A quiet moan slipped from Agatha’s lips before she could stop it.

“Someone’s wound up,” Rio teased, her tone dripping with smug satisfaction.

Agatha could practically feel the smirk against her skin, and it only made her huff in response.

“Knock it off,” she muttered, though she made no move to step away. If anything, her body betrayed her, leaning slightly into the contact as Rio’s kisses continued. “I don’t have time for this. I need to be out the door in twenty minutes.”

Rio chuckled, her breath warm against Agatha’s neck.

“I could get it done in two.”

Agatha didn’t even hesitate—her elbow shot back, landing squarely in Rio’s ribs. A surprised “oof” escaped Rio as her grip loosened, and Agatha took the opportunity to step away, smirking to herself.

“Serves you right,” Agatha said over her shoulder, running her fingers along the neatly organized rows of designer outfits. She tried to focus, hoping one of them would magically “spark joy” in true Marie Kondo fashion.

Behind her, Rio chuckled, but the sound quickly faded into a thoughtful silence.

“Big day today,” Rio murmured, her tone softer now.

Agatha turned, her gaze landing on Rio—and her lips twitched with both amusement and irritation when she caught sight of the sweatshirt Rio was wearing. Faded gray, slightly oversized, with “Harvard” emblazoned across the front in bold lettering.

Her sweatshirt.

Agatha’s eyes narrowed.

“Nicked it from your dresser,” Rio said sweetly. She tugged at the hem of the sweatshirt as if staking her claim. “Full disclosure—this is mine now.”

Agatha’s lips twitched, betraying her. She hated how much she loved seeing Rio in her things, how easily it softened her. But, of course, she wasn’t about to let Rio know that.

“Full disclosure,” Agatha countered, arching a brow, “if you ever catch me wearing that hideous orange Longhorn sweater from your alma mater, check me into the nearest psychiatric facility, because I’ve clearly lost my mind. Orange—honestly, you look like a walking creamsicle, Rio.”

She shivered for dramatic effect, adding a disdainful flourish with her hand.

But a moment later, her mind finally connected the dots. Rio was makeup-free, her hair pulled back in a messy bun, and she was wearing sweatpants.

“You’re not going to work today?” Agatha asked, her voice soft but hesitant.

And of course, Rio caught it immediately.

Honestly, the idea of Rio leaving the house today—after everything with James Hughes yesterday—had been gnawing at Agatha since the moment she opened her eyes. The thought of her stepping out into the world where a very real threat loomed over her made Agatha’s stomach churn.

Worse, Agatha had been ready to let her go, to pretend like she wasn’t worried. Because she didn’t want to fight.

Not again.

Not after yesterday.

She didn’t want to push Rio away, didn’t want to risk saying the wrong thing, but gods—this entire situation felt like a lose-lose.

And Agatha hated losing.

“No,” Rio said quietly, her voice pulling Agatha from her spiraling thoughts. “I called in.”

Agatha’s breath hitched at that, a mixture of relief and something warmer blooming in her chest.

“You called in?” Agatha repeated, her brow furrowing slightly as she tried—and failed—to mask the rush of emotion swelling in her chest.

Rio nodded, closing the distance between them until there was barely a breath of space left. Her hands came up to cup Agatha’s face, her thumbs brushing softly over her cheeks in a gesture so gentle it made Agatha’s knees threaten to buckle.

“Jen’s letting me work from here,” Rio murmured, her voice low and soothing. The corners of her lips quirked upward into a smile that was equal parts affectionate and teasing. “Figured I’d stick around and make sure someone doesn’t overthink herself into a frenzy before one of the biggest days of her career.”

Agatha’s lips twitched, her initial instinct to glare completely undermined by the way she leaned into Rio’s touch. She knew the look she managed was more petulant than intimidating, but she couldn’t quite bring herself to care.

“I do not overthink,” she countered, though her voice lacked conviction.

Rio’s brow arched, her skepticism radiating loud and clear.

“You’ve been standing in your closet for the last 10 minutes.”

“I was picking out a statement piece!”

Rio’s smirk deepened as her hands slid from Agatha’s face to encircle her waist, pulling her close.

“You’ve had three cups of coffee.”

Agatha pressed her lips together in defiance.

“I function better caffeinated.”

Rio’s chuckle was soft, a low hum of reassurance as her hand trailed up and down Agatha’s back, the touch as steady as the ground beneath her feet. Her dark eyes locked onto Agatha’s, and in an instant, the teasing gave way to something more profound—a kind of understanding that made Agatha’s chest ache.

“And you’re trying very hard not to admit you’re glad I’m staying home,” Rio murmured, her voice warm and knowing.

Agatha opened her mouth, a sharp retort at the ready, but it withered on her tongue. She hesitated, swallowing the urge to deflect. Instead, she let out a slow breath, the tension in her shoulders easing as her gaze softened.

“I am,” she admitted quietly, the words slipping free like they had been waiting to be said. “Glad, I mean.”

Her hands moved almost instinctively, reaching up to settle on Rio’s shoulders. Her fingers brushed through the soft baby hairs at the back of Rio’s neck before raking gently against her scalp. The response was immediate—Rio’s eyes fluttered closed, and a quiet hum of approval escaped her lips, a sound so content that it made Agatha’s heart tighten.

“Thank you,” Agatha whispered, her voice trembling just enough to betray the depth of her emotion. “I can’t—I didn’t want to think—”

She broke off, struggling against the weight of what she wanted to say.

The words felt too heavy, too fragile, too much.

But Rio didn’t need the words.

She leaned in, her lips capturing Agatha’s in a kiss so sure, that it seemed to erase every unsaid thought and every lingering fear. The kiss wasn’t rushed or frantic—it was steady and a reminder of every reason why Agatha fucking loved this woman.

“I’ll be safe here,” Rio murmured, her voice low and steady, punctuated by the tender press of her lips.

“I’ll stay put all day. I promise.”

Her hands slid up to cradle Agatha’s face as she kissed her again, this time firmer.

“You just focus on the trial,” Rio continued, her voice soft but laced with conviction, each word a whisper against Agatha’s lips.

“On Brooke.”

Another kiss, deeper this time.

“On bringing her family justice.”

She kissed her again, this time long and lingering, as though pouring every ounce of her strength, her faith, her love into Agatha. When she finally pulled back, Rio’s dark eyes burned fiercely, her fingers tightening on Agatha’s face.

“And holding those fucking bastards accountable ,” she growled, the last words pressed against Agatha’s mouth like a command and a plea all at once.

Agatha's thoughts spiraled as she kissed Rio, her lips moving with a fervor that conveyed everything she couldn’t put into words. She had never truly had this before—someone who didn’t just tolerate the demands of her career but understood it. Someone who respected the weight of her work and pushed her to be better—to be relentless.

The fact that Rio—Rio, who loved the law as much as she did, who loved work as much as she did—had willingly stayed home today for her, for her peace of mind, it was everything.

It was more than Agatha ever dared to ask for, more than she even knew she needed.

The thought hit her like a lightning strike, and she surged forward, her kiss searing and passionate.

The kiss wasn’t just a thank you.

It was a demand.

And it told Rio everything —that this wasn’t going to stop at a kiss.

Rio groaned against her lips, her hand slipping around Agatha’s waist as she backed her into the wall of neatly arranged shoes. The soft thuds of toppling heels barely registered as Agatha’s robe loosened, Rio’s fingers tugging it apart and slipping under the silk.

“I thought you didn’t have time,” Rio teased, her voice husky, her breath warm against Agatha’s lips as her hand cupped a bare breast, her fingers squeezing greedily, exactly the way she knew Agatha loved.

Agatha gasped, her body arching into Rio’s touch, her fingers tangling in Rio’s messy bun and tugging her closer.

“You said you could get it done in two. Chop. Chop ,” Agatha goaded, her voice a mix of challenge and breathless need as she tilted her hips into Rio’s, her robe sliding further from her shoulders, forgotten.

Rio’s dark chuckle sent a shiver racing through Agatha, her lips brushing against Agatha’s jawline before murmuring in a low, smoky tone—

“Then I better not waste a second.”

And just like that, Rio dropped to her knees. She grabbed Agatha’s leg, her fingers firm as she hooked it over her shoulder. Agatha’s breath hitched, her chest heaving as she looked down, only to catch Rio’s a wink—a move that would have been infuriating if it weren’t so devastatingly hot.

Any thoughts of irritation dissolved the moment Rio’s mouth found her. Agatha’s head snapped back, her eyes slamming shut as a raw, guttural moan tore from her throat, so visceral it startled even herself. The sound of more heels clattering to the floor barely registered.

Rio was right.

She only needed two minutes, and as Agatha sagged against the wall, legs trembling, Rio stood up, licking her lips with a grin so smug that it made Agatha’s head spin.

Agatha shot her a glare, just as weak and wobbly like her legs, and she knew it.

Rio smirked unapologetically, turning to walk out of the room to give Agatha space to collect herself. But then she stopped mid-step, tilting her head as her eyes scanned the closet. She looked to her left, then back across the room, her gaze thoughtful. Without a word, she strode across the room and plucked a pair of plum-colored pants from their hanger.

Agatha blinked in confusion, still trying to steady her breathing, as Rio moved to grab a crisp white button-down that had a jeweled button that secured the collar and then a navy-teal blazer.

Rio turned back to her expression neutral as she crossed the room toward Agatha.

Wordlessly, Rio placed the outfit into Agatha’s outstretched arms. Agatha stared down at the ensemble, a faint laugh escaping her lips, but Rio wasn’t done. Leaning forward, she brushed

against Agatha—deliberately, of course—and pulled out a pair of sleek navy heels from the rack and added them to the pile in Agatha’s arms.

“Wear that,” Rio instructed, her smirk practically dripping with confidence.

She stepped back, her gaze lingering on Agatha for a moment longer, as though committing her to memory. Then, she turned and started to walk away.

But just as she reached the door, Rio paused.

She glanced over her shoulder, her dark eyes meeting Agatha’s, and a devastatingly beautiful smile curved her lips.

“Go get ’em, killer.”

The midday courtroom buzz carried an undercurrent of tension as Agatha leaned back in her chair, allowing herself a fleeting breath before the next round. She’d put Brooke’s parents on the stand first thing this morning, their testimony painting a portrait of a loving, hardworking daughter, full of life and ambition.

Fox had pounced on every opportunity to claw at their credibility, treading carefully to avoid leaving a bad taste in the jury’s mouth being the “big corporate” lawyer bullying grieving parents. Her questions were measured, her tone gentle, and while she managed to chip away at the edges of their testimony—pointing out that living states away meant they couldn’t know “everything” about their daughter’s life—it wasn’t enough to destroy the picture Agatha had drawn.

Agatha knew better than to underestimate Fox.

Every five feet she earned, Fox clawed back four, her counterstrikes as relentless as they were precise.

It was a game of cat and mouse, their movements circling the jury like a carefully choreographed dance, each word spoken an adjustment, a feint, a recalibration.

But for now—for this fleeting moment—Agatha was ahead.

She knew it.

And Fox knew it.

But this morning was just a warm-up.

The real battle was about to begin.

Agatha rose to her feet.

“We call Harrison Smith to the stand.”

Agatha and the rest of the court room turned as Harrison Smith walked down the aisle, dressed in a sleek blue suit that fit him like a glove. His boyish charm was undeniable, his clean-cut features and hesitant smile toward the jury radiating an air of harmlessness.

Agatha fought the urge to roll her eyes at the performance.

Of course he was polished.

Of course he was perfectly packaged for the jury’s sympathy.

If Madeline Fox ever left the law, she’d make a fortune in dog training. Only Fox could take men this dangerous and reframe them as harmless, tail-wagging puppies.

She waited for him to adjust himself in the chair, his hands folding neatly on the edge of the stand as though he were posing for a magazine spread. The jury’s eyes were on him, already softening under the weight of his hesitant smile.

When he finally shifted, his gaze flicking nervously toward Fox, Agatha spoke.

“Good afternoon, Mr. Smith,” she said, her tone polite. She stepped forward, her heels clicking sharply against the courtroom floor, commanding attention with every movement.

Rio after all, picked an amazing outfit.

“Good afternoon,” Harrison replied, his voice smooth, rehearsed—almost too perfect.

Agatha arched a brow. Of course it was rehearsed. Everything about him screamed preparation, from the suit to the carefully calibrated smile.

“You’re the head of logistics at Vanguard Industries, correct?” she began, her tone deceptively casual.

“Yes, that’s correct,” Harrison replied, his smile widening just enough to flash teeth.

“And you’ve held that position for, what, three years now?”

“That’s right.”

“You must be quite the standout, Mr. Smith,” Agatha said, tilting her head slightly. “At thirty years old, already managing such a vital department at one of the country’s largest defense corporations. Quite impressive.”

“Thank you,” he said, his cheeks coloring faintly in what could have been feigned humility.

Agatha turned gracefully, walking back to the counsel table with her heels clicking sharply against the polished floor. She picked up a thick stack of papers, holding them up for the court to see, her expression one of calculated detachment.

“Mr. Smith,” she began, her voice calm but pointed, “here is a list of every employee currently working at Vanguard Industries.”

She allowed the weight of the stack to land audibly on the table, the sound reverberating through the silent courtroom.

The jury’s attention shifted from her to Harrison, who seemed to straighten slightly in his seat.

“My team,” Agatha continued, briefly thinking of Rio and the countless days she’d poured into combing through the data, “did some research.”

She let the words hang for just a moment before lifting her gaze back to Harrison.

“Off the top of your head, could you estimate the average age of individuals holding leadership positions at Vanguard? Positions equivalent to yours.”

Harrison’s hesitation was palpable. He blinked once, his jaw tightening just slightly as he shifted in his seat.

“Uh... I’d say somewhere in their... late-thirties or early-forties?” he guessed, his voice carrying just a touch of uncertainty.

Agatha tilted her head, her lips curling into a faint smile that didn’t reach her eyes.

“Late thirties,” she repeated, her tone almost thoughtful. “Interesting.”

She picked up another document from the stack, flipping through it slowly, deliberately, as if to prolong the silence just enough to make him sweat.

“Because,” she continued, lifting her gaze again to meet his, “our findings indicate that the average age at promotion for your level at the company is actually forty-eight. Quite a bit older than your twenty-seven, wouldn’t you agree?”

Harrison’s Adam’s apple bobbed as he swallowed, but he nodded slightly.

“I suppose so,” he said cautiously.

“And yet here you are,” Agatha said, gesturing toward him with an open hand, “managing logistics at one of the country’s largest corporations, years ahead of the curve. Truly remarkable.”

Fox shifted in her seat, her sharp gaze fixed on Agatha, who didn’t so much as glance in her direction.

“Tell me, Mr. Smith,” Agatha said, leaning forward slightly as she clasped her hands behind her back. “Do you think your friendship with Brandon Vanguard—your college roommate, no less—might have helped accelerate your rise to such an influential position at 27?”

The courtroom was silent, every pair of eyes fixed on Harrison.

“I... I don’t think so,” Harrison said after a beat, his voice tighter now. “I’d like to think I earned my position based on merit.”

Agatha let out a soft hum, neither affirming nor denying his statement. Instead, she turned, picking up yet another piece of evidence from the arsenal Rio had meticulously prepared for her.

“Well see if your merit speak for itself,” she said, handing it to the bailiff for distribution. The jury leaned forward as they examined the document—authored and signed by Harrison.

Fox’s expression didn’t falter, but Agatha saw it—the subtle tension in her jaw, the way her fingers tightened on her pen.

Agatha was about to drop a bomb, and Fox knew it.

Agatha held up a sheet of paper, unassuming in its simplicity. She approached the witness stand.

“This,” she began, holding the document up for the jury’s scrutiny before handing it to Harrison, “is one of your logistics reports, correct? Prepared and approved by you?”

Harrison leaned forward slightly, his fingers brushing the paper. He glanced over it, his lips thinning into a straight, carefully controlled line.

“Yes,” he replied, his tone measured. “That’s correct.”

Agatha tilted her head slightly, her expression sharp but feigning curiosity.

“Why is a senior manager writing reports, Mr. Smith? Shouldn’t you just be approving them?”

The question hung in the air like a loaded weapon. Harrison shifted, his discomfort flickering across his features for a split second before he masked it with a polished response.

“I still get my hands dirty with the logistics agents,” he answered smoothly, his voice carrying just enough humility to sound genuine. “It keeps me aware of any issues or bottlenecks my employees might be facing. And, frankly, I think my team appreciates a boss who isn’t afraid to get into the trenches with them.”

Agatha fought the urge to roll her eyes, but she could practically feel the smirk radiating from Fox across the room.

Of course.

Such a good fucking answer.

She hated it.

With a carefully neutral expression, she stepped closer, as if acknowledging the response but not letting it derail her momentum.

“Well, that’s admirable, Mr. Smith,” Agatha said smoothly, her tone cool, unbothered, though her mind raced ahead to her next move. “I’m sure your employees do appreciate it. But tell

me—when exactly do you find the time to personally draft these reports? Between overseeing an entire department and, as you said, being in the trenches?”

Harrison blinked, the faintest flicker of uncertainty flashing across his face.

“I, uh, prioritize,” he said after a beat. “I make time where it’s needed.”

Agatha tilted her head, her expression thoughtful, almost indulgent.

“Of course. Prioritization is key in any leadership role. So, if you’re personally drafting reports, I imagine these must be particularly important. Wouldn’t you agree?”

Harrison hesitated again, his jaw tightening.

“Yes,” he said carefully. “Important enough to require my direct attention.”

Agatha smiled—a slow, deliberate curve of her lips that sent a ripple of anticipation through the courtroom.

Agatha turned back to her desk, and reached for the next document. Lilia had it ready, sliding it into her hand without missing a beat. Agatha lifted it, holding it up for the jury, the dense text and numerous pages clearly visible even from a distance.

“This,” she began, her voice crisp and commanding, “is one of Vanguard’s standard logistics reports. You’re familiar with these, I assume, Mr. Smith?”

Harrison straightened in his seat as she walked toward him, the document extended. He took it, his fingers flipping through the thick stack of pages. His brow furrowed slightly as his eyes skimmed the densely packed data.

“Yes,” he said after a moment, his tone cautious. “It looks like one of our standard reports.”

Agatha clasped her hands behind her back, giving him a moment before tilting her head slightly. “How many pages would you say that is?”

Harrison hesitated, flipping to the back before glancing up.

“Twenty-two.”

She nodded, stepping closer.

“And would you agree it’s fairly detailed? Inventory, dates, itemized costs, carrier information—all laid out in exhaustive detail, correct?”

“Yes,” he said, his voice tightening.

Agatha turned to the jury, her tone shifting to one of conversational authority.

“Ladies and gentlemen, this is a logistics report for a shipment valued at ten point three million dollars. Twenty-two pages. Every item accounted for, every dollar explained.”

She returned her gaze to Harrison, her eyes narrowing slightly.

“Now, Mr. Smith,” she continued, “you mentioned earlier that you personally draft reports when they’re particularly important. Is that correct?”

“Yes,” Harrison said again, visibly bracing himself.

Agatha pivoted, reaching for another document. She held it up, this one noticeably thinner, almost flimsy in comparison to the first.

“And this,” she said, her tone sharpening, “is the report you personally wrote and signed for a shipment valued at eleven point two million dollars. One page long .”

She strode forward, placing the single-page document in front of him.

Harrison shifted uncomfortably in his seat, glancing at the single-page report in front of him as if it might offer some kind of escape.

“Yes,” he said slowly, his voice slightly uneven. “But that’s because—due to the nature of this particular shipment—it was entirely classified. National security protocols require us to keep certain details off the logs.”

Agatha nodded as though considering his words, but the sharp gleam in her eyes told a different story. She stepped closer to the jury, gesturing to the two reports she had presented earlier.

“I see,” she said, her tone calm but edged with skepticism. “National security. Certainly a valid concern for a company like Vanguard. But let me ask you this, Mr. Smith.”

She turned back to face him, her heels clicking with purpose.

“In the 23-page report we reviewed earlier—the one for a $10.3 million shipment—there are ten items labeled as ‘logistic supplies,’ totaling $789,000. The rest of the cargo, however, includes meticulously detailed entries: missiles, drones, top-of-the-line surveillance gear. Each item explicitly listed, down to the model and serial numbers.”

She let her words hang for a moment, then took a step closer to the witness stand.

“Would it surprise you to learn that my team”—her lips curved into a faint smile as Rio crossed her mind—“reviewed every single logistics report filed over the last three years? And that in every single case where Vanguard cited ‘logistic supplies’ or ‘security hardware,’ they accounted for less than 5% of the reported cargo?”

Harrison opened his mouth, but no words came. He hesitated, clearly trying to formulate a response, when Fox’s voice cut through the courtroom.

“Objection.” Fox’s tone was sharp, clipped. “Is counsel testifying, or is she going to ask a question?”

Judge Marks barely glanced up.

“Move it along, Ms. Harkness.”

Agatha didn’t miss a beat, her smile tightening as she turned back to Harrison.

“Mr. Smith,” she said smoothly, her voice ringing with quiet authority, “the average shipping report for Vanguard contains only 5% classified material. But this report”—she pointed toward the single-page document still sitting before him—“claims the entire ship’s cargo is confidential. Is that correct?”

Harrison fidgeted again, his shoulders stiffening as his eyes flicked down to the stack of reports Agatha had placed before him. His hand hovered for a moment before reluctantly taking the documents.

“Yes,” he said finally, his voice barely above a murmur. “That’s correct.”

Agatha nodded slowly, her expression sharp and calculating as she moved back to her desk. Lilia was already there, sliding a stack of reports into her hand like clockwork. But instead of approaching Harrison immediately, Agatha leaned casually against the table, letting the tension in the room simmer.

“When you select the reports to write, Mr. Smith, do you have certain accounts you prefer to manage, or do you simply help wherever your team needs assistance?” she asked, her tone deceptively light.

Harrison shifted uncomfortably in his seat.

“I just help where the team needs help,” he said carefully.

“So, you don’t choose?”

“Objection—asked and answered,” Fox interjected, her voice cutting through the room.

“Sustained,” Judge Marks said firmly. “Move it along, Ms. Harkness.”

Agatha turned her head slightly, giving the judge a brief nod of acknowledgment before pivoting back to Harrison.

“Do you believe in luck, Mr. Smith?”

A scoff sounded from Fox’s side of the courtroom, and Agatha could practically feel her opponent bristle beside her. Good.

Harrison blinked at the question, clearly thrown.

“I—I guess so,” he said hesitantly, his voice shaky. “I don’t know if I believe in luck as much as I believe in just... working toward what you want.”

Agatha’s smirk deepened, the predator in her sensing blood. God, he just set himself up.

“‘ Working toward what you want ,’” she repeated, her voice slow, deliberate, as if savoring the words. She took a step forward and extended her hand toward the stack of reports he was now holding.

“So, tell me, Mr. Smith—would you call it luck that you— and only you —are the logistics agent who files reports on the Meridian Star ? The same ship that carries tens of millions in ‘only classified cargo’ almost bi-weekly for three years? Or would you say you ‘ worked toward what you wanted ,’ ensuring that no one else writes these reports but you?”

The question lingered in the air, each second of silence stretching longer than the last. Harrison’s throat bobbed as he swallowed hard, his face pale under the weight of the courtroom’s collective gaze.

His silence spoke louder than any denial could.

Agatha didn’t need him to answer.

She already had him cornered.

"Mr. Smith," Agatha began, her voice cutting through the charged atmosphere, "were you aware that Brooke Sinclair flagged one of these reports when she noticed the account number didn’t align with any known accounts, and the ‘vague itemization’ raised concerns for her?"

Harrison shifted uncomfortably in his seat, his hands tightening on the edges of the witness stand.

"I was aware," he admitted, his tone guarded. "She worked in a different department than my team, but her supervisor did escalate it to me. I worked with her, and due to the confidential nature of the manifest—"

Agatha cut in smoothly, her tone cool but pointed.

"Confidential or not, she flagged the report, didn’t she? She raised questions about the validity of the account number and the lack of transparency in the itemization."

Harrison nodded, though reluctantly.

"Yes, she did."

Agatha raised her eyebrows, leaning slightly against the edge of her table as if settling in for a particularly interesting story.

Agatha took a step closer, her heels clicking deliberately on the floor.

"And what exactly did you do in response to her concerns?"

Harrison hesitated, his jaw tightening.

"I explained to her that certain logistics details are classified, as per company policy. I assured her that the proper protocols were followed and that there was no need for concern."

Agatha tilted her head, her eyes narrowing.

"You assured her? And did that satisfy her concerns, Mr. Smith?"

“Yes,” he replied, a touch too quickly. “As far as I could tell, she understood the explanation and moved on.”

Agatha nodded slowly, as though considering his response. Then she straightened, her posture tightening as her tone took on an edge.

“And yet, Mr. Smith,” she said, stepping closer to the witness stand and fixing him with an unrelenting stare, “a week later, Brooke Sinclair flagged another one of your reports. This time, she took her concerns directly to James Hughes, didn’t she?”

Harrison froze for a beat, his mouth opening slightly before he seemed to catch himself.

“I—I wasn’t aware of that.”

Agatha arched an eyebrow.

“You weren’t aware that she raised her concerns about your report with Vanguard’s Head of Security?”

“No,” he said, his voice wavering slightly. “That wasn’t brought to my attention.”

Agatha’s lips curved into a small, sharp smile.

“Interesting. Because emails between Ms. Sinclair and Mr. Hughes, obtained during discovery, show that she explicitly questioned discrepancies in your report. Would you like me to read them for the court?”

Harrison’s face drained of color. Fox immediately rose.

“Objection, Your Honor. This line of questioning is argumentative and speculative without proper context.”

“Overruled,” Judge Marks said, his tone measured but firm. “Proceed, Ms. Harkness.”

Agatha held up a printout, her movements deliberate.

“In one email, dated five days before her death, Brooke Sinclair wrote, and I quote, ‘ This manifest doesn’t align with standard protocols. The vague itemization and missing account details are alarming. I believe this warrants further investigation .’”

She let the words hang, her eyes boring into Harrison’s pale face.

“Mr. Smith,” Agatha said, her voice quiet but icy, “do you still believe Brooke Sinclair was ‘satisfied’ with your explanation?”

The courtroom fell silent. Harrison sat frozen, his lips parting slightly as if to respond, but no words came out.

The weight of Agatha’s question hung in the air, suffocating and inescapable.

Agatha’s gaze didn’t waver.

When Harrison finally attempted to speak, it was little more than a stammer, his carefully rehearsed composure beginning to crack.

“I—uh, well, I mean—”

Agatha took a deliberate step forward, cutting him off smoothly but firmly.

“Mr. Smith,” she began, her voice steady and razor-sharp, “in front of you, you have over 100 logistics reports, all authored and approved by you for the Meridian Star’s cargo. However,” she paused for effect, letting the silence stretch just long enough for everyone to hang on her next words, “you are not the final approver, are you?”

Harrison shifted in his seat.

“No,” he admitted, his voice barely above a murmur.

“These reports,” Agatha continued, stepping closer, her tone growing sharper with each word, “typically require two additional signatures—one from a member of senior leadership and another from security to confirm the contents and approve the course of direction. Correct?”

Harrison fidgeted, his fingers curling against the edges of the stack before him.

“Yes.”

Agatha tilted her head slightly, her smile razor-sharp.

“Please read the leadership approval on your report. Pick any one—it doesn’t matter.”

He hesitated before reaching for the top report, his hands trembling ever so slightly as he flipped to the signature page.

“Brandon Vanguard,” Harrison finally said, his voice cracking just enough to betray him.

The courtroom fell deathly silent, as though the very walls were holding their breath.

Agatha tilted her head ever so slightly, her eyes sharp as a blade.

“And the security sign-off?” she pressed, her voice calm, almost conversational—a stark contrast to the storm brewing beneath.

Harrison hesitated, his eyes darting briefly toward Fox, who sat rigid, her face impassive yet brimming with restrained fury.

There was no lifeline for him here, no escape.

“James Hughes,” he said finally, the name falling from his lips like a stone sinking into dark waters.

The mention of that name made Agatha’s stomach churn, revulsion crawling under her skin. But she didn’t let it show—not even for a second. She took a deliberate step forward, her heels clicking against the polished floor, the sound echoing like a ticking clock.

“James Hughes,” she repeated, her voice quieter now, but no less piercing. “The Head of Security at Vanguard Industries. The same James Hughes to whom Brooke Sinclair escalated her concerns. Is that correct?”

Harrison’s Adam’s apple bobbed as he swallowed hard, his discomfort visible for all to see.

“Yes,” he croaked.

Agatha let the admission hang in the air, heavy and damning. She moved to the edge of the jury box, her gaze sweeping across their faces, ensuring they felt the gravity of every word spoken.

“Grab another report,” she instructed, her voice steady. “Let’s see who signed that one.”

Harrison swallowed hard but complied, pulling another report from the stack.

“Brandon Vanguard and James Hughes,” he read aloud, his tone flat but strained.

Agatha didn’t miss a beat. She stepped forward, plucking a random report from the middle of the stack.

“And this one?” she asked, handing it to him.

Harrison’s fingers trembled as he scanned the page.

“Brandon Vanguard and James Hughes.”

Agatha raised her eyebrows, her lips curving into a faint smirk.

“Let’s try from the bottom, shall we?”

“Objection!” Fox’s voice rang out, sharp and tinged with exasperation. “This is a waste of the court’s time.”

Agatha turned toward Judge Marks with the measured grace of someone who knew exactly how to wield the room’s attention. Her expression was composed, deliberate, her voice steady yet cutting.

“Your Honor, I agree. To save the court’s time, we will stipulate that all 123 one-page reports authored and approved by Mr. Smith—each connected to the Meridian Star cargo carrier and containing vague classifications such as ‘logistics supplies’ and ‘security hardware’—share one undeniable commonality. Every single one bears the signatures of Brandon Vanguard and James Hughes.”

A ripple of murmurs spread through the courtroom.

“Mrs. Fox?” Judge Marks prompted, turning his attention to the opposing counsel.

Fox hesitated, her jaw tightening as she weighed her options.

“We will stipulate that for now,” she said finally, her voice clipped, “but reserve the right to retract pending verification of those signatures.”

“So stipulated,” Judge Marks said with a nod, before turning back to Agatha. “Anything else for the witness, Ms. Harkness?”

Agatha smiled, slow and predatory, the kind that made people sit up straighter, bracing themselves for what was coming next. She raised a single finger, her movements precise as she pivoted toward Harrison.

“Just one,” she said, her tone deceptively light.

She stepped closer to the witness stand, her eyes locking onto Harrison’s.

The silence in the courtroom was deafening, the tension coiled tight as a spring.

“Mr. Smith,” she began, her voice low but cutting enough to slice through charged air, “would you say it was luck that Brooke Sinclair died before she could escalate her concerns even further? Or would you call it what you just described earlier—‘ good old-fashioned working toward what you want ?’”

The question hit the room like a semitruck into one of those electric clown cars—and the collective gasp from the gallery confirmed it. All eyes turned to Harrison, whose face drained of color, his mouth opening and closing as if searching for a response that would not damn him further.

“Objection!” Fox’s voice rang out, sharp and desperate, with a thin veneer of control barely masking her frustration. “Argumentative! Counsel is clearly attempting to inflame the jury with baseless accusations.”

Agatha didn’t so much as blink.

Instead, she turned to Judge Marks seeing the warning look.

“Withdrawn,” she said smoothly, though the smirk tugging at the corner of her lips hinted that she knew the damage was already done. The words she’d left hanging in the air had planted themselves firmly in the jury’s minds, like red wine spilled on cream carpet, impossible to erase.

“No further questions, Your Honor,” she added, her tone crisp and biting as she cast a final, scathing glance at Harrison Smith before striding back to her table.

Her heels clicked against the courtroom floor, each step radiating a confidence that only deepened when she got closer to Fox and Ratcliff.

Agatha didn’t need to look back to know she’d rattled her opponent.

The tension was practically tangible.

But when she finally did glance over, she was greeted with the sight of Fox exchanging hushed words with Ratcliff, her frustration written in every sharp gesture, her mask of composure slipping just enough to reveal cracks.

And for the first time, Agatha saw it.

Fox was floundering.

There was no regaining control here—Agatha was pulling ahead, and Fox knew it.

“Mrs. Fox, any questions?” Judge Marks prompted.

Fox hesitated, clearly startled, and Agatha felt a surge of satisfaction ripple through her. She leaned back slightly in her chair, her smirk widening as Fox glanced at Ratcliff, their conversation growing quieter but more visibly strained.

Finally, Fox rose to her feet with a forced calm that didn’t quite meet her eyes.

“No questions at this time, Your Honor,” she said stiffly. “We reserve the right to recall Mr. Smith after reviewing the reports in detail.”

“Granted,” Judge Marks replied, dismissing Harrison Smith with a wave of his hand. “Ms. Harkness, call your next witness.”

Agatha felt the victory settle over her shoulders like a familiar mantle, but it wasn’t without weight. A nervous coil twisted low in her stomach as she straightened, her broken hand flexing instinctively against the cast as she cleared her throat to call the next—and final witness.

“We call James Hughes to the stand,” she announced, her voice steady, though the gravity of the moment sent a ripple of tension down her spine.

The doors at the back of the courtroom opened, and all eyes turned toward them.

James Hughes strode down the aisle, dressed in a sleek black suit that did nothing to mask the swelling around his nose or the deep bruises under his eyes. Agatha’s gaze flicked upward, locking onto his face, and she felt the smallest, sharpest thrill.

She’d done that.

A slow, deliberate smirk spread across Agatha’s lips as he passed, her gaze locking onto his with an intensity that made the tension in the courtroom practically hum.

James Hughes glared back at her, his expression a volatile mix of resentment and barely concealed rage.

Her smirk deepened, her fingers instinctively brushing the edge of her cast—a quiet reminder of the satisfying crack that had reverberated through her fist just yesterday.

She watched as James Hughes strode to the witness chair. He settled into the seat, his gaze locking onto hers, sharp and defiant.

For a moment, the courtroom seemed to fade, the air between them charged. And then, like a flame sparking in the dark, Rio’s words echoed in her mind, steady and sure, filling her chest with fire.

"Go get ’em, killer."

Agatha’s smirk widened into something lethal.

Oh...she was going to fucking destroy him.

Chapter End Notes

Thoughts? I really love writing Agatha in court. I just love how she commands a scene and she may not have any magical powers in this story, I feel like she certainly has a flare for magic when in her element as a lawyer.

A Door Appears

Agatha leaned back slightly in her chair, savoring the moment like the most expensive bottle of whiskey she owned. The one that she only broke out for special occasions.

James Hughes sat before her, visibly bristling beneath his carefully composed exterior, but it wasn’t just his discomfort she was savoring—it was the sheer gravity of what this moment represented.

James Hughes was so many things to her.

At first, she thought Vanguard itself was her ultimate target—her great adversary. But when Rio had pulled back the curtain on the company’s underbelly, her focus had shifted. Her white whale wasn’t Vanguard. It wasn’t even Brandon Vanguard or Harrison Smith, as much as she’d relished taking them apart piece by piece.

No, the real prize, the true puppet master pulling every blood-soaked string, was sitting right in front of her.

James. Fucking. Hughes.

In the beginning, Brandon Vanguard, Harrison Smith, and James Hughes had always reminded her of that three-headed dog from Harry Potter—what was it called?

Ah yes, Fluffy.

Together, they guarded their arms smuggling empire they’d built, the so-called “stone” of their operation. But Agatha’s gut, that instinct she trusted more than any piece of evidence, told her the truth.

Hughes wasn’t one of the heads.

He was the brains.

The Voldemort of this twisted operation.

God—she really needed to stop reading Harry Potter to her son.

But now that the metaphor had taken root, she wasn’t about to let it go.

Because, like Voldemort, Hughes had made the ultimate mistake: he’d come for her family.

The bastard had threatened Nicky.

And worse, he had actually tried to kill Rio.

But this is where this analogy stopped.

Because Agatha wasn’t some naive, broomstick-clutching eleven-year-old who thought she could take down the ultimate dark wizard with luck and courage.

No.

She was everything the rumors whispered about her.

She was the Witch of Wall Street.

She was powerful.

She was merciless.

She was relentless.

And most importantly—she always, always , finished what she started.

Agatha’s lips curved as her nails rapped on the table in a restless movement before she stood, smoothing the lines of her plum pants. Her heels clicked against the courtroom floor with the precision of a metronome.

Click. Click. Click.

Each step drew the jury’s attention.

She turned to face him fully, her gaze locking onto his. And for just a moment, she let the silence stretch savoring the tension— the anticipation.

Then, ever so slowly, her lips curved into a predatory smile.

“Well, Mr. Hughes,” she began, her voice just as sharp as her smile, “shall we begin?”

Hughes just stared at her that flicker of defiance still shining in his eyes.

And god , if that didn’t send a pleased thrill down her spine.

She loved when they thought they could hold their ground against it her.

It made tearing them apart so much sweeter.

“You are the Head of Security at Vanguard, correct?” she asked, her tone innocuous, like she was just ticking off a box.

Hughes’s jaw tightened. For a moment, she thought he might not answer, but then he gave a stiff nod.

“Yes,” he said, his voice clipped.

One-word answers.

Smarter than his peers.

But she wasn’t worried.

She just needed to pry him open like a stuck pickle jar—and everyone knew the best way to unstick a pickle jar was to slam the lid on the countertop.

Her gaze flickered briefly to his face, taking in the bruises, the swollen nose, the undeniable evidence of her fist meeting his face. She resisted the urge to smirk, fighting it back with every ounce of willpower.

Time to give him a little tippy-tap on the metaphorical countertop.

“The injury to your face looks painful,” Agatha said, her voice laced with feigned concern, her expression a perfect mask of mock sympathy. “Did you get that at work?”

The words had barely left her lips when the courtroom erupted into motion.

“Objection!” Fox shot to her feet, her voice sharp and furious, the word echoing off vaulted ceilings like a god damn opera house.

“Ms. Harkness!” Judge Marks barked, his tone clearly unimpressed.

But Agatha didn’t flinch.

She didn’t even blink.

Her focus was singular—locked on James Hughes.

His reaction was all she cared about.

And — there — it — was .

His eyes narrowed, his jaw clenched, and his lip curled into a snarl—a visceral, unrestrained display of the fury she’d been hoping to bring out.

Agatha’s chest filled with satisfaction, allowing the evil smirk she was holding back to curl slowly and fucking deliberately.

She wanted him to see it, to feel it, to know exactly who had just gotten under his skin.

Judge Marks was most certainly going to rip her apart in a second, but she couldn’t bring herself to care.

Worth it.

Every bit of it.

The jar was officially loosened.

“Counsel,” Judge Marks said, his tone sharp and scolding. “Bench. Now .”

Agatha turned away from Hughes calmly, though the cockiness in her stride faltered just slightly under the weight of Judge Marks’ glare. As she approached the bench, she caught the soft sound of footsteps behind her—Fox, moving to walk next to her. Their shoulders nearly brushed as Fox leaned in just enough to murmur under her breath.

“You have balls, Harkness,” she muttered, a hint of reluctant admiration in her tone. “I’ll give you that.”

Agatha’s lips twitched, a brief flicker of amusement threatening to break through her composed exterior.

But there was no time to bask in the rare compliment from Madeline Fox. Because like a coin flipped in midair, as soon as they reached the bench, Fox’s demeanor changed entirely.

“Your Honor,” Fox began, her voice brimming with indignation, “Ms. Harkness is blatantly baiting the witness. Yesterday’s events were to be explicitly kept from the jury to not prejudice my client with opposing counsels' baseless accusations. Her reckless disregard for this court’s instructions is—”

Judge Marks exhaled heavily, raising a hand to cut off Fox mid-rant.

Her words died instantly, though the heat in her glare remained fixed on Agatha.

“ Ms. Harkness ,” Marks said, the simmering warning in his tone clear as he leaned forward slightly, his gaze locked onto hers. “Let me make myself crystal clear. If you so much as hint at yesterday’s events again—if you even think about dancing near that line with your clever little word games—I will not just fine you, I will hold you in contempt.”

His voice dropped further, the weight of his words pressing down like a gavel.

“And unlike the last time I held you in contempt— you will go to jail ,” he said, his gaze locked onto hers. “And not only that, but I will personally ensure my sheriffs escort you to the dirtiest, most uncomfortable cell the great city of New York has to offer.”

Then, with a slow exhale, he continued, his voice as sharp as ever.

“And, as I’m sure you’re aware, paperwork moves slow down there. So don’t test me, Ms. Harkness. Am I making myself clear?”

Judge Marks’s words hung heavy in the air, filled with enough warning and bite to make even her pause.

Agatha was a master at walking the line—no, she fucking lived on it .

That razor-thin boundary where control and chaos teetered, where risk flirted with reward. She loved that line, thrived on it, and danced along its edges with a near manic grin. But Agatha knew, the line was different for everyone, and for most, she relished in finding out what lay on the other side.

But Judge Marks?

He was one of the rare few where crossing the line wasn’t a game. With Judge Marks, she had no desire to find out what waited on the other side.

So, she nodded, keeping her expression neutral.

“I understand, Judge,” she said, making sure to lace her tone with just enough contrition to be believable.

Marks studied her for a long moment, his eyes narrowing as if trying to gauge the sincerity of her words. The silence stretched between them before he finally leaned back in his chair and gave her a curt nod.

“Continue with your questioning, Ms. Harkness. But tread carefully ,” Judge Marks warned.

Agatha gave a nod, her gaze snapping briefly to Fox. She threw her a pointed look as they stepped back from the bench. Only when Fox was seated again, Agatha pivoted her focus back to James Hughes.

“Mr. Hughes,” she began, her voice steady, “what does the Head of Security at Vanguard actually do?”

Hughes shifted in his seat, his movements stiff, his jaw tightening before he answered with a gruff voice.

“Due to the nature of Vanguard’s work,” he started, his tone laced with well rehearsed authority, “we must ensure that the weapons we create are protected from our enemies both internal and overseas. I oversee all surveillance and security at our warehouses. Additionally, I ensure that when transporting those weapons—whether by ground or sea—they are safeguarded. That is my job, Ms. Harkness. I protect.”

Agatha’s lips twitched slightly at his choice of words.

Protect.

What a joke.

Agatha leaned forward slightly, her eyes sharpening as she let her next question roll out.

“To be in such a vital position at Vanguard, one would assume you have some experience in law enforcement, security, or the military. Is that a correct assumption, Mr. Hughes?”

Hughes answered without missing a beat.

“I was a captain in the Marines. Served 15 years. Retired. I completed three tours in Iraq. Special forces.”

Agatha nodded, her jaw tightening briefly before she forced out the words, her voice professional but clipped.

“Thank you for your service, Mr. Hughes.”

He didn’t acknowledge her thanks—not a nod, not a glance. He simply stared back at her, impassive.

Good.

She didn’t mean it.

Agatha let the silence hang for a moment before tilting her head slightly, her tone turning curious but no less pointed.

“When you say special forces, are you referring to a branch of the military called a Marine Raider?”

The slightest flicker of surprise crossed Hughes’s face. It was brief—so brief most people wouldn’t have noticed—but Agatha did. She knew she’d thrown him off.

He swallowed, his Adam’s Apple bobbing, before replying.

“Yes. For five years.”

Agatha nodded again, already knowing the answer. It had taken a ridiculous amount of favors and no small amount of leverage to unearth that piece of his past. Her government contacts had pulled strings she didn’t even know existed, and she was certain the debt she owed them now was a ticking time bomb waiting to explode.

Because if you thought Wall Street was filthy, the government? It was a fucking cesspool.

But it would be worth it in the end.

Agatha’s eyes bore into Hughes as she leaned casually against her table.

“What does a Marine Raider do, exactly?” she asked, her tone deceptively light. Then, without missing a beat, she added, “The unclassified version, of course.”

Hughes’s jaw ticked.

It was subtle, but Agatha caught it. He didn’t like being cornered, and she was dragging him there, inch by inch.

“A Marine Raider,” he began, his voice still gruff but now more measured, “is responsible for direct action missions, special reconnaissance, and foreign internal defense. We’re trained to operate in hostile environments and neutralize high-value targets. Among other things.”

“ Among other things ,” Agatha repeated not for her but for the jury, her tone carefully neutral, though her lips twitched in amusement at his vague deflection.

She took a step forward.

“So, essentially,” she continued, “you’re highly trained to assess threats, execute operations with precision, and ensure mission success by any means necessary. Would you agree with that summary, Mr. Hughes?”

He shifted slightly, his posture still rigid.

“Yes.”

Agatha paused, letting the weight of that admission settle over the courtroom.

“And would you say those skills translate well into your current role at Vanguard?” she asked, her voice smooth, almost conversational, as if she weren’t about to tie a noose with his own words.

“They do.”

Agatha nodded, the familiar curl of excitement stirring in her chest—the thrill of laying the foundation for her case.

She was building something here—brick by deliberate brick.

This wasn’t a criminal case, she didn’t need to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that James Hughes was responsible for Brooke Sinclair’s death. This was a civil case, and all she needed was a preponderance of the evidence—a tipping of the scales that suggested her version of events was more likely than his.

Agatha returned to the table, retrieving one of Harrison Smith's one-page logistics reports for the Meridian Star . She held it up, letting the jury take in the familiar document before turning her attention back to Hughes.

“Do you sign all logistics reports, Mr. Hughes?” she asked.

“No,” he replied, his voice clipped. “That would be impossible with the sheer amount of work we do—I’m only one person. I have lower-level managers who sign off.”

Agatha nodded, taking a few measured steps forward.

“So, you don’t sign any reports yourself?”

“I didn’t say that,” Hughes snapped, his words coming out a little too harshly before he quickly caught himself.

He exhaled, steadying his tone.

“I sign off on our larger-level projects—depending on the cargo or if the destination is flagged as hostile.”

Agatha’s lips curved faintly, her gaze sharpening.

“I see. So, your signature indicates a higher level of scrutiny? That a shipment is significant enough to require your personal approval?”

Hughes nodded stiffly.

“Yes.”

Agatha let the moment breathe, her silence deliberate as she scanned the jury, letting the weight of his words hang in the air. Then, she turned her attention back to Hughes, the report still in her hand.

“When a signature is placed on a logistics report,” she began, her tone thoughtful yet probing, “what does that mean, exactly? What do you and your team evaluate before approving a report?”

Hughes shifted in his seat, clearly considering his response.

“We look at the cargo contents,” he said carefully, his voice steady but guarded. “We evaluate the destination, assess current threats. We coordinate with the military and the Department of Defense to ensure they are aware of our cargo’s movement. And we select the best path to ensure the shipment reaches its destination safely.”

Agatha nodded, her expression composed, though her mind buzzed with precision.

“So, you’re telling this court that every signed logistics report represents a comprehensive review—cargo, route, security, coordination with external agencies—all of it?”

“Yes,” Hughes affirmed, though a faint edge of impatience colored his tone.

Perfect .

Right where she wanted him.

Agatha turned, walking back to her table where Lilia handed her a neatly prepared, vividly color-coded diagram that Rio had painstakingly put together. It compared one of the Meridian Star’s routes to a standard Vanguard cargo run.

She strode forward with purpose, handing one copy to Hughes while placing another on the display for the jury to see.

“Mr. Hughes,” she began, as she gestured to the diagram, “on this chart, you’ll notice two lines across the Atlantic Ocean. The green line represents the Queen’s Voyager , a cargo ship carrying $11.3 million worth of equipment. All details for this shipment were meticulously laid out in the standard 23-page logistics report we reviewed earlier. The ship departed from New York on June 7th and arrived at Camp Lemonnier in Africa 15 days later.”

She paused, letting Hughes and the jury absorb the clear trajectory marked on the chart.

“Would you consider this route and timeframe typical for a Vanguard shipment of this scale?”

Hughes glanced down at the chart, his jaw tightening slightly before answering.

“Yes, that’s a standard route and timeframe.”

Agatha’s lips curved ever so slightly—a predator circling its prey.

“Thank you,” she said, her voice cool and sharp. She pivoted slightly, her hand now gesturing to the red line on the diagram, that was all over the place on the document.

“And this,” she continued, her tone hardening, “is the Meridian Star’s trajectory. A cargo ship carrying $11.2 million in ‘ classified materials ,’ according to your one-page report. It departed from New York on April 12th, and arrived at the same destination.”

She paused again, this time locking her gaze on Hughes.

“Do you notice anything... unusual about this path, Mr. Hughes?”

Hughes shifted in his seat, his eyes darting from the diagram in his hands to the one displayed for the jury. His jaw worked slightly as he stared at the red line, its erratic path unmistakably out of sync with the efficient trajectory of the green line.

“It’s not... standard,” he admitted, his voice tight.

Agatha tilted her head, her expression carefully neutral.

“Not standard. That’s one way to put it.”

She took a step closer to the jury, letting the diagram stay in their view.

“The Meridian Star’s route, as you can see, took nearly double the time of the Queen’s Voyager to reach the exact same destination—28 days instead of 15.”

She turned back to Hughes, her eyes narrowing slightly.

“Mr. Hughes, can you explain why a ship carrying ‘classified materials,’ requiring such high levels of security and oversight, would take an indirect, erratic path across the Atlantic Ocean, extending its journey by almost two weeks?”

Hughes fidgeted, his hand gripping the edge of the witness stand.

“There could be several reasons for that,” he said cautiously. “Weather, unexpected logistical changes, ensuring the ship avoided potential hostile territories.”

Agatha let his answer hang in the air for a moment before stepping forward again, her heels clicking with deliberate precision.

“Interesting. Because according to meteorological records, the weather was clear on the Meridian Star’s entire route during that time. And Vanguard’s own internal communications show no mention of logistical changes. In fact...”

She returned to her table, picking up a new document with a flourish.

“...this internal memo dated April 11th states that the Meridian Star’s path was pre-approved by security management. Care to guess whose signature authorized that pre-approval?”

Hughes’ jaw tightened, and a flicker of discomfort passed over his face.

“Yours, Mr. Hughes,” Agatha said, her voice sharp. “So, again, I ask you—why would you send a ship carrying $11.2 million in ‘classified materials’ on a route that doubled its travel time? Was it really about avoiding potential risks? Or were there... other reasons?”

Fox immediately rose to her feet.

“Objection, Your Honor. Counsel is clearly speculating!”

Judge Marks raised a hand to Fox but kept his focus on Agatha.

“Move it along, Ms. Harkness.”

She walked back to the table, her heels clicking with a deliberate rhythm, and picked up a neatly organized stack of cargo paths Rio had meticulously created for the Meridian Star .

Turning back to Hughes, she approached the witness stand slowly, her expression sharp but calm, every move calculated.

“Mr. Hughes,” she began, holding up one of the diagrams for the jury to see, “would it surprise you to learn that the Meridian Star —regardless of date, weather, or geopolitical climate—routinely takes two, sometimes three, times as long as a standard cargo ship to reach its destination?”

Hughes’ lips pressed together so tightly they nearly disappeared, his discomfort palpable.

“Yes,” he said after a moment, his voice clipped. “That does surprise me.”

Agatha’s eyes gleamed as she set the records down and reached for the stack of logistics reports authored by Harrison Smith. She lifted them with a deliberate flair, the weight of the evidence clear in her posture as she approached him.

“Why would that surprise you, Mr. Hughes?” she asked, pausing just long enough to let the tension stretch.

“After all...”

She placed the stack of reports directly in front of him with a soft thud, her voice dropping into something quieter, sharper.

“You approved the path for every single one.”

Hughes’ jaw tightened, the faintest flicker of something—panic, perhaps—passing through his eyes before he schooled his expression.

Agatha relished the crack in his composure, knowing she was beginning to pry the lid off the jar.

She stepped back, letting the jury absorb the weight of her words, before continuing.

“So, tell us, Mr. Hughes—why would want the Meridian Star , a ship carrying sensitive and classified cargo under your direct approval, to take such an inefficient, erratic route?”

She folded her arms, her gaze unrelenting.

Mr. Hughes cleared his throat, his voice carefully controlled as he responded,

“It’s not standard. But the nature of our work can’t always accommodate a procedure. Sometimes adjustments are necessary.”

Agatha tilted her head slightly, her lips curving into a small, calculated smile.

“But every time, Mr. Hughes? Doesn’t that seem... suspicious?”

“Objection!” Fox shot to her feet, her voice sharp. “Counsel is asking the witness to speculate.”

Agatha didn’t miss a beat.

She turned to the judge.

“Your Honor, Mr. Hughes is a highly trained military professional. He is, quite literally, an expert witness in speculation.”

The murmurs that rippled through the courtroom were immediate, and Judge Marks raised a hand for silence. His eyes narrowed at Agatha, a warning in his gaze, but his tone was even as he replied.

“I’ll allow it,” he said finally, though his voice carried an edge of caution. “But tread carefully, Ms. Harkness.”

Agatha turned back to Hughes, her gaze locking onto his with a sharpness that made him visibly stiffen.

“Answer the question, Mr. Hughes,” she said, baiting him. “Using your long history in the military and examining intel, doesn’t it seem suspicious to you that every single route taken by the Meridian Star deviates so drastically from standard procedure?”

Hughes hesitated, the tension in the room thickening as he struggled to find a response. His lips parted, but no words came immediately.

Agatha was getting closer, and she wasn’t about to let him wriggle free now.

Hughes finally exhaled, his jaw tightening as he leaned slightly forward.
