“It’s... unusual,” he admitted, his voice measured but strained. “But I wouldn’t immediately classify it as suspicious. There are many factors that could contribute to deviations.”

Agatha’s eyebrow arched.

“ Unusual ,” she repeated, letting the word hang in the air like a cloud.

The courtroom was silent, every pair of eyes locked on Hughes.

Agatha’s expression didn’t change, though inside, the shift in gears felt like sliding a blade under a gap in armor— strategic .

She tilted her head slightly, her voice calm.

“Did you know Brooke Sinclair?”

Hughes straightened immediately at the sudden change in questioning.

“No, I never met her. But I did read the email that was escalated to me. I was just looking into investigating when I found out about her suicide.”

Agatha paused, letting his words hang in the room before taking a slow step closer to the witness stand.

“So, just to clarify for the jury, you’re telling us that you never met Brooke Sinclair?”

“That’s correct.”

Agatha’s lips curled into a faint, calculated smile.

“Interesting,” Agatha said, pacing slowly.

She stopped near the jury box, her gaze sharp and calculating.

“Back to your military background, Mr. Hughes. From what I’ve learned about Marine Raiders, their expertise isn’t limited to just protecting assets. They excel in strategic offensives—calculated moves to neutralize threats before they can even become a problem. Would you say that’s an accurate description?”

Hughes exhaled deeply through his nose.

“Yes.”

Agatha tilted her head, her lips curling into a faint, knowing smile.

She turned and walked back to her desk. Lilia was already holding out the flash drive, and Agatha took it with a small nod of gratitude before handing it to the courtroom clerk.

“Could you display this on the monitor, please?” she asked, her tone calm but carrying an undercurrent of anticipation.

The courtroom clerk nodded, moving to the large flat-screen TV bolted to the wall, positioned perfectly for the jury and the witness to view. Meanwhile, Agatha leaned against her table, her fingers tapping softly on the wooden surface. Her gaze bore into Hughes, who stared back, his expression stoic but Agatha could see the flicker of unease in his eyes.

Oh, she was going to bury him.

“It’s all set, Ms. Harkness,” the clerk said, breaking the silence.

Agatha nodded her thanks, taking the pointer remote and gesturing toward the screen, which displayed a grainy, black-and-white video feed of a quiet, unassuming street. The jury leaned forward, their interest piqued, as Agatha stepped closer to the monitor.

“Mr. Hughes, do you recognize this street?” she asked.

Hughes scoffed lightly.

“No, it looks like any other street.”

Agatha nodded, as she picked up an affidavit from her desk, before carrying it up to the judge.

“This,” she began, holding the paper aloft for the courtroom to see, “is an affidavit signed by Amit Kannan, owner of the Quick Stop market on the corner of Berkley and Kline Street, here in New York City. Mr. Kannan attests that the footage was taken by my associate Rio Vidal on October 12th.”

She paused, turning slightly to point at the TV screen where the grainy footage of a street corner stood frozen.

“This camera,” she continued, “is positioned to capture activity on Berkley Street.”

She paused, turning back to face the room.

“Brooke Sinclair lived on Berkley Street. Her townhome isn’t visible in this footage, but it’s just three houses up from where the camera cuts off. So, anyone walking toward the camera would be heading directly toward Brooke Sinclair’s home.”

She pivoted to James Hughes, her gaze sharp and unwavering.

“Mr. Hughes,” she said, her voice soft but cutting, “can you read the timestamp in the top- right corner for us?”

Hughes squinted slightly, leaning forward. The hesitation was small, but Agatha didn’t miss it.

“July 18th, 2019, 9:13 PM,” he said, his voice carefully neutral.

“And where were you on July 18th, 2019, at approximately 9:13 PM?” asked Agatha.

Hughes immediately shook his head.

“That was over five years ago,” he said nearly incredulously. “I couldn’t say for sure, but I was likely at work.”

“You work that late?” Agatha asked, her tone almost casual.

“I’m on call every day, all year round,” Hughes replied, his voice firm, though the defensiveness in his tone was impossible to miss. “This job keeps me very busy.”

Agatha’s lips curved, the faintest flicker of a smirk threatening to surface.

“I’m sure it does,” she said almost mockingly.

Her gaze never wavered from his as she brought up the remote and clicked it. The footage on the monitor shifted, zooming in on a black car parked under the dim glow of a streetlamp.

“Let’s talk about that vehicle, Mr. Hughes,” she said, her tone hardening ever so slightly. “Do you recognize it?”

He barely looked at it.

“No, I don’t recognize it"

“Are you sure?” Agatha pressed, her voice sharper now, though still maddeningly polite. “Take your time, Mr. Hughes. It’s a very distinctive vehicle—a black Cadillac with tinted windows. You’re telling me you’ve never seen it before?”

Hughes’s lips thinned, but he didn’t answer.

“Okay then. Let's move on shall we? Keep your eyes on that car, Mr. Hughes,” Agatha instructed as she fast-forwarded the footage.

On the screen, the SUV sat unmoving, all night, leaving during the day, and then returning every night.

“This vehicle,” Agatha continued, her voice slicing through the growing tension in the room, “can be seen on this street every night for five consecutive days. All leading up to July 23rd —the night Brooke Sinclair died.”

She paused the footage on the final night. The courtroom was so silent that the faint hum of the tv seemed deafening.

Then she pressed play again, and the screen moved, and a figure finally emerged from the SUV. Their shadow stretched long and ominous across the pavement as they began to walk down the street.

Agatha timed it perfectly, and paused the video just before the figure stepped into the pool of light cast by a streetlamp.

“When I hit this button,” Agatha said, holding up the remote, her gaze sweeping the room, “that man will step under the streetlight, and we’ll all see his face. You, me, the jury— everyone .”

She turned to Hughes, her stare unrelenting, drilling into him with the force of inevitability.

“So, Mr. Hughes,” she said, her voice low and challenging, “I’m giving you one last chance. Would you like to change any part of your previous testimony?”

Hughes didn’t answer.

He just stared at her.

His face was unreadable but his silence wasn’t just damning— it was everything.

And then for the first time since he took the stand, James Hughes looked towards Madeline Fox.

Agatha turned watching the look catch—watching the exact moment Fox understood what that look meant.

And then suddenly, Agatha watched the realization flickered across Fox’s face.

The silence in the courtroom stretched unbearably until the scratch of a chair shifting abruptly across tile floor sounded.

“Your Honor,” Fox said, rising to her feet, her voice tight, “the defense would like to request a brief recess.”

Judge Marks didn’t like delays, and the tight set of his jaw made it clear he was seconds from denying the request. But Agatha, could already see the writing on the walls.

“We have no problem with the request, Your Honor,” she said smoothly.

Marks looked at her, surprise flickering across his face, before he sighed heavily.

“Recess granted,” he announced begrudgingly, banging his gavel. “You may step down, Mr. Hughes.”

His gaze flicked between Fox and Agatha.

“You have twenty minutes.”

The courtroom stirred as Judge Marks stood, prompting everyone else to rise.

The tension that was left in the room upon his exit was palpable, thick enough to cut with a knife.

Agatha returned to her table and sank into her chair beside Lilia, her eyes never leaving the scene unfolding across the courtroom. Hughes strode past her, glaring at her while Ratcliff immediately intercepted him, leaning in close and speaking in a hushed but urgent tone.

Meanwhile, Fox was glued to her phone, her posture taut with tension. Her lips pressed into a thin, unforgiving line as she glanced sharply in Agatha’s direction. Their eyes met for a brief moment, and Fox’s expression darkened further as she brought the phone to her ear.

“Yeah...we have a problem...”

Fox’s voice carried faintly, her words trailing off as she moved toward the door, her heels clicking against the floor with uncharacteristic speed.

Agatha leaned back slightly, arms crossing over her chest as she watched each moment of turmoil across the aisle feeding the steady drumbeat of triumph thrumming beneath her skin.

“You had him,” Lilia whispered, her voice cutting through the moment, low but insistent. “Why didn’t you finish it?”

Agatha turned her head slowly, her gaze meeting Lilia’s questioning eyes. A smirk spread across her face, cocky and full of confidence.

“You’ll see,” she murmured.

Reaching for her phone, Agatha tapped the screen to life needing the distraction.

100 unread emails.

10 messages from Billy about clients.

1 message from Jen.

She opened that one and snorted.

“Don’t fuck it up.”

Agatha rolled her eyes and then her attention snagged on a different message entirely.

1 message from Rio.

Her hand stilled, hovering above the notification. Slowly, she clicked it open.

“I love you.”

Three words.

So simple, yet—the way they leapt off the screen and settled into her chest felt like a punch.

Her fingers hovered over her phone screen, trembling slightly, before her body seemed to move of its own accord.

Suddenly, the words “I love you too” were typed out in the reply bar, stark and waiting.

It was right there.

All she had to do was push send.

Just do it.

Her thumb hovered over the button, every instinct screaming at her to press.

To leap.

But she couldn’t.

Her body refused to obey—betraying her as it always did when it came to Rio Vidal.

Because even her body knew better.

It wasn’t enough to send it in a text.

This isn’t what she deserves. This would be a cop-out.

Her hand dropped from the phone, the message bar glowing on the screen, mocking her with its unsent words. She stared at it, the weight of hesitation pressing heavily on her chest.

"Agatha."

Fox's voice sliced through her internal war, snapping her back to reality. Agatha blinked, looking behind her to see Fox standing a few feet away from her. The sharp set of Fox’s jaw and the narrowed focus of her gaze told Agatha everything she needed to know before a word was spoken.

“A word?” Fox asked.

Agatha’s lips twitched, half-tempted to quip back, but instead, she turned and lightly smacked Lilia on the arm, nodding for her to follow. Lilia gave her a questioning look but obeyed, the two of them standing and trailing behind Fox out of the courtroom.

Fox led them down the hallway with the precision of someone who knew exactly where they were going. She opened the door to one of the shareable attorney conference rooms, stepping aside to let Agatha and Lilia enter.

As soon as they crossed the threshold, Agatha froze for the briefest of moments, her sharp gaze landing on the man seated at the table.

William Vanguard.

Founder and CEO of Vanguard Industries.

One of the richest—and most dangerous—men in the world.

Lilia faltered beside her, catching herself mid-step, but Agatha didn’t break stride. She moved forward, her eyes narrowing slightly as she took in the room. Ratcliff sat at one end of the table, his face a blank mask, but the way his hands fidgeted with a pen betrayed his unease.

William Vanguard, on the other hand, looked perfectly composed. His tailored suit was immaculate, his silver hair brushed back with precision, and his steely eyes were locked directly on Agatha as though she were the only person in the room.

Fox closed the door behind them, and the soft click of the lock seemed to reverberate louder than it should have.

“Ms. Harkness,” Vanguard said smoothly, his voice carrying the polished weight of someone accustomed to being obeyed. He didn’t stand or offer a hand—he merely gestured to the empty chairs across from him. “Please, sit.”

Agatha’s smile was laced with mock politeness.

“How gracious of you,” she drawled, sliding into the chair opposite him without breaking eye contact. Lilia hesitated for just a fraction of a second before following suit, her gaze darting nervously between Agatha and Vanguard.

Fox moved to the side of the room, her arms crossed as she leaned against the wall, her sharp eyes watching the interaction like a hawk.

“So,” Agatha began, leaning back in her chair and crossing one leg over the other. Her tone was casual, almost lazy, but the sharpness in her eyes was unmistakable. “To what do I owe the pleasure of this little meeting?”

Vanguard’s lips curved into a small, tight smile.

“I thought it was time we spoke,” he said, before giving her a look. “Man to man, so to speak.”

Agatha leaned back in her chair, a low, dark laugh spilling from her lips.

The audacity of William Vanguard was almost impressive.

Almost.

Agatha just lifted a brow at him.

Vanguard leaned forward, his fingers steepled on the table before him.

“I am prepared to settle this— privately ,” Vanguard said, his tone calm and measured, the voice of a man who believed he was holding all the cards. “Two hundred million. Here and now. And you drop your suit.”

The room went utterly still.

Beside her, Lilia inhaled sharply, and Agatha could practically feel the tension radiating from her.

Understandable—if they took the deal, the firm would pocket a seventy-two million dollar contingency fee, the largest in its history. But Agatha didn’t so much as flinch. Her expression remained unreadable, her gaze locked on Vanguard with a searing intensity that could have sliced steel.

“ Two hundred million ,” she repeated slowly, as though testing the weight of the words. Her lips curled into a faint smirk, and she tilted her head slightly, as if considering his offer.

And then, she laughed again—low and mocking.

“You think this is about money?” Agatha’s voice was sharp, precise, each word a barb aimed straight for William Vanguard’s composure.

She leaned forward, mirroring his posture, the faintest glint of malice shimmering in her eyes.

“Do you honestly believe two hundred million is enough to make me walk away? After everything your company has done—not just to Brooke Sinclair, but to my family?”

The weight of her words hung in the room like a thundercloud, echoing, rumbling, and threatening to strike.

Vanguard’s jaw tightened, his mask of corporate indifference slipping for the briefest of moments. He exhaled sharply, his hands flattening against the table as if to steady himself.

“I did not authorize... that ,” he said at last, his voice low but firm, as if the word alone could distance himself from the atrocities committed under his company’s banner.

That , of course, being the murder of Brooke Sinclair and the threats made against Agatha’s family.

“But I am the leader of this company,” he continued, his tone shifting—hardening. “And I acknowledge that my grandson is involved in this scheme. I want this resolved, Ms. Harkness —quietly. Efficiently. So I’ll ask again: What is it going to take?”

Agatha leaned back slightly, considering his words, the weight of them and the man himself. William Vanguard was powerful, yes, but he was also desperate—a cornered beast trying to salvage what remained of his empire.

The thought made her heart pound, not with fear, but with exhilaration.

“Let me get this straight,” she began, her voice cool, calculated, every word dripping with controlled venom. “You want me to name my price so you can sweep this under the rug, protect your legacy, and keep your name out of every headline that screams ‘murder,’ ‘conspiracy,’ and ‘corruption.’ Is that about right?”

Vanguard didn’t answer, but the slight narrowing of his eyes was all the confirmation she needed.

She tilted her head, tapping a single finger on the table.

“And you think money is the solution,” Agatha said, her voice laced with sharp disdain. “That throwing enough cash at me will make me forget the death threats. The attempted murder of the woman I love and Brooke Sinclair’s blood on your company’s hands.”

She heard the soft intake of breath from Lilia beside her, and it jolted her.

The weight of her own words echoed in her mind.

The woman I love.

Oh.

She’d said it out loud.

Not to Rio, where it belonged, but here—in a room full of adversaries during a negotiation.

Such a Harkness, move.

Her chest tightened, but she shoved the thought aside. Vanguard, thankfully, seemed oblivious to the revelation.

“Then tell me,” Vanguard said, his voice clipped and controlled, though the tension in his jaw betrayed him. “What will it take?”

Agatha let the silence stretch, her eyes narrowing as she searched for the perfect response. Her mind replayed a specific statement made by Brandon Vanguard during Fox’s cross- examination. A smug, offhand comment that had stuck with her like a thorn.

She leaned forward, her gaze fixed on William Vanguard, her words deliberate and slow.

“Your grandson and your counsel,” she said, her tone almost conversational, though the edge in her voice was unmistakable. She paused to flick her eyes briefly to Fox, then back to Vanguard. “They alluded earlier that as a ten-billion-dollar company, three hundred and sixty- one million dollars isn’t outside the realm of possibility to lose without really noticing it.”

Her lips curved into a faint, calculated smirk.

“So,” Agatha said, her voice dripping with finality, “ just so you really feel it —make it three hundred and seventy-two. Even.”

The room fell into a suffocating silence. Even the faint hum of the overhead lights seemed to dim under the weight of her words.

Agatha crossed her arms, her body language unshakable, her gaze steady as she waited.

This wasn’t a negotiation.

She was dictating terms.

Fox pushed off the wall, throwing Agatha an outraged look.

“That is absolutely ridiculous—”

Vanguard silenced her with a single raised hand.

“ Fine ,” he said, his voice cold as he moved to stand. “My attorneys will draft the agreement.”

He paused as he reached Agatha, his towering frame casting a shadow over her. There was a begrudging respect etched into his expression.

Agatha stood, meeting his gaze head-on.

He extended his hand towards her.

“I mean this with the greatest amount of respect, Ms. Harkness—but I sincerely hope our paths never cross again.”

Agatha grasped it firmly, her grip steady, her eyes unflinching.

But as he moved to pull away, she tightened her hold, just enough to halt him—to pull him closer to her.

“Get your people in line, Mr. Vanguard,” she said, her voice whispered but razor-sharp. “If your attack dog come after me or mine again , I can promise you one thing: our paths will cross again. And if you put us on that road—I can assure, I will be the only one who makes it to the end. Do you understand?”

William Vanguard’s jaw tightened, his expression hardening into a mask of reluctant acknowledgment before he gave a single, stiff nod.

Agatha’s grip on his hand loosened, releasing him. She watched as he turned on his heel and strode out of the room, clothing the door behind him.

She turned back to find Lilia watching her with wide eyes, a faint smile curling on her lips— small but unmistakably proud. The sight stirred something unfamiliar and warm in Agatha’s chest, but she quickly buried it, her focus snapping to the remaining occupants of the room.

“Well, the gang’s all here,” she quipped, her tone light and mocking as she clapped her hands with exaggerated flourish. “Let’s go tell Judge Marks about the agreement, shall we?”

Her gaze landed on Fox and Ratcliffe, both of whom looked less than thrilled.

Agatha arched a brow, her gaze sweeping over them, letting the moment stretch just enough to revel in their unease. Then, with a sly smirk, she flicked her fingers toward the door.

“ Vámonos ,” she said, her tone dripping with wicked amusement, before breaking into a delighted cackle.

And then with her trademark flair, she pivoted sharply on her heel, the movement a seamless blend of precision and theatrics, before walking out of the room.

Agatha stepped out of the courthouse, the heavy oak doors swinging shut behind her with a sharp finality. The crisp evening air filled her lungs as she took in a deep breath, and for the first time in years, she felt something close to weightlessness. The burden she had carried for nearly five years—Vanguard, Brooke—was finally lifted.

It was over.

The preliminary agreement was signed, the case dismissed.

Justice, albeit quiet and purchased , had been served.

Brooke Sinclair’s parents had sobbed when she delivered the news of the settlement and they accepted the payout without hesitation. But their relief crumbled into heartbreak moments later, as the reality settled in.

The settlement was proof.

Their daughter hadn’t taken her own life.

She had been killed.

Vanguard had finally acknowledged what they always knew, even if only in the shadows.

Agatha exhaled slowly, letting the chill seep into her bones as she felt Lilia move to stand quietly to her side. And with that, Agatha's thoughts turned briefly to the firm.

Now, one hundred and thirty-four million dollars richer.

The biggest settlement in the firm's history.

Her lips quirked into a faint but tired smirk.

After a while, Lilia broke the quiet.

“Alice and Jen are waiting for us at Bemelmans,” she said, her voice light but carrying a spark of excitement. “Celebratory drinks are very much warranted.”

Agatha hesitated.

Normally, that’s exactly how she’d celebrate a victory—surrounded by admirers, a drink in hand, basking in the glow of recognition. The liquor warming her body, their compliments fueling her ego. And if there was ever a case deserving of such a triumph, it was this one.

But as the thought settled, she realized that wasn’t what she wanted.

Not tonight.

Her mind wandered, immediately, to Nicky’s laughter no doubt echoing through the house. To Rio likely being the reason behind his laughter.

Her heart flipped, happy but certain.

If that wasn’t answer enough, she didn’t know what was.

She turned to Lilia with a small, genuine smile.

“Rain check on Bemelmans?” Agatha asked, her voice quieter than usual.

Lilia blinked, momentarily caught off guard by the deviation from Agatha’s typical post- victory routine. But then she really looked at her.

And, of course, she saw it immediately.

Lilia’s lips curved into a warm, knowing smile.

“Go home, Harkness,” Lilia teased gently.

Agatha couldn’t stop the smile that crept onto her face—soft, almost bashful. But it didn’t take long for her to catch herself. She quickly masked the smile with a glare, shooting it at Lilia as if to blame her for pulling that reaction out of her.

Lilia met the mock glare with an infuriatingly knowing smirk that had Agatha huffing and walking away.

Descending the courthouse steps, Agatha strode toward her town car. Dan was already there, holding the door open without a word. She slid inside, settling into the cool leather seat as the door closed with a soft, final click behind her.

For a moment, she didn’t move. The weight of the day hung in the air, heavy yet strangely cathartic. Slowly, she reached into her purse, pulling out her phone. The screen lit up as she unlocked it, her fingers hesitating for a beat before navigating to her messages.

And there it was.

The words I love you stared back at her from the text box, still unsent to Rio.

Dan’s voice crackled softly through the intercom.

“Where to, Ms. Harkness?”

Agatha stared down at those words.

“Home, Dan. Take me home.”

Agatha wasn’t sure what to expect when she walked into the house. The lack of greeting at the door caught her off guard—odd, considering Nicky was home. She quickly toed off her heels, the relief immediate, and shrugged out of her coat, hanging it neatly on the hook by the door.

The faint hum of the television drifted down the hallway, its volume gradually increasing as she moved closer.

Sonya was in the kitchen, stirring something on the stove. She glanced up, her expression flickering with surprise at seeing Agatha home so early. But she recovered quickly, offering a warm smile.

Agatha returned it, brief but genuine, before heading toward the living room.

Peeking over the back of the couch, she spotted two dark heads of hair, both facing toward the TV. Her gaze shifted to the screen, and she had to bite back a snort of disbelief.

A documentary about bugs.

Bugs.

Seriously?

Agatha stepped forward, rounding the couch quietly to get a better view, and her heart nearly exploded at the sight before her. Nicky was snuggled against Rio’s side, practically glued to her as they both watched the TV intently. Rio, still wearing Agatha’s Harvard sweater, had one arm draped casually over the back of the couch, the other resting lightly on Nicky’s shoulder.

The sight hit Agatha like a tidal wave of warmth.

Rio’s head turned at the sound of her approach, her dark eyes going wide in surprise before softening almost instantly.

“Hey,” she said softly.

At the sound of Rio’s greeting, Nicky’s gaze flicked up, his eyes wide at seeing Agatha home way earlier than usual. But instead of scrambling off the couch to run and hug her like he usually would, he stayed exactly where he was—tucked against Rio’s side.

“Hi, Mom,” he said with a big smile before promptly returning his attention to the TV, clearly more interested in the documentary than her.

Shaking her head with a bemused smile.

Bugs.

Bugs outranked her.

She huffed as that she stepped forward and eased herself onto the couch, settling in beside Nicky—now sandwiched between his two favorite people. Nicky detached himself slightly from Rio, to press himself equally between them.

Agatha reached out, fingers threading through his dark hair in a motion so familiar that he didn’t even glance away from the screen. His focus remained on the TV.

“I heard about the deal—congratulations,” Rio said, her voice low and warm.

Agatha looked over at her.

“News travels fast,” Agatha replied with a small shake of her head, a soft smile tugging at her lips.

“You win, Mama?” Nicky asked casually, still glued to the television, not even bothering to look up.

Agatha rolled her eyes with exaggerated fondness, her hand gently ruffling his hair.

“Of course, honey,” she said with a mock air of offense.

Rio snorted at that.

The three of them sat there quietly for a few moments, the only sound the narrator’s voice on the documentary and the occasional rustle as Nicky shifted against them. Agatha sagged into the couch, letting the weight of the day begin to melt away.

But after a while she felt the instinctive urge to touch Rio, and let her hand slide from Nicky’s hair, her arm draping across the back of the couch. She hesitated for a heartbeat, then let her fingers brush against Rio’s shoulders, dancing lightly over her skin before moving up to her neck, playing gently with the loose strands of her hair.

Rio relaxed into the touch, but her eyes turned to Agatha, locking onto her with a quiet, questioning look. Agatha’s hand in her hair wasn’t unusual—but in front of Nicky?

That was something entirely new.

Rio’s gaze lingered, her expression asking a silent question.

Are you sure?

Agatha answered not with words but with a gentle tug on Rio’s hair, a small, playful pull that drew a smile to Rio’s lips. Then, just as easily, her fingers returned to their soothing rhythm, combing through Rio’s dark strands.

Rio sighed softly, her eyes fluttering closed as she leaned into Agatha’s touch, contentment radiating from her like a warm glow. They sat like that for a few quiet minutes, Agatha’s fingers threading lazily through Rio’s hair, the gentle murmur of a narrator discussing some beetle playing softly in the background.

The silence stretched, peaceful and unbroken, until Rio’s voice emerged, carrying a weight of quiet curiosity.

“How does it feel?” she asked, her words soft. “To finally get them... to be done with it?”

Agatha let the question hang in the air for a moment, her fingers pausing briefly before continuing their movements. She contemplated her answer, carefully turning the words over in her mind.

Honestly, she wasn’t sure how she felt about it. For years, she’d envisioned this exact moment. She had imagined what it would feel like to take Vanguard down, to win against all odds, to come out on top. In her mind, the victory had always been accompanied by a surge of power, an intoxicating high that she believed would fuel her for the rest of her career.

But now, sitting here with Nicky curled between them and her fingers threading through Rio’s hair, the reality was so different.

Vanguard—her white whale, her ultimate victory—felt so insignificant in this moment.

Because, as corny as it sounded, this —Nicky and Rio, together— with her , this was her real win.

Agatha felt the thought settle deep in her chest, warm and so fucking unshakable .

Her gaze fell to Nicky, nestled comfortably between them, his wide-eyed focus locked on the screen. He looked so content, so at ease— so happy . Everything she wanted him to be.

Then her eyes shifted to Rio.

Rio, who had taken her by complete surprise. Rio, who had walked into Agatha’s meticulously controlled life and flipped it upside down like a snow globe, scattering all her carefully laid pieces and rearranging them into something far more beautiful, far more chaotic, and yet—far more alive.

Agatha swallowed hard, her throat tight as the weight of the question and this moment settled over her. She wasn’t used to this—to feeling her heart so full it threatened to burst. But as she looked at the two of them, her son and the woman she loved, she realized something undeniable.

It wasn’t the power she’d chased or the victories she’d stacked like trophies.

It was this.

It was them.

Without fully realizing what she was doing, her fingers slid behind Rio’s neck, curling gently, and she tugged Rio forward. Rio’s eyes widened slightly, but before she could say anything, Agatha’s lips met hers in a soft kiss, right above Nicky’s head.

The kiss lingered just a moment before Agatha pulled back, her forehead brushing lightly against Rio’s. Her heart hammered in her chest, but this time, she didn’t hesitate.

“I love you,” Agatha whispered, her voice barely audible, yet carrying every ounce of truth she felt.

Rio blinked, utterly still for a beat, as if the world itself had paused. Then, slowly, that beautiful radiant smile—the one always made Agatha’s heart lurch in her chest—bloomed across her face, reaching her dark eyes making them almost glimmer.

“I love you too,” Rio murmured, her voice thick with emotion.

Agatha leaned in, kissing her again, this time softer, as though sealing the words into each other.

“Ew, gross,” Nicky’s voice piped up, cutting through the tender moment.

Agatha pulled away abruptly, expecting to see him looking up at them in horror. Instead, his eyes remained glued to the television, his hand out stretched and pointing at it.

“Look how many legs that bug has,” he exclaimed, scrunching up his nose in exaggerated disgust.

Agatha turned toward the screen, her own nose wrinkling at the sight of a massive, multi- legged creature crawling across it.

She shivered too, because he was right—that was disgusting.

“That’s eumillipes persephone, ” Rio said smoothly, beating the narrator to the punch. “It has the most legs of any known animal—up to 1,306.”

Agatha rolled her eyes fondly because—of course, Rio would know that.

Her gaze drifted to Rio, who watched the alien-like bug crawl across the screen with genuine interest, her brow slightly furrowed in concentration. There was something so quintessentially Rio about it—her effortless intelligence.

Agatha’s lips curved into a smile, unbidden and warm. A familiar feeling blossomed in her chest, spreading outward like sunlight breaking through the clouds.

She recognized it now, clearly and unreservedly: her love for Rio.

“Mama,” Nicky said, pulling her attention away from Rio.

Agatha looked down to find him staring up at her with that soul-piercing blue eyes of his. He reached up, his small hand brushing her cheek.

“You’re smiling,” he said so innocently, yet so yet profound.

Agatha’s chest tightened at his words—and at the gentle touch of his small fingers tracing the faint lines on her face. Lines that had she was more than aware had grown more defined lately, not from stress or worry, but from the sheer amount of smiling she’d been doing.

Since Rio.

Her gaze flicked upward to the woman in question, who was watching the interaction with an expression so achingly soft it made Agatha’s breath catch in her throat.

Agatha swallowed hard, shifting her attention back to Nicky.

Today had already been full of admissions she never thought she’d voice, but this one came more easily. It felt natural, as though saying I love you had opened some hidden door inside her, one that now let all her vulnerable truths flow freely.

“It’s because I’m happy, baby,” Agatha said, her voice soft and tender.

Nicky’s face lit up at that, his thumb gently tracing the curve of her smile as if committing it to memory.

“I like it when you smile, Mama. It’s my favorite,” he said with childlike certainty.

Agatha’s gaze lifted to Rio, who was watching the exchange.

Without a word, Rio’s hand came up to cover hers.

“Mine too,” she murmured in agreement.

Agatha’s heart swelled, her fingers tightening around Rio’s as she glanced back at Nicky.

She had spent her life chasing power—commanding boardrooms, conquering courtrooms, bending the will of some of the most powerful men in the world.

Power had been her fuel, her purpose, her identity.

But now, sitting here with Rio’s hand in hers, Nicky tucked close, she realized: this was power.

Not the fleeting, transactional power of deals and victories, but something deeper, something enduring.

The power to be seen.

To be loved.

To love.

To build a life that was hers undeniably hers.

Her fingers squeezed Rio’s again, and she smiled softly, feeling the warmth of it spread through her.

“Mine too,” Agatha echoed, her words reverberating out of her mouth with a newfound strength, a quiet, undeniable certainty.

And it was in that moment, surrounded by the family she never thought she deserved, Agatha Harkness—the Witch of Wall Street—realized she had finally found the one thing she had been chasing all her life.

True power.

And God—she felt invincible.

Chapter End Notes

Wow. Honestly, I can't believe its over. This journey has been nothing short of incredible. Thank you to all the kudos and comments, they have truly fueled me to write.

The Epilogue is already planned and will be a 2 year jump into the future. I am hoping to get it up before the new year, but we will see. Once again, thank you all so much :)With her trademark flair, she pivoted sharply on her heel, the movement a seamless blend of precision and theatrics, and swept out of the room with purpose.

To Glory at the End

2 years later

Agatha sat in her leather chair, one leg crossed over the other, as the soft glow of her office lamp illuminated the sleek, organized space. The New York Times article was splayed across her desk, the bold headline Vanguard’s Ghosts: A Legacy of Violence nearly jumping off the screen. She scrolled further, pausing at the photograph of James Hughes in handcuffs, his jaw clenched and his eyes blazing with fury as he glared into the camera.

Agatha’s lips curved into a slow, satisfied smirk.

That glare—it felt personal, as though Hughes had aimed it squarely at her.

And, to be fair, he had every reason to.

If it hadn’t been for her civil case against Vanguard, the mountains of evidence unearthed thanks to Rio’s work, and her ability to leverage that evidence in open court, he would have walked away unscathed.

When William Vanguard had first offered the Sinclair family and Agatha an NDA and a generous payout, it had been a chess move. On the surface, it seemed like the company was tying up loose ends, silencing their adversaries with a gilded gag. But Agatha had seen the opening, the weak spot in the armor, and she’d taken it.

Getting the Sinclair's to sign had been a delicate negotiation. They had balked at the idea of silencing Brooke’s voice, of letting Vanguard appear to sweep their daughter’s death under the rug. But Agatha had assured them, that this wasn’t the end—it was a pivot.

They had trusted her to take the case, and they trusted then as well, and they signed.

The payout was substantial, but it wasn’t the money Agatha cared about—it was the clause. The NDA barred her from disclosing what she knew about Vanguard’s actions, but nowhere did it prohibit her from other forms of influence.

That loophole became her weapon.

She made a series of generous donations to key political figures the following year, each accompanied by well-placed hints. An investigation into Vanguard, she suggested in private meetings, would be the perfect statement piece for any ambitious politician’s platform. After all, as she’d pointed out coyly, the FBI already had all the evidence they needed—the case files shared before the NDA had been signed.

And what do you know?

Within months, those long-forgotten case files were resurrected, breathing new life into an investigation that had once seemed doomed to gather dust on a shelf. The wheels of government bureaucracy turned slowly, as they always did, but with Agatha’s subtle prodding, momentum built. Over the years that followed, subpoenas were issued, testimonies were painstakingly collected, and the walls began to close in on Vanguard’s dirty little secret.

In the end, justice caught up with them.

Agatha smirked to herself, the edges of her lips curling as she scanned the article. It felt like finally reaching the last page of a book she'd been eager to finish for two long years. And now—now she could finally close that book, slide it onto her shelf, and move forward.

Her moment of quiet triumph was interrupted by a knock at the door. Without looking up, she assumed it was Billy, probably with another client update or an unnecessary stack of paperwork.

“Come in,” she called distractedly, still scrolling through the article.

The sound of multiple footsteps made her glance up, and her eyebrows shot up in surprise.

Jen, Alice, and Lilia walked into her office.

Agatha’s brow furrowed immediately, her mind racing to figure out why they were here. She mentally scanned her calendar—no meetings, no case updates, no glaring oversights she could think of. The blankness of it all left her uneasy, so she defaulted to what had always been her best defense when blindsided by this trio.

Resigned, she leaned back in her chair, narrowing her eyes at them.

“I didn’t do it,” she said preemptively.

Jen arched a brow, Alice smirked, and Lilia outright snorted.

“Relax, Harkness,” Jen said, crossing her legs. “You’re not in trouble. For once.”

Relief flickered through Agatha, though she didn’t fully trust it. Rising from her chair, she walked around the desk, her nails drumming a steady rhythm against the wood as she rounded toward them. Her sharp gaze landed on Jen.

“Now you’re making me want to misbehave, Jen,” she teased, taking a seat across from them and letting her eyes sweep over the trio.

She flicked her hand, gesturing for them to get to the point.

“So, what’s this all about?”

The three women exchanged glances, a silent battle of wills playing out between them. That alone was enough to set Agatha on edge. These weren’t just any women—they were powerhouses, each one as formidable as she was. For them to hesitate? It meant whatever they were about to say, Agatha probably wasn’t going to like.

Finally, Lilia exhaled a long-suffering sigh, muttering under her breath, “c owards ,” before squaring her shoulders and meeting Agatha’s gaze head-on.

“We need you to talk to Rio.”

Agatha blinked, utterly caught off guard. For a moment, all she could do was stare at Lilia, before dragging her eyes to Jen and Alice, both of them nodded in confirmation—albeit a little shaky.

Agatha sat back in her chair, mind whirling as to why she —of all people was being asked to talk to Rio.

“Why? What did she do?” Agatha asked, her tone equal parts curiosity and amusement.

Jen gave her a pointed look, clearly unamused.

“She’s on a rampage, Agatha. She’s making the first-year associates cry. She’s turned the bullpen into a warzone where people are afraid to even breathe in her direction.”

Agatha snorted, unable to hide her amusement. If there was one person in the firm who had zero tolerance for coddling the first years, it was her.

But the situation still puzzled her. Why were they bringing this to her?

She leaned back, crossing her arms as her mind churned.

“Correct me if I’m wrong,” she said, her voice taking on that sharp, mocking edge, “but there’s a very lengthy HR document on file that explicitly states I have no say or authority over Rio due to our... relationship.”

She let the words hang in the air, her gaze sliding over the three women.

“And you two,” she continued, pointing at Lilia and Jen, “are practically the patron saints of rule-following. So why, exactly, are you coming to me with this?”

The room went silent.

Agatha’s sharp eyes scanned their faces, and as she really looked at them, realization struck.

Her eyes widened, her mouth falling open in disbelief.

“Wait—are you... scared of her?” she asked incredulously.

The three partners exchanged hesitant glances, their silence speaking louder than words.

Finally, Alice cleared her throat, shifting slightly in her seat before meeting Agatha’s gaze.

"Agatha—your wife is terrifying," Alice said, her wide eyes emphasizing the point. "She literally growled at me yesterday when I pointed out her page numbers were off on the brief she sent me."

Agatha bit her lip, fighting to keep the grin threatening to break across her face.

One... she would never tire of hearing someone call Rio her wife. Just the thought of it sent a warm flutter through her chest, and instinctively, her fingers found the wedding ring on her hand—a sleek gold band with a stunning 3-carat dark gray diamond at its center. She twirled it almost absently, a habit she developed since Rio placed the ring on her finger a year ago.

And two... the idea of Rio growling at Alice? It had her on the verge of actual giggles because she could picture it so vividly because Rio had been very spicy lately...understandably so.

Little did the partners know though, she had been trying—and failing—to get Rio to take even the smallest step back from work. Not to stop entirely, because that wasn’t who Rio was, but to ease off the accelerator just enough to catch her breath.

It was like trying to convince a hurricane to take a day off.

She sent a look toward the partners, noting the faint hopefulness etched on their faces.

It was almost amusing.

They clearly thought Agatha took the more dominant role in her relationship with Rio. She was older, wildly successful, and carried a presence that commanded any room she walked into. Of course, they would assume she was the one steering the ship at home.

But that couldn’t have been further from the truth.

Sure, Agatha had a say—of course she did. They were a team, a great fucking team , one that moved in sync and complemented each other in ways Agatha had never thought possible.

But Rio?

She was a force of nature.

That natural order of all things.

Rio never let Agatha “dominate” anything unless they were in bed, and even then, that was only on the rare occasion Rio allowed it.

Their dynamic was entirely flipped from what anyone might expect.

And Agatha didn’t mind in the slightest—she loved it.

But they didn’t need to know that.

So, Agatha sighed, adding just the right amount of exasperation for dramatic effect.

“Fine. I’ll talk to her,” she said, injecting as much bravado into her voice as she could muster —like she had any chance of accomplishing what they were asking without having the kitchen sink hurled at her head—metaphorically of course.

Agatha had just stood up from the chair and was halfway to the door when a thought struck her. She stopped, turning slowly to face the three partners, her eyes narrowing suspiciously.

“Wait a second,” she said, crossing her arms. “You three have never hesitated to air your grievances with me. Does this mean”—her gaze sharpened as she pursed her lips—“you’re more scared of her than you are of me?”

The idea sounded impossible, ridiculous even, as she said it.

But the words had barely left her mouth before the replies came in unison.

“Yes.”

“Absolutely.”

“Without a doubt.”

Agatha blinked, completely stunned by the rapid-fire responses. Her mouth opened and closed as she tried to find a rebuttal, but for the first time in a long while, she had nothing.

The three partners exchanged smirks, clearly enjoying her rare moment of speechlessness. Agatha shot them a glare, as she turned on her heels and walked out the door.

On her way to Rio’s office, her mind was already working overtime.

Scarier than me? Rio?

The idea was ludicrous.

She wasn’t sure whether to be insulted or impressed—or maybe a little of both.

Her fingers danced at her side as a mischievous glint creeping into her eyes.

If they think I’ve gone soft, maybe it’s time to remind them who they’re dealing with.

Nothing too dramatic, of course.

Just enough to reestablish her dominance and put some respect back on her name.

Still, the fact that anyone thought Rio was scarier than her?

Agatha snorted.

"Ridiculous," she muttered under her breath, but her steps slowed as she approached the door to the best office in the third-year hallway. Her hand hovered over the handle as she paused, Rio’s mood this morning flashing in her mind like a neon warning sign.

Agatha Harkness wasn’t scared.

She was being cautious.

She was being smart.

And... oh .

Her lips pressed into a tight line as the realization hit her.

She was being a little bitch.

The thought was like a slap across the face, and it snapped her out of her hesitation.

Agatha Harkness didn’t back down from challenges—not in the courtroom, not with corporate overlords, and certainly not with her wife. Even if said wife had, over the past few months, perfected a glare so fierce it looked like she was ready to reap your soul.

With her signature flair, Agatha pushed the door open and stepped inside, her gaze sweeping over the space as a familiar mix of affection and amusement tugged at her lips.

It had been Rio’s office for only four months, yet it looked as though she’d occupied the space for years. Rio, in true fashion, never did anything half-assed. Her office was a seamless blend of structure and life, like a greenhouse masquerading as a workspace.

Agatha couldn’t say a word about it, though, considering every single plant in this room had been her doing. One for Rio’s first office. Another to celebrate her first chaired case. Another for her first win, and then her second-anniversary at the firm. And, of course, there were more than a handful of "apology plants" scattered about—peace offerings for when Agatha’s foot had firmly lodged itself in her mouth.

The result was less an office and more an art gallery of rare, expensive plants. Rio loved them all, treating each one with the meticulous care that only she could manage.

Agatha couldn’t name a single one.

But Rio?

She knew every single one, down to the tiniest detail.

Agatha’s smirk deepened as her eyes landed on Rio, seated behind the desk, completely absorbed in the document before her.

God, she was beautiful.

Not that this was news—Rio always looked beautiful—but today, she seemed to glow. It was an understated radiance, the kind that left Agatha a little breathless if she thought about it too long.

Without even glancing up, Rio spoke.

“What brings you to my neck of the woods, my love?”

My love.

No matter how many times Agatha heard it, the soft flutter in her chest was always the same.

She stepped forward and took a seat in one of the dark leather chairs—ones she’d gifted Rio during her first year. Afterall, if Agatha was going to sit in Rio’s office, she was going to be comfortable.

“So...” Agatha began slowly, watching Rio’s reaction to her words. “I need to talk to you about something. And I need you to not bite my head off.”

Rio didn’t look up immediately, but Agatha didn’t miss the slight tension in her jaw. Her wife’s eyes stayed fixed on the paper, as though determined to finish whatever she was reading first. After what felt like an eternity, Rio set the document aside and leaned back in her chair, finally meeting Agatha’s gaze.

“I make no promises,” Rio said evenly, her eyes narrowing just enough to make Agatha feel like she was being sized up for battle.

Agatha fought against the urge to fidget. Give her a high-profile suit or a high-stakes negotiation any day. Hell, throw her into a boardroom with ten stuffy old white guys who loved to mansplain corporate law—she’d take it all over this conversation.

But this?

Convincing her wife to take a step back from work?

This felt like walking into a lion’s den with a steak necklace.

“Honey...” she started, her tone laced with forced sweetness.

Rio’s narrowed eyes sharpened even further, cutting through Agatha’s attempt to soften the blow with a pet name.

Agatha sighed, and decided to bite the bullet.

“The partners,” she began, bracing herself, “have asked that you... maybe take a step back. Work from home a couple of days? Or even take some time off?”

The silence that followed was deafening. Rio leaned back in her chair, her expression inscrutable as she regarded Agatha with the weight of a thousand unsaid words.

And then, finally, she spoke.

“They asked?” Rio said slowly—dangerously, her jaw tightening. “ Or did you plant the idea? ”

Agatha winced internally, knowing exactly why Rio would jump to that conclusion. After all, the new plant sitting proudly on Rio’s desk—was the most recent apology plant. Agatha had bought it after their last attempt at this same conversation went spectacularly south. Not her finest hour, and certainly not Rio’s most forgiving mood. The fallout, despite the plant’s hefty price tag, had left Rio a little tender on the subject.

Agatha immediately held up her hands, palms out, a gesture of surrender.

“I did not—I swear,” she said earnestly.

They didn’t lie to each other.

Ever .

Not even when it would have been easier.

Not even when it hurt.

That softened Rio slightly, her posture relaxing just enough for Agatha to notice. She tilted her head, her gaze sharp but tinged with curiosity.

“Why? I’m still operating at my usual capacity.”

Agatha lost the fight against a smirk as her next words bubbled up.

“You’re making the first years cry too much,” she said, almost proudly. “Which, as you know, I fully support. But apparently, it’s creating a ‘ hostile environment .’”

Rio’s eyes widened in mock outrage, her mouth opening to launch into what Agatha was sure would be a fiery retort—until a visible wince crossed her face. Rio closed her eyes and her jaw tightened as she took a deep, controlled breath.

Agatha instantly sat up straighter, the smirk vanishing as her worried gaze locked onto Rio.

She held her breath, every nerve on high alert.

Rio took a few more deep breaths before opening her eyes and leveling a pointed look at Agatha.

“Come talk to your daughter,” she said, exhaling a frustrated huff. “She’s been a menace all day.”

Agatha stood, a sly grin creeping back onto her face as she moved around the desk.

“Funny, the partners said the same thing about you,” she quipped.

But her teasing trailed off as she rounded the desk and saw Rio’s very, very pregnant belly fully on display now, unobstructed by the desk. Agatha’s heart did that thing it always did when she saw it—flipped, softened, and swelled all at once.

A soft smile spread across Agatha’s face as she moved forward, lowering herself onto her knees in front of Rio. Her hands reached out instinctively, smoothing over the curve of Rio’s stomach. The firm kicks that met her palm were immediate, startlingly strong, and drew a sharp hiss from Rio above her.

“She’s treating my insides like a rage room,” Rio huffed, her voice a perfect blend of exasperation and reluctant affection.

“Well, she is my daughter,” Agatha quipped, her lips curling into a smirk. “And, if given enough time, I can turn any room into a rage room. She’s been in there for 38 weeks, my love —of course, she’s going to rage.”

She leaned closer, her face softening as she directed her attention to Rio’s belly.

“I know you’re getting antsy in there, sweetheart,” she murmured, her tone shifting to something gentler, though still playful. “But I happen to be very partial to your mami , and you’re not making this easy for her with all your little tantrums.”

In true to Harkness fashion, her daughter responded with a firm kick against Agatha’s hand.

Rio groaned above her, a sound that was half frustration and half pain.

“I swear,” Rio said through gritted teeth, glaring down at Agatha like it was somehow her fault. “I know she doesn’t have your DNA, but you’ve clearly managed to pass your attitude down to her anyway.”

“Well, she developed her ears like 10 weeks ago,” Agatha said, smirking as she gently rubbed her hand over the swell of Rio’s stomach. “I can’t help it if she’s already picked up on my stellar personality.”

Rio groaned, rolling her eyes as she sank further back into her chair.

“Fantastic. She’s going to come out negotiating nap times and winning arguments by sheer force of sarcasm.”

“Only if we’re lucky,” Agatha teased, leaning in to press a soft kiss to Rio’s belly. “But let’s face it—she’s going to be a powerhouse. Just look at her parents.”

Rio’s lips quirked into a smile despite her irritation, her fingers ghosting across Agatha’s cheekbone.

“You’re way too proud of her already, and she’s not even here yet.”

“Of course I am,” Agatha said, tilting her head up to meet Rio’s gaze. “She’s already making her mark, even if it’s on your bladder.”

Rio couldn’t help but laugh at that, though the motion made her wince slightly.

Agatha was instantly alert, concern flickering across her face.

“Are you really okay?” she asked, her voice softening as her hand stilled on Rio’s belly.

“I’m fine,” Rio reassured her, though her voice carried the unmistakable weight of fatigue. “She’s just... very active today.”

Agatha’s lips pressed into a thin line. The past couple of weeks had been grueling. Rio was barely sleeping, and their daughter seemed determined to test her limits with relentless kicks and flips, as though preparing for her debut with a vengeance.

“Honey,” Agatha said softly, her voice stripped of its usual bravado, replaced by pure, unguarded warmth. She reached for Rio’s hand, threading their fingers together gently. “I know you don’t want to step back. But you can’t keep pushing through this on sheer willpower alone. You barely slept last night, and I can see how exhausted you are. And now, with her kicking you like this...”

Her voice trailed off, but the concern in her eyes spoke volumes.

Rio sighed, leaning her head back against the chair, her free hand coming to rest over their intertwined fingers.

“I just... I hate the idea of slowing down,” Rio murmured, her voice tinged with frustration and weariness. “Of feeling like I’m not doing enough.”

Agatha squeezed her hand gently.

“You’ve already done more than enough, my love. The partners wanted me to remind you— and I’m quoting here— that you’ve doubled your peers’ billable hours and brought in three times the revenue this year alone . Slowing down? You’d still be miles ahead of everyone else.”

She leaned closer, her free hand brushing softly over Rio’s belly, where their daughter gave another assertive kick.

“You’re not slowing down, honey. You’d just be moving at the same pace as everyone else for once.”

Rio huffed a quiet laugh, a small smile breaking through the stubborn tension on her face.

“That’s not exactly comforting, you know.”

“No?” Agatha arched a brow, a teasing glint in her eyes. “Then let me put it another way: you can take a step back because you’ve earned it. And, selfishly, I want you to—because I need you to take care of yourself. For her.”

She pressed her hand gently to Rio’s belly.

“And for me.”

Rio’s eyes softened, her resistance finally cracking under the weight of Agatha’s words.

“I hate it when you’re right,” she muttered, her voice tinged with reluctant affection.

Agatha’s lips quirked into a smug grin.

“Must be so hard for you to be with me, then—since I’m always right,” Agatha quipped, her grin unapologetically smug.

Rio huffed, arching an eyebrow at her.

“Not always wise, though—considering you think making smart comments to your very pregnant wife is a good idea.”

Agatha laughed softly, leaning in to press a kiss to Rio’s hand.

“I am Agatha Harkness, darling. I live on the edge. It keeps things interesting.”

Rio rolled her eyes but didn’t pull away.

“Interesting isn’t the word I’d use,” she muttered, though the corner of her mouth betrayed a faint smile.

Agatha smirked, squeezing Rio’s hand gently.

“You love it.”

“ Debatable ,” Rio shot back, but her smile widened as she looked at Agatha. Her expression softened as she leaned back into the chair, exhaustion momentarily forgotten. “I do love you, though.”

Agatha’s smirk faded into something warmer

“I love you too,” Agatha said, the words rolling off her tongue with an ease she still wasn’t entirely used to.

She still didn’t say them often, but this moment warranted it.

Rio’s lips curved into a soft smile, one that quickly twisted into a grimace as she winced in pain.

Agatha immediately felt the sharp, determined kick against her palm.

“Hey, none of that now,” Agatha chided gently, addressing the culprit inside Rio’s belly.

Rio groaned, her hand pressing against the swell of her stomach.

“Sing her that song,” she said through gritted teeth. “The one that always settles her down.”

Agatha raised an eyebrow, her expression incredulous.

They were at work, and if anyone walked in on her singing to Rio’s stomach, her reputation would undoubtedly take a hit.

“Agatha,” Rio said firmly, sensing her hesitation. “If you want me to go home and stay home, I need to be able to walk. And for that to happen, she needs to calm down.”

Agatha was backed into a corner.

“Fine,” Agatha huffed, glaring down at Rio’s stomach as if her daughter could see her displeasure. “But if Jen catches me doing this, I will never live it down. And you—” she pointed a finger at Rio “—will never hear the end of it.”

Another sharp kick.

“ Agatha ,” Rio said, her tone bordering on a growl.

“Yup, yup. I’m going,” Agatha muttered, resigned. She took a steadying breath, shooting another wary glance at the door, and then began, her voice a low melodic cadence.

“Seekest thou the road to all that’s foul and fair”

Rio leaned back in her chair closing her eyes, her breathing easing almost immediately.

Gather sisters fire, water, earth and aira Darkest hour, wake thy power, earthly and divine Burn and brew with coven true and glory shall be thine

Their daughter responded too, the fierce kicks softening into faint, rhythmic movements beneath Agatha’s hand, as if soothed by the melody.

Agatha’s voice softened further as she continued to sing, her fingers tracing lazy circles over Rio’s belly.

Down, down, down the road Down the witches' road Down, down, down the road Down the witches' road Down, down, down the road Down the witches' road

The song was one she’d carried with her for years, though she rarely thought about its origins. It was an old tune she’d learned from her eccentric elderly neighbor—a woman who her mother had sworn was both a witch and the devil.

Naturally, that made Agatha seek her out because coincidently, Evanora called Agatha the same thing.

Circle sewn with fate Unlock thy hidden gate

Turns out, the woman was neither witch nor devil, just a lonely widow who had taken an unexpected shine Agatha. When Evanora was off on one of her infamous benders, Agatha would slip away to the widow’s house. She’d sit at the old woman’s worn kitchen table, eating food that tasted real.

Marching ever forward 'Neath the wooded shrine I stray not from the path I hold death's hand in mine Primal night, giveth sight Familiar by thy side If one be gone, we carry on Spirit as our guide

The widow always sang this song when she cooked. Said it was passed down through the women in her family, and since Agatha was the closest thing she’d ever have to a daughter, she taught it to her.

It had stuck with Agatha ever since.

Down, down, down the road Down the witches' road Down, down, down the road Down the witches' road Down, down, down the road Down the witches' road

It stuck with her through the chaos, the fights, and the aching loneliness of her childhood years. It became her battle cry, her lullaby, her anchor. When Nicky was sick, lying in a hospital bed, she’d sung it to him too, softly stroking his hair while his small body fought so hard against what was trying to take him from the world.

Blood and tears and bone Maiden, Mother, Crone

And when Nicky noticed Rio wincing at their daughter’s increasingly ferocious kicks, he’d been the one to suggest Agatha sing it to her.

“It always makes me feel better,” he’d said matter-of-factly, as if that alone was reason enough.

Rio, of course, had lit up at the idea. Encouraging it with her signature grin, knowing full well how mortified Agatha would be singing to her wife’s stomach. But Agatha never backed down from a challenge.

And so, she sang.

The road is wild and wicked Winding through the wood Where all that's wrong is right And all that's bad is good Through many miles of tricks and trials We'll wander high and low Tame your fears, a door appears The time has come to go

Much to her surprise—and Rio’s amusement—the fiery daughter calmed immediately.

And now, it was the only thing that seemed to soothe her.

Down, down, down the road Down the witches' road Down, down, down the road
Down the witches' road
Down, down, down the road Down the witches' road

She smiled softly, her voice carrying the last verse with all the love and warmth blooming in her chest.

“ Follow me, my friend ,” she sang, her gaze lifting to meet Rio’s.

Rio’s tired eyes softened. Her lips curved into a faint, tender smile, and Agatha felt their daughter’s restless movements still beneath her palm.

And then Rio’s hand came down, their fingers intertwining. The subtle bump of their wedding rings against each other sent a quiet ripple of meaning through Agatha—a reminder of the life they had built, and the one they were still creating.

As the last words of the song left her lips, Agatha felt it settle deep in her chest, filling her with a peace she never thought she’d have.

“To glory at the end.”

THE END.

Chapter End Notes

What a journey this has been.

I am going to take a break for a while, but I do have some plans for future stories, one being a spin off from this one, from Rio's POV.

Okay...well...I will see you when I see you. Its been fun :)
